b 106 06 05 03 04 01 02 figure b.91 awqat mosque layout example key 01 men prayer hall 02 iwan 03 women prayer hall 04 minaret 05 ablution 06 toilet dubai building code part b architecture b.9.4.6.2 jumaa mosques shall jumaa mosque (friday prayer) a) accommodate more than 300 male worshippers (assumed to be 80% of total number of planned worshippers) b) provide prayer rooms for women accommodating 20% of total number of worshippers. jumaa mosques accommodating more than 500 worshippers shall provide secondary prayer hall for daily prayers. following requirements and recommendations apply to secondary prayer hall

b 106 06 05 03 04 01 02 figure b.91 awqat mosque layout example key 01 men prayer hall 02 iwan 03 women prayer hall 04 minaret 05 ablution 06 toilet dubai building code part b architecture b.9.4.6.2 jumaa mosques shall jumaa mosque (friday prayer) a) accommodate more than 300 male worshippers (assumed to be 80% of total number of planned worshippers) b) provide prayer rooms for women accommodating 20% of total number of worshippers. jumaa mosques accommodating more than 500 worshippers shall provide secondary prayer hall for daily prayers. following requirements and recommendations apply to secondary prayer hall

b 106 06 05 03 04 01 02 figure b.91 awqat mosque layout example key 01 men prayer hall 02 iwan 03 women prayer hall 04 minaret 05 ablution 06 toilet dubai building code part b architecture b.9.4.6.2 jumaa mosques shall jumaa mosque (friday prayer) a) accommodate more than 300 male worshippers (assumed to be 80% of total number of planned worshippers) b) provide prayer rooms for women accommodating 20% of total number of worshippers. jumaa mosques accommodating more than 500 worshippers shall provide secondary prayer hall for daily prayers. following requirements and recommendations apply to secondary prayer hall
1) secondary prayer hall shall be one third of overall mens prayer hall area. 2) secondary prayer hall should be provided with mihrab, as shown in figure b.88

3) division between main and secondary prayer halls shall be through solid construction that provides thermal separation properties for air-conditioning, and maintains visual connection between two halls when both spaces used. glazed walls may be provided
04 example of jumaa mosque layout provided in figure b.92
b.9.4.6.3 eid mussalla space provided for performing eid al-fitr and eid al-adha prayers shall be as required by iacad

key 01 men main prayer hall 02 men secondary prayer hall 03 women prayer hall 04 minaret 05 iwan 06 ablution 07 toilet 03 07 06 01 02 05 figure b.92 jumaa mosque layout example b 107 dubai building code part b architecture ablution spaces b.9.4.7 ablution spaces shall be well planned to avoid restriction of movement during ablution. fixture clearances shall conform to b.8.1.5
ablution spaces shall meet following requirements
a) required number of ablution spaces (calculated in accordance with b.8.1.3.2) shall be provided with fixed seats or height adjustable rotatable stools
b) accessible ablution spaces shall be provided in accordance with c.8.6
c) ablution areas shall be separated from toilet blocks, see figure b.93

02 04 01 1.5 03 figure b.93 example of ablution area separation from toilets key 01 ablution 02 wash basins 03 entrance lobby 04 toilet b 108 dubai building code part b architecture ablution wash basins and standing ablution spaces with faucets optional

convenience of users and comfortable reach ranges shall be taken into account when determining appropriate fixture heights according to model of ablution chosen. clearances allowed shall be not less than minimum values shown in figure b.94. 400 400 400 400 600 800 800 (b) plan 400 400 600 0 5 4 0 5 7 (a) section figure b.94 ablution seat clearance section b 109 dubai building code part b architecture mosque accommodation b.9.4.8 for residence associated with mosque, area of bedroom shall be not less than 15 m2
location of accommodation shall provide privacy to residents. residence block shall be separate from mosque main mass and positioned away from heavy mosque traffic
residence units should be adjacent to each other, in order to minimize impact on mosque outdoor areas or any planned future expansion of mosque
assigned parking bay for mosque imam and moazen shall be provided with indicative designated parking board
mosque accommodation shall meet following minimum requirements. a) awqat mosque

1) mosque cleaner/keeper accommodation shall consist of studio unit with kitchen and toilet. unit shall be positioned in proximity to mosque service blocks. 2) imam residence accommodation shall consist of minimum two-bedroom unit with living room, enclosed kitchen and three toilets. one of bedrooms shall be en-suite bedroom

3) imam residences shall be provided with dedicated outdoor open space or courtyard. b) jumaa mosque. 1) mosque cleaner/keeper accommodation shall consist of studio unit with kitchen and toilet. unit shall be positioned in proximity to mosque service blocks. 2) imam residence accommodation shall consist of minimum two-bedroom unit with living room, enclosed kitchen and three toilets. one of bedrooms shall be en-suite bedroom
3) moazen residence accommodation shall consist of minimum one- bedroom unit with living room, enclosed kitchen and toilet

4) imam and moazen residences shall each be provided with dedicated outdoor open space or courtyard. mosque-specific sanitary requirements b.9.4.9 positioning of mosque toilets shall be planned carefully with cognisance of wind direction. toilets shall not be positioned in front of or adjacent to prayer hall. entrance of toilets shall be separated from ablution spaces to maintain purity of ablution spaces

4) imam and moazen residences shall each be provided with dedicated outdoor open space or courtyard. mosque-specific sanitary requirements b.9.4.9 positioning of mosque toilets shall be planned carefully with cognisance of wind direction. toilets shall not be positioned in front of or adjacent to prayer hall. entrance of toilets shall be separated from ablution spaces to maintain purity of ablution spaces

mosques shall be provided with combination of western and eastern water closet. at least 25% of total number of male and female toilets shall be eastern style water closet, or as requested by iacad depending on mosque location
cleaners room shall be provided in proximity to toilet blocks
toilet compartments in mosque shall be made of solid construction partitions. each compartment shall be not less than 1,100 mm  1,500 mm. mosque sanitary provisions shall conform to b.8.1

b 110 dubai building code part b architecture b.9.5 restaurants and food facilities b.9.5.1.1 general requirements in this subsection apply to following spaces a) restaurants b) food services and beverage sales outlets such as 1) coffee shops 2) juice serving outlets 3) grocery shops 4) farm and fruit slate outlets 5) sweet refreshment 6) flour mills 7) roasters 8) frozen and chilled cold stores for food facilities storage 9) bakeries and pastries 10) retail supermarkets and 11) sea food sales outlets

spaces shall be equipped with necessary sanitary, health and safety facilities and minimum kitchen areas in accordance with health and safety requirements issued by dm, general conditions for licensing of food establishments ref. b.55

spaces shall be equipped with necessary sanitary, health and safety facilities and minimum kitchen areas in accordance with health and safety requirements issued by dm, general conditions for licensing of food establishments ref. b.55

b.9.5.1.2 food preparation food preparation areas shall be designed based on food and beverage items to be offered and flow of food between preparation area and diner. design process in pd iso/ts 22002-2 shall be followed to control operational conditions within food establishment and to promote environmental conditions that favourable for production of safe food
operator brand standards (e.g. hotels, schools) shall be followed where applicable
operator brand standards (e.g. hotels, schools) shall be followed where applicable
operator brand standards (e.g. hotels, schools) shall be followed where applicable

food preparation areas in healthcare facilities shall conform to dha regulations and guidelines ref. b.3 to ref. b.18. intersection between walls, floors and ceiling shall be sealed and rounded to facilitate cleaning process

food preparation areas in healthcare facilities shall conform to dha regulations and guidelines ref. b.3 to ref. b.18. intersection between walls, floors and ceiling shall be sealed and rounded to facilitate cleaning process

b.9.5.1.3 kitchen requirements floors, walls and ceilings of kitchens shall be made of smooth material that non-absorbent, non-combustible, non-toxic, crack-free and easily cleaned. floors shall be hard-surfaced, non-absorbent and drained. they shall be constructed with waterproof, non-absorbent washable materials without fissures or crevices
wall finishes shall be smooth, waterproof, resistant to fracture, light-coloured and readily cleanable
working surfaces for preparation of food shall be manufactured from stainless steel or other approved impervious material to facilitate cleaning and maintenance of hygienic conditions
gas supplies shall be in accordance with ch. 11 of uae flsc ref. b.1
kitchen hoods and associated kitchen extract ductwork shall be provided to all areas involving cooking activities, i.e. stoves, gas rings, tandoors, etc
b 111 dubai building code part b architecture kitchen hoods and associated kitchen extract duct work shall be designed and installed in accordance with h.4.12.15 and uae flsc ref. b.1

chimneys installed in bakeries, restaurants and roasteries shall be located on rear side of plot, or inside shafts and ducts. position, height and ventilation of chimneys shall be determined in accordance with h.4.12.18. cold stores and freezers doors shall be openable from both sides. safety releases shall be provided on insides of doors to avoid risk of accidental entrapment

chimneys installed in bakeries, restaurants and roasteries shall be located on rear side of plot, or inside shafts and ducts. position, height and ventilation of chimneys shall be determined in accordance with h.4.12.18. cold stores and freezers doors shall be openable from both sides. safety releases shall be provided on insides of doors to avoid risk of accidental entrapment

b.9.6 educational facilities b.9.6.1 requirements in this subsection apply to all educational facilities. general requirements educational facilities shall be located in designated plots in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs. building heights and number of floors allowed shall conform to planning regulations
d) number of students permitted in each classroom shall be determined in accordance with dm planning guidelines for public amenities ref. b.56 and ministry of education requirements

e) segregation of vehicular and pedestrian movement shall be provided inside facility to avoid intersection with movement of students to and from facilitys buildings. bus pick-up and drop-off areas shall be located in safe area, away from vehicular traffic, for student circulation

f) separate parking areas should be provided for school buses and cars g) sanitary requirements for students shall be based on fixture dimensions defined in c.8.3.4.4 and reach ranges defined in c.5.7.3

schools b.9.6.2 natural and artificial lighting shall be configured to avoid glare on vertical writing surfaces and on students desks. for window orientation, it preferable that window openings face left side of classrooms. school shall have library, with adequate area to accommodate number of students in school

schools b.9.6.2 natural and artificial lighting shall be configured to avoid glare on vertical writing surfaces and on students desks. for window orientation, it preferable that window openings face left side of classrooms. school shall have library, with adequate area to accommodate number of students in school
educational buildings shall be designed in accordance with dm ph&sd guides ref. b.49, ref. b.50
school shall include sports courts according to requirements applied by ministry of education
educational facilities shall meet following requirements
a) daylighting provisions and acoustical treatment shall be prioritized for classrooms and teaching spaces
b) educational facilities shall be equipped with health clinic conforming to dha school clinic regulations ref. b.9

c) facilities shall include rooms for management staff, teachers, administrators and supervisors, and waiting areas for parents. areas of these rooms shall be suitable for number of staff in facility. school shall have at least one canteen or dining hall. canteen shall be of adequate size to serve students. school shall have adequate number of laboratories, computer rooms, and activities hall (multipurpose hall or auditorium)

school shall have allocated area for playing fields and open spaces. these areas should not be less than 200% of area allocated to classrooms, with 30% of these spaces shaded. mast for flag should be provided
first grade student classrooms shall be located on ground floor

b 112 dubai building code part b architecture laboratory facilities shall be distanced from classroom areas. b.9.7 residential buildings laboratories shall be provided with sufficient means of exhaust systems when facility planned to be used for conducting chemical experiments. stairways for regular use by school students shall conform to b.6.4.1.6
apartment buildings b.9.7.1 apartment buildings shall be located in designated plots in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs

minimum fire separation and egress requirements for schools provided in section 5.3.2, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for apartment buildings provided in section 5.5.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. kindergartens b.9.6.3 kindergartens shall have playgrounds and open space of area not less than 200% of area allocated to classrooms. at least 30% of this area shall be shaded. part of this area shall be planted and part of it shall be provided with sand/playground areas. play equipment and recreational facilities shall be provided for children

minimum fire separation and egress requirements for schools provided in section 5.3.2, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for apartment buildings provided in section 5.5.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. kindergartens b.9.6.3 kindergartens shall have playgrounds and open space of area not less than 200% of area allocated to classrooms. at least 30% of this area shall be shaded. part of this area shall be planted and part of it shall be provided with sand/playground areas. play equipment and recreational facilities shall be provided for children

minimum fire separation and egress requirements for schools provided in section 5.3.2, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for apartment buildings provided in section 5.5.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. kindergartens b.9.6.3 kindergartens shall have playgrounds and open space of area not less than 200% of area allocated to classrooms. at least 30% of this area shall be shaded. part of this area shall be planted and part of it shall be provided with sand/playground areas. play equipment and recreational facilities shall be provided for children

kindergartens shall have at least one canteen and multipurpose hall. canteen shall be of adequate size to serve students and shall conform to health and safety requirements ref. b.50, ref. b.55. kindergarten classrooms shall be provided at ground level only

kindergartens shall have at least one canteen and multipurpose hall. canteen shall be of adequate size to serve students and shall conform to health and safety requirements ref. b.50, ref. b.55. kindergarten classrooms shall be provided at ground level only

minimum fire separation and egress requirements for kindergartens provided in section 5.3.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. nurseries b.9.6.4 clear distance between beds in nursery rooms shall be not less than 1,000 mm

minimum fire separation and egress requirements for kindergartens provided in section 5.3.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. nurseries b.9.6.4 clear distance between beds in nursery rooms shall be not less than 1,000 mm

nurseries shall be provided with large shaded and planted playground including sand pit, covering area that suitable in proportion to number of children enrolled, with minimum area of 0.6 m2 per child nurseries shall be located at ground level only. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for nurseries provided in section 5.3.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. b 113 all dwelling units in apartments shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. labour accommodation b.9.7.2 b.9.7.2.1 general building requirements labour accommodation shall be located in designated plots in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs

nurseries shall be provided with large shaded and planted playground including sand pit, covering area that suitable in proportion to number of children enrolled, with minimum area of 0.6 m2 per child nurseries shall be located at ground level only. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for nurseries provided in section 5.3.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. b 113 all dwelling units in apartments shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. labour accommodation b.9.7.2 b.9.7.2.1 general building requirements labour accommodation shall be located in designated plots in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs

nurseries shall be provided with large shaded and planted playground including sand pit, covering area that suitable in proportion to number of children enrolled, with minimum area of 0.6 m2 per child nurseries shall be located at ground level only. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for nurseries provided in section 5.3.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. b 113 all dwelling units in apartments shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. labour accommodation b.9.7.2 b.9.7.2.1 general building requirements labour accommodation shall be located in designated plots in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs

labour accommodation shall be constructed from permanent use, durable and sustainable materials. temporary installations shall not be used. accommodation buildings shall be separated from kitchens, workshops and stores in accordance with uae flsc ref. b.1
prayer rooms shall be provided in accordance with b.8.3.3. prayer rooms shall be accessible to all occupants, with proximity to other communal amenities
all residential rooms, kitchens, dining rooms and halls shall be provided with ventilation and air conditioning according to h.4

minimum fire separation and egress requirements for labour accommodation provided in section 5.5.3, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. dubai building code part b architecture b.9.7.2.2 labour accommodation rooms number of workers in each room shall not exceed 8 workers

minimum fire separation and egress requirements for labour accommodation provided in section 5.5.3, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. dubai building code part b architecture b.9.7.2.2 labour accommodation rooms number of workers in each room shall not exceed 8 workers

supervisors room shall be provided for every 40 labourers. room shall include separate sanitary facilities for supervisor. doors to rooms shall not open directly into road or sikka. buildings main entrance shall be accessible within plot limits
if double-deck bunks used, clear distance between lower and upper bunk shall be not less than 0.9 m. triple-deck bunks shall not be used
toilets and bathroom blocks shall be provided with all necessary fixtures. water tanks shall be covered with sun protection to provide room temperature water in summer

all sleeping units in labour accommodation shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. b.9.7.2.3 labour accommodation amenities labour accommodation amenities shall meet following requirements

all sleeping units in labour accommodation shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. b.9.7.2.3 labour accommodation amenities labour accommodation amenities shall meet following requirements

a) multipurpose halls (dining and tv) shall have areas proportionate to number of workers, accommodating at least 30% of building occupants at single time. these halls shall be provided with furniture and equipment for its intended purpose, as follows

1) adequately sized kitchen shall be provided for food preparation with total area not less than one third of dining hall area. kitchens shall be located such that they accessible to all users on ground floor of building
2) dining halls shall be located on ground floor and connect directly to kitchen. design and furnishings of kitchen shall meet general criteria for licensing food facilities ref. b.55
b) indoor recreational facilities shall occupy not less than 25% of total net area
c) space provisions for each of these amenities shall conform to b.5.1
d) travel distance between water fountains shall be not more than 30

e) first aid room with area of not less than 10 m2 shall be provided at rate of one per thousand workers and at minimum of one per labour accommodation building. room shall conform to dm ph&sd guidelines for first aid ref. b.42
f) room for workers equipment shall be provided at rate of 0.1 m2 per worker and area of not less than 10 m2
g) laundry tray or tub for every 30 persons shall be provided, along with places for drying laundry

staff accommodation b.9.7.3 staff accommodation shall be located in designated plots in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs. staff accommodation shall be of permanent construction. temporary structures shall not be used. each floor for staff accommodation shall be provided with communal kitchen, dining area, and lounge. dining and lounge area shall be able to accommodate one third of floor occupants at single time. at least one kitchen and one lounge shall be provided for every 400 m2 of na. kitchen area shall be not less than 25 m2. rooms shall be limited to single or double occupancy. each room shall have attached toilet

staff accommodation b.9.7.3 staff accommodation shall be located in designated plots in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs. staff accommodation shall be of permanent construction. temporary structures shall not be used. each floor for staff accommodation shall be provided with communal kitchen, dining area, and lounge. dining and lounge area shall be able to accommodate one third of floor occupants at single time. at least one kitchen and one lounge shall be provided for every 400 m2 of na. kitchen area shall be not less than 25 m2. rooms shall be limited to single or double occupancy. each room shall have attached toilet

space planning of student accommodation shall take into account safety and security
privacy of accommodation shall be provided. male and female residences shall be segregated

b.9.8 industrial and warehouse facilities industrial/factory/workshop and warehouse/storage buildings shall be located in designated industrial plot in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs

setbacks for industrial and warehouse plots shall conform to affection plans and dcrs. office space within industrial and warehouse buildings shall be provided according to planning authoritys allowance and shall be limited to maximum of 20% of total ga. when operation of building expects large quantity of heavy vehicle access of more than one trip per 100 m3 of ga at peak hour ref. b.40, segregated access points should be provided for light vehicles and heavy vehicles or trucks

no doors shall open directly into roadway side, except for emergency exit doors, which shall be set at minimum of 2 from roadway edge. landing shall be provided on exterior side of exit door at same height as door in accordance with table 3.1, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1

vehicular entrances shall lead to loading/unloading areas. loading and unloading areas may be open to sky or covered. manoeuvring area in loading and unloading areas shall conform to b.7.3 or be based on specialist traffic and manoeuvring analysis

net internal height of any factory/workshop or warehouse/storage shall be sufficient to support processes occurring within. adequate space shall be provided for staff dining rooms, pantries and changing facilities, accommodating at least 25% of staff at same time
b 115 dubai building code part b architecture kitchen facilities shall be separated from factory/workshop or warehouse/storage as mandated by uae flsc ref. b.1

minimum fire separation and egress requirements for warehouse/storage buildings provided in section 5.14, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for industrial/factory/workshop buildings provided in section 5.15, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. multitenant warehouses shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. b 116 dubai building code part b architecture b.9.9 motor fuel dispensing facilities motor fuel dispensing facilities shall be located in designated plot in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs

motor fuel dispensing facilities shall conform to all applicable requirements of section 3, ch. 13 of uae flsc ref. b.1 and of operator. all health and safety and security design requirements shall be fulfilled to ensure safety of users, workers and facility itself. vehicle entrances and exits shall meet requirements for turning radius and dimensions as shown in figure b.95

0 1  1.2 8.0 02 1.2 figure b.96 fuel station minimum dimensions b 118 dubai building code part b architecture b.9.10 healthcare facilities b.9.11 hotel establishments healthcare buildings shall be located in designated plot in accordance with affection plan, land use classification and dcrs

healthcare buildings, including but not limited to hospitals, outpatients facilities, surgical centres, pharmacies and similar facilities, shall be designed according to dha regulations and guidelines ref. b.3 to ref. b.18 in addition to laws set out by ministry of health and dcd in uae flsc ref. b.1. design of healthcare facilities for dubai healthcare city authority shall also follow fgi guidelines ref. b.56. following requirements shall be met in design of healthcare facilities. a) healthcare facility shall be designed ensuring independent access, amenities and building service systems. same requirements apply to facilities located within mixed-use buildings and malls. hotels establishments should adhere to classification criteria set by department of tourism and commerce marketing (dtcm) according to level of classification pursued ref. b.19 to ref. b.36

healthcare buildings, including but not limited to hospitals, outpatients facilities, surgical centres, pharmacies and similar facilities, shall be designed according to dha regulations and guidelines ref. b.3 to ref. b.18 in addition to laws set out by ministry of health and dcd in uae flsc ref. b.1. design of healthcare facilities for dubai healthcare city authority shall also follow fgi guidelines ref. b.56. following requirements shall be met in design of healthcare facilities. a) healthcare facility shall be designed ensuring independent access, amenities and building service systems. same requirements apply to facilities located within mixed-use buildings and malls. hotels establishments should adhere to classification criteria set by department of tourism and commerce marketing (dtcm) according to level of classification pursued ref. b.19 to ref. b.36

minimum room areas and space provisions shall conform to dtcm requirements ref. b.19 to ref. b.36. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for hotel accommodation provided in section 5.9, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. hotel suites and standard rooms shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. hotel apartments shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. b) prayer rooms shall be provided in healthcare facilities in accordance with b.8.3.3

minimum room areas and space provisions shall conform to dtcm requirements ref. b.19 to ref. b.36. minimum fire separation and egress requirements for hotel accommodation provided in section 5.9, ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. b.1. hotel suites and standard rooms shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. hotel apartments shall be separated by 1 h fire resisting construction as required by table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. b.1. b) prayer rooms shall be provided in healthcare facilities in accordance with b.8.3.3
b.9.12 utility buildings c) privacy of treatment facilities and segregation of men and women shall be provided

design of utility buildings, such as substations, waste water treatment plant and district cooling buildings, shall conform to minimum requirements of ch. 14 of uae flsc ref. b.1. table 14.1, 5 (viii), ch. 14 of uae flsc ref. b.1 amended by dcd to align with dewa requirements for access around equipment. batteries, relay and control panels and other equipment in substation shall be arranged such that minimum of 1,000 mm exit access width available between such arrangements or between equipment and wall
detailed requirements for substations given in g.7

b 119 dubai building code part b architecture b.10 buildings interaction with outdoor environment b.10.1 healthy entrances to capture particulates from occupant shoes at all regularly used entrance(s) to building, one of following shall be installed a) permanent entryway system, comprised of grilles, grates or slots that allow for easy cleaning underneath. system shall be at least width of entrance and 3 long in primary direction of travel (sum of indoor and outdoor length) b) rollout mats, at least width of entrance and 3 long in primary direction of travel (sum of indoor and outdoor length) c) material manufactured as entryway walk-off system, at least width of entrance and 3 long in primary direction of travel (sum of indoor and outdoor length)
example of healthy entrance shown in figure b.97

1 2 figure b.97 example of healthy entrance b 120 dubai building code part b architecture b.10.2 screening of building equipment all outdoor mechanical equipment, including antennas, rooftop equipment and refuse storage areas, should be concealed from public view by solid walls, screens, fences, parapet walls, enclosing structures or landscape. b.10.3 building fences and boundary walls building fences and boundary walls shall be provided according to each building or occupancy operational needs and as specified in affection plan or dcr

when fences provided, fence height shall be limited to maximum of 3 m, except for utility service buildings. utility service building fences shall be provided according to utility operational requirements. b.10.4 smoking areas smoking strictly prohibited in all public areas in accordance with local order no 11  2003 ref. b.57

places where smoking allowed shall be determined in accordance with conditions listed in manual of regulating smoking in public places issued by authority ref. b.58. this manual defines public places where smoking strictly prohibited and places where smoking allowed under specific conditions
designated smoking areas shall be at least 7.5 away (see figure b.98) from entrances of building, doors and operable windows and outdoor air intakes of ventilation systems
annual permit issued from competent department of authority for all places where smoking allowed, upon submission of all required documents and drawings mentioned in guideline

figure b.99 illustration showing ratio of indigenous plants in provided planted area b 122 dubai building code part b architecture b.10.6 sustainable materials recycled materials b.10.6.1 based on cost, recycled content (as defined in iso 14021) shall constitute at least 10% of total value of materials in project. this shall be calculated as follows value of recycled content = (value of post-consumer recycled content) + half (value of pre-consumer recycled content) if only fraction of product or material recycled, then only that percentage (by weight) can contribute to recycled content value

mechanical, electrical and plumbing components, as well as furniture and specialty items such as elevators, shall not be included in this calculation. only materials permanently installed in building shall be included
regional materials b.10.6.2 based on cost, at least 10% of building materials shall have extracted, harvested or recovered, as well as manufactured, within 800 km of project site
if only fraction of product or material extracted, harvested, or recovered and manufactured locally, then only that percentage (by weight) can contribute to regional value

mechanical, electrical and plumbing components as well as furniture and specialty items such as elevators shall not be included in this calculation. only materials permanently installed in building shall be included
figure b.100 open grid pavement system b 123 dubai building code part b architecture b.10.6.3 asbestos-containing materials asbestos-containing materials shall not be used

lead or heavy metals containing material b.10.6.4 paints or other materials that might contain percentage of lead or other heavy metals that more than prescribed limits set by dm, shall not be used, unless metal encapsulated in systems such as photovoltaic cell. all paints and materials containing lead or other heavy metals shall be accredited/certified from dubai central laboratory or any source approved by authority
d) buildings located adjacent to or within protected areas or ecologically sensitive areas and e) buildings requiring environmental assessment where relevant authority requests it
some of types of buildings that require environmental assessment illustrated in figure b.101

dubai building code part b architecture d) fire exit access and fire exits shall be identified by exit signs as mandated by ch. 5 of uae flsc ref. b.1
e) visual clutter caused by inappropriately designed or located signage and other elements in environment shall be avoided
f) environments identity shall be clearly and consistently communicated through design of graphic elements to increase users recognition during navigation

g) signage should be positioned at key decision-making points on path of travel. it should be positioned over path of travel at height of not less than 2,100 mm, measured from ffl to bottom of sign, and high above head level in high pedestrian traffic areas. signage should be positioned to avoid shaded areas and glare
h) information on signs should be kept to minimum, without duplication. complex information should be broken down, beginning with general information and moving towards more specific information
i) standardized nomenclature should be adopted to organize information in similar environments
j) signage should be provided with both english and arabic text. arabic, being primary language texts, shall be aligned to right

b.11 wayfinding in buildings b.11.1 general when there well-designed wayfinding system, people able to understand their environment. this provides users with sense of control and reduces anxiety, fear and stress
from user perspective, wayfinding process involves four stages as given in table b.34
stage of process description of stage orientation route decision route monitoring attempt to determine ones own location in physical space in relation to chosen destination
selection of course of direction to destination
checking to make sure that selected route heading towards to destination
destination recognition when destination recognized
table b.34 wayfinding process b.11.2 general requirements following requirements and recommendations apply to wayfinding elements, including visual, acoustic and tactile references
a) people shall be able to identify their location in building without walking more than 70 in open spaces and 30 inside buildings

b) all business and administration buildings shall display name of building in faade and shall provide directory adjacent to entrance which lists all facilities or services contained in building. this building directory may be digital/dynamic or static. c) orientation signs to exit, toilet and select destination or amenities shall be present at corridor intersections and at every 30 m. b 125 dubai building code part b architecture b.11.3 position directional signs on long route should be repeated sequentially starting from decision-making point/junction. these serve as confirmation signs and repeater signs along route, as shown in figure b.102

02 01 03 key 01 route decision 02 directional sign 03 route monitoring < 30 < 30 figure b.102 position of signs during navigation signs shall not be located such as to obstruct openings required for light and ventilation, any required means of egress or any required access

exterior sign shall not be located such as to overhang sidewalk or other pedestrian walkway unless vertical distance, measured from bottom of overhanging portion of sign to surface of sidewalk, at least 2,100 mm
b 126 dubai building code part b architecture b.11.4 signage types types b.11.4.1 fire exit access and fire exits shall be identified by exit signs as mandated by ch. 5 of uae flsc ref. b.1
wayfinding signage classified according to wayfinding processes as shown in table b.35

wayfinding process orientation sign type information route decision and monitoring directional recognition identity advice advisory and regulatory table b.35 sign types use of sign indicates specific locations within environment, helping in understanding
guides users through environment to their destination
displays necessary information for users to identify place
draws attention to objects, situations or behaviours that might affect wellbeing and convenience of users or activities in environment
information signs b.11.4.2 information displaying nearest exit, nearest toilets and distance to them shall be displayed at adequate intervals in buildings, but not more than 30 apart
all maps presented in open spaces shall be designed with north in upper part and displaying north symbol
maps and directories shall be mounted in entrances to help building occupants to navigate
maps should be easy to understand, without too much information. they shall use contracted colours and symbols to aid understanding

graphic device such as red star or red target symbol shall be used to indicate users positioning on map. b.11.4.3 directional signs directional signs shall be used to give information to users about how to reach their destination

arrows shall be designed with shaft longer than header stem. thickness shall be same in all arrow lines. header lines shall have angle of 45 (see figure b.103). arrow alignment, typology and hierarchy shown in table b.36. examples of directional signs given in figure b.104

figure b.103 example of good arrow design b 127 dubai building code part b architecture hierarchy arrows to be aligned on left arrows to be aligned on right top of sign   straight up to left, then ahead to right, then ahead ahead, then to left ahead, then to right go up on left go up on right bottom of sign turn left turn right go down on left (to be used with vertical transportation such as stairs or escalators) go down on right (to be used with vertical transportation such as stairs or escalators) go down ahead (to be used with vertical transportation such as elevators, stairs or escalators) table b.36 arrow alignment, typology and hierarchy b 128 figure b.104 examples of directional signs with correct alignment and hierarchy of arrows dubai building code part b architecture identity signs b.11.4.4 identity signs intended to identify destination. they shall meet following requirements

b.11.4.6 digital screens screens should be matte, with wide angle of vision and providing good contrast. in all instances, screens shall fulfil following criteria

a) all fenced open spaces, such as parks, golf courses and hotels, shall display their a) whenever installed in walls, screens should be visible at height between 1,600 mm and 2,000 mm without interfering with accessible route and with slight inclination (15to 30). b) digital screens should be visible from distance of not less than 1,000 mm

a) all fenced open spaces, such as parks, golf courses and hotels, shall display their a) whenever installed in walls, screens should be visible at height between 1,600 mm and 2,000 mm without interfering with accessible route and with slight inclination (15to 30). b) digital screens should be visible from distance of not less than 1,000 mm

a) all fenced open spaces, such as parks, golf courses and hotels, shall display their a) whenever installed in walls, screens should be visible at height between 1,600 mm and 2,000 mm without interfering with accessible route and with slight inclination (15to 30). b) digital screens should be visible from distance of not less than 1,000 mm
c) interaction space as noted in part c shall be provided in front of screen
name at entrance door
b) all building faades shall display name of building as well as makani number

c) all doorframes shall present information on service(s) available in space. raised standardized pictograms and text with contrasted colour shall be used to identify different services. signage shall be mounted at height between 1,200 mm and 1,600 mm on left of door

b.11.4.5 advisory signs advisory signs shall be mounted to indicate safety procedures such as fire escape routes, no smoking areas and other regulatory information. advisory signs such as evacuation plans, required by ch. 5 of uae flsc ref. b.1 shall be provided. advisory signs shall also be placed at rest areas, elevators, access points, etc., to inform users about giving priority or give way to others (such as elderly, people with prams, pregnant women and persons with disabilities)
b 129 dubai building code part b architecture b.11.5 typography b.11.6 symbols in public spaces, internationally recognizable icons and signs preferred instead of text
all relevant textual information shall be provided both in arabic and english. when numerals used, at least arabic numerals shall be displayed
signs font size should be adjusted according to reading distance, as shown in table b.37

reading distance (m) minimum size (mm) recommended size (mm) 50 20 5 4 3 2 1 0.5 170 140 70 56 42 28 14 7 200 180 140 110 84 56 28 14 table b.37 accessible text according to reading distances signs should present chromatic contrast against their background, and between texts or icons and sign background, avoiding reflections
long texts should be aligned to left in latin languages and to right in arabic language

for short texts, tactile format shall be used when sign located in hand interaction space (in vertical parametrics, between 1,250 mm and 1,750 mm in horizontal parametrics, between 900 mm and 1,250 mm)
standard symbols can be used independently or combined with text, where appropriate. text may be incorporated to facilitate understanding of less established symbols
for short text, symbols shall be placed as prefix to description in text

c.4 to c.11 c 2 dubai building code part c accessibility c.2 definitions c.2.1 terms access aisle clear, level area parallel to parking space for people with additional mobility needs to get in or out of passenger vehicle

accessibility ease of independent approach, entry, evacuation and/or use of building and its services and facilities by all of buildings potential users, regardless of disability, age or gender, and with assurance of individual health, safety and welfare

accessible route route that allows continuous and barrier-free movement. built elements combine to guarantee that anyone can enter, move, use, exit, orient themselves and communicate autonomously and comfortably, both in public space and around and inside buildings

ambulant disability disability that either temporary or permanent in nature that result in unstable or slow movement, such that sufferer capable of walking without confinement to wheelchair or bed, with or without support of other walking aids

assistive listening system (als) amplification system utilizing transmitters, receivers and coupling devices to bypass acoustical space between sound source and listener by means of induction loop, radio frequency, infrared or direct-wired equipment
c 3 bollards vertical posts that separate pedestrian path from vehicular traffic
characters letters, numbers, punctuation marks and typographic symbols
childrens use design of spaces and elements specifically for use primarily by people 12 years old and younger
cross-slope slope that perpendicular to direction of travel
curb ramp element of accessible pedestrian route that connects different levels through inclined planes, usually between roadway and sidewalk
detectable warning standardized surface feature built into or applied to walking surfaces or other elements to warn of hazards on circulation route
flare sloped surface that flanks curb ramp and provides graded transition between ramp and sidewalk
functional limitations restrictions in performing fundamental physical and mental actions in daily life, such as mobility (physical) or memory (mental)
gangway variable-sloped pedestrian walkway that links fixed structure or land with vessel

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handrail horizontal or sloping rail intended for handhold and grasping by hand for guidance or support

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handrail horizontal or sloping rail intended for handhold and grasping by hand for guidance or support

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handrail horizontal or sloping rail intended for handhold and grasping by hand for guidance or support

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handrail horizontal or sloping rail intended for handhold and grasping by hand for guidance or support
interaction space space required by person to interact with another person, furniture, appliance, machine or another item or to transfer from wheelchair to seat or toilet or to park pram

light reflectance value (lrv) proportion of visible light reflected by surface at all wavelengths and directions when illuminated by light source, expressed on scale of 0 to 100, with value of 0 for pure black and value of 100 for pure white. luminance amount of light emitted from surface or source in any given direction

dubai building code part c accessibility manoeuvring space minimum three-dimensional space within which it possible to complete manoeuvre to gain access to specific facility, component or fitting, in particular while using wheelchair or walking aid

mobility aid device used by persons with functional limitations to assist walking. examples include canes, arm crutches and walkers. mobility device manual or motorized device used by persons with functional limitations in their mobility. examples include manual and sports wheelchairs, electric powered wheelchairs, and three and four- wheeled mobility scooters. operable with elbow range of manual operations that can be executed a) with one hand only b) without wrist turning c) without finger grip d) without very precise psychomotor skills or e) with low strength requirements

pendulum test value (ptv) parameter that provides information about slip resistance of floor surface. many floor manufacturers provide ptv in technical specifications of their products. people of determination people with specific needs or disabilities, suffering from temporary or permanent, full or partial deficiency or infirmity in their physical, sensory, mental, communication, educational or psychological abilities

pendulum test value (ptv) parameter that provides information about slip resistance of floor surface. many floor manufacturers provide ptv in technical specifications of their products. people of determination people with specific needs or disabilities, suffering from temporary or permanent, full or partial deficiency or infirmity in their physical, sensory, mental, communication, educational or psychological abilities

pendulum test value (ptv) parameter that provides information about slip resistance of floor surface. many floor manufacturers provide ptv in technical specifications of their products. people of determination people with specific needs or disabilities, suffering from temporary or permanent, full or partial deficiency or infirmity in their physical, sensory, mental, communication, educational or psychological abilities
pictogram pictorial symbol that represents activities, facilities or concepts

power-assisted door swinging or sliding door which opens by reduced activation force on door- operating hardware and closes automatically after activation force released and functions with decreased forces. public use availability of interior or exterior rooms, spaces or elements for use by public. public use can be provided at building or facility that privately or publicly owned
riser near-vertical element in set of stairs, forming space between one step and next running slope slope that parallel to direction of travel

service animal guide dog, signal dog or other animal individually trained to work or perform tasks for people of determination and identified with certification, including (but not limited to) a) guiding individuals with impaired vision b) alerting individuals with impaired hearing to intruders or sounds c) providing minimal protection or rescue work d) pulling wheelchair and e) fetching dropped items. site plot of land bounded by plot line or designated portion of public right-of-way. site can be single plot or multiple plots together

tactile map map conveying information to people blind or have impaired vision through raised surface perceptible by touch. tactile surfaces pavements and floors that textured surfaces with contrasted colour, which perceptible and identifiable by feel or cane or residual functional vision, that warn or inform people with visual impairment
visual contrast visual perception between one element of building and another achieved by colour, textural or reflectance contrast

c 4 dubai building code part c accessibility wayfinding system of providing appropriate information to assist person to pass through built environment towards specific destination. wayfinding includes orienting oneself, knowing ones destination, following best route, recognizing ones destination and finding ones way back out. wheelchair chair fitted with wheels and used as means of transport by person unable to walk as result of illness, injury, or disability. this encompasses manual wheelchairs, sports chairs, electric powered wheelchairs and mobility scooters, unless otherwise stated
c 5 dubai building code part c accessibility c.2.2 als ada bs en ch

c 7 dubai building code part c accessibility c.4 accessibility general requirements c.5 accessible routes and circulation c.4.1 general c.5.1 general principles this part specifies requirements for building elements, assemblies and components that make up building. requirements relate to building use and circulation, and to some elements of exterior building environment, such as accessibility of public spaces

this part applicable to common parts of multi-occupancy residential buildings and accessible residential units within. it not applicable to individual dwellings, villas or townhouses. requirements for individual dwellings specified in part k

stated dimensions primarily based on adults, with additional specifications given to suit children and people of varying heights. where facility intended to serve children, dimensions and other provisions can be adjusted to make them suitable for children
all areas of newly designed and newly constructed buildings and facilities shall conform to these requirements
where site, building, facility or space contains more than one use, each portion shall conform to applicable requirements for that application
c.4.2 accessible emergency provisions people of determination shall be provided with equal level of emergency protection as others
in addition to this part, provisions for emergency and alarm systems, refuge, evacuation and egress shall be in accordance with uae flsc ref. c.1
c.4.3 gender equality where building features segregated use by gender, same level of accessibility shall be provided for both genders
c 8 accessible routes shall be provided in accordance with following requirements

a) site arrival points. minimum of one accessible route shall be provided to each building or facilitys accessible entrance from any of following that serve it 1) accessible parking spaces and accessible passenger loading zones (see figure c.1) 2) public streets and sidewalks and 3) public transportation stops. b) within site. minimum of one accessible route shall connect accessible buildings, accessible facilities, accessible elements and accessible spaces that on same site
c) building entrances shall be provided in accordance with c.5.4

d) multi-storey buildings and facilities. minimum of one accessible route shall connect each story and mezzanine. spaces exempted from elevator provisions in c.5.9.3 shall also be exempted from provision of accessible routes and other accessibility provisions. e) spaces and elements. minimum of one accessible route shall connect accessible entrances of building or facility with all accessible spaces and elements within building or facility. f) accessible routes shall be integrated with, or be located adjacent to, general circulation routes available to building users. g) signage indicating accessible and general circulation routes shall be provided in accordance with c.11. dubai building code part c accessibility c.5.2 general requirements for accessible routes accessible routes should be linear and continuous. numerous directional changes along path of travel should be avoided
accessible routes with clear width less than 1,500 mm shall provide passing spaces as shown in figure c.2. passing spaces shall be minimum of 1,500 mm  1,500 mm, and spaced at maximum intervals of 50

1,500 0 0 5 , 1  0 0 5 , 1  (a) passing spaces (b) 180 turn figure c.2 clear widths at turns and minimum dimensions of passing spaces (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 403.5.2) figure c.1 direct accessible route from parking area to building entrances key 01 accessible route 02 sign c 9 dubai building code part c accessibility maximum running slope and cross-slope gradients in accessible routes shall be in accordance with figure c.3. slopes greater than 5% shall be designed as ramps conforming to c.5.9.1
clear height of 2,100 mm shall be maintained along accessible routes in accordance with figure c.4. clear height shall be maintained under suspended elements

figure c.3 permitted slope gradient in accessible routes 0 0 1 , 2  0 0 1 , 2  (a) internal (b) external figure c.4 clear height of accessible route c 10 dubai building code part c accessibility accessible routes shall have minimum luminance of 100 lux. lighting changes along accessible route shall be gradual to prevent glare. floor surfaces shall conform to c.7.2.1

figure c.3 permitted slope gradient in accessible routes 0 0 1 , 2  0 0 1 , 2  (a) internal (b) external figure c.4 clear height of accessible route c 10 dubai building code part c accessibility accessible routes shall have minimum luminance of 100 lux. lighting changes along accessible route shall be gradual to prevent glare. floor surfaces shall conform to c.7.2.1
c.5.3 external accessible routes clear width of external accessible routes should be determined using table c.1, allowing for all pedestrians in all directions of travel
uneven surfaces in accessible routes should be avoided. maximum height of any irregularity shall be 5 mm
minimum width of accessible routes shall be kept free of protruding objects such as doors, vegetation, furniture, equipment and signs
accessible routes shall avoid unprotected level changes. route minimum width (mm) recommended width (mm) tactile warning surface shall precede any sudden level change (see c.7.2.2)

external accessible route 1,200 (see figure c.5) accessible routes intended for walking shall present reflectance contrast with surfaces not intended for walking. contrast shall be minimum 30 points lrv and/or by texture difference that easily perceptible by foot or using cane
note lrv, also called albedo, usually provided for paints and flooring materials. it can be also measured with app called albedo with balance calibration card with 18% grey

c 11 turning and change of direction 1,500 (see figure c.2) table c.1 external accessible route widths 1,800 for two-way movement or when heavy traffic anticipated 1,575 to accommodate varying types of wheelchairs to avoid trip hazards, curb heights shall be maximum of 150 mm and minimum of 75 mm
where height change occurs at pedestrian crossing, curb ramps shall be provided (see c.6.2)
vehicular accesses shall not modify slope or width of accessible route (see c.6.1)

drain grids should not be installed on accessible routes, or on pedestrian crossings that form part of accessible route. utility covers should not be installed on accessible routes intended for walking. if this unavoidable, maximum height difference between utility cover and accessible route shall be 5 mm. if pedestrian bridge forms part of accessible route it shall be accessible by ramp (provided in accordance with c.5.9.1) or elevator (provided in accordance with c.5.9.3). pedestrian bridge shall provide shade to users

dubai building code part c accessibility 915 915 (a) swing door (b) sliding door figure c.24 clear width of doors (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 404.2.3.) 3 1  6  figure c.25 maximum threshold rise c.5.8 accessible doors minimum accessible door requirements c.5.8.1 note doors can be manually operated, or power-assisted. automatic doors preferred for high pedestrian traffic areas. following requirements and recommendations apply to accessible doors

dubai building code part c accessibility 915 915 (a) swing door (b) sliding door figure c.24 clear width of doors (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 404.2.3.) 3 1  6  figure c.25 maximum threshold rise c.5.8 accessible doors minimum accessible door requirements c.5.8.1 note doors can be manually operated, or power-assisted. automatic doors preferred for high pedestrian traffic areas. following requirements and recommendations apply to accessible doors

a) revolving gates, revolving doors and turnstiles shall not be part of accessible route. where they used for general circulation, adjacent accessible doors shall be provided, and these shall be available for use at all times

b) where double-leaf doors and gates provided, at least one active leaf shall have clear width of 915 mm. active leaf shall conform to requirements of this subsection. where active leaf in bank of doors it shall be marked with symbol for people of determination
c) single doors, except toilet doors, shall have minimum clear width of 915 mm, measured between face of door and face of doorstop, with door open 90 (see figure c.24)
d) opening space of door shall not encroach upon manoeuvring spaces and accessible routes (see figure c.10)

e) floor surfaces at doors should be levelled to floor. when levelling not achievable, raised threshold shall have maximum height of 13 mm and be bevelled down to height of 6 mm chamfered (see figure c.25). threshold shall have maximum slope gradient of 50%

e) floor surfaces at doors should be levelled to floor. when levelling not achievable, raised threshold shall have maximum height of 13 mm and be bevelled down to height of 6 mm chamfered (see figure c.25). threshold shall have maximum slope gradient of 50%
f) force required to open door shall not exceed 25 n, unless door automatic/power-assisted. g) swinging door leaves shall be able to open 90

c 21 dubai building code part c accessibility hardware requirements c.5.8.2 c.5.8.2.1 door opening hardware means of opening and closing (such as door handles, pull handles and push plates) shall be placed at height between 865 mm and 1,220 mm. they shall be easy to grasp and use. pressure mechanisms or levers shall be automatic, or easy to operate with elbow or closed fist as shown in figure c.26. door levers and handles shall be separated from door by minimum of 40 mm (see figure c.27 and figure c.28)

c 21 dubai building code part c accessibility hardware requirements c.5.8.2 c.5.8.2.1 door opening hardware means of opening and closing (such as door handles, pull handles and push plates) shall be placed at height between 865 mm and 1,220 mm. they shall be easy to grasp and use. pressure mechanisms or levers shall be automatic, or easy to operate with elbow or closed fist as shown in figure c.26. door levers and handles shall be separated from door by minimum of 40 mm (see figure c.27 and figure c.28)
to open sliding doors, vertical fixed bar or pull handle shall be provided. vertical bar or pull handle shall be installed between 865 mm and 1,220 mm above floor (see figure c.28)

c.5.8.2.2 vision panels it recommended that vision panels provided for doors in entrance lobbies and high traffic areas. vision panels should be minimum of 100 mm wide and should be positioned vertically in viewing range of wheelchair users (as described in c.7.1). provision of vision panels in fire doors shall conform to ch. 1 and ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. c.1. guidance given in bs 8300 for door hardware, access control systems and vision panels should be followed

figure c.37 power-assisted door floor mark c 27 dubai building code part c accessibility c.5.9.1.2 ramp runs ramp runs shall be designed in accordance with figure c.38 and figure c.39. following requirements and recommendations apply to ramp runs
a) usable clear width shall be minimum of 1,000 mm when measured between handrails
b) ramp level change should be indicated through tactile warning surface or change in floor surface material with difference of 30 points lrv
c) open ramps shall have outside edge protection as shown in figure c.39
d) guardrails shall be provided in accordance with b.6.4.1.8
c.5.9 vertical circulation ramps c.5.9.1 c.5.9.1.1 accessible and pedestrian ramp requirements following requirements and recommendations apply to accessible and pedestrian ramps
a) where ramps used for means of egress, width and number of ramps required shall conform to with section 3.7, ch.3 of uae flsc ref. c.1

b) ramps shall be provided when change in level has gradient greater than 5%. c) when ramps provided, it recommended that stepped access also provided for use by people with ambulant disability. d) slope of ramp shall meet specifications given in table c.13
e) maximum cross-slope gradient shall be 2%
f) ramp landings shall be provided if ramp run exceeds 10 (see c.5.9.1.3)
g) if series of ramp runs rises more than 2.4 m, alternative means of step-free access, such as enclosed elevator or lift platform conforming to c.5.9.3, should be provided

57 a) handrails shall conform to b.6.4.1.7

b) ramps with change in level greater than 300 mm shall have continuous handrails on both sides. c) any ramp wider than 2,100 mm shall have additional intermediate handrail. each segment of ramp shall have clear width of 1,000 mm

d) handrails shall be mounted at height between 865 mm and 965 mm. all pedestrian ramps shall have additional handrail, mounted at height between 650 mm and 750 mm, to facilitate use by children and people of short stature (see figure c.46). handrail height shall be measured vertically from finished ramp surface

e) handrails shall be safely secured. handrail section and its mounting system should not interfere with continuous gripping surface. handrail shall be separated from supporting wall by minimum of 57 mm
f) handrails shall have reflectance contrast of not less than 30 points lrv against their background
g) handrail materials exposed to sun shall not reach temperatures that can harm users

h) handrails shall extend horizontally above landing for 300 mm minimum beyond bottom and top of ramp runs. extensions shall return to wall, guardrail, or landing surface, or shall be continuous to handrail of adjacent ramp run

elevators c.5.9.3 c.5.9.3.1 general location, arrangement and total number of elevators in building shall conform to part

as part of overall elevator provision, at least one accessible elevator (or lift platform as described in c.5.9.4) shall be provided in every building with more than one floor, with following exemptions a) two-storey restaurants, where equal level of amenities, views, exterior terraces and seating options provided on both storeys. guest facilities on accessible level (such as washrooms, food counters and stations) shall be accessible and connected to accessible route. non-accessible floor seating and dining area shall be not more than 30% of overall dining area c.5.9.3.2 accessible elevator requirements elevators serving public areas shall be accessible from accessible entrance level. where different means of vertical circulation provided there shall be sign indicating direction to accessible elevator in addition to minimum and recommended elevator specifications given in part d, following requirements and recommendations apply to accessible elevators
a) depending on number and position of doors, dimensions of elevator cabin shall be as shown in table c.15, and recommended cabin sizes in part depending on building occupancy

c) number of elevators required and travel distance between elevators shall conform to part

d) wheelchair users should be provided with enough room to turn around inside elevator and exit forwards. where this not possible, mirror shall be installed inside elevator to aid reversing out. size and position shall be selected to be as non-visually distracting as possible
e) elevator doors shall have minimum width of 900 mm and minimum height of 2,100 mm (see figure c.47)
f) elevator doors shall be automatic and shall figure c.47 elevator dimensions remain open for minimum of 3 s. doors shall present colour contrast against lobby walls

g) where user in doorway, door shall automatically reopen and shall not produce force greater than 135 n. sensors should be located at two levels so that lower items can be detected. h) minimum clear manoeuvring space of 1,500 mm  1,500 mm shall be provided in front of elevator access door and in front of hall call button

i) floor indicators shall be located at height range of 1,800 mm to 2,000 mm (see figure c.47). c 35 1,500 1,500 900 300 0 0 1 , 2  0 0 0 , 2 - 0 0 8 , 1 0 0 2 , 1 - 0 0 9 0 0 5 , 1  dubai building code part c accessibility j) minimum of two handrails shall be installed on each of side walls at height m) button to reach exit floor (usually ground floor) should be raised of 900 mm  100 mm from floor

k) buttons shall be located at height between 900 mm and 1,200 mm above floor. they shall present high-embossed arabic (0, 1, 2, 3 etc.) numerals (see figure c.48 and figure c.49). braille numerals shall be located on left lower side of each button in accordance with figure c.48
l) for elevators serving multiple floors, keypad should be installed at maximum height of 1,200 mm so that all floors can be called

figure c.48 example of buttons path with braille language figure c.49 example of keypad with raised dot in number five key c 36 minimum of 3 mm from other buttons and be circled with green line not less than 2 mm wide, as shown in figure c.48
n) call buttons at each floor may contain tactile icons instead of digits. these should be colour-contrasted against background
o) where touch screens or buttons installed, tactile button shall be included to activate alternative interface for blind or visually-impaired passengers, e.g. audible floor count system
p) braille and tactile signage shall be provided on door jamb at height of 1,500 mm

q) elevator shall have hands-free intercom that allows two-way communication, enabling permanent contact between passengers in elevator and rescue service. intercom shall have sign (graphic and tactile) indicating phone number of alarm centre and appropriate number to report emergency
r) audible signals shall sound or audible voice announcement shall be made when each floor reached. visual signals should be provided in public use buildings for hearing impaired people

s) to allow users with hearing impairment to communicate in emergency one of following options shall be provided 1) audio/visual intercom or 2) means of sending and receiving emergency sms text messages from inside cab, either by maintaining necessary network coverage or through alternative system
t) lights should be installed to provide uniform illumination of minimum of 100 lux
u) in panoramic elevators it recommended that full height opaque wall or corner section 800 mm wide provided

dubai building code part c accessibility 1,500  9 0 0 0 2 2 , 1  5 6 8  0 0 2 , 1 - 0 0 9 1,500  1 , 5 0 0 figure c.50 lift platform dimensions lift platforms c.5.9.4 for buildings other than private residences, lift platforms shall be installed only where restrictions in building do not allow installation of passenger elevator (for example, in existing buildings to navigate changes in floor level)
following requirements and recommendations apply to vertical lift platforms
a) lift platform shall have minimum dimensions shown in figure c.50
b) landing of 1,500 mm  1,500 mm shall be provided to give access to platform, and shall be kept free of obstacles
c) side interaction space in front of lift-calling button shall be located at height between 900 mm and 1,200 mm
d) platform access shall have minimum clear width of 900 mm and be free of obstacles
e) side protection shall be provided to separate users from walls of lift platform shaft
f) inside platform cabin, minimum of two handrails shall be provided at height between 865 mm and 965 mm from floor
g) control buttons shall be located at height between 900 mm and 1,200 mm. they shall have continuous pressure button operation and shall be operable with elbow or closed fist
h) there should be additional external control for platform that can be used by authorized personnel when necessary
i) if cabin open or not fully enclosed with half height enclosure only reaching halfway up cabin, maximum travel height shall be 2,000 mm in public use buildings and 3,000 mm in private housing

c 37 dubai building code part c accessibility c.5.10 temporary facilities in outdoor spaces following requirements and recommendations apply to temporary facilities and signs located on sidewalks, squares and other outdoor spaces (including signs and terraces for cafes and restaurants)

a) minimum clear width and height requirements for accessible routes shall be maintained. b) facility shall not interrupt any guidance element (such as faades, walls and guardrails) without providing alternative

c) facility should not encroach upon accessible route. where accessible route adjacent to terrace, perimeter of terrace should be protected by continuous element with minimum height of 900 mm (except at access to terrace). continuous element shall be detectable by people with visual impairment
d) where terraces installed close to vehicular routes, elements such as traffic bollards and other rigid obstacles shall be installed at minimum intervals of 1,200 mm (see figure c.51)

escalators and moving walks c.5.9.5 c.5.9.5.1 general escalators and inclined moving walks not usually considered part of accessible route. however, they can be made more accessible. signage leading to accessible route shall be provided for escalators and moving walks

escalators c.5.9.5.2 escalators shall include following a) horizontal and vertical edges to tread nosing of all steps, finished in yellow b) handrails that include colour contrast dots or similar c) clear information on direction of travel (e.g. at traffic lights) and d) approach route and exit area flooring that visually contrasts with surrounding floor in texture and colour
at both ends of flight, escalator shall move horizontally for minimum of four treads before changing direction vertically
audio system indicating start and end of escalators recommended
c.5.9.5.3 moving walks moving walks considered complementary elements of accessible routes and shall conform to following requirements
a) moving surface shall present maximum gradient of 5%
b) beginning and end of moving walk shall comprise surface that visually contrasts with surroundings
c) direction of travel shall be marked
audio system indicating start and end of moving walks recommended

barrier access and queuing on vehicular access shall not obstruct accessible route

1,250 1,875 2,500 table c.16 dimensions and gradients of curb ramps c.6.2 curb ramps c.6.2.1 all curb ramp types described in c.6.2.2 shall conform to following
general a) running gradient shall be not more than 8%. depending on height of sidewalk, length shall conform to table c.16. curb height shall be not less than 75 mm and not more than 150 mm

b) total width of curb ramps in pedestrian crossings shall be same as that of accessible route. total width shall be not less than 1,200 mm, with no interruptions by any obstacle or raised pavement. c) curb ramps shall not interfere with accessible route. curb ramps shall be free of any obstruction such as signposts, traffic lights and similar items
d) curb ramps shall have tactile warning paving at 300 mm from curb edge to driveways
e) curb ramp edge surfaces shall be completely level with road
f) colour and texture of curb ramp should be similar to accessible route
g) surface of curb ramp shall conform to c.7.2.1
h) maximum cross-slope gradient shall be 2%
i) curb ramps shall be located or protected to prevent obstruction by parked vehicles
j) curb ramps located on both sides of street should align
k) visual, audible and tactile warning devices shall be provided when pedestrian crossing required
