c.6.4 accessible parking accessible parking provision c.6.4.1 public or private parking areas associated with public street, open space or building shall have accessible parking spaces. these parking spaces shall be reserved for holders of accessible parking stickers issued by any authorized jurisdiction
number of accessible parking spaces shall be obtained from table c.17
for hospitals and healthcare facilities, 10% of overall parking capacity should be accessible
accessible van parking should be provided at rate of 10% of overall accessible parking count. at least one accessible van parking space should be provided for each building or facility

accessible parking spaces shall conform to minimum dimensions in table c.18. all buildings except private housing buildings with reserved seating space for wheelchair users, such as cinemas and sport facilities 25 to 500 total parking spaces 2% of total, and minimum of one more than 500 total parking spaces 1% for additional parking spaces over 500 one for every two reserved seating spaces for wheelchair users buildings and open spaces without parking facilities but with following uses two bays in public areas, as close as possible to building entrance (maximum 50 m) a) administration headquarters b) hospitals c) education buildings d) sport facilities e) beaches with accessible routes f) g) clinics

rehabilitation and day care centres and table c.17 minimum number of accessible parking spaces parking type parking space dimensions (m) car  angled and perpendicular car  parallel  along sidewalk accessible van table c.18 parking dimensions 2.5  5.5 2.5  6.0 3.35  5.5 c 44 dubai building code part c accessibility c.6.4.2 following requirements and recommendations apply to accessible parking spaces

location of accessible parking spaces a) accessible parking spaces should be located as close as possible to public facilities. b) accessible parking spaces shall be located maximum of 50 from building entrance. accessible route shall provide access to sidewalk from road, or accessible curb ramp shall be provided
c) minimum of one accessible parking space shall be provided adjacent to each accessible entrance

d) where parking area served by multiple accessible building entrances, accessible parking spaces shall be maximum of 50 from each accessible entrance. distribution of accessible parking be such that all accessible parking spaces not located in same area
e) when multi-level parking provided, at least one accessible parking space shall be available at grade level whenever grade parking provided

f) accessible parking spaces shall have access aisle at least of 1,200 mm wide. access aisle shall be connected to accessible route. angled parking spaces shall have side access aisle, to allow for approach and transfer from drivers side. rear access aisle shall be provided to parking spaces along sidewalk. g) if accessible parking aisle shared between two vehicles parking adjacently, aisle shall be centrally accessible for both vehicles (see figure c.59)

h) parking spaces shall be marked with symbol for people of determination, painted on ground and on signpost. this sign should be visible from driving position and mounted at height of 2,100 mm (see figure c.60)

i) for parking areas controlled by vehicle barriers, meters or ticket dispensers, equipment shall be installed at appropriate location and height for use by people of determination. guidance given in bs 8300 on these provisions for people of determination should be followed
j) wayfinding signs conforming to c.11 shall be provided to indicate location of accessible parking spaces

k) for enclosed parking areas, wayfinding signs shall be provided at any directional change option inside parking area. signs should use symbols and colours of each area and floor to help people find their cars, toilets and exits
l) pedestrian routes within parking areas shall be identified by floor painting with reflectance contrast of 30 points lrv compared to vehicular routes
c 45 dubai building code part c accessibility 8% 5

2 figure c.59 example of accessible parking spaces with side aisle figure c.60 example of accessible parking space along sidewalk with sign on post 3.3 1.2 2.5 6.0 1.2 key 01 curb to parking 02 sign key 01 curb to parking 02 sign c 46 dubai building code part c accessibility c.7 accessible building elements c.7.1 windows and window hardware following requirements and recommendations apply to windows and window hardware
a) any opening window located externally or internally shall not project into accessible routes within 2,100 mm of ffl

b) window controls shall not require wrist turning. they should be easy to manipulate with one hand or elbow, or be automatically operated. windows shall be capable of being opened and closed using limited force. force needed to open window shall be not more than 22.2 n
c) window controls should contrast visually with their background for benefit of partially sighted people. controls should be within accessible reach ranges, mounted between 900 mm and 1,200 mm
d) design should prioritize similar levels of access to natural light for all building users

e) to provide exterior views for children, people of short stature and wheelchair users, bottom of any glazed opening should be maximum of 900 mm above internal floor level. to provide minimum clear viewing range, no horizontal transoms should be positioned between 900 mm and 1,200 mm above floor level (see figure c.61 and figure c.62). 0 0 2 1  , 0 0 9  figure c.61 window viewing range 0 0 2 , 1  0 0 9  figure c.62 minimum clear viewing range ( british standards institute. figure extracted from bs 83002018. permission to reproduce extracts from british standards granted by bsi standards limited (bsi). no other use of this material permitted)

c 48 dubai building code part c accessibility when grate openings longitudinal, they shall be installed such that length of openings perpendicular to direction of travel over grate (see figure c.64 and figure c.65)
c.7.2.1.3 other requirements floor surfaces shall be firm, smooth and stable
c.7.2.1.3 other requirements floor surfaces shall be firm, smooth and stable
c.7.2.1.3 other requirements floor surfaces shall be firm, smooth and stable
tiles presenting rounded edges and excessive joints should not be used in accessible routes to prevent wheel vibration, tripping and noise
internal and external surfaces shall not have loose elements and shall allow for movement or dragging

rugs and carpets shall be firmly fixed to floor and shall allow easy movement for wheelchair users. rugs and carpets shall not increase force required to roll over ceramic pavement by more than 25%. this can be measured with dynamometer comparing effort required to move person seating in wheelchair on both surfaces. pile height shall be maximum of 13 mm. exposed edges of carpet shall be fastened to floor surfaces and shall have trim along entire length of exposed edge

rugs and carpets shall be firmly fixed to floor and shall allow easy movement for wheelchair users. rugs and carpets shall not increase force required to roll over ceramic pavement by more than 25%. this can be measured with dynamometer comparing effort required to move person seating in wheelchair on both surfaces. pile height shall be maximum of 13 mm. exposed edges of carpet shall be fastened to floor surfaces and shall have trim along entire length of exposed edge
carpets installed at entrance lobbies shall be limited to maximum height difference of 5 mm from surrounding floor finish

15 figure c.64 elongated openings in floor or ground surfaces (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 302.3) key 01 dominant direction of travel 02 long dimension perpendicular to dominant direction of travel floor surfaces shall be finished with appropriate flooring materials or coatings that do not produce glare

15 figure c.64 elongated openings in floor or ground surfaces (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 302.3) key 01 dominant direction of travel 02 long dimension perpendicular to dominant direction of travel floor surfaces shall be finished with appropriate flooring materials or coatings that do not produce glare

floor patterning that could be mistaken for steps, e.g. stripes, should not be used in common circulation areas
lighting shall not be installed in floors if it produces glare in area of accessible routes
lighting installed in floors shall not produce heat

imperfections or irregularities that create level difference of more than 5 mm, or holes larger than 15 mm in diameter, shall not be allowed in floor surface. such differences can be avoided by careful selection of material and regular maintenance

a) seating height shall be between 430 mm and 480 mm above ffl. seating depth shall be between 450 mm and 500 mm (see figure c.74 and figure c.75)

b) backrest with height of between 400 mm and 500 mm shall be provided. c) allowable stresses shall not be exceeded for materials used when vertical or horizontal force of 113 kg (1,112 n) applied at any point on seat, fastener, mounting device or supporting structure
d) side interaction space shall be provided on at least one side, as shown in figure c.74 and figure c.75. space shall not encroach on accessible route
e) mixture of seating options (e.g. fixed or removable, with or without arms, wider seats) should be provided for customers or visitors to building

f) it recommended that furniture with standing support provided, in combination with benches of varied height, to allow use by diverse group of people. where possible, seats of varied height and width should be provided for people of large stature or those with restricted leg movements
g) seating should contrast visually with surrounding surfaces for ease of identification

grab bars a) grab bars with circular cross-sections shall have outside diameter of 30 mm minimum and 50 mm maximum, as shown in figure c.101(a)

b) grab bars with non-circular cross-sections shall have maximum cross-section dimension of 50 mm and perimeter dimension of 100 mm minimum and 160 mm maximum, as shown in figure c.101(b) and figure c.101(c)

(a) grab bar with circular cross section (b) grab bar with non-circular (square) cross-section (c) grab bar with non-circular (oval) cross-section figure c.101 grab bar cross-sections (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 609.2.2) key 01 100 mm to 160 mm perimeter grab bars shall be structurally stable and separated from wall by minimum of 45 mm. they shall withstand force of 1 kn in any direction. c 73 dubai building code part c accessibility c.8.4 family toilets it recommended that one family toilet provided for each block of toilets. minimum of one family toilet shall be provided within 300 of any part of building

(a) grab bar with circular cross section (b) grab bar with non-circular (square) cross-section (c) grab bar with non-circular (oval) cross-section figure c.101 grab bar cross-sections (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 609.2.2) key 01 100 mm to 160 mm perimeter grab bars shall be structurally stable and separated from wall by minimum of 45 mm. they shall withstand force of 1 kn in any direction. c 73 dubai building code part c accessibility c.8.4 family toilets it recommended that one family toilet provided for each block of toilets. minimum of one family toilet shall be provided within 300 of any part of building
family toilets shall be provided in malls, parks and amusement parks
accessible family toilet shall conform to requirements specified for accessible toilets and following (see figure c.102)

a) it shall contain folding changing boards for adults and babies that do not interfere with any of approaching manoeuvring and transfer spaces to water closet and sink. board usable area shall be at height of 500 mm from floor
b) it shall contain second sink for children at height of 500 mm from floor
c) clear manoeuvring space of minimum 2,000 mm diameter shall be provided that free of obstacles
d) in addition to water closet, urinal shall be provided with usable height of 400 mm
e) full-length mirror shall be provided for ease of use by children
f) emergency call button shall be provided

key 01 folding adult changing board 02 waste bin 03 urinal 04 folding baby changing board 05 emergency call bell 06 toilet 07 horizontal grab bars 08 child sink 09 adult sink figure c.102 example of family toilet  2,0 0 0 02 08 09 c 74 dubai building code part c accessibility c.8.5 controls and accessories all controls and accessories shall conform to following requirements
a) fixtures shall have reflectance contrast with walls of minimum 30 points lrv
b) flushing systems, which operated by pressure or with flush handle, shall be located on open side of toilet. controls shall have surface operable with only one hand, closed fist or elbow
c) controls and accessories shall be mounted at height between 400 mm and 1,200 mm as shown in figure c.103(a) and in accordance with reach ranges specified in c.5.7
d) dispensers located in toilet facilities for use by children shall align with reach ranges of children specified in c.5.7.3

e) toilet paper dispensers shall be minimum 200 mm and maximum 250 mm from front of water closet, measured to centre line of dispenser. outlet of dispenser shall be minimum 400 mm and maximum 1,200 mm above finish floor and shall not be located behind grab bars (see figure c.103(b)). dispensers shall not be of type that controls delivery or that does not allow continuous paper flow

f) mirrors located above washbasins or countertops shall be installed with bottom edge of reflecting surface maximum 1,050 mm above finish floor or ground. mirrors not located above washbasins or countertops shall be installed with bottom edge of reflecting surface maximum 900 mm above finish floor or ground (see figure c.103(c))

c 75 0 0 2 , 1  0 0 4  (a) controls and accessories 0 0 2 , 1 - 0 0 4 0 5 0 , 1  0 0 9  (b) toilet dispensers (c) mirrors figure c.103 mounting heights for restroom accessories key 01 soap dispenser 02 paper towel dispenser 03 sanitary napkin dispenser 04 hand dryer 05 combined paper towel dispenser and waste bin 06 toilet paper dispenser dubai building code part c accessibility c.8.6 ablution areas minimum of one accessible ablution unit shall be available in each ablution area. accessible ablution units shall be provided either as accessible sink or through clear approach to ablution faucet
in addition to dimensions and characteristics of accessible sink specified in c.8.3.6, each ablution unit shall conform to figure c.104 or figure c.105 and following requirements
a) it shall be linked to accessible route and shall be closest sink to entrance door

b) two horizontal grab bars shall be mounted each side of ablution sink, between 850 mm and 900 mm above ffl. grab bars shall have support length equal to length of sink. c) hand spray system and soap and paper dispensers shall be mounted within reaching range of sink. all accessories, including bidet shower, should be mounted between 700 mm and 1,200 mm above ffl
d) ablution drainage grates shall be levelled with floor finish with maximum level difference of 5mm

c 76 0 0 3 , 1  1,500 06 0 0 9 key 01 paper dispenser 02 shower handset 03 soap dispenser 04 drainage grile/grate 05 horizontal bars 06 wash basin figure c.104 accessible ablution sink dubai building code part c accessibility for level approach to ablution unit, wall-mounted grab bar between 850 mm and 1,050 mm above ffl preferable, as shown in figure c.105. approaching free space of 1,300 mm length shall be provided

key 01 wall mounted grab bar 02 stainless steel grating 0 5 0 , 1 - 0 5 8 1,300 figure c.105 level approach to ablution faucet c 77 dubai building code part c accessibility c.8.7 drinking fountains for drinking fountains in urban spaces and buildings following and figure c.106 apply
a) two fountains with different heights shall be provided one between 750 mm and 1,200 mm above ground or ffl and accessible fountain between 750 mm and 900 mm above ground or ffl
b) drinking fountains shall allow frontal approach and provide knee and toe clearance specified in c.5.6.2
c) if push button manual, it shall be accessible mechanism that easy to operate. it shall be positioned between 700 mm and 1,200 mm above ffl or ground level
d) water shall be attainable at height of between 750 mm and 900 mm above ffl, and near to approaching space (see figure c.106). design should prevent user from getting wet during use
e) spout shall be located minimum 400 mm from back vertical support and maximum 125 mm from front edge of fountain unit, including bumpers
f) drinking fountains should be provided with bottle fillers
g) where possible, drinking fountains should be located in alcove to avoid protrusion hazard
h) drinking fountains should be installed against visually contrasting background to increase their visibility

50 or less 51 to 500 501 to 1,000 2 2 2 plus 1 per 25 over 50 1 per 4 receivers 20 plus 1 per 50 over 500 1 per 4 receivers minimum number of receivers to be hearing aid compatible hearing enhancement system shall be provided in following building types and occupancies a) public use reception areas b) meeting rooms and waiting areas for more than 25 people c) auditoriums d) accessible service counters e) theatres f) mosques g) cinemas and h) concert halls

50 or less 51 to 500 501 to 1,000 2 2 2 plus 1 per 25 over 50 1 per 4 receivers 20 plus 1 per 50 over 500 1 per 4 receivers minimum number of receivers to be hearing aid compatible hearing enhancement system shall be provided in following building types and occupancies a) public use reception areas b) meeting rooms and waiting areas for more than 25 people c) auditoriums d) accessible service counters e) theatres f) mosques g) cinemas and h) concert halls

expert advice should be sought when selecting hearing enhancement system appropriate for situation and purpose. guidance on provision of hearing enhancement systems given in bs 8300 should be followed

hearing enhancement systems compatible with language translation systems. sign should be posted indicating that enhancement system available. where hearing enhancement system provided, accessibility symbol for hearing impairment shall be provided. to aid effectiveness of hearing enhancement system, rooms shall be designed with sound absorbing surfaces to reduce transference of noise (see part h)
assistive listening receivers for hearing enhancement system shall be provided in accordance with table c.24. for induction loop systems, it not mandatory to provide hearing aid compatible receivers

c 79 1,001 and above 40 plus 1 per 100 over 1,000 1 per 4 receivers table c.24 minimum number of receivers c.9.2 provisions for service animals in theatres, cinemas, conference rooms, auditoriums and facilities where people expected to sit or wait, some seats should have space for service animal near their owner
in large buildings, such as shopping malls, leisure or entertainment facilities, and mass transport facilities, it recommended that relief facility provided for assistance animals
following requirements and recommendations apply to design of relief facilities
a) they shall not connect directly to spaces used by persons but shall be connected to accessible route

b) they should have minimum area of 3,000 mm  4,000 mm and be surrounded by 1,200 mm high fence. entrance should be easy to find and operate by visually impaired person. surface should be cleanable, with smooth finish and slope for drainage
c) waste bin and supply of plastic bags should be provided close to entrance
d) relief facilities should have accessible sign stating, for service animals only

dubai building code part c accessibility c.10 accessibility requirements for specific building types and occupancies c.10.2.3 accessible auditorium seating spaces c.10.2.3.1 general following requirements and recommendations apply to auditorium seating

dubai building code part c accessibility c.10 accessibility requirements for specific building types and occupancies c.10.2.3 accessible auditorium seating spaces c.10.2.3.1 general following requirements and recommendations apply to auditorium seating
a) it shall be connected by accessible route to seating area, and access aisle to designated wheelchair spaces
b) accessible seating may be provided with either designated wheelchair spaces or removable seating that can be converted to wheelchair spaces

c) wheelchair spaces shall be provided according to table c.25 and figure c.107. criteria width  single space width  two adjacent spaces length  front or rear approach length  side approach manoeuvring space seating access aisle minimum dimensions (mm) 900 850 1,300 1,500 1,500 x 1,500 1,000 table c.25 wheelchair space requirements for auditoriums c.10.1 general this section specifies requirements for specific building types and occupancies. requirements of c.4 to c.9 and c.11 shall be met in addition to requirements of c.10

headings: cultural buildings, libraries, museums and exhibition rooms
Description: c.10.2 assembly buildings and spaces cultural buildings, libraries, museums and exhibition rooms c.10.2.1 following requirements and recommendations apply to cultural buildings, libraries, museums and exhibition rooms

a) exhibitions should be designed to allow exploration, discovery and enjoyment of different sensorial experiences by different abled people. different users perceive information using different senses. lights, smells, sounds, colours and other multi-sensorial elements can be used to assist visitors
b) audio guides should be provided for exhibitions to explain, guide and assist visitors. induction loops shall be provided when acoustic information provided
c) visual displays shall conform to c.11.5

headings: theatres, cinemas, conference rooms and auditoriums
Description: theatres, cinemas, conference rooms and auditoriums c.10.2.2 theatres, cinemas, conference rooms and auditoriums shall conform to following requirements
a) venues shall have capability to support subtitles, sign language and audio description where performances offer them
b) stages shall be accessible (see c.10.2.4)
c) accessible toilets shall be located in proximity to seating areas, and not more than 150 away

c 80 dubai building code part c accessibility 900 850 850 (a) single space (b) two spaces 0 0 3 , 1  0 0 5 , 1  (c) front or rear entry (d) side entry figure c.107 wheelchair space for auditoriums variety of seating locations shall be provided for wheelchair users and their companions, to allow choice of seating levels and comfortable line of sight. example shown in figure c.108

c 81 1,500 1,500 1,000 1,000 1,000 1,000 figure c.108 example of reserved seating spaces in auditorium 1,300 1,000 1,300 1,000 key 01 front seating 02 aisle seating 03 rear seating 04 removable seats 05 companion seat 06 accessible aisle 07 rear wall 08 steps 09 guard 10 wheelchair space dubai building code part c accessibility in auditoriums with raked floors, wheelchair spaces should have handrail and guardrails located at any change of level where no barrier provided by other means
space at front of hall or room where sign language interpreter can easily be seen shall have independent overhead light
sufficient number of designated accessible seats for people with hearing impairments should be provided in front of sign language interpreter
wheelchair designated sitting spaces shall be marked with symbol for people of determination

c.10.2.3.2 lines of sight over seated spectators where spectators expected to remain seated during events, spectators in wheelchair spaces shall be afforded lines of sight as shown in figure c.109 and figure c.110

figure c.109 line of sight over heads of seated spectators (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010. figure 802.2.1.1.) figure c.110 lines of sight between heads of seated spectators (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 802.2.1.2. number of wheelchair spaces shall conform to table c.26

number of wheelchair spaces one reserved wheelchair space for every 50 seats or fraction thereof up to 500 seats one reserved wheelchair space for every 100 seats or fraction thereof above first 500 table c.26 required number of wheelchair spaces wheelchair sitting spaces shall not overlap accessible aisle minimum width

for facilities with fixed seats, it recommended that wheelchair spaces arranged into groups of maximum two for 50% of accessible seating capacity. each group of wheelchair spaces can have at least equal number of fixed seats, to allow person accompanying wheelchair user to be seated next to them
companion seats conforming to following should be provided for 50% of wheelchair spaces
1) in row seating, companion seats shall be located to provide shoulder alignment with adjacent wheelchair spaces
2) floor surface of companion seats shall be at same elevation as floor surface of wheelchair space
3) companion seats shall be equivalent in size, quality, comfort and amenities to seating in immediate area. companion seats can be movable
for removable or foldable seats provided in designated wheelchair spaces, conversion process shall be quick and easy
both surface of wheelchair spaces and clear manoeuvring space shall be level, having maximum longitudinal gradient of 2%
aisle seats shall have foldable or retractable armrests

c 82 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.3.3 lines of sight over standing spectators where spectators expected to stand during events, spectators in wheelchair spaces shall be afforded lines of sight as shown in figure c.111 and figure c.112

figure c.111 lines of sight over heads of standing spectators (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 802.2.2.2.1.) figure c.112 lines of sight between heads of standing spectators (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 802.2.2.2.) stages and backstage c.10.2.4 stages shall be accessible to everyone via ramp or lift. in exceptional case lift platform can be provided to make stage accessible. lift platform shall conform to c.5.9.4

figure c.111 lines of sight over heads of standing spectators (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 802.2.2.2.1.) figure c.112 lines of sight between heads of standing spectators (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 802.2.2.2.) stages and backstage c.10.2.4 stages shall be accessible to everyone via ramp or lift. in exceptional case lift platform can be provided to make stage accessible. lift platform shall conform to c.5.9.4
all controls to be operated by speaker/performer shall be operable by seated person
it should be possible to use assistive listening system on stage. stage area shall contain space for wheelchair manoeuvring clearances
buildings for public events with capacity of more than 300 spectators should have accessible backstage area with accessible toilet, including shower, changing room and space with accessible mirror
route between backstage and stage shall be accessible route

c 83 1,000 libraries and reading c.10.2.5 areas seating allocated to people of determination should be on direct route, which free of obstructions and located so that it easily identifiable by visually impaired people. aisle spacing for accessing seating area shall be minimum of 1,000 mm (see figure c.113)
space should be provided nearby for storage of wheelchair, to allow wheelchair user to transfer from their wheelchair to seat
seating designated for people of determination should not obstruct other users

dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.6 mosques and prayer rooms mosques and prayer rooms shall conform to following requirements
dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.6 mosques and prayer rooms mosques and prayer rooms shall conform to following requirements
a) in addition to clear area provided at entrance in accordance with c.5.6.1, keep clear mat shall be provided if clear entrance not guaranteed
b) seating shall be provided at entrances and at other locations where people required to remove their shoes
c) seating should be provided within prayer hall to accommodate people cannot bend to pray
d) route to designated area crossing prayer halls carpeting shall have low pile carpeting or be level with circulation area (see c.7.2.1)
e) accessible sanitary provision shall be minimum of one accessible toilet and one accessible ablution space within each prayer room for each gender

public spaces c.10.2.7 c.10.2.7.1 general following requirements and recommendations apply to public spaces, such as parks, beaches and open spaces for public use, including their facilities, services and urban furniture

public spaces c.10.2.7 c.10.2.7.1 general following requirements and recommendations apply to public spaces, such as parks, beaches and open spaces for public use, including their facilities, services and urban furniture

a) all urban furniture and signage shall not interfere with accessible route. b) where public space designed exclusively or mainly for pedestrians, all areas between buildings or lots shall be as level as possible. physical speed-calming element shall be installed at all entrances to area to limit vehicles to 10 km/h
c) in outdoor spaces it recommended that resting places located at maximum intervals of 100 m. benches with and without arms should be provided to accommodate people of various sizes
d) publicly accessible toilets shall be installed near accessible route (see c.8.1). it recommended that they located on same level as accessible entrance

e) electric mobility device chargers with interaction space shall be installed in following locations 1) accessible routes in vicinity of park entrances 2) along public beaches 3) near tourist attractions 4) in shopping malls and 5) in other places as appropriate

f) provision of continuous shaded paths encouraged. shaded areas should be provided at minimum intervals of 50 in streets and squares. each second area should be provided with seating places and space for wheelchair users without invading accessible route

c 84 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.7.2 parks, beaches and natural spaces information about nearest publicly accessible toilets and interest points within park or beach shall as minimum be installed at every route intersection. supplementary routes can be provided at beaches and natural landscape areas where walking would be difficult
supplementary route shall conform to following
a) it shall have minimum clear width of 1,500 mm and be free of obstacles
b) where natural slope of terrain allows it, routes running gradient shall be not greater than 5% and crossfall gradients shall be maximum of 2%
c) it shall reach as close as possible to waters edge or natural landscape area (see figure c.114)

d) there should be minimum of one accessible unit of each utility (such as toilets, lounges, beach cafes and restaurants, showers, changing rooms, furniture and emergency services). e) utilities should be installed as close as possible to each other and shall be connected by accessible route. access to utilities shall be via accessible route from access point and from accessible route to waters edge or natural landscape area (see figure c.114)

d) there should be minimum of one accessible unit of each utility (such as toilets, lounges, beach cafes and restaurants, showers, changing rooms, furniture and emergency services). e) utilities should be installed as close as possible to each other and shall be connected by accessible route. access to utilities shall be via accessible route from access point and from accessible route to waters edge or natural landscape area (see figure c.114)

8% 0 0 5 , 1  1 , 5 0 0 1,500 key 01 sign 02 accessible route 03 water closet 04 shower 05 caf 06 awnings area 07 rope figure c.114 accessible route at beach c 85 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.7.3 access to lakes and seas orientation rope shall be provided at point of access into water. this rope shall remain floating and its length be adapted to specific conditions of each swimming area (see figure c.115)

c.10.2.7.4 outdoor showers outdoor accessible showers shall be provided at accessible beaches and swimming pools. minimum of one shower shall be provided for every 150 of beach length. these showers shall be linked via accessible route and interaction space. they shall be minimum 1,800 mm in width and shall be provided with accessible bench (see figure c.116). bench should be bolted to floor to prevent overturning

c.10.2.7.4 outdoor showers outdoor accessible showers shall be provided at accessible beaches and swimming pools. minimum of one shower shall be provided for every 150 of beach length. these showers shall be linked via accessible route and interaction space. they shall be minimum 1,800 mm in width and shall be provided with accessible bench (see figure c.116). bench should be bolted to floor to prevent overturning

c.10.2.7.4 outdoor showers outdoor accessible showers shall be provided at accessible beaches and swimming pools. minimum of one shower shall be provided for every 150 of beach length. these showers shall be linked via accessible route and interaction space. they shall be minimum 1,800 mm in width and shall be provided with accessible bench (see figure c.116). bench should be bolted to floor to prevent overturning
each shower shall be controlled by button placed between 700 mm and 1,200 mm above floor surface. button shall be operable with elbow or closed fist (see figure c.116)

0 0 2 , 1 - 0 0 7 figure c.116 outdoor shower key 01 shower jet key 01 approx. 400 mm diameter buoy every 10 02 acoustic information point in first buoy 03 approx. 200 mm diameter buoy every 10 04 rope figure c.115 orientation rope c 86 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.7.5 playgrounds playgrounds that offer variety of play options (visual, auditory and tactile) preferred. to be accessible, playground shall conform to following requirements
a) each playground shall conform to basic requirements for accessibility of fixed accessible furniture (see c.7.3)
b) playground surfaces shall consist of rubber or compacted sand
c) surfaces shall be smooth, firm and free of any sharp objects or projections, in order to avoid injuries

d) playgrounds shall be designed to allow all children, regardless of their functional limitations, and according to age group for which playgrounds intended, to enjoy and use minimum of 50% of individual and group expected activities. e) all materials exposed to sun radiation shall not reach temperatures that can harm users

swimming pools c.10.2.8 c.10.2.8.1 general for public use swimming pool, accessible deck shall be provided on at least two sides of pool. accessible route shall link pool with facilities and common areas. for residential pool serving multiple units, pool deck and amenities should be accessible. other private use swimming pool accessibility provisions should be according to operation and users needs
public use swimming pools longer than 25 m, and other bathing pools, shall have minimum of one accessible means of entering water
access to water shall be by sloped entry or assisted elevation chair if pool length exceeds 25

communication shall be provided in visual and audio format simultaneously. f) materials used to construct childrens games (especially sliding ones) shall ada ref. c.2 requirements for accessible swimming pools should be followed. not contain plastics or metals that produce electrostatic discharges that can deprogram hearing aids. any existing playground that produces this effect shall be marked with magnetic warning sign (see figure c.117)
following accessibility features shall also be provided a) safety ladder provisions of americans with disability act (ada) ref. c.2 should be followed
b) underwater illumination if pool will be used at night and c) connection of swimming pool to accessible changing room for each gender in accordance with c.7.6

figure c.117 example of iso and ansi magnetic warning signs c 87 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.8.2 sloped entries sloped entries shall extend to depth of not less than 600 mm and not more than 750 mm below stationary water level (figure c.118)
c.10.2.8.3 pool chair lifts pool chair lifts shall be located where water level does not exceed 1,200 mm within swimming pool area
handrails shall be provided on sloped entry
1,5 0 0 pool chair lifts shall be located over deck and at minimum of 400 mm from edge of pool
clear deck space of 1,500 mm  1,500 mm shall be provided parallel to seat (see figure c.119)
height of chair lift seat shall be between 400 mm and 500 mm from pool deck level when in raised position
seat width shall be minimum of 400 mm
seats shall be at minimum depth of 450 mm below stationary water level when submerged

8% 0 0 1 , 5  0 0 1 , 5  figure c.118 swimming pool with sloped access key 01 accessible peripheral circulation 02 maximum gradient of 8% 03 section of swimming pool wall 04 depth at sloped entry extension to be 600 mm to 750 mm c 88 figure c.119 swimming pool chair lift key 01 minimum required space  1,5 0 0 0 0 1 , 5  dubai building code part c accessibility recreational buildings and amusement parks c.10.2.9 following requirements and recommendations apply to recreational buildings and amusements parks

a) when nature of facility requires auditorium seating places, accessible seating spaces shall be provided. these seating spaces shall conform to requirements for auditorium seating spaces in c.10.2.3
b) amusement facilities should provide equal use for people of determination
c) where providing different amusement facilities in same recreational building or amusement park, at least 50% of them should be accessible
d) amusement facilities shall have wheelchairs or other personal mobility devices available for users
ada ref. c.2 requirements for provision of recreational facilities, including amusement rides, boating facilities, fishing piers, golf facilities and spas, should be followed
c.10.2.10 dining spaces following requirements and recommendations apply to dining rooms. note example accessible dining room shown in figure c.120
a) accessible route shall be provided to at least half of dining areas
b) illumination of minimum 100 lux shall be provided in at least 10% of dining room
c) acoustic treatment should be incorporated into dining rooms

d) at least 10% of tables shall conform to c.7.3.3 and shall be connected by accessible route. e) accessible route with minimum clear width of 1,000 mm shall be provided to reach accessible tables, all food service areas, condiments and utensils
c 89 f) where self-service aisles or counters provided, all food, condiments and cutlery shall be within reach ranges specified in c.5.7. counters shall conform to c.7.3.5
g) for heavy traffic areas and expected two-way passage, minimum clear passage of 1,500 mm should be maintained
h) space for children strollers and mobility devices shall be provided
i) minimum of 10% of seats shall be movable

1,000 figure c.120 example of accessible dining space dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.11 kitchen and kitchenettes c.10.2.11.1 general kitchen work surface shall have sections of maximum depth of 600 mm and maximum height of 850 mm above finish floor for wheelchair users. these sections shall be kept clear of floor-mounted cupboards, equipment or legs
kitchens shall conform to clearances specified in either c.10.2.11.2 or c.10.2.11.3
c.10.2.11.2 pass-through kitchen in pass-through kitchens (see figure c.121) minimum clearance of 1,200 mm shall be provided
c.10.2.11.3 u-shaped kitchen in u-shaped kitchens (see figure c.122) manoeuvring clearance of 1,500 mm shall be provided

1,500 1,500 figure c.122 manoeuvring clearance for u-shaped kitchens (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 804.2.2. ) kitchens should be designed in accordance with ada ref. c.2 and bs 8300

1,200 figure c.121 clearance for pass-through kitchens (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 804.2.1.) c 90 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.12 transport buildings, stations and terminals c.10.2.12.1 general this subsection specifies general accessibility requirements for transport related buildings such as a) railway and metro stations b) underground railway and rapid transit stations c) airports and terminals and d) sea terminals

1,200 figure c.121 clearance for pass-through kitchens (modified figure based on 2010 ada standards for accessible design, us department of justice 2010, figure 804.2.1.) c 90 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.12 transport buildings, stations and terminals c.10.2.12.1 general this subsection specifies general accessibility requirements for transport related buildings such as a) railway and metro stations b) underground railway and rapid transit stations c) airports and terminals and d) sea terminals

all platforms and waiting areas shall be connected by accessible routes. accessible ticket sales and information counters and seating areas shall be provided. audio and visual communication systems shall be provided
in addition, accessible transportation facilities should be designed in accordance with ada ref. c.2 and bs 8300
c.10.2.12.2 bus shelters bus shelter shall conform to following requirements
a) location of shelter shall not encroach upon accessible pedestrian route, public space or transportation platform
b) accessible route shall be provided, free of protruding obstacles on both sides and with minimum clear height of 2,100 mm. route shall have minimum clear width of 1,200 mm
c) there shall be no obstacle between space covered by bus shelter and transport vehicle
d) any glazed walls shall be marked (see c.7.2.3)

e) minimum of one fixed bench shall be provided. f) minimum of one standing support shall be provided, located at height between 700 mm and 750 mm above floor surface and separated from wall or vertical enclosure by minimum of 200 mm
g) bus shelter shall have minimum average illumination of 50 lux, measured at ground level, during off-service hours. minimum average illumination shall be 100 lux at boarding time
h) boarding area platform shall have detectable warning surface
i) bus signposts shall not obstruct accessible routes. no elements shall protrude below accessible route clear height requirement
c.10.2.12.3 gangways gangway shall be used for embarking and disembarking from berth and to and from vessel
gangway shall have maximum gradient of 8%, measured from vessel or berth surface to gangways intersection with berth surface or vessel landing deck (see figure c.123)

width of gangway should be appropriate to vessel infrastructure, but shall be not less than 1,000 mm. it recommended that this increased to 1,800 mm for vessels with high pedestrian traffic (see figure c.124)
gangway/ramp interface with berth surface and vessel landing deck should be levelled and not exceed vertical gap of 13 mm chamfered

gangway/ramp run with rise greater than 150 mm should have handrails on both sides and be of uniform height above floor. handrails should extend horizontally at least 300 mm beyond top and bottom of gangway/ramp and return to wall, or post. c 91 dubai building code part c accessibility upper and lower handrail should be provided on each side of gangway/ramp. upper handrail should be 865 mm to 965 mm and lower handrail 650 mm to 750 mm above gangway/ramp surface to top of handrail. handrails shall have a) circular section with outside diameter of 30 mm to 40 mm and b) reflectance contrast of at least 30 points lrv
full run of gangway/ramp, including all landings, should be evenly illuminated to at least 100 lux at all interior and exterior gangway/ramps and landings
gangway/ramp shall have anti-slip and non-reflective surface

r 1,500 0 0 0 , 1  r 1,500 8% key 01 vessel 02 landing 03 berth figure c.124 access to vessel key 01 berth 02 tactile warning strip 03 vessel 04 boarding ramp 05 accessible route figure c.123 gangway ramp c 92 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.2.13 sport buildings and exercise rooms c.10.2.13.1 exercise rooms accessible route shall be provided between equipment in sports and exercise rooms

exercise machines and equipment shall have clear interaction space. interaction spaces shall be provided on access side of equipment to allow transfer. one interaction space can be shared between two pieces of equipment. c.10.2.13.2 sport buildings accessible sports facilities shall conform to international paralympics committees requirements ref. c.3
for sports facilities, accessible route shall be provided to connect boundary of each activity area
for court sports, at least one accessible route shall connect both sides of court
where bowling lanes provided, minimum of 5%, but not less than 1, shall be on accessible route conforming to c.5
tiered auditorium seating for sports facilities shall conform to c.10.2.3

c.10.3 residential buildings general c.10.3.1 apartment buildings, staff accommodation and labour accommodation buildings shall have accessible route for accessing buildings and residential amenities. video doorbell should be provided to facilitate communication with residents for people of determination

c.10.3 residential buildings general c.10.3.1 apartment buildings, staff accommodation and labour accommodation buildings shall have accessible route for accessing buildings and residential amenities. video doorbell should be provided to facilitate communication with residents for people of determination

c.10.3 residential buildings general c.10.3.1 apartment buildings, staff accommodation and labour accommodation buildings shall have accessible route for accessing buildings and residential amenities. video doorbell should be provided to facilitate communication with residents for people of determination

c.10.3.2 adaptable units in residential buildings for new housing developments with more than ten units, minimum of 2% of total units and all common spaces in building should be adaptable to meet accessibility needs and conform to accessibility requirements of this part. this allows low-cost conversion of house to meet accessibility needs of any future residents persons of determination
volume 1, section 2 of approved document ref c.4 provides guidelines for designing adaptable accessible units
all adaptable accessible units in new housing buildings shall conform to following requirements
a) entrance and internals doors shall conform to c.5.8
b) wall-mounted switches and socket outlets shall conform to c.5.7.4
c) bathroom shall contain sufficient space clearances to contain minimum of one accessible bathtub or shower, accessible sink and water closet with appropriate space clearances
d) all walls, ducts and boxings shall be strong enough to support grab rails, seats or other adaptations that could impose load up to 1.5 kn/m2

c 93 dubai building code part c accessibility e) in accessible residential units with more than one level, at least kitchen, one bathroom and one living room or bedroom shall be accessible from entrance door without any level changes
f) inside adaptable accessible unit, manoeuvring space inside kitchen shall be minimum 1,200 mm free of door openings and fixed elements, and 1,500 mm where turning required as shown in figure c.125
0 0 1,5 inside adaptable accessible unit, at least one bedroom shall conform to following requirements and figure c.126
1) clear access route of 1,000 mm shall be provided from doorway to window or balcony
2) clear access zone of 1,000 mm shall be provided to one side and foot of bed
3) clear space of 1,200 mm  1,200 mm shall be provided at direction changes
in duplexes and units of two or more levels lift platform may be provided

0 0 6 1,000 1,000 1,200 x 1,200 1,200 x 1,200 0 0 0 , 1 1,200 x 1,200 figure c.126 manoeuvring space in bedroom in adaptable unit ( crown copyright 2015. figure based on diagram 3.9 of building regulations (2010), approved document part m, volume 1, 2015 edition with 2016 amendments. contains public sector information licensed under open government licence v3.0) figure c.125 manoeuvring space in adaptable kitchen c 94 dubai building code part c accessibility controls shall be placed at height of 400 mm to 1,200 mm, except for those to be used from bed. these should be placed within ready reach of occupants. electric outlets shall conform to ranges and locations specified in c.5.7
clear route shall be provided to bed with minimum clear space of 1,500 mm  1,500 mm beside bed not obstructed by any furniture (see figure c.130)
bed shall have maximum height of 500 mm
dressing mirror shall be provided, in which user can see their reflection from distance of 250 mm to 2,000 mm
shelves and drawers shall be provided between 700 mm and 1,200 mm from floor. clothes hangers should be provided between 1,100 mm and 1,400 mm above floor
minimum illumination of 200 lux shall be provided in guest room area
connecting rooms shall have accessible doors
viewing device should be provided in door, with its bottom at height of between 900 mm and 1,200 mm
changes in level or lip in washroom or shower area shall be limited to maximum 5 mm
c.10.4 hotel buildings c.10.4.1 all common spaces in hotel establishment shall be accessible

headings: accessible guest room with mobility features
Description: general accessible hotel rooms should be dispersed between different hotel room types as necessary in accordance with c.10.4.2 and c.10.4.3. c.10.4.2 accessible guest room with mobility features minimum number of accessible guest room with mobility features shall be provided in accordance with table c.27

general accessible hotel rooms should be dispersed between different hotel room types as necessary in accordance with c.10.4.2 and c.10.4.3. c.10.4.2 accessible guest room with mobility features minimum number of accessible guest room with mobility features shall be provided in accordance with table c.27

headings: accessible guest room with mobility features
Description: hotel rooms count accessible guest rooms with mobility features 50 to 500 above 500 2% of total number of rooms 1% for additional rooms over 500 table c.27 number of accessible guest room with mobility features accessible rooms should be located at lower levels of hotel, preferably in first three guest room floors of building. accessible toilet with grab bars, accessible shower and sink shall be provided (see figure c.127 and figure c.128)

hotel rooms count accessible guest rooms with mobility features 50 to 500 above 500 2% of total number of rooms 1% for additional rooms over 500 table c.27 number of accessible guest room with mobility features accessible rooms should be located at lower levels of hotel, preferably in first three guest room floors of building. accessible toilet with grab bars, accessible shower and sink shall be provided (see figure c.127 and figure c.128)
50% of accessible hotel rooms shall contain roll-in showers. other 50% shall contain accessible bathtubs (see figure c.129). alarm string shall be provided at shower or tub
50% of accessible hotel rooms shall contain roll-in showers. other 50% shall contain accessible bathtubs (see figure c.129). alarm string shall be provided at shower or tub
accessible rooms shall be provided with audible and visual fire alarms in accordance with ch. 8 of uae flsc ref. c.1

headings: accessible guest rooms with communication features
Description: hotel rooms count accessible guest rooms with communication features 50 to 500 4% of total number of rooms above 500 rooms 2% for additional rooms over 500 table c.28 number of accessible guest rooms with communication features where provided, such guest room shall a) provide compatibility with adaptive equipment used by people with hearing impairments b) contain telephone interface jacks that compatible with both digital and analogue signal use c) contain visible notification devices to alert room occupants of incoming telephone calls and door knock or bell and d) contain telephones with volume controls compatible with telephone system
ada ref. c.2 requirements for provision of guest rooms with communication features and telephones should be followed
c.10.5 education buildings following requirements and recommendations apply to education buildings, as necessary
a) at building entrances, accessible route shall be provided, segregated from vehicle circulation
b) there should be accessible route from bus yard to building entrance

c) seats with different characteristics should be provided dependent on students needs. space flexibility shall be provided to guarantee that places can be provided for wheelchair users, left-handed users, and people of large stature, limited mobility or breathing, and their communication accessories

d) accessible seats at desks shall be removable and dimensions of desks shall allow use by people in wheelchairs. e) in childrens schools and nurseries, toilets and furniture of appropriate height shall be provided (see c.8.3.4.4)

d) accessible seats at desks shall be removable and dimensions of desks shall allow use by people in wheelchairs. e) in childrens schools and nurseries, toilets and furniture of appropriate height shall be provided (see c.8.3.4.4)
f) accessible toilets shall be provided for teachers, students and visitors

g) for students using assistive devices such as computers or optical character recognition systems, electrical socket outlets should be provided as close as possible to their seats. cables between devices and socket outlets shall not obstruct circulation routes

c 98 dubai building code part c accessibility c.10.6 healthcare buildings c.10.7 business and industrial buildings in addition to accessibility and design requirements imposed by dha regulations and guidelines ref. c.5 to ref. c.15, following requirements and recommendations apply to health and social care buildings

a) horizontal and vertical circulation should be designed to ease movement of beds and gurneys, particularly at changes of directions, at access to rooms from corridors, and in dimensions of elevator cabins
b) corridors shall have handrails along their entire lengths
c) all private patient rooms shall be accessible

all offices, industrial and laboratory facilities including common areas shall be accessible. accessible workstations shall be provided and adapted individually for employees with functional limitation. offices, industries and laboratory facilities shall conform to following requirements for accessible working areas

a) access aisles to workstations shall allow for accessible route with minimum clear width of 1,000 mm. b) manoeuvring space shall be provided for persons in wheelchairs to approach d) minimum of one accessible toilet room for each gender shall be provided in each accessible working area
department or area
c) work counters used by people of determination shall conform to c.7.3.5

d) lighting levels at work areas shall be minimum of 200 lux. e) information on visual displays shall be supplemented by tactile and/or auditory information, colour contrasted, and located on glare-free surface

c 99 dubai building code part c accessibility c.11 signage and wayfinding accessibility requirement c.11.1 wayfinding guidance for accessibility c) letters, numbers, symbols and pictographs shall be glare-free and presented in wayfinding can be particularly challenging for some people of determination. example someone has hearing impairment will rely on visual information but might not be able to hear someone providing directions. someone blind will not be able to see directory, but if it in predictable location and has information in tactile format, they can read it and use sound and even smell to gather more information about their environment

it important to provide wayfinding information in variety of different formats visual, auditory, olfactory and physical. all people use different forms of information gathering to find their way to their destination, but this especially important for people of determination
depending on diversity of population, visual, acoustic and tactile references shall be used to guide person to avoid risks and to reduce confusion
c.11.2 general requirements signs with texts and symbols, visual references and tactile information like high- embossed characters or braille text shall be provided
signs provided to assist person in wayfinding process shall conform to following requirements

a) colour coding shall be used to differentiate zones or hierarchies of text messages. colours that create confusion for colour-blind should be avoided. for example, red and green should not be used together where contrasting colours required. b) signage shall be positioned in manner that wheelchair users or children can see it easily
c 100 high reflectance contrast
d) signage with text shall be provided in english and arabic languages
e) colour contrast between text and its background shall have minimum clear reflectance contrast of 50 points lrv
f) accessibility pictograms shall conform to iso 7000
ada ref. c.2 requirements for accessible signage and wayfinding should be followed

c.11.3 tactile maps and signage general features c.11.3.1 tactile maps that offer embossed visual information and acoustic information should be provided when possible. tactile maps should include only essential information location of services and routes, and position of elements such as information, main services and toilets
terms and concepts used should be easy to understand
graphic plane representation (lines, surfaces) should be defined through embossment, textures and colour contrasts

signs and lettering of map shall be represented through visual contrast between fonts and background colours. font size should be minimum of 20 mm in sans serif type font. information shall also be represented in braille
maximum area of horizontal fixed tactile maps should be 800 mm  450 mm
symbols used shall be clearly differentiated (by form, colour and texture) and shall be easily associated with their representation
for complex tactile maps, buttons for oral information shall be provided

dubai building code part c accessibility location of tactile maps c.11.3.2 when tactile map provided, it shall be located within accessible route and its location shall be indicated with tactile orientation and warning surface. map should be located in well-lit area. obstacles in front of tactile map, such as glass protections, shall be avoided
when mounted in busy public place, tactile map shall include sound information

in large building or open space for public use (park, beach), tactile map shall be located in proximity to main entrance area. in building with more than one floor, it shall be located near stairs or elevator

when fixed to vertical surface, tactile map shall be centred between 1,250 mm and 1,750 mm above floor. on horizontal or inclined surfaces, height shall be between 900 mm and 1,200 mm from floor and inclination shall be between 30 and 45 from horizontal level

raised characters for tactile signage c.11.3.3 tactile signage should be provided. letters, numbers, symbols and pictographs should be raised minimum of 0.8 mm and should be between 16 mm and 50 mm high. if tactile sign mounted on wall, its centre should be at maximum height of 1,500 mm above floor
c 101 long messages should be avoided for letters and symbols in high embossment
braille characters shall be separated 10 mm minimum from any other tactile characters or borders

raised characters should be provided for rooms or spaces identification signage. this signage shall preferably represent single icon or character, for example, number of elevator floor, restrooms icon
high embossment characters shall be sans serif upper case
tactile signage shall be in high embossment and not engraved
symbol height shall be not less than 30 mm. embossment thickness shall be between 2 mm and 5 mm for letters and 2 mm for symbols
tactile surfaces shall have reflectance contrast with surrounding surfaces of minimum 50 points lrv

c.11.4 braille braille dots shall have domed or rounded shape (see figure c.131). indication of upper case letter or letters shall only be used before first word of sentences, proper nouns and names, individual letters of alphabet, initials and acronyms
braille characters should be located beneath corresponding text, at minimum distance of 10 mm from edge of sign

ada ref. c.2 requirements for braille signage may be followed. top view side view figure c.131 example of braille characters dubai building code part c accessibility c.11.5 position of signage signs shall be mounted outside accessible route

signs shall be well illuminated at all times and be positioned such that lighting and sunshine do not produce shadows or glare on signs. backgrounds of signs in reflective or strong visual textures should be avoided. obstacles between signs and observers shall be avoided
signs on walls should be centred at height of 1.5 m. if this space intended for use mainly by children, bottom edge of any sign should be at maximum height of 1.25 (see figure c.132 and figure c.133)
when sign mounted on horizontal or inclined plane, inclination should be between 30  and 45  from horizontal level (see figure c.134)
interior signage at doors should be positioned at latch side of door
1  figure c.133 vertical visual reach  far distance 5 2

1  figure c.132 vertical visual reach  close distance figure c.134 inclined sign and tactile maps c 102 dubai building code part c accessibility c.11.6 accessibility signs and symbols c.11.7 combination of communication processes signs to facilities should incorporate approved accessibility symbols for people of determination in uae (see figure c.135)
signs should be provided to inform people have hearing impairment of locations in building where hearing enhancement systems installed, and where they can obtain necessary equipment for them

to ensure accessible communication process, combination of different communication channels shall be provided depending on building type or occupancies. communication shall include minimum of two of three channels of communication acoustic, visual and tactile
several possible valid combinations of accessible communication process shown in figure c.136

accessibility symbol representing people of determination which to be used for any information and/or service for group, including wayfinding, and to indicate all accessibility in built environment. visual impairment symbol to indicate services, aids and equipment and facilities that support specific group
hearing impairment symbol to indicate services, aids and equipment and facilities that support specific group, such as induction loops

d.4 to d.9 2 dubai building code part vertical transportation d.2 definitions d.2.1 terms acceleration rate of change of speed or velocity of elevator (m/s2)
arrival rate rate at which passengers arrive for service by elevator system, in persons per 5 min or percentage of building population per 5 min
average time to destination average period of time (s) from when passenger either registers landing call or joins queue until responding elevator begins to open its doors at destination floor
average waiting time average period of time (s) from when passenger either registers landing call or joins queue until responding elevator begins to open its doors at boarding floor
boarding floor floor that provides entry into building, including ground floors, basements, parking, podium parking, and connections between towers and car parks at high level
boarding floor floor that provides entry into building, including ground floors, basements, parking, podium parking, and connections between towers and car parks at high level
capacity factor filling rate of elevator during each trip, measured in percentage to rated load

door closing time period of time (s) measured from instant car doors start to close until doors locked. door dwell time period of time (s) elevator doors open for fixed length of time (dwell) after elevator arrives at floor. passengers can then alight or board. these times different to landing calls and car calls

3 door opening time period of time (s) measured from instant car doors start to open until they 800 mm apart. door pre-opening time time-saving feature allowing elevator doors to open in safe zone while arriving at landing within 200 mm from landing level
flight time time between instant car doors locked and time when elevator level at next adjacent floor
grouping elevators in common lobby serving all or part of floors as one group

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handling capacity (hc5) average number of passengers that elevator or group of elevators can transport in period of 5 min

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handling capacity (hc5) average number of passengers that elevator or group of elevators can transport in period of 5 min

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handling capacity (hc5) average number of passengers that elevator or group of elevators can transport in period of 5 min

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handling capacity (hc5) average number of passengers that elevator or group of elevators can transport in period of 5 min

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. handling capacity (hc5) average number of passengers that elevator or group of elevators can transport in period of 5 min
handling capacity (hc5%) percentage of occupant load that elevator group can transport in period of 5 min
high depth building more than 7 below or more than two basements below level of exit discharge, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. d.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc
high-rise building building height greater than or equal to 23 and up to 90 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. d.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc
jerk rate of change of acceleration (m/s3)
occupant load total number of persons that might occupy building or portion thereof

occupiable floor floor designed for human occupancy in which individuals congregate for accommodation, amusement, work, educational or similar purposes. rated capacity load (kg and number of people) for which elevator has built and at which it designed to operate

occupiable floor floor designed for human occupancy in which individuals congregate for accommodation, amusement, work, educational or similar purposes. rated capacity load (kg and number of people) for which elevator has built and at which it designed to operate
rated speed (v) speed (m/s) for which elevator has built and at which it designed to operate
super high-rise building building height greater than 90 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. d.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc
swing mode elevator elevator that used for multiple purposes, e.g. passenger/service, passenger/fire/ service, or fire/service
dubai building code part vertical transportation d.2.2 ac asme bs en ch

6 dubai building code part vertical transportation d.4 general d.5 safety and reliability vertical transportation includes elevators, escalators and moving walks. this section prescribes international standards to be followed for safety, reliability and energy conservation of vertical transportation (vt) systems

6 dubai building code part vertical transportation d.4 general d.5 safety and reliability vertical transportation includes elevators, escalators and moving walks. this section prescribes international standards to be followed for safety, reliability and energy conservation of vertical transportation (vt) systems

6 dubai building code part vertical transportation d.4 general d.5 safety and reliability vertical transportation includes elevators, escalators and moving walks. this section prescribes international standards to be followed for safety, reliability and energy conservation of vertical transportation (vt) systems

6 dubai building code part vertical transportation d.4 general d.5 safety and reliability vertical transportation includes elevators, escalators and moving walks. this section prescribes international standards to be followed for safety, reliability and energy conservation of vertical transportation (vt) systems

it also sets out following acceptable design methods for establishing minimum number of passenger elevators in different building types a) design method 1  prescriptive design using predefined numbers of passenger elevators for single occupancy building types (e.g. apartment building with associated parking and retail at ground floor) (d.8) and b) design method 2  design parameters for use in performance-based vertical transportation design by vt consultants (d.9)

it also sets out following acceptable design methods for establishing minimum number of passenger elevators in different building types a) design method 1  prescriptive design using predefined numbers of passenger elevators for single occupancy building types (e.g. apartment building with associated parking and retail at ground floor) (d.8) and b) design method 2  design parameters for use in performance-based vertical transportation design by vt consultants (d.9)

it also sets out following acceptable design methods for establishing minimum number of passenger elevators in different building types a) design method 1  prescriptive design using predefined numbers of passenger elevators for single occupancy building types (e.g. apartment building with associated parking and retail at ground floor) (d.8) and b) design method 2  design parameters for use in performance-based vertical transportation design by vt consultants (d.9)
accessibility requirements for vertical circulation, including provision of accessible elevators, defined in c.5.9.3

vertical transportation shall be designed, installed, tested, commissioned and maintained in accordance with one of following suites of standards a) asme a17 suite of standards or b) bs en 81 suite of standards
one suite of standards shall be selected for project. suites of standards shall not be used interchangeably
elevators required for firefighting shall conform to section 2.9, ch. 2 and section 3.9, ch. 3 respectively of uae flsc ref. d.1, in addition to chosen suite of standards
in addition, enhanced handrail protection shall be provided at entry to escalators and moving walks as shown in figure d.1

a) elevators in group do not serve equal number of stops/floors. b) up-peak traffic demanding. c) there multiple function areas in floors/mixed use buildings. d) tenants and visitors enrol to get into building/office premises
dcs offers following advantages over conventional control system
1) 2) 3) 4) 5) it improves time to destination by grouping people travelling to same floors at learned intervals
it results in organized lobby space, allowing more people to wait in lobby
it able to perform express travel with fewer intervening stops

it improves system efficiency and handling capacity, allowing group of elevators to transport more passengers in fixed period of time. it allows terminals to be mounted away from elevator lobby, reducing congestion in elevator lobbies
dcs offers following disadvantages over conventional control system
i) it has relatively lower performance during lunchtime peak

ii) for correct and efficient operation of dcs, each passenger needs to enter their destination and not tail-gate. groups of people tend to allow one person to enter destination floor, which means dcs computes that there only one person when there could be two, three or more persons

iii) it not user-friendly for people unfamiliar with system. passenger getting into wrong elevator has to exit and take another elevator to reach their destination. table d.40 sets out building types that benefit from dcs compared to conventional control system. 39 dubai building code part vertical transportation d.10 annex vertical transportation design summaries and report template d.10.1 summary  design method 1 vertical transportation selection 40 vertical transportation selection summary (design method 1) project name location plot no

building maintenance unit permanently installed unit that provides easy and safe access to building envelope for maintenance, inspections and cleaning. containment glass barrier resisting penetration and preventing people from falling even after failure or breakage. damp-proof course layer of waterproof material or construction in wall of building near ground, primarily to prevent rising damp
low-rise building building height less than or up to 15 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. e.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc

gross wall area area of wall that provides thermal barrier of building. it includes solid area and any openings in wall, such as doors or windows. it actual measured area, not projected area on drawing
groundwater pressure pressure of groundwater held within soil or rock, in gaps between particles
high-rise building building height greater than or equal to 23 and up to 90 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. e.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc
mid-rise building building height greater than 15 but less than 23 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. e.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc
mould type of fungus that grows on damp or decaying material surfaces

operational forces forces sustained by building envelope during operation of building, e.g. impact from equipment or occupants. rope access or abseiling form of work positioning that allows rope access technicians to descend, ascend and traverse ropes for access and work while suspended by their harness
shading coefficient (sc) ratio of solar heat gain at normal incidence through glazing to that occurring through approximately 3 mm thick clear float glass

e 3 dubai building code part e building envelope shading device projecting fixture that extends outside external wall of any building, or cover (such as louver), to protect any door or window from rain or solar effect. skylight or overhead glazing glass or other transparent or translucent glazing material installed at slope of 15 or more from vertical
solid metal panels factory manufactured panel consisting of solid metal skin or skins without core. solid metal panels could be aluminium, steel, copper, zinc, stainless steel, titanium, etc
super high-rise building building height greater than 90 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. e.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc

thermal bridge component or assembly of components penetrating through otherwise continuous thermal line through which heat transferred at substantially higher rate than through surrounding envelope areas. examples could be metal fastener, concrete beam, balcony slab or column. thermal insulation materials/products or methods and processes used to reduce heat transfer. heat energy can be transferred by conduction, convection or radiation. flow of heat can be delayed by addressing one or more of these mechanisms and dependent on physical properties of material employed to do this
thermal transmittance rate of transfer of heat through material(s) or assembly, expressed as u-value
vapour resistance layer material layer within wall or roof build-up with high resistance to moisture vapour
