e 7 dubai building code part e building envelope e.4 structural e.4.1 strength and stability general e.4.1.1 any part of building envelope presents hazard if it becomes detached from building. building envelope and associated openings shall be designed and constructed to safely resist loads required by part f and those mentioned in this section

e 7 dubai building code part e building envelope e.4 structural e.4.1 strength and stability general e.4.1.1 any part of building envelope presents hazard if it becomes detached from building. building envelope and associated openings shall be designed and constructed to safely resist loads required by part f and those mentioned in this section

building envelope shall a) be capable of safely sustaining, and transmitting to supporting structure of building, all static and dynamic design loads (i.e. dead, imposed, thermal, seismic, wind, etc.) without fracture or permanent deterioration of its performance note pressure coefficients often vary across building envelope. higher pressure expected at corners

building envelope shall a) be capable of safely sustaining, and transmitting to supporting structure of building, all static and dynamic design loads (i.e. dead, imposed, thermal, seismic, wind, etc.) without fracture or permanent deterioration of its performance note pressure coefficients often vary across building envelope. higher pressure expected at corners

permanent fixture loading e.4.1.3 building envelopes which intended to support permanent fixtures and/or building maintenance equipment attached to either internal or external faces shall be capable of withstanding, without excessive deflection or permanent deterioration of its performance, forces arising from these fixtures, including during use

operational forces e.4.1.4 building envelope shall be capable of sustaining and transferring following loads without any reduction in its performance a) horizontal load applied on surface of panels or on framing members in b) be securely fixed to and supported by structure of building. this shall accordance with section 4.5.1 of asce/sei 07-16 comprise both vertical support and horizontal restraints c) be made, where necessary, to accommodate differential movement of cladding and supporting structure of building (such as differential settlement, inter-storey drifts, etc.) b) uniformly distributed load of 0.6 kn/m2 or 1 kn vertical load, whichever most onerous, applied anywhere on internal ledges, horizontal framing members or horizontal surfaces and c) loads resulting from operation of cleaning cradles, anchor restraint points, d) be of durable materials/products. service life of fixings shall be not less equipment or operators

parts of building envelope protecting occupants from change in level greater than 760 mm shall either be designed to withstand forces given in section 4.5.1 of asce/sei 7-16 or be provided with guardrail in accordance with b.4.2.5.2
balustrades and guardrails at balconies, terraces, roofs and changes in level greater than 760 mm shall conform to b.4.2.5.2
wind loadings e.4.1.2 wind load shall be calculated in accordance with part f or by wind tunnel testing carried out in accordance with part f
wind loadings e.4.1.2 wind load shall be calculated in accordance with part f or by wind tunnel testing carried out in accordance with part f
test loads simulating wind loading shall be applied perpendicularly to building envelope at its weakest point

thermal movements e.4.1.5 building envelope shall be capable of accommodating changes in dimension and shape of its components resulting from changes in service temperatures, and from differential service temperatures between inside and outside of building, without any reduction in its performance

e 8 dubai building code part e building envelope deflection e.4.1.6 under action of most onerous combination of loads, deflections of building envelope components shall be limited such that no defect occurs, and deflections fully recovered after removal of loads. allowable limit deflection shall be determined by material properties, distance between points of attachment and methods of attachment. note deflections given in table e.1 generally acceptable in line with part 3 of cwct standard for systemised building envelopes ref. e.2

component measurement maximum deflection storey-height assemblies, other than masonry between points of attachment to structure 1/200 for span  3,000 mm 5 mm + 1/300 for 3,000 mm < span < 7,500 mm 1/250 for span  7,500 mm opaque infill panels in secondary framing, excluding glass between points of support 1/360 for brittle material such as stone 1/90 for non-brittle materials such as aluminium or steel manufacturer recommendation shall also be sought

framing containing glass between ends of frame 1/125 span of member single glass between ends of unit 1/175 span of double-glazed unit insulating glass units manufacturer recommendation shall also be sought

fixings e.4.1.7 fixings to secure building envelope shall be selected based on proven performance of fixing. manufacturer test data generally determined using european technical assessment (eta), british standard (bs), european norm (en) or astm international (astm) standard

table e.1 maximum recoverable deflection under design load e.4.3 structural use of silicone deflection limits of main structural elements given in f.8

e.5.4 thermal bridges for all new air-conditioned buildings, thermal bridges shall be either eliminated or insulated to reduce amount of heat transfer. thermal bridging can occur at connection points between concrete or steel beams, external walls and columns, and around doors and windows (see figure e.5)
note bre publication on assessing effects of thermal bridging at junctions and around openings ref. e.8 gives further details

02 e.5.3 shade effect calculation use of external shading recommended. impact of external shading (where used) and adjacent buildings can be taken into account when calculating external load criteria. examples of shading devices shown in figure e.4

opaque building envelope surfaces shall have solar reflectance index (sri) value not less than that shown in table e.8 and figure e.6, for minimum of 75% of roof area. e.5.6 sealing of windows and doors doors and window frames on building exterior shall be sealed. sealing materials shall conform to sections 4 to 7, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1. they shall also prevent transmission of air and sound that might occur as result of pressure differences across exterior of building. air leakage shall be controlled in accordance with part h

opaque building envelope surfaces shall have solar reflectance index (sri) value not less than that shown in table e.8 and figure e.6, for minimum of 75% of roof area. e.5.6 sealing of windows and doors doors and window frames on building exterior shall be sealed. sealing materials shall conform to sections 4 to 7, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1. they shall also prevent transmission of air and sound that might occur as result of pressure differences across exterior of building. air leakage shall be controlled in accordance with part h

element steep sloped roofs (slopes steeper than 16) flat and low sloped roofs (slopes lower than or equal to 16) external walls table e.8 building envelope sri value requirements sri value 29 78 29 > 1 6 sri29 1 6 sri78 sri78 sri29 figure e.6 illustration of sri value requirements based on slope of roof e 17 dubai building code part e building envelope e.5.8 exterior light power, pollution and controls average lighting power density for exterior connected lighting load for building envelopes shall not exceed 2.2 w/m2 for each illuminated wall or surface area or 16.4 w/linear metre for each illuminated wall or surface length
permanently installed exterior lighting shall meet following requirements

a) all exterior light fixtures on building site, other than architectural accent lighting (see e.5.8b) and civil aviation safety lighting, shall be shielded, such that full light emitted by fixture, either directly or indirectly by reflection or by refraction from any part of fixture, projected below horizontal plane passing through lowest part of fixture (see figure e.7)
note civil aviation safety lighting not covered in this part
c) downward directed lighting shall be used for lighting of signage
d) all exterior lighting shall be fitted with automatic controls, so that lights can be set not to operate during daylight hours

e 18 figure e.7 example of downward directed lighting projected below horizontal plane of lowest part of fixture dubai building code part e building envelope e.6 sustainable materials e.7 moisture construction materials shall be chosen in accordance with b.10.6

e.7.1 general moisture control fundamental to functioning of any building. controlling moisture important to protect occupants from adverse health effects and to protect building, its mechanical systems and its contents from physical or chemical damage

e.7.2 ground moisture building envelope walls shall a) resist passage of moisture from ground to inside of building b) not be damaged by moisture from ground and c) not carry moisture from ground to any part of building which could be damaged

for building envelope walls that not subject to groundwater pressure, damp- proof course shall be provided at least 150 mm above level of adjoining ground, as shown in figure e.8, unless there part of building design that protects wall. damp-proof course shall be continuous with any damp-proof membrane in floor

e 19 dubai building code part e building envelope e.7.3 precipitation including windblown spray e.7.3.1 building envelope shall resist penetration of precipitation general a) to inside of building and b) to any part of building envelope that might be damaged by moisture

horizontal and inclined surfaces e.7.3.2 horizontal surfaces or inclined surfaces within building envelope (see figure e.9) shall a) be jointless and impermeable to moisture or b) have sealed joints and be impermeable to moisture or c) have overlapping joints and either be impermeable to moisture or be backed by material that directs precipitation towards outer face

02 03 04 06 01 05 07 08 09 10 figure e.8 minimum height for damp-proof course at ground level ( crown copyright, 2013. figure based on diagram 8 of building regulations (2010), approved document part c, 2004 edition with 2010 and 2013 amendments. contains public sector information licensed under open government licence v3.0) key 01 out 02 in 03 internal ground floor 04 continuous damp proof course between wall and floor membrane 05 at least 150 mm if wall external wall 06 external ground floor 07 external pavement 08 insulation 09 compacted soil 10 soil 01 75 02 guidance on protection for building envelope walls that subject to groundwater pressure can be found in bs 8102

figure e.9 horizontal, inclined or vertical surfaces e 20 key 01 vertical surfaces 02 inclined surfaces 03 horizontal surfaces 03 dubai building code part e building envelope vertical surfaces e.7.3.3 vertical surfaces within building envelope (see figure e.9) shall meet following requirements as appropriate to external wall build-up type. examples of external wall build-up types given in figure e.10

figure e.9 horizontal, inclined or vertical surfaces e 20 key 01 vertical surfaces 02 inclined surfaces 03 horizontal surfaces 03 dubai building code part e building envelope vertical surfaces e.7.3.3 vertical surfaces within building envelope (see figure e.9) shall meet following requirements as appropriate to external wall build-up type. examples of external wall build-up types given in figure e.10

a) solid external walls wall shall hold moisture arising from rainwater until moisture can be released in dry period, without penetrating to inside of building or causing damage to building. if wall insulated, insulation shall provide resistance to ingress of moisture to keep wall dry

b) solid external walls with air cavities or with rainscreens outer leaf of external cavity wall shall either be separated from inner leaf by drained air space, or prevent precipitation from being carried to inner leaf. c) curtain walling, doors and windows joints between curtain walling, doors, windows and interfaces with other walls shall resist penetration of precipitation to inside of building. joints shall not permit moisture to reach any part of building which could be damaged

key 01 cladding 02 thermal insulation layer (vapour resistance layer on outer face) 03 block wall 04 plaster 05 cavity 06 glass 07 framing 08 plaster or gypsum board 09 aerated blockwork 10 out 11 in e 21 10 11 10 11 08 (a) solid external walls (b) windows, doors or curtain walls 10 11 10 11 09 09 (c) solid external walls with rainscreens (d) solid external walls with cavaties figure e.10 examples of external wall build-up types dubai building code part e building envelope e.8 acoustics building envelope shall meet acoustic requirements given in h.10

flashing e.7.3.4 flashing shall be installed to prevent moisture from entering building envelope or redirect moisture to exterior. flashing shall be installed at a) perimeters of exterior door and window assemblies b) penetrations and terminations of exterior wall assemblies c) exterior wall intersections with roofs, balconies and similar projections and d) built-in gutters from which moisture could enter wall

e.7.4 risk of interstitial or surface condensation building envelope shall a) be designed and constructed such that its structural and thermal performance not adversely affected by interstitial condensation and b) not promote surface condensation or mould growth, for given occupancy conditions

e.7.4 risk of interstitial or surface condensation building envelope shall a) be designed and constructed such that its structural and thermal performance not adversely affected by interstitial condensation and b) not promote surface condensation or mould growth, for given occupancy conditions

headings: risk of interstitial or surface condensation
Description: e.7.4 risk of interstitial or surface condensation building envelope shall a) be designed and constructed such that its structural and thermal performance not adversely affected by interstitial condensation and b) not promote surface condensation or mould growth, for given occupancy conditions
technical solutions to minimize condensation risk depend on wall type
1) curtain wall, skylight, doors and windows can incorporate thermal breaks in glazed framed systems. 2) roofs and solid external walls can include vapour resistance layer

3) interfaces and junctions between different elements of building envelope (such as windows) can ensure continuity of vapour resistance layer by extending and overlapping vapour resistance layer between elements

note bs 5250 gives further guidance on control of condensation in buildings. while guidance provides principles to control condensation, some commentary and forms of construction given in annexes might not be applicable to dubai climate. e 22 dubai building code part e building envelope e.9 protection from falling, collision and impact e.9.1 protection against impact with glazing safety glazing shall be installed in critical locations in doors, side panels and low level glazing, as shown in figure e.11 and figure e.12

figure e.11 safety glazing at door and adjacent areas ( crown copyright, 2013. figure based on diagram 5.1 of building regulations (2010), approved document part k, 2013 edition. contains public sector information licensed under open government licence v3.0) key 01 ffl e 23 0 0 8 01 key 01 ffl figure e.12 safety glazing at windows ( crown copyright, 2013. figure based on diagram 5.1 of building regulations (2010), approved document part k, 2013 edition. contains public sector information licensed under open government licence v3.0) in accordance with section 5, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1, safety glazing for use in critical locations shall conform to minimum classifications in either table e.9 or table e.10

critical location height classification in test standard bs en 12600 low level areas all heights doors below 900 mm from ffl doors side panel above 900 mm from ffl class 1 class 2 class 3 table e.9 minimum classification for safety glazing area of glazing in critical location (m2) classification in test standard ansi z97.1 cpsc 16 cfr 1201 ref. e.9 0.9 >0.9 b table e.10 minimum classification for safety glazing dubai building code part e building envelope e.9.2 containment e.9.3 manifestation glazing at areas lower than 800 mm from ffl and protecting change in level greater than 760 mm shall provide containment, as shown in figure e.13. transparent glazing in following locations shall incorporate manifestation features 800 a) adjacent to doors b) in doors without frames or handles and c) in other areas where occupants might inadvertently come into contact with glazing

manifestation shall 1) be located between 750 mm and 1,500 mm above ffl 2) occupy minimum of 50% of area horizontally at each 900 mm width interval, with minimum 50% opacity and 3) contain visual elements of any type of bands or marks (such as logos and artistic 02 illustrations)
01 manifestation should be permanent if possible, e.g. etching of glazing, but alternatively, if applied materials used, they should be durable and not easily removed

>760 manifestation and visual detection elements not required in following cases key 01 internal ffl 02 external ffl i) where glass surface less than 500 mm wide ii) where glass surface does not extend more than 850 mm above ffl iii) where fixed element in front of glass surface blocks entire approaching figure e.13 examples of glazed areas that need to provide containment space and iv) where faade glazing in upper floors with no access from outside, and where there no possibility of user confusing it with access glazing
if glazing panel covers areas above and below 800 mm from ffl, entire glazing panel shall provide containment

e 24 dubai building code part e building envelope e.9.4 safe opening and closing of windows e.9.5 overhead glazing sliding and operable windows shall be located at height not less than 900 mm from ffl. overhead glazing shall be laminated. it shall include post-breakage containment system, such that if glass breaks, glass held in place until it can be replaced

e 24 dubai building code part e building envelope e.9.4 safe opening and closing of windows e.9.5 overhead glazing sliding and operable windows shall be located at height not less than 900 mm from ffl. overhead glazing shall be laminated. it shall include post-breakage containment system, such that if glass breaks, glass held in place until it can be replaced
operable windows shall be restrained to limit opening to 100 mm to prevent falls

there shall not be any construction features at bottom of window that can be exploited as ladder or climbing feature. safety and fragility of overhead glazing shall be determined in accordance with cwct tn 66 ref. e.10. overhead glazing shall be tested in accordance with cwct tn 67 ref. e.11. operable windows, skylights and ventilators shall be constructed or equipped such that they can be opened, closed and adjusted safely. wherever practicable, height of controls or handles shall be in accordance with part c as indicated in figure e.14. if controls or handles cannot be positioned as indicated in figure e.14, manual or electrical means of remote operation shall be provided in that location instead

figure e.14 height of controls or handles key 01 ffl e 25 dubai building code part e building envelope e.10.4 fire testing of non-fire resistance rated, non-loadbearing faades and aesthetic features/mashrabiya requirements in section 4.2.1, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1 shall be met, with following amendments
a) exceptions listed in section 4.2.1, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1 expanded to include concrete, terracotta, glass, ceramics and mineral wool
b) in addition to materials listed in section 4.2.1, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1, solid metal panels conforming to e.10.5 may be used
requirements in section 4.5, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1 shall be met, with following amendments
1) steel flashing not required around window openings

2) flashing shall match flashing included in nfpa 285 fire test(s) forming basis of fire safety design(s) of faade. e.10 fire safety e.10.1 general fire safety of faade and roof elements of building envelope shall conform to ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1 and specific requirements of this section. to prevent external fire spread, building shall be physically separated from adjacent plots/buildings or building envelope shall be fire resistance rated (see sections 2.7 and 2.8, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1)
requirements for guardrails and balustrades as described in section 2.17, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1 superseded by b.4.2.5.2
requirements for safety glazing in sections 5.4.2 to 5.4.4, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1 superseded by e.9

e.10.2 sprinklers sprinklers on balconies, as mentioned by ch. 9 of uae flsc ref. e.1, not mandated by dubai civil defence (dcd), provided that materials of construction of balcony conform to ch 1. of uae flsc ref. e.1
sprinklers on inside of rainscreen/glazing/curtainwall, as mentioned by ch. 9 of uae flsc ref. e.1, not mandated by dcd

e.10.3 spandrels fire resistance rated spandrel required by section 2.8.10, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1 may be less than 915 mm, provided that perimeter barrier system in section 3.2.4d tested, certified and listed with intended spandrel specifications, complete with installation guidelines

roofing in non-sprinklered buildings roofing in buildings without fire suppression

astm e108 with pass criteria class roofing in malls, assembly, hospitals and educational

or bs en 13501-5 with pass criteria class broof(t4) or ul 790 with pass criteria class or fm 4470 or fm 4471 with pass criteria pass table e.13 fire test requirements for solid metal panel in roofing e 28 dubai building code part e building envelope e.11 screening of building equipment in accordance with b.10.2, all outdoor mechanical equipment (including antennas, rooftop equipment and refuse storage areas) should be concealed from public view by solid walls, screens, fences, parapets, enclosing structures or landscaping. e.10.9 signboards and billboards signboards and billboards on faades shall conform to section 4, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1. when cumulative surface area of signboards/billboards on faade greater than 50 m2, or signboard/billboard straddles more than one storey, then they shall be fire tested as part of faade system in accordance with section 4, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1. e.10.10 solar panels photovoltaic (pv) cells or panels installed on roofs or faades shall conform to section 2.2, ch. 14 of uae flsc ref. e.1. if pv panels attached to or integrated with faade then they shall also be tested in accordance with section 4, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. e.1

e 29 dubai building code part e building envelope e.12 maintenance e.12.1 general method of safely maintaining building envelope shall be provided. manually operated systems (e.g. rope access) or power operated systems (e.g. cleaning cradles) and building maintenance units (bmus) shall conform to e.12
e.12.2 rope access rope access or abseiling systems shall have permanent dedicated fixed anchors
e.12.3 imposed loading loading of permanent building maintenance equipment attached to either roof or faades shall be included as permanent fixture loading (see e.4.1.3)

e.12.4 cable stabilization and anchors hanging lifelines and all untensioned cables of working platform shall be stabilized when vertical travel exceeds initial 61 m, and at further intervals of 61 or less. hanging cables, other than suspended wire ropes, that in constant tension shall be stabilized when vertical travel exceeds initial 183 distance, and at further intervals of 183 or less. building anchors and components of intermittent stabilization system shall be capable of sustaining without failure at least four times maximum anticipated load applied or transmitted to anchors and components. design wind load for each anchor shall be not less than 1,334 n or design wind load of building, whichever higher. if there two anchors on one attachment point, wind load may be shared

building anchors and stabilizer ties shall be capable of sustaining anticipated horizontal and vertical loads from winds which might act on platform and wire ropes if platform stranded on building face. if building anchors have different spacing to that of suspension wire rope, or if building requires different suspension spacings on one platform, one building anchor and stabilizer tie shall be capable of sustaining wind loads. building anchors that extend beyond face of building shall be free of sharp edges or points. where cables, suspension wire ropes and lifelines might be in contact with building face, external building anchors shall not interfere with their handling or operation
tie-down anchors fasteners, and affected structures shall be resistant to corrosion

e.12.5 power circuit and operation equipment power circuit of power-operated systems shall be independent electrical circuit. it shall remain separate from all other equipment within or on building (other than power circuits for hand tools that will be used in conjunction with equipment). equipment power circuit may be connected to emergency power system, if building has one. power circuit shall be provided with disconnect switch that can be locked in off and on positions. switch shall be located in primary operating area of equipment in convenient position to allow operators of equipment access to switch. disconnect switch for power circuit shall be locked in on position when equipment in use

effective two-way voice communication system shall be provided between equipment operators and persons stationed within building being serviced. communications facility shall be operable and shall always be manned by persons stationed within building whenever equipment being used. e 30 dubai building code part e building envelope e.12.6 protection from impact on building envelope hard or sharp components of maintenance equipment shall be covered with soft protection to prevent building envelope from being impacted

energy impact that maintenance equipment or operator might exert on building envelope shall be calculated. building envelope shall be capable of withstanding applied or transferred impacts that might occur during maintenance without sustaining damage that not repairable and without deterioration of its performance. note cwct tn 96 ref. e.13 gives guidance to assess cradle and suspended access equipment loads
e.12.7 health and safety e.12.7.1 rope access systems shall follow safety guidelines such as irata ref. e.14
rope access back-up fall arrest system shall be provided
back-up fall arrest system may be achieved by using two ropes working line and safety line

power-operated systems e.12.7.2 means shall be provided to traverse all carriages and their suspended equipment to safe area for maintenance and storage. working platform shall, as part of its normal operation, be capable of being lowered to safe surface for access and egress of personnel. working platform shall be provided with safe means of access and egress to lower safe surface. following non-exhaustive list of safety features shall be included before installation of building maintenance unit/glass cleaning cradle a) provisions in case of power failure b) overload safety device c) wire rope equalizer limit switch d) emergency stop e) secondary brake with over-speed protection (mechanical) f) slack rope device g) lanyard restraint trip assembly h) rotational slew limits i) factor of safety for wire rope j) cradle details (i.e. anti-collision bar, handrail/mid rail height, etc.) k) horizontal traversing wheel locking device and l) working environment (i.e. weather conditions such as temperature, humidity, wind speed, etc.). e 31 dubai building code part e building envelope performance statements definitions references framework structural system requirements materials loads performance and serviceability requirements geotechnics annex seismic acceleration and damping parameters annex dubai sustainable concrete baseline (dscb) annex precast stairs f.1 f.2 f.3 f.4 f.5 f.6 f.7 f.8 f.9 f.10 f.11 f.12 f 1 dubai building code part f structure f.1 performance statements performance statement building structure shall safely sustain and transmit to ground combined dead, imposed, thermal, wind and seismic load conditions for its intended life

performance statement will be met by following requirements of f.5 to f.9 f.8 and f.9 f.5.5 f 2 dubai building code part f structure f.2 definitions f.2.1 terms floor height distance between adjacent floor levels measured from top of floor to top of floor above. geotechnical laboratory physical or legal entity in charge of carrying out geotechnical soil investigations and licensed to practice investigation activities in dubai in accordance with applicable legislation. geotechnical specialist contractor physical or legal person in charge of carrying out specialist geotechnical works and design, and licensed to practice geotechnical construction and design activities in dubai in accordance with applicable legislation. ground level average level of ground surface or sidewalk at centre of all exterior walls of building. serviceability condition beyond which structure or member becomes unfit for service and judged to be no longer useful for its intended use. strand high strength steel wires wound around central wire, typically seven-wire strand, which can be used as prestressing reinforcement in tendons. tendon complete assembly consisting of anchorages, prestressing reinforcement, and sheathing with coating for unbonded applications or ducts filled with grout for bonded applications

f 10 dubai building code part f structure f.4 framework f.4.1 application f.4.2 units units shall be in accordance with a.12.2

this part applies to design and construction of buildings, and structures or appurtenances connected to building. structures that require special consideration of their characteristics, functions and environment as listed in part not covered herein. villas and townhouses shall be designed in accordance with part k

in calculations, drawings, specifications and basis of design reports, engineer shall state codes and standards that adopted as basis for design and specification of materials and workmanship. codes and standards shall be specified by document number and title, including version/revision and, where applicable, units (i.e. metric)
where there conflict between this part and referenced codes or standards, most restrictive requirements shall be met
f 11 dubai building code part f structure f.5 structural system requirements optimized structural design f.5.1 general conditions structural design of buildings shall be undertaken by engineer
engineer shall only use appropriate structural analysis and design software, approved by authority

design shall facilitate safe fabrication, transport, handling and erection of structural elements and materials, with due regard to site-specific conditions. as far as reasonably practicable, it shall also take account of needs of maintenance, final demolition, recycling and reuse of materials. typical design issues presented in figure f.1 for inclusion in design stages

f 12 material specification aesthetics structural performance cost substructure superstructure appearance strength dead load sense of place stiness live load durability wind stability seismic robustness soil pressure fire blast wave thermal g n c e f l l e h w design construction maintenance decommissioning buildability sustainability subsoil performance safety/risk site access ground conditions weather recycling re-using pollution energy alternative sources embedded energy energy consumption during building life bearing settlement soil retention liquefaction groundwater construction use re-use decommissioning maintenance movement figure f.1 typical issues in relation to structural design requirements dubai building code part f structure f.5.2 design life f.5.3 design acceptance criteria f.5.4 structural stability design life shall be specified by engineer based on minimum recommended values in table f.1. design life of project shall be agreed between engineer, owner and authority prior to commencing design. structure type temporary structures replaceable structural parts (i.e. bearings, gantry) agricultural and similar buildings special structures (i.e. buildings higher than 300 m, monumental building or structures designated as essential for community) table f.1 recommended minimum design life design life 10 years 10 to 25 years 15 to 30 years 50 years 100 years design shall honour all design acceptance criteria defined by design basis codes and standards

measures shall be taken to ensure that building stable under design basis load conditions. where necessary, these measures shall also allow for maximum credible loads for which collapse limit state might be chosen as being applicable

any features of structure that have critical influence on its overall stability shall be identified and included in design, including all members that provide restraint to critical members in compression. structure shall provide continuous load paths transferring actions from their point of application to ground (see figure f.2)

f 13 dubai building code part f structure 02 01 03 04 15 14 key 01 diaphragm 02 collector 03 structural (shear) wall 04 basement wall 05 shear transfer in diaphragm 06 transfer slab/diaphragm 07 distributor 08 below grade soil pressure 09 inclined column 10 moment resisting frame 11 out-of-plane wind pressure or inertial loads 12 gravity loads 13 structural (shear) wall 14 in-plane inertial loads 15 collector 16 thrust 13 12 11 10 09 16 08 05 06 07 figure f.2 typical actions and structural system ( aci. modified figure based on figure r12.1.1, aci 318-19, pg.176) f 14 dubai building code part f structure f.5.5 robustness against disproportionate collapse measures shall be taken to ensure that building robust and resistant to disproportionate collapse under specified load conditions. one of following approaches shall be used

a) direct design explicit consideration of resistance to progressive collapse during design process through either 1) tie forces method (see figure f.3) 2) alternate path method or 3) enhanced local resistance method
further details on direct design methods can be found in ufc 4-023-03 ref. f.1

b) indirect design implicit consideration of resistance to progressive collapse during design process through provision of minimum levels of strength, continuity, and ductility. further details on indirect design method can be found in appendix c of asce/sei 7-16. it recommended that direct design approach undertaken in accordance with ufc 4-023- 03 ref. f.1, as illustrated in table f.2. risk category (per table 1.5-1 of asce/sei 7-16) design requirement ii iii iv no specific requirements
indirect design approach
or direct design option 1 tie forces for entire structure and enhanced local resistance for corner and penultimate columns or walls on first storey
or direct design option 2 alternate path for specified column and wall removal locations
ap for specified column and wall removal locations and enhanced local resistance for all perimeter first storey columns or walls
tie forces and alternate path for specified column and wall removal locations and enhanced local resistance for all perimeter first storey columns or walls

table f.2 risk category and design requirements f 15 dubai building code part f structure f.5.6 durability general f.5.6.1 all elements shall be designed with appropriate detailing and material specifications to achieve specified design life, considering environment of project. concrete structures f.5.6.2 recommendations of bs 8500-1 shall be implemented in design and specifications of concrete structures. concrete mixes shall conform to minimum requirements listed under f.11. project-specific durability design report shall be provided when one of following conditions met a) structures with designated design life of more than 50 years service life modelling may be used at preliminary design stage as part of durability study. additional protection measures should be included in durability design report. appropriate provision shall also be made to enable inspection and maintenance to be carried out

table f.2 risk category and design requirements f 15 dubai building code part f structure f.5.6 durability general f.5.6.1 all elements shall be designed with appropriate detailing and material specifications to achieve specified design life, considering environment of project. concrete structures f.5.6.2 recommendations of bs 8500-1 shall be implemented in design and specifications of concrete structures. concrete mixes shall conform to minimum requirements listed under f.11. project-specific durability design report shall be provided when one of following conditions met a) structures with designated design life of more than 50 years service life modelling may be used at preliminary design stage as part of durability study. additional protection measures should be included in durability design report. appropriate provision shall also be made to enable inspection and maintenance to be carried out

steelwork structures f.5.6.3 engineer shall provide steelwork material specifications, stating steel grades and protective paint systems which durable and compatible with climate of dubai. protective paint coatings for steelwork shall be specified in accordance with bs en 12944 as minimum, with additional requirements to address susceptibility of protective coatings to ultra violet degradation. b) structures exposed to design sulphate class ds-4 or greater (as defined in table a.2 of bs 8500 12015) material specifications shall also state inspection and maintenance requirements with definition of expected coating life. c) structures exposed to design chlorides class xd-3 (as defined in table a.2 of bs 8500-12015) and d) structures exposed to design chlorides (from sea water) class xs-2 or greater (as defined in table a.2 of bs 8500-12015)

figure f.3 tie forces method for disproportionate collapse key peripheral ties vertical ties longitudinal ties f 16 dubai building code part f structure f.6 materials f.5.7 fire resistance f.6.1 general construction type and fire resistance rating of structural elements shall be determined based on type of building, its height/size and occupancy in accordance with section 2, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. f.2. this section provides minimum requirements for design and construction of building and structural components using reinforced concrete, post-tensioned (pt) concrete, precast concrete, steel and masonry. all proposed fire protection products and systems shall be tested and certified by accredited laboratories and approved by dubai civil defence (dcd)

fire resistance rating of main structural elements shall be taken into account in structural design and clearly stated in structural drawings. fire resistance of concrete and masonry elements shall conform to requirements of aci 216.1. fire resistance of steel structures shall conform to requirements of aisc design guide 19 ref. f.14

for other materials, such as aluminium, timber, gypsum board, glass and plastic, structural requirements stated under ch. 23 to ch. 26 of ibc ref. f.3 shall be followed. these materials shall only be used where also permitted by sections 2, 4, 6 and 7, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. f.2
specification of all constituent materials of structural system shall be compatible with specified codes and clearly detailed in design documentation
design shall take into account how strength, stiffness and durability of all materials changes over time

f.5.8 sustainability sustainability standards shall be observed when designing structure, during buildings lifecycle. design of permanent works, together with construction operations shall fulfil resource efficiency standards in terms of materials. concrete mixes shall conform to f.11. f.6.2 structural concrete design basis f.6.2.1 design of concrete for structural purposes, including plain concrete and concrete containing non-prestressed reinforcement, prestressed reinforcement or both, shall conform to requirements of aci 318-19 including standards referenced therein. concrete strength f.6.2.2 concrete used for structural elements shall have compressive strength not less than fcu = 35 n/mm2 and fc = 28 n/mm2

f.5.8 sustainability sustainability standards shall be observed when designing structure, during buildings lifecycle. design of permanent works, together with construction operations shall fulfil resource efficiency standards in terms of materials. concrete mixes shall conform to f.11. f.6.2 structural concrete design basis f.6.2.1 design of concrete for structural purposes, including plain concrete and concrete containing non-prestressed reinforcement, prestressed reinforcement or both, shall conform to requirements of aci 318-19 including standards referenced therein. concrete strength f.6.2.2 concrete used for structural elements shall have compressive strength not less than fcu = 35 n/mm2 and fc = 28 n/mm2

concrete for blinding and screeds shall have compressive strength not less than fcu = 20 n/mm2. all concrete in contact with ground shall be designed for aggressiveness of contact soil (refer to f.5.6.2)

f 17 dubai building code part f structure concrete mixes f.6.2.3 design and technical specification of concrete mixes shall conform to either table f.3 or alternative dubai sustainable concrete baseline (dscb) described in f.11

table f.3 sets minimum requirements for cement/binder content, type of cement/binder, and maximum water/cement (w/c) ratio for different grades of concrete used in substructures and superstructures. for any mix design to be used as alternative to those in table f.3, concrete mix shall be submitted to dubai municipality (dm) for approval. mixes in table f.3 and f.11 have developed by dm to account for conditions of dubai and durability requirements stipulated under bs en 206 and bs 8500-1. dm mixes provide minimum durability specifications for concrete structures. engineer shall modify durability specification based on structural design (service life, exposure conditions, concrete grade, concrete cover, etc.)

note following notes applicable to both (table f.3 and f.11) mix design approaches. a) silica fume may be added to concrete mixes to achieve required strength and/or durability requirements of any project
b) testing of concrete specimens at 56 days for compressive strength may be allowed for mixes with high percentages of cement replacements
c) temporary works (such as shoring, shotcrete, etc.) do not need to conform to this specification
d) screed not providing structural protection does not need to conform to this specification

e) use of high percentage of ground granulated blast-furnace slag (ggbs) in concrete mixes may cause difficulties in handling concrete (pumping, placing, finishing, etc.). it therefore recommended to specify and accept higher slumps for such mixes in order to avoid any addition of water to concrete mix on construction site

f) minimum recommended clear concrete cover to reinforcement for substructures 50 mm/75 mm (50 mm for concrete cast against blinding 75 mm for concrete cast directly against soil) and 30 mm for superstructures. final concrete cover shall be specified by engineer based on structural and durability considerations of building

table f.3 green concrete combinations f 19 modulus of elasticity f.6.2.4 modulus of elasticity of concrete (ec) shall be calculated in accordance with 19.2.2.1 of aci 318-19. for high strength concrete (fc > 55 n/mm2), engineer shall specify range of acceptable ec values at specified test age in accordance with aci 318-19. assumed values should be verified by testing on-site during construction. in absence of testing, engineer shall adopt equation 6-1 of aci 363r-10. values adopted in design shall be stated by engineer in design drawings

table f.3 green concrete combinations f 19 modulus of elasticity f.6.2.4 modulus of elasticity of concrete (ec) shall be calculated in accordance with 19.2.2.1 of aci 318-19. for high strength concrete (fc > 55 n/mm2), engineer shall specify range of acceptable ec values at specified test age in accordance with aci 318-19. assumed values should be verified by testing on-site during construction. in absence of testing, engineer shall adopt equation 6-1 of aci 363r-10. values adopted in design shall be stated by engineer in design drawings
section properties f.6.2.5 moment of inertia and cross-sectional areas for linear elastic first order analysis shall be defined in accordance with 6.6.3 of aci 318-19
for non-linear response history analysis, cracked section properties shall be defined in accordance with appendix of aci 318-19

for thermal non-elastic modelling, effective cracked cross-sectional area of axial members under tension should be calculated by engineer. in case of members with direct tension only, reference should be made to aci 224.2r-92 for axial stiffness calculations. detailing of reinforcement f.6.2.6 detailing of reinforcement shall be in accordance with aci 318-19 ch.25 and aci 315r

a) if structural analysis assumes that slab provides torsion resistance (twisting moments) in plane, this moment shall be included in reinforcement design for slab and its connections to resisting structures. otherwise, slab shall be taken as non-torsion element and no torsional stiffness shall be included in analysis

b) for slabs with pre-compression in excess of 2.0 n/mm2 (as average over area away from concentrations) or dimension in one direction more than 50 m, or more than one point of stiff restraint, following shall be taken into account 1) elastic shortening due to prestressing force 2) creep (including shortening due to prestress force) and 3) drying shrinkage of concrete

c) for heavily stressed members (such as transfer beams) where pre- compression exceeds 3.0 n/mm2, engineer shall account for consequence of shortening of member. this shall include effect of shortening on connections and design of supporting elements (typically columns and walls)

d) minimum thickness of slabs depends on type of pt concrete system adopted. it recommended to keep minimum slab thickness of 200 mm with localized thickness reduction, provided that pt systems can be accommodated
e) designer shall verify that proposed pt system fits within slab depth considering bursting reinforcement with appropriate concrete cover
f) for two-ways slabs with varying cross sections along slab span, tendons shall provide effective pre-compression of 0.9 n/mm2 in accordance with aci 318-19
concrete strengths lower than fcu = 40 n/mm2 may only be used when it can be demonstrated that lower strength suitable and accepted by authority, making sure effects of creep and shrinkage included
concrete strengths lower than fcu = 40 n/mm2 may only be used when it can be demonstrated that lower strength suitable and accepted by authority, making sure effects of creep and shrinkage included
f.6.3.4 concrete mix designs shall be in accordance with f.6.2.3

concrete mixes tendons f.6.3.5 only tendons with nominal tensile strength of 1,860 mpa and approved by dubai central laboratory shall be used. jacking force shall not exceed 80% of tendons tensile strength

concrete mixes tendons f.6.3.5 only tendons with nominal tensile strength of 1,860 mpa and approved by dubai central laboratory shall be used. jacking force shall not exceed 80% of tendons tensile strength

ducts f.6.3.6 ducts for grouted multiple wire, multiple strand, or multiple bar tendons shall have minimum internal cross-sectional area of two times cross-sectional area of post-tensioning steel. wall thickness of metal ducts shall not be less than 0.4 mm. profile of tendons shall conform to following tolerance levels a) vertical tolerance 5 mm and b) horizontal tolerance 100 mm

ducts f.6.3.6 ducts for grouted multiple wire, multiple strand, or multiple bar tendons shall have minimum internal cross-sectional area of two times cross-sectional area of post-tensioning steel. wall thickness of metal ducts shall not be less than 0.4 mm. profile of tendons shall conform to following tolerance levels a) vertical tolerance 5 mm and b) horizontal tolerance 100 mm

ducts f.6.3.6 ducts for grouted multiple wire, multiple strand, or multiple bar tendons shall have minimum internal cross-sectional area of two times cross-sectional area of post-tensioning steel. wall thickness of metal ducts shall not be less than 0.4 mm. profile of tendons shall conform to following tolerance levels a) vertical tolerance 5 mm and b) horizontal tolerance 100 mm
grout f.6.3.7 grouts shall have strength not less than strength of concrete at 28 days and shall contain additives to compensate for and/or minimize shrinkage
grout f.6.3.7 grouts shall have strength not less than strength of concrete at 28 days and shall contain additives to compensate for and/or minimize shrinkage

f 21 dubai building code part f structure permissible stresses in post-tensioning steel f.6.3.8 maximum jacking stress for post-tension elements shall be lesser of 0.80 fpu, or maximum jacking stress recommended by system supplier
06 03 01 01 immediately after force transfer, tendons shall have maximum stress of 0.70 fpu at anchorages, points and couplers

headings: minimum bonded reinforcement for post-tensioned concrete
Description: h h minimum bonded reinforcement for post-tensioned concrete f.6.3.9 in addition to requirements of aci 318-19, minimum area of bonded un- tensioned reinforcement shall be provided in all flexural members, as follows. a) negative moment areas at column supports in flat slabs

1) minimum area of top un-tensioned reinforcement as in each direction shall be computed by as = 0.00075 acf where acf gross cross-sectional area of concrete slab-beam strips in each of two orthogonal equivalent frames intersecting at column, in two-way slab
2) this reinforcement shall be distributed across effective width, extending 1.5 h beyond opposite faces of supporting column, where h slab thickness (see figure f.5)
3) spacing of un-tensioned reinforcement shall not exceed 350 mm centres
4) minimum length of un-tensioned reinforcement in negative moment areas shall extend one-fifth clear span, on each side of support
5) non-tensioned reinforcement shall only consist of fully bonded deformed bars

1) minimum thermal and shrinkage 1) un-tensioned reinforcement shall be provided reinforcement shall be in accordance with aci 318-19. for slab thicknesses of 200 mm or less, minimum reinforcement shall be provided at bottom layer. for thicker slabs, minimum reinforcement can be split between top and bottom layers. 2) bottom reinforcement mesh shall run through column location. c) integrity reinforcement. at member supports, at least one tendon comprising at least two strands shall pass through columns or walls. following shall be observed
1) if tendon not passing through columns or walls, then minimum amount of bottom un-tensioned reinforcement shall be provided for structural integrity

2) minimum bottom un-tensioned reinforcement shall be lower of either 150% of minimum calculated flexural reinforcement, or (2.1 bw h/fy ) where bw width of column face through which reinforcement passes
3) un-tensioned reinforcement bars passing through column shall extend beyond column or shear cap face by minimum distance equal to or greater than bar development length

f 23 in accordance with aci 318-19 to resist spalling and longitudinal edge tension forces induced by anchorage devices. quantity shall be calculated for anchorage arrangement. effects of abrupt changes in section and stressing sequence shall also be included. 2) area of tension reinforcement (and/or prestressed tendons) provided parallel to slab edge shall resist bending moments from ultimate vertical loads calculated for continuous slab, spanning la. this reinforcement shall be evenly distributed across width equal to 0.7 la and shall be continuous along edge (see figure f.6)

3) area of reinforcement placed perpendicular to slab edge shall be greater of thermal and shrinkage minimum reinforcement, or quarter of reinforcement provided parallel to edge. it shall be placed evenly between anchorages and extend greater of la or 0.7 la plus full anchorage length into slab

02 hairpin 02 01 03 05 06 figure f.9 tendon placement at opening section a-a f 26 dubai building code part f structure reinforcement and strands f.6.4.4 reinforcement and prestressed strands shall conform to requirements stated under section 1 of pci design handbook ref. f.12. precast floor slabs acting compositely with topping concrete shall have reinforcement in topping not less than 8 at 200 mm mesh. in order to allow for composite action of precast slab and concrete topping, engineer shall specify that any conduits and pipes shall be installed within screed rather than within structural topping. where above conditions not met, composite action shall not be considered in design. contractor shall ensure that surface of precast slab prepared and cleaned before concrete topping cast on-site. integrity ties shall be provided in accordance with 16.2 of aci 318-19 (see figure f.12). 02 03 02 04 03 01 04 05 figure f.12 ( aci. modified figure based on figure r16.2.5, aci 318-19, pg. 221) integrity ties in large precast panel structures key 01 vertical ties 02 longitudinal ties 03 transverse ties 04 perimeter transverse ties 05 perimeter longitudinal ties f.6.4 precast concrete design basis f.6.4.1 precast concrete elements, including those that normally reinforced and/or prestressed, shall be designed and specified in accordance with this subsection, supplemented by requirements given in aci 318-19 and precast/prestressed concrete institute (pci) design handbook ref. f.12
concrete f.6.4.2 reinforcement and prestressed strands shall conform to requirements stated under section 1 of pci design handbook ref. f.12

concrete used for precast structural elements shall have compressive strength of not less than fcu = 40 n/mm2 measured at 28 days. lower strength may only be used if its suitability can be demonstrated and it accepted by authority

minimum transfer strength (when prestress force transferred to concrete) shall be 25 n/mm2, unless adequacy of lower strength can be demonstrated in design, making sure effects of creep and shrinkage included
concrete mixes f.6.4.3 concrete mix designs shall be in accordance with f.6.2.3

f 27 dubai building code part f structure storage, transportation, handling and erection f.6.4.5 precast and prestressed elements often require separate analysis of loading scenarios during storage transportation and handling. design under these conditions shall be undertaken in accordance with section 5 of pci design handbook ref. f.12. in particular, following requirements shall be included during design of temporary conditions

a) precast units shall be designed to resist all stresses induced by storage, handling, transport and erection, without permanent deformation. they shall be braced for handling and transportation when necessary
b) each element shall be stable after erection and resist wind, accidental impact and loads that might be imposed due to other construction operations
c) surfaces shall remain free of discernible cracks by limiting elastic flexural tension to modulus of rupture, modified by suitable safety factor
d) arrangement of temporary bracing shall not interfere with adjacent erection and other construction processes. bracing shall be maintained until permanent connections completed
e) method used for transporting precast concrete products shall be included in structural design including size and weight limitations and dynamic effects imposed by road conditions

f) temporary handling load conditions responsibility of contractor. however, for structures where construction-stage loads might be particularly onerous and/or govern, engineer shall include implications of one or more viable construction procedures on precast concrete component design. g) engineer shall communicate any assumptions they make for construction to contractor as part of submission. this particularly important when combining precast concrete with steelwork and/or in-situ concrete

f 28 connections f.6.4.6 typical connections for precast elements shall be designed in accordance with section 6 of pci design handbook ref. f.12 and ch. 16 of aci 318-19 (see figure f.13 for typical bearing support)

01 02 03 04 05 06 figure f.13 typical bearing support ( aci. modified figure based on figure r16.2.6, aci 318-19, pg. 222) key 01 support 02 precast member 03 unreinforced edge 04 bearing length 05 25 mm minimum and not less than size of chamfer 06 clear span/180  55 mm (slabs) clear span/180  80 mm (beams) dubai building code part f structure in particular, following requirements shall be included during design of permanent and temporary conditions. a) connections shall have adequate strength to transfer forces to which they subjected during their lifetime

01 02 03 04 05 06 figure f.13 typical bearing support ( aci. modified figure based on figure r16.2.6, aci 318-19, pg. 222) key 01 support 02 precast member 03 unreinforced edge 04 bearing length 05 25 mm minimum and not less than size of chamfer 06 clear span/180  55 mm (slabs) clear span/180  80 mm (beams) dubai building code part f structure in particular, following requirements shall be included during design of permanent and temporary conditions. a) connections shall have adequate strength to transfer forces to which they subjected during their lifetime
b) stresses across connections caused by restraint of creep, shrinkage and temperature change (volume change) shall be included in design
c) connections shall meet durability and fire resistance requirements of connecting elements
d) connections shall be checked for all load scenarios including horizontal forces arising from earthquake and wind events
e) precast members shall have positive connections (ties) to supporting structures unless seating lengths greater than maximum expected movements
precast staircase f.6.4.7 precast staircases may be included in buildings if they not part of lateral load resisting structural frame

design of precast stairs shall be in accordance with aci 318-19 and pci handbook ref. f.12. they shall be designed in such way that they can be safely incorporated into structure. additional design recommendations provided in f.12

f.6.5 structural steel design basis f.6.5.1 design of structural steel shall be in accordance with aisc 360 including codes and standards referenced therein. seismic design shall follow aisc 341. compatible materials shall be specified in accordance with standards set by astm international (astm). welding shall be specified in accordance with standards set by american welding society (aws)

f.6.5 structural steel design basis f.6.5.1 design of structural steel shall be in accordance with aisc 360 including codes and standards referenced therein. seismic design shall follow aisc 341. compatible materials shall be specified in accordance with standards set by astm international (astm). welding shall be specified in accordance with standards set by american welding society (aws)

steel grades f.6.5.2 table f.5 and table f.6 summarize steel grade that shall be adopted in design. steel sections can be selected in accordance with either american or british specifications. engineer responsible for ensuring compatibility of material specification with design basis, including detailing requirements and ductility in general

f.6.5.4.3 post-installed anchors post-installed anchors into reinforced concrete elements may be used for purpose of supporting steelwork where it impractical to install cast-in anchors
f.6.5.4.3 post-installed anchors post-installed anchors into reinforced concrete elements may be used for purpose of supporting steelwork where it impractical to install cast-in anchors
post-installed anchors shall be designed based on provisions of aci 318-19, with consideration for all conceivable failure mechanisms (see figure f.14)

f 31 n n n n 01 02 03 n n n n n n n n 04 05 06 07 v v 08 09 (a) tensile loading v vv v v 10 (b) shear loading v v key 01 steel failure 02 pullout 03 concrete breakout 04 concrete splitting 05 side-face blowout 06 bond failure  single 07 bond failure  group 08 steel failure preceded by concrete spall 09 concrete pryout for anchors far from free edge 10 concrete breakout figure f.14 failure modes for anchors ( aci. modified figure based on figure r17.5.1.2, aci 318-19, pg. 238) dubai building code part f structure f.6.6 masonry design basis f.6.6.1 design of load-bearing masonry walls shall be in accordance with tms 402/602 including codes and standards referenced therein. design of non-load-bearing masonry walls which not part of main structural frame, shall be in accordance with either tms 402/602 or bs en 1996-1, bs en 1996-2 and bs en 1996-3

wall panels f.6.6.2 wall panels shall be constructed with suitable strength bricks or concrete blocks, arranged in interconnected manner, typically using cement mortar. wall panel dimensions between movement joints and/or lateral supporting structures shall not exceed capacity of wall panel. wall panels shall be tied to all vertical and horizontal supporting structures. supporting structures shall have sufficient strength and stiffness to provide support required by wall panel without incurring movement that would cause distress

wall panels f.6.6.2 wall panels shall be constructed with suitable strength bricks or concrete blocks, arranged in interconnected manner, typically using cement mortar. wall panel dimensions between movement joints and/or lateral supporting structures shall not exceed capacity of wall panel. wall panels shall be tied to all vertical and horizontal supporting structures. supporting structures shall have sufficient strength and stiffness to provide support required by wall panel without incurring movement that would cause distress

any cuts/chases into wall panels shall be included in calculations by engineer. brick and block strengths f.6.6.3 solid bricks and blocks for load-bearing wall panels shall have compressive strength of not less than 9 n/mm2. bricks and blocks (including hollow blocks) in non-load bearing walls shall have compressive strength of not less than 6 n/mm2

any cuts/chases into wall panels shall be included in calculations by engineer. brick and block strengths f.6.6.3 solid bricks and blocks for load-bearing wall panels shall have compressive strength of not less than 9 n/mm2. bricks and blocks (including hollow blocks) in non-load bearing walls shall have compressive strength of not less than 6 n/mm2

any cuts/chases into wall panels shall be included in calculations by engineer. brick and block strengths f.6.6.3 solid bricks and blocks for load-bearing wall panels shall have compressive strength of not less than 9 n/mm2. bricks and blocks (including hollow blocks) in non-load bearing walls shall have compressive strength of not less than 6 n/mm2

f 32 dubai building code part f structure f.7 loads f.7.1 general loads shall be defined in accordance with asce/sei 7-16 and this section. f.7.2 load combinations loads shall be factored and combined in accordance with ch. 2 of asce/sei 7-16

f 32 dubai building code part f structure f.7 loads f.7.1 general loads shall be defined in accordance with asce/sei 7-16 and this section. f.7.2 load combinations loads shall be factored and combined in accordance with ch. 2 of asce/sei 7-16
results from compatible linear analyses of load cases acting individually may be combined and summed algebraically

f.7.3 dead loads dead loads shall be calculated using densities and volumes of materials making up construction. default densities of common materials scheduled in table f.7. note more refined densities and densities of other materials can be sourced from referenced codes and standards, material data sheets, or obtained via testing. engineer responsible for ensuring densities assumed in design align with those of specified construction materials

f 33 f.7.4 superimposed dead loads engineer responsible for determining superimposed dead loads for components not included as either live or dead loads (including anticipated internal partitions, floor and ceiling finishes, facades and external cladding). loads shall be defined as concentrated point loads, uniform loads on plan, and/or uniform loads on elevation, as appropriate. following minimum load allowances (defined as average uniform loads on plan) shall be adopted for purpose of evaluating maximum load effect a) internal drywall partitions 0.75 kn/m2 b) suspended services with ceiling finishes 0.50 kn/m2 and c) suspended services without ceiling finishes 0.30 kn/m2

f 33 f.7.4 superimposed dead loads engineer responsible for determining superimposed dead loads for components not included as either live or dead loads (including anticipated internal partitions, floor and ceiling finishes, facades and external cladding). loads shall be defined as concentrated point loads, uniform loads on plan, and/or uniform loads on elevation, as appropriate. following minimum load allowances (defined as average uniform loads on plan) shall be adopted for purpose of evaluating maximum load effect a) internal drywall partitions 0.75 kn/m2 b) suspended services with ceiling finishes 0.50 kn/m2 and c) suspended services without ceiling finishes 0.30 kn/m2

when minimum load effect critical (e.g. buoyancy check), appropriate minimum load criterion shall be assumed. minimum load for features that easy or likely to be removed should be zero (0.0 kn/m2). engineer shall provide detailed calculations supporting superimposed dead load assumptions. if supporting calculations not provided, vertical load listed in table f.8 shall be included for partition assumptions. type of wall superimposed dead load applied vertically, including finishes (kn/m2) lightweight block wall normal weight block wall drywall 4.5 5.5 4.0 table f.8 minimum superimposed dead load loading plan drawings showing load provision should be submitted for approval. design assumptions shall be validated against systems installed. any late amendments and/or retrospective changes shall not be made without new approval

dubai building code part f structure f.7.5 live loads minimum uniform live loads shall not be less than those listed in ch. 4 of asce/sei 7-16. following requirements shall also be applied. a) concentrated live load shall be evaluated for objects creating significant point loads, including machinery, vehicles and storage racks. b) minimum live load for garage and car parking 3.5 kn/m2 which should be validated based on type of vehicles accessing facility. engineer shall also take into account load imposed by emergency vehicles along designated route. c) live load for drained areas of floor surrounding swimming pool 2 kn/m2. pool tanks and other areas susceptible to flooding to be designed for load not less than maximum retained head of water
d) engineer shall design supporting structure to withstand loading imposed by mechanical, electrical and plumbing (mep) equipment in designated areas and along proposed equipment access route

f.7.6 soil loads and hydrostatic pressure minimum soil and hydrostatic pressure loads shall not be less than those listed in table f.9. lower values shall not be used without project-specific justification. description minimum load (kn/m3) soil for planters (saturated) compacted soil for trafficable areas water brackish water table f.9 material densities 19 22 10 10.3 in addition to geotechnical requirements specified in f.9, engineer shall include following in design of permanent structures. a) all foundation elements and retaining walls shall be designed following recommendations given in geotechnical interpretive report (gir). b) design water table shall be established in gir considering fluctuation of water table level during design life of structure. in particular, effect of dewatering in neighbouring areas, seasonal variation of water table, future developments (such as canal, water bodies, landscaping and similar) and potential impact of climate change shall be included in definition of design groundwater level. design groundwater level and its fluctuations shall be stated by engineer in design drawings and agreed with authorities. c) in any case, minimum water table level shall be assumed as follows

f.7.6 soil loads and hydrostatic pressure minimum soil and hydrostatic pressure loads shall not be less than those listed in table f.9. lower values shall not be used without project-specific justification. description minimum load (kn/m3) soil for planters (saturated) compacted soil for trafficable areas water brackish water table f.9 material densities 19 22 10 10.3 in addition to geotechnical requirements specified in f.9, engineer shall include following in design of permanent structures. a) all foundation elements and retaining walls shall be designed following recommendations given in geotechnical interpretive report (gir). b) design water table shall be established in gir considering fluctuation of water table level during design life of structure. in particular, effect of dewatering in neighbouring areas, seasonal variation of water table, future developments (such as canal, water bodies, landscaping and similar) and potential impact of climate change shall be included in definition of design groundwater level. design groundwater level and its fluctuations shall be stated by engineer in design drawings and agreed with authorities. c) in any case, minimum water table level shall be assumed as follows
1) in proximity to bodies of water 0.00 dubai municipality datum (dmd) plus 1.0 for seasonal and tidal variations
2) away from bodies of water actual water table level with dewatering taken into account, as defined in gir, plus 1.0 for seasonal and tidal variations

d) for structures below water table, hydrostatic uplift and lateral pressures shall be checked in accordance with section 10 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated united kingdom national annex (uk na). any dewatering system, whether used for construction or throughout design life, temporary unless system can be demonstrated to be reliable throughout design life. e) where construction of project staged, or in case of construction on adjacent plot, any possibility of unbalanced lateral soil load shall be included

f) any retaining wall assumed to be subjected to lateral pressure during construction shall be designed according to possible surcharge and hydrostatic loading. lateral soil pressure arising from compacted soil placement shall be included where this exceeds at rest or passive pressure (as relevant)

f 34 dubai building code part f structure g) bracing conditions of retaining structure and construction sequence shall be f.7.10 self-straining forces carefully captured in analysis and design. h) uplift due to heave shall also be included for both permanent and temporary conditions whenever applicable. f.7.7 construction load minimum design load requirements during construction of buildings shall be defined in accordance with asce 37

f 34 dubai building code part f structure g) bracing conditions of retaining structure and construction sequence shall be f.7.10 self-straining forces carefully captured in analysis and design. h) uplift due to heave shall also be included for both permanent and temporary conditions whenever applicable. f.7.7 construction load minimum design load requirements during construction of buildings shall be defined in accordance with asce 37
construction-stage loads, including locked in stresses arising from construction sequence and affecting overall behaviour of structure, shall be included by engineer

engineer shall clearly state construction load assumptions on detailed design drawings and verify that structural system can withstand these loads during all stages of construction. any departure from engineers assumptions by contractors construction sequence shall be assessed

f.7.8 accidental impact load structural elements shall be designed to resist accidental impact loading conditions specified under section 4.6 of asce/sei 7-16. secondary protection system should be provided to all primary structural members to avoid accidental impact load

f.7.9 helipad and heliport loads minimum live load allowance for helipad and heliports shall be in accordance with section 4.11 of asce/sei 7-16. structures shall be designed to resist any self-straining forces arising from contraction or expansion of structural elements. such volume changes can result from shrinkage, creep and/or moisture change in component materials, including soil. it might occur at any stage in structures lifecycle. use of details to alleviate self-straining forces may be used when practical and when not in violation of any assumed load paths. such details, where permanent, shall be durable and have provision for maintenance. f.7.11 thermally induced forces thermally induced forces shall be derived considering structural restraints, and changes in temperature of structural members arising across construction/ operational phases, seasonal and daily variations

f.7.9 helipad and heliport loads minimum live load allowance for helipad and heliports shall be in accordance with section 4.11 of asce/sei 7-16. structures shall be designed to resist any self-straining forces arising from contraction or expansion of structural elements. such volume changes can result from shrinkage, creep and/or moisture change in component materials, including soil. it might occur at any stage in structures lifecycle. use of details to alleviate self-straining forces may be used when practical and when not in violation of any assumed load paths. such details, where permanent, shall be durable and have provision for maintenance. f.7.11 thermally induced forces thermally induced forces shall be derived considering structural restraints, and changes in temperature of structural members arising across construction/ operational phases, seasonal and daily variations

for effects on covered concrete structural members, mean monthly temperatures should be used to establish appropriate temperature range. default thermal range of 20 c may be used for exposed elements above ground level and 15 c for non-exposed elements (i.e. basement). gradient thermal analysis (non-uniform) shall be applied for permanently exposed slabs like roofs and exposed last podium floors

for steel structural members and structural members exposed to solar radiation, range equivalent to maximum temperature swing appropriate. default thermal range of 25 c may be used for protected steel elements. for exposed steelwork, this can arise from hourly maxima and minima. engineer shall assess thermal range and assess thermally induced forces on case by case basis considering construction stages, exposure and when steel structure locked in final configuration. f 35 dubai building code part f structure 50 40 note for further guidance, mean monthly temperatures and relative humidity values for specific sites available from national centre for meteorology and seismology website (www.ncms.ae/) ref. f.4. figure f.15 and figure f.16 show air temperature data and relative humidity data, respectively, from national centre for meteorology and seismology

for steel structural members and structural members exposed to solar radiation, range equivalent to maximum temperature swing appropriate. default thermal range of 25 c may be used for protected steel elements. for exposed steelwork, this can arise from hourly maxima and minima. engineer shall assess thermal range and assess thermally induced forces on case by case basis considering construction stages, exposure and when steel structure locked in final configuration. f 35 dubai building code part f structure 50 40 note for further guidance, mean monthly temperatures and relative humidity values for specific sites available from national centre for meteorology and seismology website (www.ncms.ae/) ref. f.4. figure f.15 and figure f.16 show air temperature data and relative humidity data, respectively, from national centre for meteorology and seismology

building inter-storey shear shall be calculated using 10-year return (mri) wind pressures and floor to floor height (hs)
these two calculations shall meet limits given in table f.11

description overall displacement inter-storey drift table f.11 displacement limits deflection limit h/500 between hs/400 and hs/600 purpose of overall displacement calculation to control displacements of building which might cause overstress or fatigue damage or loss of effectiveness to cladding, internal partitions or other non-structural components of buildings
inter-storey displacement may be estimated from inter-storey drift or calculated to include other deformations of structure

a) taller than 120 b) height of building greater than five times its average width normal to wind direction over top of building (i.e. aspect ratio, h/bav > 5) c) of unusual shape or surroundings not covered by wind loading provisions of asce/sei 7-16 or other reliable published data, and which cannot be designed safely with conservative wind loads or d) any other building where designer wishes to better establish wind behaviour
wind tunnel testing shall follow wind tunnel procedure described in ch. 31 of asce/sei 7-16
