f.8.2 strength buildings, other structures, and parts thereof, shall be designed and constructed to support safely factored loads in load combinations defined in this part without exceeding appropriate strength limits states for construction material. general f.8.3.1 deflection limits shall be adopted that enable functional requirements to be maintained. limits may be governed by requirements of internal and/or external furniture, finishes, fixtures and fittings

f.8.2 strength buildings, other structures, and parts thereof, shall be designed and constructed to support safely factored loads in load combinations defined in this part without exceeding appropriate strength limits states for construction material. general f.8.3.1 deflection limits shall be adopted that enable functional requirements to be maintained. limits may be governed by requirements of internal and/or external furniture, finishes, fixtures and fittings

f.8.2 strength buildings, other structures, and parts thereof, shall be designed and constructed to support safely factored loads in load combinations defined in this part without exceeding appropriate strength limits states for construction material. general f.8.3.1 deflection limits shall be adopted that enable functional requirements to be maintained. limits may be governed by requirements of internal and/or external furniture, finishes, fixtures and fittings

vertical and horizontal deflections shall be within limits specified in referenced design standards, as applicable, and project-specific requirements dictated by features such as cladding, crane girders, members supporting sensitive machinery, etc

when checking for deflections most adverse realistic combination and arrangement of serviceability loads shall be included. engineer shall verify that adopted deflection limits will enable functional performance of building to be maintained

concrete beam and slab deflection f.8.3.2 deflection limits for concrete slabs and beams shall be in accordance with section 24.2.2 of aci 318-19. value of incremental deflection (inc) shall not exceed 20 mm after installation of partitions and finishes and shall be calculated in accordance with aci 435r and aci 318-19. incremental deflection limits do not consider pre-cambering which may be used to reduce effect of total deflection as deemed necessary. when evaluating deflection of concrete structures, detrimental effects of cracking shall be included by modifying stiffness (ei) for areas which have exceeded allowable tensile stresses. modified ei shall be chosen based on extent of cracking under design load. default stiffness modifiers given in aci 318-19 may be followed for regular structures subject to approximately uniform loads

concrete beam and slab deflection f.8.3.2 deflection limits for concrete slabs and beams shall be in accordance with section 24.2.2 of aci 318-19. value of incremental deflection (inc) shall not exceed 20 mm after installation of partitions and finishes and shall be calculated in accordance with aci 435r and aci 318-19. incremental deflection limits do not consider pre-cambering which may be used to reduce effect of total deflection as deemed necessary. when evaluating deflection of concrete structures, detrimental effects of cracking shall be included by modifying stiffness (ei) for areas which have exceeded allowable tensile stresses. modified ei shall be chosen based on extent of cracking under design load. default stiffness modifiers given in aci 318-19 may be followed for regular structures subject to approximately uniform loads

f 44 dubai building code part f structure steelwork deflection limits f.8.3.3 deflection limits for steel structures shall conform to requirements stipulated in aisc 360 and aisc design guide 3 ref. f.17. crack widths shall be controlled in accordance with maximum crack widths defined in referenced codes and standards. engineer shall perform crack width calculation checks in accordance with aci 224r

f 44 dubai building code part f structure steelwork deflection limits f.8.3.3 deflection limits for steel structures shall conform to requirements stipulated in aisc 360 and aisc design guide 3 ref. f.17. crack widths shall be controlled in accordance with maximum crack widths defined in referenced codes and standards. engineer shall perform crack width calculation checks in accordance with aci 224r

f 44 dubai building code part f structure steelwork deflection limits f.8.3.3 deflection limits for steel structures shall conform to requirements stipulated in aisc 360 and aisc design guide 3 ref. f.17. crack widths shall be controlled in accordance with maximum crack widths defined in referenced codes and standards. engineer shall perform crack width calculation checks in accordance with aci 224r
following points should also be taken into account. a) for cantilever elements span length can be equal to double cantilever length
b) deflection limits do not take into account pre-cambering, which may be used to reduce effect total deflection as deemed necessary
post-tensioned concrete deflection control f.8.3.4 design for strength and serviceability requirements of members shall conform to aci 318-19
post-tensioned concrete deflection control f.8.3.4 design for strength and serviceability requirements of members shall conform to aci 318-19
post-tensioned concrete deflection control f.8.3.4 design for strength and serviceability requirements of members shall conform to aci 318-19
structural calculations shall verify that short- and long-term deflections, camber, vibration frequency and amplitude within permissible limits

it also recommended that basements and liquid retaining structures be classified in relation to degree of protection against leakage. appropriate limit to cracking depending on classification should be selected by engineer and owners representative, paying due regard to required function of structure, intrinsic durability requirements, and soil and water properties. ciria c766 ref. f.10 provides guidance on aesthetically acceptable crack widths. in absence of more specific requirements, following maximum crack width limits shall be adopted. 1) for sections of structure in contact with groundwater, crack width limits (wk) defined as function of ratio of hydrostatic pressure, hd to wall thickness of containing structure, hw
effects of cracking should be included by modifying stiffness ei properties as detailed in aci 318-19
i) for hd/hw <5, wk = 0.2 mm

ii) for hd/hw >35, wk = 0.05 mm. most pt concrete structures combine non-prestressed reinforced concrete, un-cracked pt and cracked pt sections. design method shall capture real behaviour of structural system by taking into consideration stiffnesses of cracked and un-cracked sections
f.8.4 crack control in concrete structure significance of cracking contained within three categories. a) cracks that lead to durability problems and consequently reduction in structural capacity
b) cracks that lead to loss of serviceability of structure (e.g. leakage of water or damage to finishes)
c) cracks that aesthetically unacceptable. f 45 2) for intermediate values of hd/hw, linear interpolation between 0.2 mm and 0.05 mm shall be used
3) section of structure not in contact with water, wk = 0.3 mm
4) structural elements (such as piles) under permanent tension loads, wk = 0.1 mm

above listed limits may be adopted providing that they do not contradict requirements of aci 224r and that proprietary waterproofing system provided for structural elements in contact with water in accordance with bs 8102. dubai building code part f structure f.8.5 crack control in restrained members engineer shall assess impact of following design aspects where structural walls, columns and piles provide significant restraint to shrinkage and temperature movements, reinforcement provisions should be verified against requirements stated under either aci 89-s15 (as in r24.4.2 of aci 318-19) or ciria c766 ref. f.10. f.8.6 drift and deformation of buildings 1) elastic shortening 2) creep and shrinkage of concrete structures where engineer shall refer to aci 209.2r and environmental conditions of dubai as discussed in f.7.11 3) 4) foundation settlements transfer elements, as discussed in f.8.10 and 5) construction stages. general f.8.6.1 engineer shall assess drift and deformation of building considering whole life of structure, including construction stages. analysis methodology and parameters adopted shall be discussed and agreed with authority. contractor shall review and validate differential vertical shortening analysis as it strongly dependent on construction stages sequence. contractor shall submit type of corrections to be implemented on-site to engineer and authority, for review and approval

f.8.6.4 drift and deformation due to wind shall be assessed in accordance with f.7.12.4

drift and deformation due to wind drift and deformation due to seismic f.8.6.5 movements of buildings due to earthquake effects shall conform to requirements stipulated under section 12.12 of asce/sei 7-16. drift due to permanent gravity load f.8.6.2 engineer and contractor shall verify that any deviation from plumbs for building and cores, under permanent gravity loads only, conforms to limits stated in section 7 of aci 117-10. if necessary, engineer shall specify any correction in setting out of building. this should be validated by contractor, taking into account sequence and method of construction. drift and deformation due to differential vertical shortening f.8.6.3 non-linear static construction sequence analysis should be performed to assess deflection and drift due to differential vertical shortening. at minimum, analysis shall be performed by engineer and/or contractor for following structures a) multi-storey buildings with different stresses between core and perimeter columns b) structures with asymmetrical structural plan layout and/or asymmetrical massing c) buildings with stepped setbacks d) buildings with outriggers

f 46 dubai building code part f structure f.8.7 movement joints and building separation f.8.8 vibration movement joints shall be provided, where necessary, to address requirements of expansion and/or deflection under load for above-ground structures. minimum separations between structure and any surrounding obstructions shall not be less than total maximum displacement (mt) as specified in section 12.12 of asce/sei 7-16 mt=((m1 )2+(m2 )2) eq. f.7 where m1 and m2 maximum inelastic response displacements of adjacent structures at their adjacent edges. m=(cd max)/ie eq. f.8 where cd deflection amplification factor in table 12.2-1 of asce/sei 7-16 max maximum deflection at location required by this section, determined by elastic analysis and ie importance factor determined in accordance with 11.5.1 of asce/sei 7-16

f 46 dubai building code part f structure f.8.7 movement joints and building separation f.8.8 vibration movement joints shall be provided, where necessary, to address requirements of expansion and/or deflection under load for above-ground structures. minimum separations between structure and any surrounding obstructions shall not be less than total maximum displacement (mt) as specified in section 12.12 of asce/sei 7-16 mt=((m1 )2+(m2 )2) eq. f.7 where m1 and m2 maximum inelastic response displacements of adjacent structures at their adjacent edges. m=(cd max)/ie eq. f.8 where cd deflection amplification factor in table 12.2-1 of asce/sei 7-16 max maximum deflection at location required by this section, determined by elastic analysis and ie importance factor determined in accordance with 11.5.1 of asce/sei 7-16

movement joints common source of water infiltration. structures should be designed below ground level, without movement joints to mitigate risk of water ingress. design for construction without permanent joints below ground level can be achieved by following recommendations provided in ciria c766 ref. f.10. steelwork f.8.8.1 natural frequency of steelwork floor systems for normal occupancy shall be evaluated in accordance with aisc design guide 11 ref. f.18 or sci p354 ref. f.19

movement joints common source of water infiltration. structures should be designed below ground level, without movement joints to mitigate risk of water ingress. design for construction without permanent joints below ground level can be achieved by following recommendations provided in ciria c766 ref. f.10. steelwork f.8.8.1 natural frequency of steelwork floor systems for normal occupancy shall be evaluated in accordance with aisc design guide 11 ref. f.18 or sci p354 ref. f.19

concrete f.8.8.2 cast-in-place floor systems designed in accordance with minimum thickness and deflection requirements of aci 318-19, have generally found to provide vibration performance suitable for human comfort under typical service conditions. however, there might be situations where serviceability conditions not satisfied. for example a) long spans and open floor plans b) floors with strict vibration performance requirements such as precision manufacturing and laboratory spaces and c) facilities subject to rhythmic loadings or vibrating mechanical equipment

concrete f.8.8.2 cast-in-place floor systems designed in accordance with minimum thickness and deflection requirements of aci 318-19, have generally found to provide vibration performance suitable for human comfort under typical service conditions. however, there might be situations where serviceability conditions not satisfied. for example a) long spans and open floor plans b) floors with strict vibration performance requirements such as precision manufacturing and laboratory spaces and c) facilities subject to rhythmic loadings or vibrating mechanical equipment
further guidance can be sought in atc design guide 1 ref. f.13

performance of pt concrete floors may follow recommendation of tr43, table 1 ref. f.11. for those pt concrete floors that do not follow these recommendations, their performance should be assessed in accordance with dynamic assessment method defined in tr43, appendix g ref. f.11. precast concrete structures shall be checked for vibration as detailed in section 9.7 of pci design handbook ref. f.12

performance of pt concrete floors may follow recommendation of tr43, table 1 ref. f.11. for those pt concrete floors that do not follow these recommendations, their performance should be assessed in accordance with dynamic assessment method defined in tr43, appendix g ref. f.11. precast concrete structures shall be checked for vibration as detailed in section 9.7 of pci design handbook ref. f.12

performance of pt concrete floors may follow recommendation of tr43, table 1 ref. f.11. for those pt concrete floors that do not follow these recommendations, their performance should be assessed in accordance with dynamic assessment method defined in tr43, appendix g ref. f.11. precast concrete structures shall be checked for vibration as detailed in section 9.7 of pci design handbook ref. f.12

f 47 dubai building code part f structure f.8.9 fatigue structural members that support vibrating machinery, vehicles or plant should be checked for fatigue resistance. stress changes due to normal fluctuations in wind loading do not need to be included in fatigue check. however, where aerodynamic instability can occur, account should be taken of wind-induced oscillations
where fatigue critical, design shall be checked in accordance with following codes a) appendix 3 of aisc 360 for steel and b) aci 318-19, aci 215r and aci 408.2r for concrete
all design details shall be fully defined, including clear specification of workmanship and quality assurance tests

f.8.10 transfer elements any beam, slab or truss structure used to redirect vertical gravity or lateral load path of upper stories to vertical structure of lower stories shall be treated as transfer element
following shall be included in design of transfer elements. a) transfer beams to be supported on at least two direct supports

b) eccentricity between column axis and longitudinal axis of beam not permitted. load transferred to planted column, transfer beam or slab shall not be less than loads calculated by manual method (tributary area)

c) any structural elements supporting planted/floating columns that might cause progressive collapse to be included as key element. reinforcement shall be detailed to facilitate robustness by means of provision of adequate peripheral, vertical and horizontal ties. d) entire length of supporting columns shall be included as critical length and stirrups shall be spaced closely to provide effective confinement for columns

e) structural systems elements of planted portions of structure shall have redundancy to provide alternative load paths in case of failure of any structural member, as discussed under f.5.5. f) any structural members or element that do not fall under purview of this part should be analysed and designed for various possible critical combinations. g) transfer structure shall be capable of withstanding reactions from any attached building components. reactions should be maximum values that might reasonably be transmitted considering strength of attached component and its connection
h) engineer shall check that deflections of structural members supported by transfer elements within deflection limits specified in f.8.3

f 48 dubai building code part f structure f.9 geotechnics f.9.1 introduction this section provides minimum geotechnical requirements that appropriate for geology, stratigraphy, geotechnical and groundwater conditions of dubai. major characteristic of ground in dubai its calcareous origin for both soils (e.g. calcareous sand) and soft calcareous rocks, with clay minerals of various expansion potential. groundwater saline with chlorites and sulphates that make very aggressive environment for concrete and reinforcement in ground
geotechnical requirements and design aspects discussed in f.9.3 to f.9.5

geotechnical design of buildings shall be based on requirements stated herein and referenced standards (see figure f.18). this section should be also read in conjunction with all other relevant sections of this part. additional studies expected for unusual constructions, and might result in variation from these requirements which would require approval from authority

any geotechnical design packages submitted and executed by geotechnical specialist contractor shall be reviewed and approved by engineer. all geotechnical design works and site investigation reports shall be submitted to authority for necessary approval
all geotechnical design and execution packages shall be undertaken by qualified geotechnical civil engineer

dubai building code part f structure f.9.2 standards decision to develop site and carry out site investigation geotechnical site investigations and geotechnical works shall be designed to meet or exceed minimum requirements of codes and standards listed in f.3

dubai building code part f structure f.9.2 standards decision to develop site and carry out site investigation geotechnical site investigations and geotechnical works shall be designed to meet or exceed minimum requirements of codes and standards listed in f.3

f.9.3 geotechnical site investigation general f.9.3.1 geotechnical site investigations shall be planned and carried out in accordance with bs 5930, bs en 1997-22007 and associated uk na, bs 1377 and bs 10175

as indicated in bs 5930, primary objectives of geotechnical investigation as follows a) to assess general suitability of site for proposed works b) to enable adequate and economic design to be prepared c) to foresee and provide against difficulties that may arise during construction due to ground and local conditions and d) to predict any adverse effect of proposed construction on neighbouring structures. schematic representation of geotechnical site investigation illustrated in figure f.19

desk study walk-over survey ground investigation   preliminary investigation main investigation field works and tests samples laboratory testing geotechnical investigation factual report (gifr) geotechnical interpretative report (gir) design figure f.19 schematic organization of site investigation f 50 dubai building code part f structure geotechnical desk study f.9.3.2 geotechnical desk study shall provide conceptual model of site based on all available morphological, geological, hydrological, geotechnical information, and land use history from public sources and technical literature. extent of study will vary according to nature of project and anticipated ground conditions

planning geotechnical investigation f.9.3.3 extent of geotechnical investigation dependent on complexity, size and criticality of development. guidance on spacing and depth of investigation points given in annex b of bs en 1997-22007, and associated uk na. soil investigation for any building shall be defined by a) location of building b) magnitude of imposed loads c) number of floors d) shape of building e) previous uses of land f) terrain surface features g) geological features and h) surface water drainage

f 51 geotechnical on-site investigations f.9.3.4 requirements for geotechnical soil investigations provided in bs en 1997-2 and associated uk na and bs 5930. as minimum, investigations shall include following a) non-intrusive investigations (mapping, geophysics) b) intrusive investigations (boreholes, trial pits, observation wells) c) sampling of soils, rocks and groundwater d) in-situ testing including 1) standard penetration test (spt) 2) cone penetration test (cpt) 03 rb-1 3) pressure meter 01 rb-4 cp-1 4) permeability cp-3 5) in-situ strength and dmp-1 dmp-2 6) deformability

rb-2 rb-3 cp-2 depth of investigation shall extend to at least three times shortest plan dimension of proposed foundation as specified in annex b of bs en 1997- 22007. 02 key soil test boring with spt cpt dilatometer test 01 building layout 02 utilities line 03 topographical contour line minimum number of boreholes shall conform to bs en 1997-22007, associated uk na and following 1) 2) 3) for high-rise buildings more than g+12, one borehole per 750 m2 and minimum of five boreholes for buildings less than g+12, one borehole per 750 m2 and minimum of three boreholes and for large structures 60 grids between boreholes required
example of organization and phasing of on- site investigation given in figure f.20

03 rb-1 01 rb-4 cp-1 cp-3 dmp-1 dmp-2 rb-3 rb-2 cp-2 02 figure f.20 typical organization and phasing of on-site investigation dubai building code part f structure geotechnical laboratory testing f.9.3.5 requirements for geotechnical soil investigations shall conform to bs 1377, bs en 1997-22007 and associated uk na and bs 5930. following list indicates minimum level of laboratory testing a) soil classification/index tests b) soil engineering properties tests (strength, stiffness, deformability) c) rock classification/index tests d) rock engineering properties tests and e) soil, rock and groundwater chemical tests
soil tests shall be conducted in laboratories licensed and approved by eiac. all soil tests shall conform to eiac approved standards

geotechnical reporting f.9.3.6 throughout, and particularly at end of investigation, geotechnical laboratory shall issue geotechnical investigation factual report (gifr) and geotechnical interpretative report (gir), which then reviewed and approved by engineer

for major developments and special projects, gir should be issued by engineer based on gifrs issued by geotechnical laboratory. f) accurate account of equipment specified, mobilized and used for on-site investigation and in-situ testing including methodologies and standards adopted g) all levels of topography including any lidar scans or other means of obtaining point cloud data, all site investigation points (e.g. trial pits, boreholes, cpts, spts), all stratigraphic levels, groundwater levels recorded and similar, to be specified in dmd h) groundwater monitoring level, period and frequency i) groundwater temperature j) borehole and trial pit logs with coordinates and description of encountered strata, levels and types of all specimens taken (soil, rock and groundwater) k) qualitative and quantitative description of boring (e.g. rock quality designation, total core recovery, etc.) l) levels and results of all in-situ tests (e.g. spt) m) borehole logs shall be supplemented with all relevant laboratory tests that facilitate classification of strata (e.g. uniaxial compressive strength) n) colour photos of borehole cores, including depth labels and colour chart o) full documentation of all performed laboratory tests, with suitable illustrative plots/diagrams following items shall be as minimum included in gifr p) ground profile plot with key information of stratigraphy and groundwater level a) clear definition of site, general topography b) site plan/drawing with all as-completed investigation location coordinates c) time and duration of on-site investigations d) meteorological/weather conditions at time of investigations e) use and state of site at commencement of on-site investigation (see figure f.21)

f 52 dubai building code part f structure 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09 10 11 12 figure f.21 typical geological section key 01-07 boreholes 08 ground fill 09 sand 10 sandstone 11 conglomerate 12 calcisiltite f 53 gir shall include following details as minimum when submitted to authority 1) details of recommended foundation system, with allowable bearing capacity, modulus of sub-grade reaction and allowable settlement 2) provision to mitigate effects of expansive and collapsible soils in accordance with recommendations provided in ch. 32 and 33 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. i) ref. f.20 3) provision to mitigate effect of soil liquefaction, which shall be assessed as stipulated in f.9.4.5 4) provision to mitigate effect of soil settlement and loads from adjacent plots 5) various seismic parameters for uppermost 30 m, in accordance with specified codes 6) piles working load capacity under compression and tension for different sizes, at varying depths and effective length (all levels should be in dmd) 7) if applicable, recommendations for pile groups with modification factors for load and settlement 8) values of modulus of elasticity of soil (es) 9) horizontal modulus of sub-grade reactions (kh) 10) constant of horizontal sub-grade reaction (nh) 11) vertical spring constants (kv) 12) poissons ratio 13) piles stiffness (ks) 14) optimal spacing between piles within pile group dubai building code part f structure 15) soil parameters required for shoring and basement wall design, such as f.9.4 geotechnical design i) average bulk density ii) angle of shearing resistance iii) cohesion iv) coefficients of soil pressure at rest (k0) pressure and v) coefficient of active and passive soil pressure for all soil layers. 16) soil classification and index test results (particle size distribution, plasticity chart) 17) rock classification and index test results 18) permeability of soil and rock layers 19) plan showing boreholes, in-situ test location and coordinates 20) water table level (in dmd) and temperature 21) laboratory test results on soil and groundwater samples for presence and concentration of ph, sulphate and chloride, or any other chemicals or components that might affect structure 22) type of cement based on chemical test results of soil types 23) summary of soil parameters 24) subsoil conditions and description 25) recommendation on earth work, excavation, filling and compaction and 26) recommendations for suitability of site material to be used as fill material

f 54 earthworks (excavation and filling) f.9.4.1 excavation works shall be designed in accordance with bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na and bs 6031. design recommendations of ch.23 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. i) ref. f.20 should also be followed for slope stability analysis. geotechnical specialist contractor shall provide slope stability analysis for any open cut excavation (see figure f.22)

figure f.22 open cut excavation dubai building code part f structure geotechnical specialist contractor shall design remedial actions when slopes display signs of instability or geotechnical analysis confirms risk of failing. list below presents some of common slope stabilization techniques which may be used in dubai
c) retaining wall. retaining walls shall be designed in accordance with f.9.4.3

d) soil nailing. in-situ reinforcement technique consisting of drilling or driving steel bars into soil mass (see figure f.23 and figure f.24). soil nails secured to steel plates at surface and optional erosion and vegetation control geosynthetic mesh can be placed over slope face. if soil loose on surface, concrete can be sprayed to cover slope face (see figure f.23). further guidance can be sought in ch. 74 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. f.20

e) filling material. material used for backfilling purposes shall be of selected fill composed of sand/granular mixture. plasticity index of backfill material should not exceed 10%. maximum particle size of backfill material shall not exceed 75 mm. percentage passing through 75 mm sieve shall not exceed 20%. organic materials content shall not exceed 2% and water-soluble salt content shall not exceed 5% f) compaction. backfill materials shall be placed in layers of thickness 150 mm to 250 mm and compacted to not less than 95% of maximum dry density. engineer shall state whether material available on site could be used for general backfilling or not after performing necessary analysis. 03 01 02 11 10 09 08 key 01 permanent facing (e.g. cast-in-place reinforced concrete) 02 temporary load-bearing mechanism (i.e. end bearing, friction, friction with end bearing piles) shall be recommended in gifr. in particular, end bearing capacity shall be agreed with authority before design commenced. design of permanent concrete structural elements shall be in accordance with f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19. design criteria listed in table f.17 applicable to reinforced concrete foundations on piles
f 57 dubai building code part f structure design criterion minimum requirement design criterion minimum requirement pile design general ensure pile design allows for both gravity and lateral loads
pile caps shall be designed in accordance with requirements specified under aci 318-19 and crsi design handbook ref. f.8. 0.2 mm considering tension load

vertical stiffness of piles table f.17 piles foundation minimum design criteria f 58 dubai building code part f structure shoring and earth retaining system general f.9.4.3 f.9.4.3.1 geotechnical design of earth retaining systems shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004+a12013 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall follow f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19. shoring systems and retaining structures deemed to be temporary if design life of system less than two years. they shall not be deemed to be part of permanent structures and physical segregation shall be provided between temporary and permanent structural systems. shoring and retaining systems shall be designed to retain soil and actual groundwater pressure (including tidal effect)

vertical stiffness of piles table f.17 piles foundation minimum design criteria f 58 dubai building code part f structure shoring and earth retaining system general f.9.4.3 f.9.4.3.1 geotechnical design of earth retaining systems shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004+a12013 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall follow f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19. shoring systems and retaining structures deemed to be temporary if design life of system less than two years. they shall not be deemed to be part of permanent structures and physical segregation shall be provided between temporary and permanent structural systems. shoring and retaining systems shall be designed to retain soil and actual groundwater pressure (including tidal effect)

note shoring and earth retaining systems typically used and accepted in dubai as follows a) non-watertight shoring systems 1) soldier piles with lagging system/king post walls 2) contiguous pile walls 3) slurry walls b) watertight shoring systems 1) secant pile walls 2) diaphragm walls 3) sheet piles c) bracing for temporary earth retaining systems 1) anchors 2) rakers and 3) struts

shoring and bracing systems further described in ch. 62, 63 and 64 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. f.20. f 59 dubai building code part f structure f.9.4.3.2 table f.18 should be followed for different depths of excavation and site conditions. required shoring systems type of shoring system permitted under following criteria all types up to 5 deep excavation one basement

shoring and bracing systems further described in ch. 62, 63 and 64 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. f.20. f 59 dubai building code part f structure f.9.4.3.2 table f.18 should be followed for different depths of excavation and site conditions. required shoring systems type of shoring system permitted under following criteria all types up to 5 deep excavation one basement

presence of buildings in adjacent plots high groundwater level proximity to water bodies

design criteria minimum requirement minimum additional loads additional uniform distributed load of 20 kn/m2 shall be taken into consideration in proximity to roads and land plots. additional surcharge load needs to be assessed based on actual conditions on-site and adjacent structures

minimum distance between anchors maximum length of anchors minimum length of anchors 1.2 10 3 maximum lateral displacement 40 mm unplanned excavations retaining walls shall be designed assuming presence of unplanned excavations in front of wall, with depth of not less than 10% of total height of vertical walls, or 10% of vertical distance between lowest anchor and bottom of excavation, but not less than 0.5

geotechnical design shall assess heave if swelling and collapsible soils have identified in gifr. further guidance can be sought in ch. 32 and 33 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. i) ref. f.20

it possible to adopt shoring systems other than those in table f.17, based on soil examination report, groundwater level, presence of water sources, adjacent buildings and surrounding constructions. heave minimum requirements listed in table f.19 shall be included in design of temporary shoring systems. table f.19 minimum requirements for earth retaining system f 60 dubai building code part f structure groundwater control and dewatering f.9.4.4 dewatering systems shall be designed in accordance with bs en 1997-12004, and associated uk na and ciria c750 ref. f.21, taking into account following. a) all existing facilities shall always be protected
b) dewatering system shall reduce loss of soft materials in soil and any effect on surrounding structures. hydrogeological model shall identify and assess any piping effect (see figure f.26)

c) depth of shoring systems and internal excavations shall prevent soil heave. this to avoid possibility of seepage, and to ensure compatibility between designs of shoring systems and dewatering system (see figure f.27). d) seepage analysis and groundwater/hydrogeological model shall be prepared for at least 20 below bottom of excavation. model shall determine following 1) type of soil and rocks 2) horizontal permeability of each layer 3) incoherent or gypsum soils and 4) other areas exposed to water leakage under surface. figure f.28 shows permeability of different soil types and recommended dewatering systems

permanent earth retaining system f.9.4.3.3 any retaining structure deemed to be permanent if design life of system more than two years. permanent retaining system shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without allowing for temporary retaining system

permanent earth retaining system f.9.4.3.3 any retaining structure deemed to be permanent if design life of system more than two years. permanent retaining system shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without allowing for temporary retaining system

temporary retaining structures listed under note to f.9.4.3.1 may be designed as permanent structures, provided they included in analysis of overall structure. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to both main structural system and permanent retaining system. in addition to requirements for temporary retaining systems stipulated under f.9.4.3.2, engineer shall design retaining system with consideration for intended design life. in particular, engineer shall consider applicable performance, serviceability and durability requirements stated in f.5.6 and f.8

temporary retaining structures listed under note to f.9.4.3.1 may be designed as permanent structures, provided they included in analysis of overall structure. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to both main structural system and permanent retaining system. in addition to requirements for temporary retaining systems stipulated under f.9.4.3.2, engineer shall design retaining system with consideration for intended design life. in particular, engineer shall consider applicable performance, serviceability and durability requirements stated in f.5.6 and f.8

basement walls f.9.4.3.4 permanent basement concrete wall should be provided in front of temporary retaining systems detailed in f.9.4.3.2. permanent basement wall shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without considering temporary retaining system. permanent basement wall shall be fully integrated with main structural system of building. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to main structural system and basement walls. geotechnical design of permanent basement walls shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall follow f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19

basement walls f.9.4.3.4 permanent basement concrete wall should be provided in front of temporary retaining systems detailed in f.9.4.3.2. permanent basement wall shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without considering temporary retaining system. permanent basement wall shall be fully integrated with main structural system of building. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to main structural system and basement walls. geotechnical design of permanent basement walls shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall follow f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19

basement walls f.9.4.3.4 permanent basement concrete wall should be provided in front of temporary retaining systems detailed in f.9.4.3.2. permanent basement wall shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without considering temporary retaining system. permanent basement wall shall be fully integrated with main structural system of building. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to main structural system and basement walls. geotechnical design of permanent basement walls shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall follow f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19

b) liquefaction shall be assessed using pga determined on basis of either (1) site-specific study considering soil amplification effects as specified in f.7.13.9 or (2) pgam, from eq. f.9
pgam=fpga.pga eq. f.9 where, pga mceg peak ground acceleration taken from table f.20 and fpga site coefficient from table f.21

dubai building code part f structure site class short period fpga b c e f 0.80 0.90 1.27 1.54 2.25 requirements for foundations design in liquefiable sites shall follow requirements in section 12.13.9 of asce/sei 7-16 and associated subclauses. this shall include consideration of following issues regarding liquefaction, namely a) lateral spreading b) global and differential settlements c) provision of ties between individual foundations and see f.7.13.9 d) negative skin friction (i.e. downdrag) on vertical capacity of piles. table f.21 pga site coefficient fpga for liquefaction assessment in dubai factor of safety (fs) against occurrence of earthquake-induced liquefaction shall be defined as available soil resistance to liquefaction, cyclic resistance ratio (crr) divided by cyclic stress generated by design event, cyclic stress ratio (csr) as shown in eq. f.10. fs shall not be less than 1.5

fs1.5(crr/csr) eq. f.10 groundwater level shall be selected based on peak over design period, which allows natural changes (such as spring tide peak), land use changes and considerations for global warming

when assessing potential for liquefaction any published and internationally accepted methodology can be used provided it internally consistent. it recommended to use idriss boulanger method ref. f.9. impact of carbonate sands on liquefaction potential should also be included. where impact of liquefaction exceeds requirements of asce/sei 7-16 (table 12.13-2 for lateral spreading and table 12.13-3 for differential settlement thresholds), then suitable ground improvement shall be required

ground improvement f.9.4.6 ground improvement shall be designed according to bs en 1997-1 and ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. i) ch.25 ref. f.20. note following ground improvement techniques accepted in dubai (see figure f.29) a) dynamic compaction b) vibro-compaction c) soil replacement d) soil mixing e) grouting and f) vertical drains

f 65 dubai building code part f structure f.9.5 execution of geotechnical works general f.9.5.1 geotechnical works shall be carried out in accordance with bs en standards listed in f.3.1.5. engineer and geotechnical specialist contractor shall also conform to following clauses. earthworks (excavation and filling) f.9.5.2 in addition to requirements of bs en 6031, following requirements shall be included in execution of excavation and backfill activities. a) materials used for backfilling purposes shall consist of selected materials such as sand/granular mixture free from organic materials or other biodegradable materials. engineer shall determine whether excavated materials can be used in general backfilling works after conducting necessary testing

d) all excavation activities shall be carried out inside plot limits only. no encroachment, no parking, and no stopping zone with minimum width of 1 shall be provided in proximity to excavated area. e) for any works required outside of plot limits, no objection certificate (noc) /approval from all relevant authorities, departments or plot owners shall be submitted

f) execution of excavation and filling activities shall conform to requirements stipulated in ch.75 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. f.20. g) installation of soil nails shall conform to requirements of bs en 14490. further guidance can be sought in ch. 88 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. f.20

f 66 shoring retaining systems f.9.5.3 in addition to requirements of bs 8081, bs en 1536, bs en 1537, bs en 1538 and bs en 12063, following requirements shall be included in construction of earth retaining structures. a) all existing structures and utilities shall always be protected

b) all works of shoring systems shall be carried out within land plot. geotechnical specialist contractor shall obtain all required approvals from all concerned authorities and owners of adjacent plots regarding any shoring system or anchors protruding outside land plot limits. c) top 2 of shoring systems on roads or services side shall be removed upon completion of basement wall works
e) anchors can be removed on-site only after obtaining written consent of engineer
foundations f.9.5.4 it envisaged that following foundation systems will be typically provided for buildings in dubai a) shallow foundations b) deep foundations and c) raft foundations

in addition to requirements of bs en 1536, bs en 12699 and bs en 14199, minimum testing criteria listed in table f.22 shall be followed during and after execution of reinforced concrete foundations on piles

dubai building code part f structure test static test on working piles minimum requirement minimum 1% of all piles and each different diameter groundwater control and dewatering f.9.5.5 in addition to requirements given in ciria c750 ref. f.21, following requirements shall also be included during execution of dewatering on-site

b) network shall be developed to monitor groundwater pressure/piezometric pressure separated from dewatering system, vertical groundwater gradients as well as horizontal gradients, and water rises inside and outside excavations/the shoring systems

c) dewatering works shall not be stopped without written approval of engineer, after achieving balance between water pressure and weight of construction. factor of safety shall be at least 1.1, irrespective of friction between walls and soil. d) care shall be taken during dewatering process to ensure that fine particles soil not removed during pumping, as this may lead to unexpected subsidence in surrounding lands and associated structures

dynamic test on working piles 5% of all piles cross-hole sonic logging (for more than 1 diameter and 20 length) 10% of all piles 900 mm or greater with minimum four tubes/holes and minimum three tubes for 750 mm. minimum length of testing 20 or full length if shorter. end bearing piles full length testing integrity test working piles 100% cubes test (concrete) reinforcement test as per technical specification as per technical specification table f.22 minimum testing requirements for pile foundation it responsibility of both engineer and geotechnical specialist contractor to select test location which does not interfere with location of permanent structural piles of main structure. geotechnical specialist contractor may propose test locations to be reviewed by engineer may accept them or propose alternative locations. non-working preliminary test pile (ptp) location and arrangement shall be submitted officially to authority during design stage and shall at least include following. 1) detailed drawings that clearly show location of test pile and instrumentation
4) minimum 1no. ptp for each project. maximum diameter and length of pile should be considered, assuming that they most suitable for site

ptp results shall be used to optimize pile design in accordance with bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. f 67 dubai building code part f structure 3) deep piled foundation it recommended that, after completion of ground improvement, weighted average of cpt tip resistance profile at least 8.0 mpa
d) all existing facilities and utilities shall always be monitored and protected by geotechnical specialist contractor

e) all activities to be carried out inside plot limits only. for any activity outside of plot limits, noc from all of relevant authority departments (e.g. dewa, rta, etc.) or plot owners should be submitted to authority
ground improvement f.9.5.6 ground improvement shall be executed in accordance with bs en 12715, bs en 12716, bs en 14199, bs en 14475, bs en 14679, bs en 14731 and bs en 15237

in addition to requirements specified in referenced codes and standards, following requirements shall also be included during execution of ground improvement on-site. a) technical design shall be prepared by geotechnical specialist contractor and approved by engineer prior to submission to authority

b) tests shall be conducted before and after ground improvement activities. tests shall be proposed by geotechnical specialist contractor, reviewed by engineer and approved by authority. geotechnical specialist contractor should perform following tests as minimum

1) bearing capacity i) one plate load test per each 750 m2 area (minimum one test for each building) to be carried out in accordance with astm d1195m. recommended acceptance criterion to achieve targeted bearing pressure with total settlements less than 25 mm. ii) one zone load test in accordance with astm d1195m shall be required for major developments comprising more than one building and special structures

2) improvement to mitigate liquefaction risk efficiency of improvement shall be verified with cpt readings (in accordance with astm d5778 or bs en iso 22476-12012). pre-improvement cpt tests should be carried out every 900 m2 maximum (or as stipulated in project specifications) to compare results with post-improvement cpt tests. locations of post-improvement cpt tests should be selected at central points between improved points. weighted average of cpt tip resistance for near and far tested point, should not be less than 6.0 mpa for shallow foundations

parameter pga pgv pgd ratio 1.20 1.22 1.25 table f.24 resultant/geometric mean ratios (malhotra, 2020) asce/sei 7-16 also adjusts seismic hazard to ensure risk-consistent hazard parameters for typical usa building stock following procedure proposed by luco ref. f.33. malhotra ref. f.22 recommends that this adjustment not made, since building stock in dubai considerably different to usa and uncertainty in methodology large. return period f.10.2.2 asce/sei 7-16 defines hazard in terms of 2% probability of exceedance in 50 years, otherwise known as return period of 2,475 years. as discussed in malhotra ref. f.22, factor of two-thirds applied to approximate hazard in usa to approximate return period of 475 years, as used in previous degeneration of seismic codes. this arbitrary requirement, which country specific. in contrast canadian building code uses 2,475-year return period directly. reason because this lower probability considered to provide more uniform margin of collapse, one that much nearer to probability of structural failure. similarly, uk national annex to bs en 1998-1 also uses 2,475-year return period. this to ensure seismic design applied to most critical structures in what generally region of very low seismicity. since dubai principally affected by large distant events in iran, it considered appropriate not to reduce seismic hazard level using arbitrary two-thirds factor used in usa, but ensure seismic design caters for these larger events. this should not increase seismic demand compared to current design practice. f 70 dubai building code part f structure f.10.3 west coast fault west coast fault presented as structure on tectonic map of arabian peninsula in johnson (1998) ref. f.36. interpretation based on figures presented by murris ref. f.34 and hancock et al. ref. f.35. both references show west coast fault as right lateral strike slip fault running along coast from abu dhabi through dubai and sharjah to ras al khaimah, whereas johnson ref. f.36 shows this as left lateral strike slip fault. they also both focus on dibba line as principal fault within uae and do not even discuss west coast fault

parameter pga pgv pgd ratio 1.20 1.22 1.25 table f.24 resultant/geometric mean ratios (malhotra, 2020) asce/sei 7-16 also adjusts seismic hazard to ensure risk-consistent hazard parameters for typical usa building stock following procedure proposed by luco ref. f.33. malhotra ref. f.22 recommends that this adjustment not made, since building stock in dubai considerably different to usa and uncertainty in methodology large. return period f.10.2.2 asce/sei 7-16 defines hazard in terms of 2% probability of exceedance in 50 years, otherwise known as return period of 2,475 years. as discussed in malhotra ref. f.22, factor of two-thirds applied to approximate hazard in usa to approximate return period of 475 years, as used in previous degeneration of seismic codes. this arbitrary requirement, which country specific. in contrast canadian building code uses 2,475-year return period directly. reason because this lower probability considered to provide more uniform margin of collapse, one that much nearer to probability of structural failure. similarly, uk national annex to bs en 1998-1 also uses 2,475-year return period. this to ensure seismic design applied to most critical structures in what generally region of very low seismicity. since dubai principally affected by large distant events in iran, it considered appropriate not to reduce seismic hazard level using arbitrary two-thirds factor used in usa, but ensure seismic design caters for these larger events. this should not increase seismic demand compared to current design practice. f 70 dubai building code part f structure f.10.3 west coast fault west coast fault presented as structure on tectonic map of arabian peninsula in johnson (1998) ref. f.36. interpretation based on figures presented by murris ref. f.34 and hancock et al. ref. f.35. both references show west coast fault as right lateral strike slip fault running along coast from abu dhabi through dubai and sharjah to ras al khaimah, whereas johnson ref. f.36 shows this as left lateral strike slip fault. they also both focus on dibba line as principal fault within uae and do not even discuss west coast fault

existence of west coast fault at best contentious. some tectonic and seismic hazard studies of region do not include this fault as local tectonic feature (e.g. pascucci et al., 2008, aldama-bustos et al. ref. f.25). other seismic hazard studies include west coast fault as seismic source (e.g. sigbjornsson and elnashai ref. f.28) however details regarding modelling parameters poorly defined

study undertaken by megahed et al. ref. f.37 on behalf of abu dhabi department of municipal affairs to determine threat posed to uae by west coast fault. findings of this study rejected existence of west coast fault. this agrees with conclusions of geological mapping of area by british geological survey ref. f.27

f 71 dubai building code part f structure f.11 annex dubai sustainable concrete baseline (dscb) f.11.1 general f.11.2 dm concrete calculator dm concrete calculator serves as tool to help members assess their concrete mixes against dscb by changing different parameters and prior to submitting for dm approval
dm concrete calculator web-based application and includes all baseline mixes in its data base
note to subscribe to dm concrete calculator, contact research and building systems section at dscbdm.gov.ae

f.11.3 standard concrete mixes ready-mixed concrete company operating in dubai might have their standard concrete mixes approved to be used. for any standard mix to be approved, it needs to have wai less than that of corresponding baseline mix (see table f.25) of same grade. preliminary comparisons may be carried out by client using dm concrete calculator. final approval for every mix issued by research & building systems section of building permits department

proposed mixes compared to wai of baseline mixes of equivalent grade. dubai sustainable concrete baseline (dscb) alternative approach to minimum requirements for concrete mixes in f.6.2.3. dscb represents allowable upper limit for environmental weighted average impact (wai) of concrete mixes which based on industry-wide lifecycle assessment (lca) and environmental product declaration conducted for most common concrete mixes used in building construction in dubai. wai calculated from normalized lca indicators/factors for each concrete mix including global warming potential, acidification potential, eutrophication potential, abiotic depletion potential fossil, blue water consumption, reused water for washing and water for washing

table f.25 lists all concrete mixes forming dscb. full details about concrete mix proportions, environmental impacts, and wai can be accessed through web- based concrete calculator. dscb does not consider durability aspects for any one of concrete mixes listed in table f.25. it recommended to consult design engineer for right durability specification for every project based on prevailing conditions of structure (service life, exposure conditions, concrete grade, concrete cover and any other relevant parameter affecting durability) and in line with f.5.6

aim to encourage industry to produce more sustainable concrete, eventually resulting in lowering impact of concrete construction on environment. it essential to balance specification of concrete for sustainability while ensuring other performance parameters optimized. engineers urged not to over-specify concrete strength and/or durability parameters and to permit flexibility in designing concrete mixes in way that encourages production of more sustainable concrete

aim to encourage industry to produce more sustainable concrete, eventually resulting in lowering impact of concrete construction on environment. it essential to balance specification of concrete for sustainability while ensuring other performance parameters optimized. engineers urged not to over-specify concrete strength and/or durability parameters and to permit flexibility in designing concrete mixes in way that encourages production of more sustainable concrete

once material approved, it added to dscb environmental impacts model and dm concrete calculator. accordingly, it may be used in concrete mixes provided that those mixes have lower wais than those of corresponding baseline mixes. f.11.5 concrete mixes for specific project this service permits, for specific project, use of mixes different from those specified in f.6.2.3 mixes may exceed wai of corresponding baseline mixes provided that total wai for all concrete mixes used in project less than that of baseline mixes, as shown in following equation

eq. f.11 (wai of proposed mix . quantity of mix)(wai of baseline mix . quantity of mix) note further information on submitting applications can be obtained from research and building systems section at dscbdm.gov.ae

b) design should take into account how stair tied to main structure, sequence of construction and temporary works involved

c) ties between precast stair and precast supports critical aspect of design. recommended types of connections illustrated in figure f.31 and figure f.32. d) precast staircase flight may be supported by steel beams, providing shear 02 studs welded to steel beam and holes in precast unit located over studs and then grouted, as shown in figure f.33

substation and mv installations liquefied petroleum gas (lpg) g.9 water g.10 district cooling g.11 telecommunications g 1 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.1 performance statements performance statement building shall provide electrical installations that safeguard occupants against outbreak of fire and personal injury due to electric shock
building shall be coordinated with needs of relevant incoming district cooling provisions
building shall enable telecommunications services that suitably future-proof and that facilitate use of multiple service providers

performance statement will be met by following requirements of g.4 to g.7 g.9 g.10 g.11 g 2 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.2 definitions g.2.1 terms electrical g.2.1.1 accessory device, other than current-using equipment, associated with such equipment or with wiring of installation
active power real component of apparent power, expressed in watts (w), kilowatts (kw) or megawatts (mw)

apparent power product of voltage (v) and current (a). it usually expressed in kilovolt-ampere (kva) or megavolt-ampere (mva), and consists of real component (active power) and imaginary component (reactive power)
arc fault detection device (afdd) device that protects specifically against arc faults. afdds automatically trip circuit when they detect dangerous electric arcs
g 3 bonding conductor protective conductor providing equipotential bonding
bunched cables two or more cables that contained within single conduit, duct or trunking, or, if not enclosed, not separated from each other by specified distance

busbar trunking system type-tested assembly, in form of enclosed conductor system comprising solid conductors separated by insulating material. assembly may consist of units such as a) busbar trunking units, with or without tap-out facilities b) tap-out units where applicable or c) flexible, end-feeder and adaptor units
cable ladder cable support consisting of series of transverse supporting elements rigidly fixed to main longitudinal supporting members
conduit part of closed wiring system for cables in electrical installations, allowing them to be drawn in and/or replaced, but not inserted laterally
connected load total electrical power (w) consumed by all devices connected to electrical distribution system
connector part of cable coupler or appliance coupler which provided with female contacts and intended to be attached to end of flexible cable remote from supply
dubai building code part g incoming utilities current-using equipment equipment which converts electrical energy into another form of energy, such as light, heat or motive power
earth conductive mass of earth, of which electric potential at any point conventionally taken as zero
design current magnitude of current root mean square (rms) value for ac to be carried by circuit in normal service

duct enclosure of metal or insulating material, other than conduit or cable trunking, intended for protection of cables which drawn in after erection of ducting. earth continuity conductor (ecc) conductor used for some measures of protection against electric shock and intended for connecting together any of following parts a) exposed conductive parts b) extraneous-conductive parts c) main earthing terminal d) earth electrode(s) or e) earthed point of source, or artificial neutral

duct enclosure of metal or insulating material, other than conduit or cable trunking, intended for protection of cables which drawn in after erection of ducting. earth continuity conductor (ecc) conductor used for some measures of protection against electric shock and intended for connecting together any of following parts a) exposed conductive parts b) extraneous-conductive parts c) main earthing terminal d) earth electrode(s) or e) earthed point of source, or artificial neutral

duct enclosure of metal or insulating material, other than conduit or cable trunking, intended for protection of cables which drawn in after erection of ducting. earth continuity conductor (ecc) conductor used for some measures of protection against electric shock and intended for connecting together any of following parts a) exposed conductive parts b) extraneous-conductive parts c) main earthing terminal d) earth electrode(s) or e) earthed point of source, or artificial neutral
emergency switching operation intended to remove, as quickly as possible, danger, which might have occurred unexpectedly

equipment any item that involves generation, conversion, transmission, distribution or utilization of electrical energy, such as machines, transformers, apparatus, measuring instruments, protective devices, wiring systems, accessories, appliances and luminaires

g 4 dubai building code part g incoming utilities equipotential bonding electrical connection maintaining various exposed conductive parts and extraneous conductive parts at substantially same potential

exposed conductive part conductive part of equipment which can be touched, and which not live part, but which can become live under fault conditions. external influence any influence external to electrical installation that affects design and safe operation of that installation

extra-low voltage voltage normally not exceeding 50 v ac or 120 v ripple-free dc, whether between conductors or to earth. fault circuit condition in which current flows through abnormal or unintended path, which can result from insulation failure or bridging of insulation. fault current current resulting from fault
feeder pillar cabinet for electrical protection and distribution equipment, mounted externally and supplying several consumers
g 5 flexible cable cable in which structure and materials make it suitable to be flexed while in service
flexible cord cable in which cross-sectional area of each conductor does not exceed 4 mm2

harmonics amount of distortion that occurs to voltage or current sine wave, which in electrical installations can be caused by various sources such as non-linear loads, variable speed drives, variable frequency drives, capacitor banks, ups backup power supplies, fluorescent light ballasts, fan speed controls, halogen lights, low voltage transformers for indoor/ outdoor lighting, unfiltered dimmer switches, ac/dc power supplies, etc. found in various electronic devices such as computers, printers, fax machines, televisions, etc

harmonics amount of distortion that occurs to voltage or current sine wave, which in electrical installations can be caused by various sources such as non-linear loads, variable speed drives, variable frequency drives, capacitor banks, ups backup power supplies, fluorescent light ballasts, fan speed controls, halogen lights, low voltage transformers for indoor/ outdoor lighting, unfiltered dimmer switches, ac/dc power supplies, etc. found in various electronic devices such as computers, printers, fax machines, televisions, etc
isolator mechanical switching device which, in open position, meets requirements specified for isolating function
live part conductor or conductive part intended to be energized in normal use, including neutral conductor
low smoke and fume (lsf) cable cable rated class cca-s1b,d2,a2 in accordance with bs en 13501-6

low voltage voltage normally exceeding extra-low voltage but not exceeding 1,000 v ac or 1,500 v dc between conductors, or 600 v ac or 900 v dc between conductors and earth. luminaire equipment which distributes, filters or transforms light from one or more lamps, and which includes any parts necessary for supporting, fixing and protecting lamps, but not lamps themselves, and, where necessary, circuit auxiliaries together with means for connecting them to supply. main earthing terminal terminal or bar provided for connection of protective conductors, including equipotential bonding conductors, and conductors for functional earthing, if any, to means of earthing

low voltage voltage normally exceeding extra-low voltage but not exceeding 1,000 v ac or 1,500 v dc between conductors, or 600 v ac or 900 v dc between conductors and earth. luminaire equipment which distributes, filters or transforms light from one or more lamps, and which includes any parts necessary for supporting, fixing and protecting lamps, but not lamps themselves, and, where necessary, circuit auxiliaries together with means for connecting them to supply. main earthing terminal terminal or bar provided for connection of protective conductors, including equipotential bonding conductors, and conductors for functional earthing, if any, to means of earthing
dubai building code part g incoming utilities maximum demand summation of all electrical power demand that has occurred during specified period, measured in kw or kva
megger test measure of insulation resistance
nominal voltage voltage by which installation (or part of installation) designated. overcurrent current exceeding rated value. for conductors rated value current- carrying capacity
protective earthing earthing of point or points in system or in installation or in equipment for purpose of safety
pv array cable output cable of pv array
pv array junction box enclosure where pv strings of any pv array electrically connected and where devices can be located
pv cell basic pv device which can generate electricity when exposed to light such as solar radiation
pv dc main cable cable connecting pv generator junction box to dc terminal of pv invertor
pv generator assembly of pv array
pv generator junction box enclosure where pv array electrically connected and where devices can be located
pv invertor device which converts dc voltage and dc current into ac voltage and ac current
pv ac module integrated module/invertor assembly where electrical interface terminal ac only, with no access being provided to dc side
pv string circuit in which pv modules connected in series for pv array to generate required output voltage
pv string cable cable connecting pv modules to form pv string
rated current value of current used for specification purposes, established for specified set of operating conditions of component, device, equipment or system
g 6 dubai building code part g incoming utilities residual current vector sum of instantaneous values of current flowing through all live conductors of circuit at point in electrical installation

residual current operated circuit breaker with integral overcurrent protection (rcbo) residual current operating device designed to perform functions of protection against overall load and/or short-circuit

residual current operated circuit breaker without integral overcurrent protection (rccb) residual current operated switching device not designed to perform functions of protection against overload and/or short-circuit

space factor ratio (expressed as percentage) of sum of effective overall cross-sectional area of cables forming bunch to internal cross-sectional area of conduit, pipe, duct, trunking or channel in which they installed
switchboard assembly of switchgear with or without instruments, excluding groups of local switches in final circuits
switchgear assembly of main and auxiliary switching apparatus for operation, regulation, protection or other control of electrical installation
temporary electrical systems electrical installation erected for particular purpose and dismantled when no longer required for that purpose
resistance area surface area of ground (around earth electrode only) on which significant voltage gradient may exist
wiring system assembly made up of cables or busbars and parts which secure and, if necessary, enclose cable or busbar

surge protection device (spd) device designed to protect electrical systems and equipment from surge events (e.g. caused by lightening or switching of electrical loads) by limiting transient voltages and diverting surge currents. xlpe cable cross-linked polyethylene as insulation of cable
short-circuit current under standard test condition (isc stc) short-circuit current of pv module, pv string, pv array or pv generator under standard test conditions
g 7 dubai building code part g incoming utilities district cooling g.2.1.2 customer building owner, developer or other representative (e.g. designer)
energy transfer station (ets) dedicated plant room in facility or building where cooling energy transfer system installed to supply chilled water to premises
premises land and buildings, owned by customer, requiring chilled cooling water
provider entity that designs, supplies, installs, tests, cleans and commissions district cooling plant that licensed and approved by municipal authorities
valve chamber (vc) dedicated space in premises, either buried or exposed, where district cooling provider provides isolating valves on district cooling chilled water pipes that serve ets
valve chamber (vc) dedicated space in premises, either buried or exposed, where district cooling provider provides isolating valves on district cooling chilled water pipes that serve ets

telecommunications g.2.1.3 building industry consulting service international (bicsi) global professional/trade association supporting advancement of information and communications technology (ict) community. building entry point (bep) point where external ducts physically enter building. this can be standalone location or incorporated into another telecoms space. cable pathway any system used to route cables, such as cable ducting, cable ladder, cable tray, conduit, duct and maintenance chamber

feeder cable cable that provides signals to property from ethernet or gpon-based sp network. feeder cables can deliver signals for connection to optical splitters and distribution on in-building telecom fibre to x (fttx) system, or provide sp connection to local optical line terminal (olt) if sp requires this locally within development

fibre concentration point (fcp) point where high core count feeder cable converted to multiple smaller core count distribution cables. fcp can be located within property boundary in bep, or outside property in meet-me-chamber (mmc). fibre to x (fttx) delivery of optical fibre signals directly to location. for sp telecom services, x can be defined as b (building), c (cabinet), h (home) or p (premise). floor telecom room (ftr) room located at each floor between main telecom room (mtr) and multiple floor optical telecommunication outlets (to), which allows transition from vertical optical fibre cables to horizontal tenant cabling

handhole small maintenance chamber installed within campus duct system specifically aiding pulling of cables on long straight duct routes where cable pulling forces might otherwise be exceeded. meet-me-chamber (mmc) maintenance chamber located in vicinity of property boundary and providing first common element of outside plant (osp) installation, with three separate duct connections from sps into chamber then following single osp route into development. for multi- building developments, this can also contain fcp, enabling feeder cables to split to separate cables to individual buildings on plot when meet-me-room (mmr) not utilized

handhole small maintenance chamber installed within campus duct system specifically aiding pulling of cables on long straight duct routes where cable pulling forces might otherwise be exceeded. meet-me-chamber (mmc) maintenance chamber located in vicinity of property boundary and providing first common element of outside plant (osp) installation, with three separate duct connections from sps into chamber then following single osp route into development. for multi- building developments, this can also contain fcp, enabling feeder cables to split to separate cables to individual buildings on plot when meet-me-room (mmr) not utilized

meet-me-room (mmr) site-specific location for sp use, as determined by agreed masterplan. mmrs form common location for feeder cables from sps to terminate and split to multiple cables feeding mtrs on different plots of development
g 8 dubai building code part g incoming utilities main telecom room (mtr) location where feeder cables from sps terminated, allowing connection to building inside plant (isp) common infrastructure

optical line terminal (olt) centralized piece of equipment providing service to many end users through pon solution. olts can support cable distances up to 20 km from centralized equipment subject to optical fibre cabling design. optical network terminal (ont) active component of fttx optical network located at tenant premises

optical splitter passive component of fttx optical network taking signal from either one or two input optical cores and equally dividing signal to splitter outputs. optical telecommunication outlet (to) fixed connecting device where tenant indoor optical fibre cable terminates. to provides optical connection for equipment connection cord of ont

passive optical network (pon) point-to-multipoint fttx network architecture utilizing unpowered optical splitters. variants of pon using same topology and passive components include gpon, xg-pon, xgs-pon and ng-pon2
g 9 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.2.2 ac acb ahu apc bapv bep bicsi bipv cap ch
