walls enclosing covered parking ramps at exit/access of basement interior walls. louvers shall not be permitted in these walls unless they protected in accordance with g.7.6.3

headings: forced ventilation with no exterior walls
Description: forced ventilation with no exterior walls g.7.6.3 rmu rooms shall be at ground floor. rmu rooms shall be 2 h fire rated to conform to table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. g.1. exterior walls do not need to be fire rated unless there risk of exterior fire spread and wall fire rated in accordance with ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. g.1

independent mechanical ventilation shall be provided to transformer rooms with no exterior walls (e.g. in basement). all equipment shall be accessed from landlord side. mechanical ventilation shall be sized to maintain ambient temperature in substation at maximum of 55 c based on outside air temperature of 48 c. supporting calculations shall be provided to justify proposed exhaust and supply rates. typical details shown in figure g.52
louvers shall be provided on two sides of room as back-up to mechanical ventilation system
total grill area shall be not less than 14.9 m2 for 1,000 kva transformer and not less than 18.6 m2 for 1,500 kva transformer

transformer rooms shall be 2 h fire rated to conform to table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. g.1. louvers shall be protected by automatic 2 h fire rated shutters or 2 h fire rated curtains on landlord side of louvers (see figure g.53). two combined fire and smoke detectors shall be provided on landlord side of louvers. they shall be located on slab soffit within vicinity of louver in accordance with dimensional requirements of table 8.1 (item 25, door release service), ch. 8 of uae flsc ref. g.1

g.7.6 substation ventilation and fire safety provisions general g.7.6.1 substations shall have adequate ventilation using natural louvers, mechanical ventilation or combination of both, depending upon how many sides of transformer room have direct access to exterior wall

g.7.6 substation ventilation and fire safety provisions general g.7.6.1 substations shall have adequate ventilation using natural louvers, mechanical ventilation or combination of both, depending upon how many sides of transformer room have direct access to exterior wall

substations shall be 2 h fire rated to conform to table 1.9, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. g.1. exterior walls do not need to be fire rated unless there risk of exterior fire spread and wall fire rated in accordance with ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. g.1

natural ventilation via two exterior walls g.7.6.2 substations at ground floor shall be naturally ventilated. minimum of two sides shall be ventilated using aluminium louvered doors and fixed aluminium louvers

headings: natural ventilation via two exterior walls
Description: natural ventilation via two exterior walls g.7.6.2 substations at ground floor shall be naturally ventilated. minimum of two sides shall be ventilated using aluminium louvered doors and fixed aluminium louvers
fixed aluminium louver window(s) should be at 600 mm above outside ground level
aluminium louvered doors shall be of following sizes a) transformer rooms 3.05 wide  2.75 high b) rmu rooms 2.4 or 3.05 wide  2.75 high
note door details shown in figure g.50 and figure g.51

g 93 dubai building code part g incoming utilities upon activation of both combined fire and smoke detectors, fire rated shutters or fire rated curtains shall automatically close and mechanical ventilation to transformer room shall automatically stop
fire rated shutters or fire rated curtains shall have automatic override switch on landlord side
at least one fire rated (90 min) exit door, with door swing in direction of egress, shall be provided

n equipment access doors may include louvers, but they shall be protected by automatic fire rated shutters or fire rated curtains on landlord side of louvers. fire curtains/shutters will close in fire and block equipment doors therefore alternative exit shall be provided and equipment doors shall not be marked as exit. l j k n p p j k figure g.50 details of substation louvers l g 94 dubai building code part g incoming utilities b) door plan key 01 3.05 m, or 2.44 if located where it opens onto sikka/road, or as per plan 02 slot central mullion b 40 mm  20 mm bracing aluminium box c heavy duty hinges heavy duty aluminium drop with locking hook e heavy duty brass tower bolt (750 mm) f heavy duty brass tower bolt (300 mm) g handles h rawl bolt c) details of additional locking arrangement figure g.51 details of substation doors a) elevation g 95 dubai building code part g incoming utilities 4 x 1,000 kva figure g.52 forced ventilation of transformer room in basement g 96 dubai building code part g incoming utilities 5.00 0.77 0.90 0.77 1.28 03 04 5.00 03 0.20 0.40 04 05 0.85 01 02 0 2 4

0.45 0.92 0.60 0.92 1.70 03 aa 0.45 0.98 aa aa 06 0.20 figure g.53 plan and section view of basement transformer room with fire rated shutter/curtains over louvers (m) key 01 150 mm pvc duct at trench level 02 transformer base 03 combined heat/smoke detector 04 2 h fire/smoke curtain on landlords side to protect louver opening 05 louvered door 06 90 min fire rated door g 97 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.7.7 transporting equipment to basement transformer rooms g.7.8 substation cable arrangement transporting transformers between public road and transformer room customers responsibility. requirements set out in table g.31 shall be followed
cable arrangements subject to dewa approval and shall conform to table g.32

element of transport route requirements ramp slab cut-out opening straight, with minimum width of 3 m. sloped curves and speed breakers (humps) not permitted. minimum clear height of 3 shall be maintained between public road and transformer room. slope of ramp shall be maintained at maximum of 110 (10%)
cut-out size shall be 3  3 and adjacent to main rta/public roadside
area below cut-out at basement level shall be designated as loading/unloading bay

area above cut-out shall be open to sky. if there floor above then minimum clear height of 7 shall be maintained. table g.31 transformer transportation requirements  main road to transformer room substation type general substation cable arrangement cable trench inside substation shall have clear depth of 950 mm from substation ffl, as indicated in figure g.54

cable route/arrangement from plot limit to substation (if setback confirmed in affection plan issued by competent authority) shall be through cable trench with removable slab as shown in figure g.55, or cable tray at high level basement

cable route/arrangement from rmu room to transformer room for split/ basement substations shall be through cable trench with removable slab as shown in figure g.53, or cable tray at high level basement

if cables passing through traffic movement area, concrete encased ducts with manholes at both ends shall be provided. spare provision for ducts shall be provided in accordance with dewa requirements. cable ducts shall have internal diameter of 150 mm

if cables passing through traffic movement area, concrete encased ducts with manholes at both ends shall be provided. spare provision for ducts shall be provided in accordance with dewa requirements. cable ducts shall have internal diameter of 150 mm
note cut-out at 950 mm depth from outside level (towards road/sikka) should be provided for hv cable entry. typical arrangements shown in figure g.54 and figure g.55
basement or split substation for basement/split substation, transformer room cable trench depth shall be 500 mm below finished floor, subject to dewa approval
for cable tray arrangement, clear depth of 950 mm shall be provided from substation ffl up to bed of tray, with minimum clear depth of 450 mm between bottom of slab and bed of tray
cable installation/maintenance space of minimum 1.2 shall be provided on at least one side of cable tray arrangement
cable tray shall pass through public/open area and not through any closed area/room (there shall be no services, pipes, etc. below cable tray)
note cable route from rmu to transformer room should be straight (without turns/bends). where unavoidable, minimum bending radius of r = 950 mm might be accepted

table g.32 substation cable arrangement g 98 dubai building code part g incoming utilities 0 5 6 0 0 3 0 5 1 0 5 9 0 0 3 0 5 1 figure g.54 typical substation cable trench setting out details figure g.55 cable lying arrangement in concrete trench key 01 wall 02 chequered plate 03 channel 04 opening 05 slope 06 pre-cast concrete g 99 key 01 pre-cast concrete kerb 02 cover heavy duty 03 200 mm thick block work 04 cables 05 0.08 diameter drain in floor at 2 c/c 06 30 n/mm2 pre-cast concrete 07 polythene sheet 08 compacted earth 09 channel width  variable according to number of cables dubai building code part g incoming utilities note 2 compliance supported by type test certificates and guaranteed routine manufacturers works test certificates. only certificates confirming that current transformers (ct) have passed type tests need to be submitted to dewa
incoming current transformer shall be dimensioned such that protection scheme operates effectively for fault current of 31.5 ka
reverse power protection shall be provided to enable in-feeds to faults within dewa 11 kv network to be cleared within 3

g.7.9 direct 11 kv supply for super high- rise towers above 200 intake arrangement g.7.9.1 point of supply to super high-rise tower supply intake of mv switchgear, which located adjacent to dewa metering/control room. switchgear shall be provided with circuit breaker, with e/f and o/c protection

g.7.9 direct 11 kv supply for super high- rise towers above 200 intake arrangement g.7.9.1 point of supply to super high-rise tower supply intake of mv switchgear, which located adjacent to dewa metering/control room. switchgear shall be provided with circuit breaker, with e/f and o/c protection
customer responsible for all equipment beyond point of supply. dewa does not supply, operate or maintain any equipment installed above ground level
all equipment procured by customer shall have dual ratio (6.6/11 kv) unless it clearly stated to be 11 kv
all equipment shall conform to relevant international standards (iec standards)
total transformer losses shall not exceed 1.5% of rated capacity
only cast resin transformers shall be installed in residential/commercial buildings

technical justification shall be submitted for availing direct 11 kv supply to super high-rise building for locating transformers above ground level(s). this depends on height of building, size of load, type of load, etc. when buildings exceed 200 then dewa may accept direct 11 kv supply. designer shall consult with dewa to confirm
mv switchgear suitable for termination of maximum cable size of 3  300 mm2 xlpe/pvc/swa/pe aluminium/copper cable with heat shrinkable type cable terminations
termination at private mv switchgear incomer shall be installed by consumer. terminations at dewa rmu shall be installed by dewa
protection requirements g.7.9.2 suitable protection and interlocking shall be provided to ensure that private substation does not have negative impact on dewa system
private substation shall be configured such that its protection operates before dewa protection during fault
mechanical and electrical interlocks shall be provided so that incomers not paralleled. in substations with multiple switchboards, interlock shall extend to all of switchboards

incomer protection relays shall conform to iec 60255. note 1 compliance supported by type test certificates and guaranteed routine manufacturers works test certificates. only certificates confirming that relays have passed type tests need to be submitted to dewa
overcurrent relay shall operate correctly for fault currents up to 31.5 ka

instrument transformers shall conform to iec 61869. g 100 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.8 liquefied petroleum gas (lpg) g.8.1 general lpg installations shall comply with ch. 11 of uae flsc ref. g.1. lpg main distribution pipes serving multiple floors of building shall be contained within dedicated 2 h fire rated shaft

g 101 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.9 water g.9.1 water metering dewa main meter shall be installed to measure and record water demand and consumption of building. each individual tenancy in building shall have sub- meter installed which connected to building main meter. additional requirements for sub-metering detailed in h.5.2.6. where building management system or central control and monitoring system installed, metering shall be integrated into system to allow real time profiling and management of water demand and consumption

headings: design and installation of water meters
Description: g.9.2 design and installation of water meters design and installation of dewa water meters, including smart metering communications requirements, shall follow specifications and sample drawings in dewa circulars and regulations ref. g.8 and as listed in table g.33

headings: design and installation of water meters
Description: dewa specification sample drawing number pew-std- ami-003 pew-std- ami-004 pew-std- ami-005 domestic water meter installation in meter room - guidelines bulk meter installation in chamber - guidelines bulk meter installation in chamber - guidelines sample drawing title water meters in meter room bulk water meters in chamber (for bulk meters 50 mm and greater diameter connection) 50 mm diameter bulk water meter installation in chamber (2 in meter with ldpe connection) table g.33 dewa specifications and sample drawings for design and installation of water meters g 102 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.10 district cooling g.10.1 general g.10.3 common technical requirements e) ets shall be provided with electric power, this section identifies coordination requirements and common technical requirements related to district cooling installations and their connection to building cooling systems. g.10.2 coordination with district cooling providers depending on location of development, customer shall contact relevant district cooling provider to obtain latest district cooling technical design guidelines ref. g.9

dewa specification sample drawing number pew-std- ami-003 pew-std- ami-004 pew-std- ami-005 domestic water meter installation in meter room - guidelines bulk meter installation in chamber - guidelines bulk meter installation in chamber - guidelines sample drawing title water meters in meter room bulk water meters in chamber (for bulk meters 50 mm and greater diameter connection) 50 mm diameter bulk water meter installation in chamber (2 in meter with ldpe connection) table g.33 dewa specifications and sample drawings for design and installation of water meters g 102 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.10 district cooling g.10.1 general g.10.3 common technical requirements e) ets shall be provided with electric power, this section identifies coordination requirements and common technical requirements related to district cooling installations and their connection to building cooling systems. g.10.2 coordination with district cooling providers depending on location of development, customer shall contact relevant district cooling provider to obtain latest district cooling technical design guidelines ref. g.9
coordination shall start in concept design phase and continue as necessary in later design stages. scope of work shall be agreed as part of service agreement between two parties
note district cooling providers in dubai include (but not limited to) those listed in ref. g.9

building design parameters shall conform to district cooling providers specific technical and interface requirements ref. g.9. following parameters shall be determined as minimum a) cooling capacity requirements b) pipe connection size c) supply/return chilled water temperature on primary and secondary sides d) maximum allowable system pressure and e) design water velocities/pressure drop

g 103 following common technical requirements shall be met for all developments featuring district cooling. note 1 list provided to assist customers but does not replace requirements from district cooling providers. a) energy transfer station (ets) shall accommodate district cooling providers heat exchangers (hexs), and all associated equipment for primary and secondary sides of hexs. chilled water system configuration shall be determined by customer and coordinated with district cooling provider
note 2 figure g.56 and figure g.57 show examples of installed ets pipework and pumps
b) secondary side shall include all equipment for supplying chilled water to premises. pipework installation shall conform to requirements identified in h.4.13

c) location, configuration and space dimension for ets and valve chamber (vc) shall be agreed taking into account route and availability of main district cooling pipes. space planning for ets, including accessibility of ets plant, shall be included in design at concept design phase
d) structural engineer shall design supporting structure to withstand loading imposed by equipment in ets and along equipment access route

lighting, communication, potable water, drainage, ventilation and cooling in accordance with part g and part h. f) district cooling facility, including but not limited to ets, cooling towers and other mechanical and electrical plant rooms, shall conform to fire safety requirements of ch. 14 of uae flsc ref. g.1

lighting, communication, potable water, drainage, ventilation and cooling in accordance with part g and part h. f) district cooling facility, including but not limited to ets, cooling towers and other mechanical and electrical plant rooms, shall conform to fire safety requirements of ch. 14 of uae flsc ref. g.1

lighting, communication, potable water, drainage, ventilation and cooling in accordance with part g and part h. f) district cooling facility, including but not limited to ets, cooling towers and other mechanical and electrical plant rooms, shall conform to fire safety requirements of ch. 14 of uae flsc ref. g.1

g) in accordance with service agreement, district cooling provider or customer shall provide heat exchanger (hexs) and primary side chilled water installation (including all piping from underground) to vc, and to and inside ets

h) district cooling provider shall design vc in coordination with relevant authorities and based on premises load demand. vc civil construction shall be carried out by customer or district cooling provider in accordance with service agreement. i) smart energy metering system shall be provided in accordance with h.4.14 as part of primary chiller water system
j) customer shall provide secondary side chilled water piping systems pumps, cooling coils, and control valves and electrical equipment
k) secondary chilled water circuit design shall align with supply stated by district cooling provider, and shall return chilled water temperatures

dubai building code part g incoming utilities l) chilled water distribution system and control q) secondary side chilled water distribution u) industrial grade programme logic controller (plc)/human machine interface (hmi) controller with open protocol capability shall be provided in ets. ets plc shall be integrated with other control systems in district cooling plant and associated building. single mode fibre-optic connectivity shall be included with district cooling plant and ets integration. sleeves for fibre-optic shall be included along with chilled water pipe and both shall be extended up to ets plc control panel
v) chilled water pipes and fibre-optics to vc/ interface point shall be routed in accordance with service agreement. ets room shall be located as close as possible to plot vc and plot limit

note 3 district cooling provider might choose to review design of secondary side chilled water distribution and air handling equipment, to give confidence that allowable chilled water temperature difference likely to be achieved
system on secondary side shall be designed as variable flow chilled water system. it shall use two- way control type valves, e.g. pressure independent control valves
system shall be accurately flow-balanced in order to achieve specified temperature difference. this work shall be performed in accordance with balancing principles for variable flow systems
r) pumps shall be provided with variable frequency drives (vfds). pump vfds shall be specified with necessary communication protocol to allow district cooling provider to monitor status of vfds
s) differential pressure transmitters shall meet following minimum requirements
1) they shall be of industrial grade, and suitable for environment in which they installed

2) they shall provide dc output of 4 to 20 with maximum loop resistance of 1,000 . 3) they shall be linear in function, with differential pressure, and capable of isolation from pipes that they monitor
t) specific products to be used for pumps, vfds, and differential pressure and temperature transmitters utilized on secondary circuits shall be agreed and confirmed with district cooling provider
t) specific products to be used for pumps, vfds, and differential pressure and temperature transmitters utilized on secondary circuits shall be agreed and confirmed with district cooling provider

m) secondary side system shall incorporate bypass to avoid chilled water stagnation. minimum pump flow shall correspond to maximum chilled water flow of 5% of full design flow. n) chilled water pumping system installed in secondary side in ets shall allow chilled water flow to vary between 5% and 100% of full design flow. chilled water pumping design and arrangement shall account for redundancy and part load conditions (during winter/night-time operation)

o) secondary system pipework shall be flushed, cleaned and provided with chemical dosing to provide corrosion protection, and to enable minimum required water condition parameters of district cooling provider to be achieved. flushing shall be carried out using bypass to avoid flow of contaminated water through hexs. p) water sample shall be analysed by district cooling provider-approved testing laboratory, to verify conformity to specified water quality parameters. analysis results shall be submitted to district cooling provider before any water flow allowed through hexs

g 104 dubai building code part g incoming utilities figure g.57 examples of ets pumps figure g.56 examples of ets pipework g 105 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.11 telecommunications g.11.1 telecommunications infrastructure design and installation of g.11.1.1 general requirements this section provides requirements for design of all telecommunications (telecom) infrastructure installations within any development including new build, greenfield, redevelopment, brownfield, and additions, alterations, renovations or refurbishments to existing buildings, in dubai

these requirements based on version two of telecommunication regulatory authority (tra), in- building telecommunication network  specification manual guidelines for fttx in new buildings ref. g.10. if tra updated to give more stringent requirements, these shall be used in preference to dbc

this section specifies minimum requirements to provide baseline infrastructure. there no restriction to extending baseline, provided that design meets requirements in this section and does not prevent competition, e.g. by using proprietary standards. all telecom infrastructure shall enable each user/ tenant freedom of choice between telecommunication service providers (sps). g 106 requirements cover all of following aspects of infrastructure a) civil infrastructure and entry ducts b) fibre concentration point (fcp) space(s) per development or plot c) meet-me-room (mmr) space(s) per development or plot d) telecom rooms e) indoor mobile service and rooftop rooms f) building pathways g) osp cables h) isp cables

this section specifies minimum requirements to provide baseline infrastructure. there no restriction to extending baseline, provided that design meets requirements in this section and does not prevent competition, e.g. by using proprietary standards. all telecom infrastructure shall enable each user/ tenant freedom of choice between telecommunication service providers (sps). g 106 requirements cover all of following aspects of infrastructure a) civil infrastructure and entry ducts b) fibre concentration point (fcp) space(s) per development or plot c) meet-me-room (mmr) space(s) per development or plot d) telecom rooms e) indoor mobile service and rooftop rooms f) building pathways g) osp cables h) isp cables

this section specifies minimum requirements to provide baseline infrastructure. there no restriction to extending baseline, provided that design meets requirements in this section and does not prevent competition, e.g. by using proprietary standards. all telecom infrastructure shall enable each user/ tenant freedom of choice between telecommunication service providers (sps). g 106 requirements cover all of following aspects of infrastructure a) civil infrastructure and entry ducts b) fibre concentration point (fcp) space(s) per development or plot c) meet-me-room (mmr) space(s) per development or plot d) telecom rooms e) indoor mobile service and rooftop rooms f) building pathways g) osp cables h) isp cables

this section specifies minimum requirements to provide baseline infrastructure. there no restriction to extending baseline, provided that design meets requirements in this section and does not prevent competition, e.g. by using proprietary standards. all telecom infrastructure shall enable each user/ tenant freedom of choice between telecommunication service providers (sps). g 106 requirements cover all of following aspects of infrastructure a) civil infrastructure and entry ducts b) fibre concentration point (fcp) space(s) per development or plot c) meet-me-room (mmr) space(s) per development or plot d) telecom rooms e) indoor mobile service and rooftop rooms f) building pathways g) osp cables h) isp cables
passive optical fibre infrastructure shall be provided to support deployment of fttx. copper access networks shall not be used for sp services

all buildings shall be equipped with physical infrastructure capable of supporting multiple high- speed sp networks which can be easily accessed by sp. developer shall assume minimum of two active sps in region, but may future-proof infrastructure by incorporating provision to support possible third sp

new installations shall be based upon minimum of category 6 balanced twisted pair cabling as specified in iso 11801 1. designers may future-proof designs by providing category 6 cabling, which supports higher data rates and provides support for newer power- over-ethernet (poe) standards that typically used for video surveillance camera and wireless local area network access points. where category 6 specified, unshielded twisted pair (utp) or shielded twisted pair (stp) may be utilized
category 6 cabling (structured cabling system) shall as minimum conform to requirements specified in g.11.4.10.7

cabling within tenant space (e.g. multi-tenanted commercial/retail building, home, unit, flat, apartment, single family home or similar) for onward distribution of services beyond tenant equipment not in scope of these requirements

requirements of this section do not replace detailed specification, act as instruction for untrained persons, or provide for every specific design circumstance. for situations beyond scope of these requirements, tra shall be consulted to obtain further clarity and guidance

dubai building code part g incoming utilities special buildings or development areas (e.g. hospitals, shopping malls, stadiums, data centres, public buildings) will need further enhanced requirements. individual agreements shall be bespoke and beyond that of minimum requirements established in this section
installations where special telecom requirements might exist shall be referred to registered dubai sp at preliminary design stage to incorporate any specific requirements above that of this section

telecoms service g.11.1.2 to support deployment of sp optical broadband networks and services, developer shall design and install in-building elements of telecom infrastructure up to and within single and multi-tenant premises (to include single or multiple buildings, villa complex, warehouses, etc.)

g) pathways shall not run through areas exposed to m) risers and cable pathways allocated for sp use 1) excessive heat (i.e. areas in direct sun or rooms with heat generating equipment) 2) moisture 3) corrosive atmospheric or environmental conditions 4) high voltages 5) radio frequency interference (rfi) or 6) electromagnetic interference (emi)

g 134 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.11.4.9.4 high density connectorized modular splitter specification high density (2 in  32 out and 2 in  8 out) connectorized modular splitters shall be used for buildings of more than 100 units. they shall meet following requirements
a) modular splitters shall be fitted inside splitter chassis (sub-rack)
b) each splitter chassis (sub-rack) shall be 483 mm (19 in) with in-built cable management facility to route uplink and downlink fibre patch cords
c) each splitter chassis (sub-rack) shall have eight (2 in  32 out) modular splitters with lc/apc connector type
d) each splitter chassis (sub-rack) shall have four (2 in  32 out) modular splitters with sc/apc connector type
e) each splitter chassis (sub-rack) shall have 12 (2 in  8 out) modular splitters with operator specific connector type
f) each splitter chassis (sub-rack) shall be 3u to 4u in height

j) for etisalat 1) for buildings up to 256 units, (2 in  32 out) and (2 in  8 out) patch-free splitters with splicing trays shall be provided 2) for buildings of 256 or more units, uplink and downlink ports of (2 in  32 out and 2 in  8 out) modular splitters shall have sc/apc connectors

g.11.4.9.5 low-density connectorized splitter specification low-density (2 in  32 out and 2 in  8 out) connectorized splitters shall be used for building with less than 100 units. they shall meet following requirements
a) low-density splitters shall be 483 mm (19 in), 1u, rack mountable
b) low-density splitters shall have in-built cable management facility to route uplink and downlink fibre patch cords
c) uplink and downlink ports of (2 in  32 out) and (2 in  8 out) splitters shall have lc/apc connectors for du

g) each modular splitter shall have visible label holder d) for buildings with less than 256 units, e) each splitter shall have two uplink ports (two inputs). uplink ports of splitters with uplink patch panels shall be connected in following order 1) first uplink port of splitter shall be connected to main uplink patch panel 2) second uplink port of splitter shall be connected to redundant uplink patch panel

g.11.4.9.6 multicore fibre cable termination fibre termination components shall be provided to splice multicore sm fibre cables with 4-core sm drop cables. termination components shall meet following requirements
a) 4-port fibre terminal box (with lc/apc and sc/ apc pigtails and adaptors) inside 12u cabinet of tenant premises (office/retail/warehouse)
b) fully loaded high- or low-density fibre patch panels with adaptors and pigtails inside mtr for sps
c) ftr mini odfs with splice trays to splice multicore fibre cables with respective 4-core drop cables
for unique identification
h) modular splitters shall have easy snap-in design which requires no tools
i) for du, uplink and downlink ports of (2 in  32 out and 2 in  8 out) modular splitters shall have lc/ apc connectors
g 135 (2 in  32 out) and (2 in  8 out) optical patch-free splitters with splicing trays shall be provided for etisalat
dubai building code part g incoming utilities all optical fibre testing shall be completed in accordance with iso/iec-14763-3

optical fibre cable required shall have following common general specifications of a) sm b) indoor grade c) cable jacket and microducts to be halogen-free and flame-retardant material (lszh type) d) air blown micro-cable in accordance with itu-t g.657 a1/a2 e) fibre optic colour coding in accordance with iso 11801-1 f) microducts for air blown micro-cables installation and g) bend-insensitive
drop fibre cable shall be 1) flexible drop fibre and 2) 4-core cable, flat cross-section
multicore fibre cable shall i) be flexi-tube (gel free) micro-cable/micro-bundle cable of 24 fibre cores and above and ii) have tight buffer structure up to 12 fibre cores

g.11.4.10.2 villa complexes and warehouses for villa complexes and warehouse developments, sp shall provide fibre optic cables. developer shall supply consolidation cabinet and 4-core fibre termination box installed inside consolidation cabinet. g.11.4.10.3 mtr to consolidation cabinet (direct fibre) direct fibre installation may be applied in mixed use developments of low-rise buildings, accommodation blocks and/or villa complexes having common mtr
fibre optic cables shall be provided from mtr to each consolidation cabinet. fibres shall pass through ftr and shall be continuous lengths, free from joints, branches or patching

g.11.4.10.4 mtr to ftr mini odf (multicore fibre) multicore fibre installation may be installed in high- rise buildings, malls or other large buildings, based on building type, quantity of tenant units and structure

number of fibre cores required per floor ftr calculated as shown in table g.44. multicore fibre cable shall be provided from mtr to mini odf inside ftr. g.11.4.10 fibre and copper cables g.11.4.10.1 general all cables (and connecting accessories) shall be selected from approved product list held by sps

all fixed and permanently installed telecom cables within building shall be halogen-free, achieve minimum rating of euroclass cca-s1b,d2,a2 when tested in accordance with bs en 13501-6 and be ce marked
note ce marking represents manufacturers declaration that products conform to applicable manufacturing and testing standard

unless for specific development type, fibre optic cables shall be supplied, spliced, labelled and tested inside mtr, ftr, and consolidation cabinets by developer. this shall include supply and installation of fibre optic cables and their related accessories
fibre optic design shall be based on building type, number of tenant units and structure
all fibre cables shall be continuous lengths free from joints and splices

multicore fibre cables shall be directly spliced to 4-core fibre cables using mini odf cabinet inside ftrs. multicore fibres shall be terminated directly into optical patch panels in mtr. these patch panels shall be used to patch to each sps splitter

g.11.4.11 bulk service developer responsible for designing and implementing bulk service infrastructure to support landlord building facility management and security applications, and in specific circumstances tenant business requirements

note this kind of service solution usually applied to projects/buildings having their own it network (single- tenant) such as hotels, hospitals, schools, universities, banks, airports and other similar establishments

note this kind of service solution usually applied to projects/buildings having their own it network (single- tenant) such as hotels, hospitals, schools, universities, banks, airports and other similar establishments

client shall have it server room and minimum of one dedicated mtr (figure g.78) for sp telecom/ network equipment installation. tenant/client shall provide written requirements during design stage, confirming bulk service and explaining service required to be provided up to client it room
exact requirements related to telecom cabling and em requirements shall be determined during design stage based on clients service requirements

for bulk services setup tenant/client shall a) install 483 mm (19 in) 42u free standing rack within mtr b) install and test 12 core fibre cable between mtr and client it server room, terminating fibre cables at both ends using 12-port fibre patch panels 1) cores one to six shall be allocated to connect etisalat equipment 2) cores seven to 12 shall be allocated to connect du equipment c) install and test 24 category 6 copper cables between mtr and client it server room 1) ports one to 12 shall be allocated to connect etisalat equipment 2) ports 13 to 24 shall be allocated to connect du equipment d) install main and spare optical splitter(s) and patch panels e) install two 12-port sc/apc pre-terminated fibre patch panels to each sp uplink fibre f) provide sc/apc adaptors and pigtail for fibre interfaces g) extend 300 mm  50 mm hdrf cable tray from mtr to client it server room

distance between mtr and client it server room shall be within 70 (to remain within 90 permanent link distance limitation, while provisioning fixed services over copper cables). g 141 dubai building code part g incoming utilities g.11.4.12 labelling scheme g.11.4.12.1 general installed system shall be administered in accordance with iso/iec 14763-1. all sections of installation shall be provided with suitable identification labels to clearly indicate location and purpose of each item or cable. instructions and optical fibre caution notices shall also be provided. all labels shall be in both english and arabic. letter sizes shall be selected to suit individual applications

g.11.4.12.2 sp gaid and eid identification plate for each unit/tenant sp identification plate (see figure g.79) shall be installed at door entrance of residential/commercial units. identification plate shall be made of plastic or light metal with alphanumeric characters (gaid or eid) engraved on it
gaid and eid reference number details shall be made available to developer during inspection stage

h.5, h.8 building shall provide drainage systems to collect and convey drainage flows in safe and efficient manner
h.6, h.8 building shall safeguard people from undue noise being transmitted from adjacent spaces, occupancies and exterior
h.10 building shall provide artificial lighting to enable safe movement when there insufficient natural light
building shall provide appropriate digital services enablement, ensuring interoperability and future-proofing of communications

h.7, h.8 h.11 h 2 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.2 definitions h.2.1 terms hvac and occupant comfort h.2.1.1 air contaminants unwanted airborne constituents that might reduce acceptability or adequacy of air quality

air leakage air that escapes from or to building through joint, coupling, junction, or surfaces which enclose building. flow of uncontrolled air within building through cracks or openings. air ventilation share of supply air that outdoor air, plus any recirculated air that has filtered or otherwise treated to maintain acceptable indoor air quality

air leakage air that escapes from or to building through joint, coupling, junction, or surfaces which enclose building. flow of uncontrolled air within building through cracks or openings. air ventilation share of supply air that outdoor air, plus any recirculated air that has filtered or otherwise treated to maintain acceptable indoor air quality
air volume amount (volume) of air delivered to space through ventilation, typically specified in litres per second or cubic metres per minute

h 3 building management system (bms) computer- based control system which controls and monitors mechanical and electrical equipment in building, such as ventilation, lighting, power systems, fire systems, and security systems, or controls and monitors number of buildings
building services all necessary services required to operate building such as plumbing, mechanical, electrical and others
cooling tower approach difference between leaving water temperature and entering air wet- bulb temperature in cooling tower

demand controlled ventilation (dcv) ventilation system that provides for automatic reduction of outdoor air intake below design rates, when actual occupancy of spaces served by system less than design occupancy. demand often assessed by using measure of amount of carbon dioxide (co2) in space to reflect occupancy levels

demand controlled ventilation (dcv) ventilation system that provides for automatic reduction of outdoor air intake below design rates, when actual occupancy of spaces served by system less than design occupancy. demand often assessed by using measure of amount of carbon dioxide (co2) in space to reflect occupancy levels
diversity factor relates to thermal characteristics of building envelope, temperature swings and occupancy load
control systems localized controls that allow users to change/adjust level of lighting and air-conditioning in space

ductwork leakage escape of air through cracks and gaps when air-conditioning ductwork not airtight. ductwork leakage results in increase in energy consumption of supply and return air fans. exhaust air air removed from building space and discharged to outside of building through mechanical or natural ventilation system

global warming potential (gwp) contribution of greenhouse gases released to atmosphere in global warming phenomenon. dubai building code part h indoor environment heat load calculation process of calculating total heat generated inside building by various sources

heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system (hvac) equipment, distribution systems, and terminals that provide either individually or collectively, processes of heating, ventilating, or air- conditioning to building or portion of building

make-up air (dedicated replacement air) air deliberately brought into building from outdoors and supplied to vicinity of exhaust hood to replace air and cooking effluent being exhausted. make-up air generally filtered and fan- forced, and it can be heated or cooled depending on requirements of application

minimum efficiency reporting value (merv) filtering efficiency of air filter that has evaluated using ashrae 52.2 test procedure. air filters performance determined by comparing airborne particle counts upstream and downstream of air filter (or other air cleaning device) under test conditions. higher merv rating equates to higher air filtration efficiency

minimum efficiency reporting value (merv) filtering efficiency of air filter that has evaluated using ashrae 52.2 test procedure. air filters performance determined by comparing airborne particle counts upstream and downstream of air filter (or other air cleaning device) under test conditions. higher merv rating equates to higher air filtration efficiency
monitoring equipment equipment used to measure, and record status or conditions related to building or to verify pre-set conditions and provide control or alarm functions if conditions vary
negative pressure pressure less than that in adjoining spaces
space pressurization static pressure difference between adjacent spaces of building, with air tending to move from higher-pressure spaces to lower- pressure spaces

supply air air entering space from air- conditioning, heating, or ventilating system for purpose of comfort conditioning. supply air generally filtered, fan-forced, and heated, cooled, humidified, or dehumidified as necessary to maintain specified temperature and humidity conditions. only quantity of outdoor air within supply air flow used as replacement air. thermal comfort condition of mind which expresses satisfaction with thermal environment. thermal comfort measurement subjective in nature as it depends on environmental and personal factors

thermal insulation materials/products or methods and processes used to reduce heat transfer. heat energy can be transferred by conduction, convection or radiation. flow of heat can be delayed by addressing one or more of these mechanisms and dependent on physical properties of material employed to do this
h 4 dubai building code part h indoor environment thermal transmittance rate of transfer of heat through material(s) or assembly, expressed as u-value

transfer air air transferred from one room to another through openings in room envelope, whether it transferred intentionally or not. driving force for transfer air generally small pressure differential between rooms
h.2.1.2 water supplies backflow flow upstream, that in direction contrary to intended normal direction of flow, within or from water fitting
deadleg length of water system pipework leading to fitting through which water only passes infrequently when there draw off from fitting, providing potential for stagnation
microbiological bacteria microorganism capable of causing disease that can be transmitted via water supply

pumped hot water return domestic hot water return system that uses pump to generate circulation in pipework system. raw water tank tank that stores non-potable water and has not received any form of water treatment
thermal balancing valve automatic valve that balances hot water return subcircuits

water outlet opening for discharge of water via plumbing fixture such as tap or showerhead. drainage h.2.1.3 cesspit holding tank installed below ground that used for temporary collection of faecal matter

drainage system system composed of drainage equipment, and other components collecting waste water and discharging by means of gravity, or effluent pumping plant which can be part of gravity drainage system. floor gully discharge fitting intended to receive water from floors through apertures in grating or from waste pipes that connect to floor gully body or trap. grease trap appliance used to intercept fats, oils and grease from kitchen appliances. greywater waste water not containing faecal matter or urine

manhole chamber construction that provides access into drainage system. chamber dimensions permit person entry at sewer drain level (if required). h 5 dubai building code part h indoor environment oil separator below-ground vessel used to intercept contaminated drainage flows that incorporate oil or petrol
rainwater water resulting from natural precipitation that has not deliberately contaminated
sanitary fittings fixed appliances supplied with water that used for cleaning and washing (i.e. baths, showers, wash basins, bidets, water closets, urinals, dishwashers and washing machines)
sanitary fittings fixed appliances supplied with water that used for cleaning and washing (i.e. baths, showers, wash basins, bidets, water closets, urinals, dishwashers and washing machines)
sanitary fittings fixed appliances supplied with water that used for cleaning and washing (i.e. baths, showers, wash basins, bidets, water closets, urinals, dishwashers and washing machines)
sanitation pipework arrangement of discharge pipework, with or without ventilated pipes, connected to drainage system
soakaway buried drainage feature used to manage surface water on-site and infiltrate into surrounding ground
h 6 upper floor any floor above lowest level, which could be basement level

exit discharge portion of means of egress between termination of exit and public way. ventilation pipework main vertical ventilating pipe, connected to discharge stack, to limit pressure fluctuations within discharge stack. wastewater water which contaminated by use and all water discharging into drainage system

exit discharge portion of means of egress between termination of exit and public way. ventilation pipework main vertical ventilating pipe, connected to discharge stack, to limit pressure fluctuations within discharge stack. wastewater water which contaminated by use and all water discharging into drainage system
water trap device that prevents foul air by means of water seal
h.2.1.4 noise unwanted sound
acoustics reverberation time time, measured in seconds (s), taken for sound to decay by 60 db after sound source has stopped
reverberation persistence of sound in space after sound source has stopped
sound pressure level physical intensity of sound, measured in decibels (db)

fire safety h.2.1.5 exit portion of means of egress that separated from all other spaces of building or structure by construction, location or equipment as required to provide protected way of travel from exit access to exit discharge. exit access portion of means of egress that leads to exit

fire safety h.2.1.5 exit portion of means of egress that separated from all other spaces of building or structure by construction, location or equipment as required to provide protected way of travel from exit access to exit discharge. exit access portion of means of egress that leads to exit
high-rise building building height greater than or equal to 23 and up to 90 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. h.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc
super high-rise building building height greater than 90 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. h.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc

lighting h.2.1.6 electronic ballast piece of equipment required to control starting and operating voltages of fluorescent lights. electronic lighting ballasts use solid state circuitry and can greatly reduce or eliminate any flicker in lamps. lighting power density electrical power consumed by lighting installation per unit floor area (w/m2) or unit length, linear metre (w/lm) of illuminated space

lux unit of illuminance, measuring luminous flux per unit area. dubai building code part h indoor environment digital services enablement and ict h.2.1.7 application programming interface (api) computing interface provided by application, system, or service which provides other applications with method to connect and interact with it. bacnet communication protocol for building automation and control networks. bacnet interfaces widely implemented in hvac and bms systems worldwide and likely to be supported long-term
cable pathway any system used to route cables, such as cable ducting, cable ladder, cable tray, conduit, duct and maintenance chamber
data governance set of processes to manage availability, usability, integrity and security of data in enterprise systems

digital services enablement process of future- proofing buildings smart application potential, by providing fundamental connectivity requirements in terms of infrastructure, systems and technology throughout design, construction and building operation stages of project. this approach allows for future implementation of smart functionalities, use cases and downstream initiatives that might not initially be defined, thereby providing flexibility in terms of timescale and adaptability in terms of meeting operator or occupier functional requirements. such initiatives might include, but not limited to, analytics, alerts, calculations, dashboards and prediction models

fieldbus family of process control protocols that widely used for real-time distributed control. internet of things (iot) system of devices embedded with sensors, software and network connectivity, that provided with unique identifiers. devices have ability of being responsive, as they collect and exchange data over network without requiring human-to-human or human-to-computer interaction

interoperability ability of different suppliers products to share data and intelligence in more open way which provides opportunities to create new use cases by combining and integrating various functions across different operational systems and their smart devices. interoperability key principle for smart buildings, iot and ict infrastructure design
javascript object notation (json) open standard data interchange format using text format

konnex (knx) field protocol which overlaps with bacnet use cases and which supports communication scenarios between products common in building control. device capabilities sufficiently standardized such that it possible to combine devices from different manufacturers into common system or network. lonworks internationally standardized proprietary protocol that overlaps with bacnet use cases. it offers several physical communications solutions for field devices.

main equipment room (mer) equipment room accommodating centralized network switching and communications equipment supporting building systems and information technology (it) application servers belonging to landlord, anchor tenant or owner-occupier. m-bus communication protocol developed to provide communications interface specifically for consumption meters
message queueing telemetry transport (mqtt) open iot protocol which supports publish/subscribe method for messaging between devices
modbus general-purpose digital communications bus which suits devices with very constrained capabilities. modbus commonly offered in devices such as electrical meters and some hvac applications

open platform communications (opc) communications standard used for system integration. object payloads typically binary in construction with origin and consumer applications both typically ms windows applications. recent standardization efforts extend opc to allow implementation on c and java platforms as well as windows api, and add methods of expressing communications as xml or web services. h 7 dubai building code part h indoor environment operational technology hardware, software, gateways and devices that support monitoring and control of various processes within facility. term typically used to cover facility and process systems such as bms and scada, as opposed to traditional corporate it systems. supervisory control and data acquisition (scada) system used to monitor and control process-based plant or equipment. scada systems typically deployed in main utility controls (e.g. power, water, gas, sewage) and/or where control system required to integrate other individual control systems. use case interaction between user and smart functionality within smart or digital building. use case describes how user expected to use technology for completion of task

secondary equipment room (ser) equipment room accommodating distributed network switching and communications equipment supporting building systems and it application servers belonging to landlord, anchor tenant or owner-occupier. equivalent alternative name secondary communications room
sensor networks network of interconnected sensor nodes that collect data about surrounding environment
smart gateway gateway device which provides smart interface to allow subsystem operating on closed protocol to communicate over encrypted tcp/ip connection using open iot protocol

smart interface/iot interface interface which allows internet scalable addressability and security communication over encrypted tcp/ip connection, using open iot protocols. smart meter smart meters provide near-real-time information on energy consumption. it helps to control and manage energy use, save money, switch energy supplier more quickly, and reduce carbon emissions. h 8 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.2.2 aav ahu amca ansi api ashrae asme astm av acronyms and abbreviations air admittance valve air handling unit air movement and control association international, inc

h 17 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.4 hvac systems and occupant comfort h.4.1 general this section sets out minimum requirements and basis of design for heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (hvac) systems and thermal comfort within buildings. relevant sustainability criteria and cross-references to uae flsc ref. h.1 included. hvac systems shall be designed to minimize energy usage and ensure comfort of building occupants. systems shall be selected to ensure long life, easy maintenance, and simple and effective controls. for systems or applications not covered by this section, design solutions and guidance shall be obtained from current edition of ashrae handbooks, guides and standards

requirements for healthcare buildings, and all relevant codes and standards, identified within dubai health authority (dha) regulations ref. h.2 to ref. h.11 and dha health facility guidelines ref. h.12 to ref. h.16

requirements for healthcare buildings, and all relevant codes and standards, identified within dubai health authority (dha) regulations ref. h.2 to ref. h.11 and dha health facility guidelines ref. h.12 to ref. h.16
penetrations of floor/ceiling assemblies, and any assemblies that required to have fire-resistance rating, shall be protected in accordance with section 3, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. h.1
h.4.3 equipment and appliance location hvac equipment and appliances shall not be installed in hazardous location unless listed and approved for specific installation
fuel-fired appliances shall not be in, or obtain combustion air from, any of following rooms or spaces a) sleeping rooms b) bathrooms c) toilet rooms d) storage closets e) surgical rooms

h.4.2 protection of structure building or structure shall not be weakened by installation of mechanical systems. mechanical equipment to be supported by structure and any associated seismic bracing shall be coordinated with structural engineer. installation of mechanical systems over structural joints should be avoided. if that not possible, flexible ducts/pipes may be used. this subsection does not apply to direct-vent appliances that obtain all combustion air directly from outdoors

h.4.2 protection of structure building or structure shall not be weakened by installation of mechanical systems. mechanical equipment to be supported by structure and any associated seismic bracing shall be coordinated with structural engineer. installation of mechanical systems over structural joints should be avoided. if that not possible, flexible ducts/pipes may be used. this subsection does not apply to direct-vent appliances that obtain all combustion air directly from outdoors
appliances shall not be installed where they might be subject to mechanical damage unless protected by approved barriers
appliances installed in outdoor locations shall be approved by authority for outdoor installation

mechanical equipment and systems shall not be installed in elevator shaft. where any portion of building or structure needs to be altered or replaced in process of installing or repairing any mechanical system, building or structure shall be left in safe structural condition in accordance with part f. individual heat rejection equipment having power rating greater than 4.0 kw, and which exhausts externally, shall be installed not less than 3 above external ground level of building
to reduce damage to property from leaks, fan coil units shall be installed in wet areas in residential apartment buildings

h 18 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.4.4 access and service space h.4.5 acoustic requirements and noise criteria hvac equipment and appliances shall be accessible for inspection, service, repair and replacement. access shall not necessitate disabling function of fire-resistance- rated assembly, or removing any of following a) permanent construction b) other appliances and c) venting systems or other piping or ducts not connected to appliance being inspected, serviced, repaired or replaced

h 18 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.4.4 access and service space h.4.5 acoustic requirements and noise criteria hvac equipment and appliances shall be accessible for inspection, service, repair and replacement. access shall not necessitate disabling function of fire-resistance- rated assembly, or removing any of following a) permanent construction b) other appliances and c) venting systems or other piping or ducts not connected to appliance being inspected, serviced, repaired or replaced
requirements given in ashrae 180 shall be met for hvac systems

level working space at least 762 mm  762 mm shall be provided in front of control side to service appliance. rooms containing appliances shall be provided with door and unobstructed access path measuring not less than 915 mm wide  2.3 high. where equipment and appliances requiring access installed on roofs or elevated structures at height exceeding 4,800 mm, such access shall be provided by permanent approved means of access

ch. 49, table 1 of ashrae hvac applications handbook ref. h.17 identifies design guidelines for acceptable noise levels for hvac-related background noise for range of typical building and room types. these design guidelines shall be used as basis for determining acceptable noise levels for specific occupancy. if higher or lower value considered desirable, analysis of economics, space use and user needs shall be obtained from acoustic consultant to determine appropriate value

ch. 49, table 1 of ashrae hvac applications handbook ref. h.17 identifies design guidelines for acceptable noise levels for hvac-related background noise for range of typical building and room types. these design guidelines shall be used as basis for determining acceptable noise levels for specific occupancy. if higher or lower value considered desirable, analysis of economics, space use and user needs shall be obtained from acoustic consultant to determine appropriate value

experienced acoustic consultant shall be engaged to provide guidance on acoustically critical spaces such as (but not limited to) audio control rooms, broadcasting studios, places of worship, lecture theatres, cinemas, shopping malls, gymnasium located over habitable spaces, school auditoria and for all performing arts spaces. note further details given in h.10

h 19 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.4.6 building hvac energy load general h.4.6.1 building hvac loads typically dominate buildings energy consumption (see figure h.1). to minimize building hvac energy load, envelope design and fabric selections shall meet minimum performance requirements for building envelope (see part e) and, where necessary, building energy load targets identified in ashrae 90.1

09 01 key 01 ahu  5% outdoor design conditions h.4.6.2 design criteria values shown in table h.1 shall be used for outdoor design conditions in dubai

design criteria dry bulb temperature relative humidity value to be used 24 c 1.5 c 50% 5% table h.2 indoor design conditions for dubai 08 07 06 05 03 chiller  35% 04 fcu  10% 05 lights  10% 06 package ac units  5% 07 primary pump  5% 08 secondary pump  5% 09 split ac  10% 04 03 figure h.1 typical building energy load profile energy load of air-conditioned buildings shall be calculated in accordance with h.4.6.2 to h.4.6.7

h 20 dubai building code part h indoor environment indoor design conditions might vary depending on occupancy or use of building. ashrae hvac applications handbook ref. h.17 shall be used as reference for all indoor design conditions for specific occupancies or usage

h 20 dubai building code part h indoor environment indoor design conditions might vary depending on occupancy or use of building. ashrae hvac applications handbook ref. h.17 shall be used as reference for all indoor design conditions for specific occupancies or usage
external load criteria h.4.6.6 building envelope shall meet requirements in part e to determine thermal transmittance and shading coefficients

when diversity factors to be used in heat load calculations not known, coefficients indicated in ashrae fundamentals handbook ref. h.18, ch. 18 shall be used. following safety factors shall be applied a) sensible heat 10% b) latent heat 5%

outdoor air design conditions h.4.6.4 all buildings that fully air-conditioned shall be provided with outdoor air system. system shall ensure that building provided with treated outdoor air for at least 95% of year. following maximum design temperatures shall be used a) dry bulb temperature 34 c b) wet bulb temperature 32 c

heat gain and loss calculations h.4.6.5 heat load calculations shall be carried out for each air-conditioned space, including peak load incidence in that space. calculations shall be carried out using software registered with authority

following parameters shall be taken into account in building load calculations a) building envelope orientation b) building envelope design and construction details c) building floor plans d) building elevations and sections e) impact of external shading factors (see e.5.3) and f) any special requirements for building use or operation

internal load criteria h.4.6.7 h.4.6.7.1 occupancy total number of occupants within building shall be determined based on room occupancy data provided by client or architect. occupant loads shall be determined in accordance with b.5.1

internal load criteria h.4.6.7 h.4.6.7.1 occupancy total number of occupants within building shall be determined based on room occupancy data provided by client or architect. occupant loads shall be determined in accordance with b.5.1

where occupancy density for each space not identified, default occupancy density values stated in ashrae 62.1, ashrae 62.2 and ashrae 170 shall be used. lighting h.4.6.7.2 project-specific lighting loads shall be used. where lighting loads not available, they shall be determined based on recommendations in ashrae 90.1

h.4.6.7.3 electrical equipment loads project specific electrical equipment loads shall be used. where equipment loads not available, they shall be as recommended in ashrae 90.1 for each application type

h 21 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.4.7 thermal comfort criteria hvac systems shall be capable of providing range of internal conditions in table h.3, for 95% of year. variable dry bulb temperature relative humidity lower limit 22.5 c 30% (min) table h.3 thermal comfort requirements upper limit 25.5 c 60% (max) for occupant comfort, normal occupied spaces shall have average air velocity between 0.2 m/s and 0.3 m/s

h.4.8 energy conservation and efficiency building systems minimum efficiency of hvac systems h.4.8.1 hvac equipment and systems shall meet minimum energy efficiency requirements and test procedures, approved by emirates authority for standardization and metrology (esma), as specified in following tables of uae.s 5010-5 a) table 1 split and packaged unit including cassette type unit b) table 2 water source heat pumps c) table 4 multiple split unit

h.4.8 energy conservation and efficiency building systems minimum efficiency of hvac systems h.4.8.1 hvac equipment and systems shall meet minimum energy efficiency requirements and test procedures, approved by emirates authority for standardization and metrology (esma), as specified in following tables of uae.s 5010-5 a) table 1 split and packaged unit including cassette type unit b) table 2 water source heat pumps c) table 4 multiple split unit

exhaust air energy recovery h.4.8.2 for buildings with requirement for treated outdoor air of over 1,000 l/s, energy recovery systems shall be provided to handle at least 50% of total exhausted air. energy recovery systems shall have at least 70% sensible load recovery efficiency
01 figure h.2 shows typical energy recovery wheel

01 02 figure h.2 ventilation energy recovery thermal wheel chillers shall meet minimum efficiency requirements and test procedures given in table 6.8.1 to table 6.8.3 of ashrae 90.12019. chiller equipment requirements shall be met for all chillers, including those where leaving fluid design temperature <4.5 c

key 01 plate heat exchanger 02 rotary heat exchanger 02 h 22 dubai building code part h indoor environment demand controlled ventilation h.4.8.3 demand controlled ventilation (dcv) using carbon dioxide (co2) sensing shall be used in spaces larger than 100 m2 and having maximum design occupancy density greater than or equal to 25 people per 100 m2. default occupancy density values from ashrae 62.1 and ashrae 62.2, shall be used when actual occupancy not known

key 01 plate heat exchanger 02 rotary heat exchanger 02 h 22 dubai building code part h indoor environment demand controlled ventilation h.4.8.3 demand controlled ventilation (dcv) using carbon dioxide (co2) sensing shall be used in spaces larger than 100 m2 and having maximum design occupancy density greater than or equal to 25 people per 100 m2. default occupancy density values from ashrae 62.1 and ashrae 62.2, shall be used when actual occupancy not known
co2 concentration set-point shall be kept below 800 ppm

alarm shall be triggered if co2 concentration rises above 1,000 ppm. this alarm can either be automatically monitored by central control system, if available, or give local audible or visual indication when activated

for all buildings with dcv, co2 sensors and systems shall be checked and recalibrated in accordance with manufacturers recommendations. recalibration shall be carried out at intervals not exceeding 12 months, and shall be carried out by specialized companies

h.4.8.4 following shall be insulated to minimize heat loss and prevent condensation pipe and duct insulation a) all pipes carrying refrigerant, hot water or chilled water and b) ducts supplying conditioned air (including prefabricated ducts). this shall include pipes and ducts passing through conditioned and unconditioned spaces

h.4.8.4 following shall be insulated to minimize heat loss and prevent condensation pipe and duct insulation a) all pipes carrying refrigerant, hot water or chilled water and b) ducts supplying conditioned air (including prefabricated ducts). this shall include pipes and ducts passing through conditioned and unconditioned spaces

h.4.9 infiltration/air leakage performance h.4.9.1 air-conditioned buildings with cooling load of 1 mw or greater shall achieve air leakage that does not exceed 5 m3/h/m2 into or out of building, at applied pressure difference of 50 pa. air tightness testing shall be carried out to verify compliance, in accordance with bs en 13829 or astm e779 or as approved by authority. positive pressure, with respect to atmosphere, shall always be maintained in building. air loss from entrances/exits h.4.9.2 loss of conditioned air from main entrance to air-conditioned building shall be mitigated by lobby or door barrier system. h.4.10 ventilation and air quality h.4.10.1 general adequate supply of outdoor air shall be provided to facilitate health and comfort of occupants of buildings and to limit condensation

h.4.9 infiltration/air leakage performance h.4.9.1 air-conditioned buildings with cooling load of 1 mw or greater shall achieve air leakage that does not exceed 5 m3/h/m2 into or out of building, at applied pressure difference of 50 pa. air tightness testing shall be carried out to verify compliance, in accordance with bs en 13829 or astm e779 or as approved by authority. positive pressure, with respect to atmosphere, shall always be maintained in building. air loss from entrances/exits h.4.9.2 loss of conditioned air from main entrance to air-conditioned building shall be mitigated by lobby or door barrier system. h.4.10 ventilation and air quality h.4.10.1 general adequate supply of outdoor air shall be provided to facilitate health and comfort of occupants of buildings and to limit condensation

h.4.9 infiltration/air leakage performance h.4.9.1 air-conditioned buildings with cooling load of 1 mw or greater shall achieve air leakage that does not exceed 5 m3/h/m2 into or out of building, at applied pressure difference of 50 pa. air tightness testing shall be carried out to verify compliance, in accordance with bs en 13829 or astm e779 or as approved by authority. positive pressure, with respect to atmosphere, shall always be maintained in building. air loss from entrances/exits h.4.9.2 loss of conditioned air from main entrance to air-conditioned building shall be mitigated by lobby or door barrier system. h.4.10 ventilation and air quality h.4.10.1 general adequate supply of outdoor air shall be provided to facilitate health and comfort of occupants of buildings and to limit condensation

adequate space pressurization shall be provided to reduce moisture and contaminant transfer between adjacent spaces, thereby reducing contamination of occupied spaces and unwanted condensation and mould growth. space pressurization (via return, transfer or exhaust air) in space or location shall be designed at expected air quality classification in accordance with authority requirements (if any) or refer to tables 5.16.1, 6.2.2.1, 6.5 of ashrae 62.12019

h 23 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.4.10.2 minimum ventilation requirements for adequate indoor air quality all air-conditioned buildings shall be ventilated either mechanically or by mixed mode. they shall meet minimum requirements of ashrae 62.1, ashrae 62.2 and ashrae 170. occupancy density shall be determined in accordance with b.5.1 where possible. if occupancy not listed in b.5.1, outdoor air flow rate shall be based on default occupancy density values stated in ashrae 62.1, ashrae 62.2 and ashrae 170. indoor air quality h.4.10.3 air filters for general ventilation shall meet efficiency classification given in iso 16890-1 based upon particulate matter

h 23 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.4.10.2 minimum ventilation requirements for adequate indoor air quality all air-conditioned buildings shall be ventilated either mechanically or by mixed mode. they shall meet minimum requirements of ashrae 62.1, ashrae 62.2 and ashrae 170. occupancy density shall be determined in accordance with b.5.1 where possible. if occupancy not listed in b.5.1, outdoor air flow rate shall be based on default occupancy density values stated in ashrae 62.1, ashrae 62.2 and ashrae 170. indoor air quality h.4.10.3 air filters for general ventilation shall meet efficiency classification given in iso 16890-1 based upon particulate matter

maximum limit for indoor air contaminants stated in table h.4 shall not be exceeded. indoor air quality testing shall be carried out prior to occupancy. test report showing compliance with these requirements shall be submitted to authority. contaminant formaldehyde total volatile organic compound (tvoc) suspended particulates (<10 m) maximum limit <0.08 (ppm) <300 g/m <150 g/m sampling duration 8 h continuous monitoring (8 h time-weighted average twa) table h.4 schedule, duration of sampling and maximum limit for contaminants air quality testing shall be carried out by specialized companies or laboratories accredited by authority

maximum limit for indoor air contaminants stated in table h.4 shall not be exceeded. indoor air quality testing shall be carried out prior to occupancy. test report showing compliance with these requirements shall be submitted to authority. contaminant formaldehyde total volatile organic compound (tvoc) suspended particulates (<10 m) maximum limit <0.08 (ppm) <300 g/m <150 g/m sampling duration 8 h continuous monitoring (8 h time-weighted average twa) table h.4 schedule, duration of sampling and maximum limit for contaminants air quality testing shall be carried out by specialized companies or laboratories accredited by authority

air quality testing equipment shall have initial and periodical calibration certificate as specified in iso/iec 17025. calibration certification shall be carried out either annually or as specified by manufacturer, whichever more frequent, and shall be carried out by external calibration facility, accredited by authority. initial and periodical calibration certificates shall be saved in dedicated register. calibration certificate shall be checked by authority to validate accuracy of readings. calibration certificates shall also be provided when renewing indoor air quality certificate of building

paints, coatings, adhesives and sealants used in building shall not exceed allowed limits for volatile organic compound (voc) specified by dubai central laboratory ref. h.19. these materials shall be accredited/certified from dubai central laboratory, or any other laboratory approved by authority

carpet systems (carpets or new permanently installed carpet padding) shall be certified/accredited by dubai central laboratory, or any other laboratory approved by authority. carpets shall not be installed in labour accommodation, educational facilities or any other places as determined by authority

carpet systems (carpets or new permanently installed carpet padding) shall be certified/accredited by dubai central laboratory, or any other laboratory approved by authority. carpets shall not be installed in labour accommodation, educational facilities or any other places as determined by authority

note alternative filtration techniques, such as electronic filters and air cleaners using photocatalytic oxidation, should be approved by authority prior to installation/use due to negative health effects that can arise from exposure to ozone and its volatile reaction products. substantial technical evidence required on use of these techniques and should be validated by international agencies and test standards. they not considered to be replacement for mechanical filtration, but can be used as aids to achieve better indoor air quality
