h 87 figure h.29 use of sound-absorbing materials to control reverberation (b) sound absorbing surface dubai building code part h indoor environment h.10.4 additional requirements for different occupancies h.10.4.1 mosques integrated approach to acoustic design of mosques essential. achieving good sound system speech intelligibility in prayer hall, that compatible with architecture, requires careful location and specification of sound-absorbing and diffusing finishes
sound insulation of prayer hall also important. walls, roof and door openings shall be designed to control ingress of noise from adjacent spaces within building and from outside
acoustic consultant should be appointed to carry out acoustic design of building and sound systems

h.10.4.2 healthcare patient rooms should be located as far as possible from roads, car parking areas and service yards. hospitals shall be designed to give appropriate levels of patient acoustic and visual privacy and dignity throughout care process. in multiple-bed rooms, visual privacy from casual observation by other patients and visitors shall be provided for each patient but speech privacy unlikely to be practicable. acoustic design of healthcare occupancies shall conform to htm 08-01 ref. h.45 or fgi guidelines ref. h.46
h.10.4.3 school operators might stipulate requirements for their brand. educational advice of acoustic consultant should be sought for design of specialist facilities such as performing arts rooms

h.10.4.4 hotels hotel operators will stipulate requirements for their brand of hotel and serviced apartments. in absence of any specific operator guidance, requirements of approved document e ref. h.44 for rooms for residential purposes shall be adopted

performing arts venues h.10.4.5 buildings for performing arts uses shall be designed individually for specific intended uses of building. specialist acoustic consultant should be involved from early stages of design. acoustic design of ancillary spaces within building shall follow relevant parts of standards listed in table h.17

performing arts venues h.10.4.5 buildings for performing arts uses shall be designed individually for specific intended uses of building. specialist acoustic consultant should be involved from early stages of design. acoustic design of ancillary spaces within building shall follow relevant parts of standards listed in table h.17

h.10.5 vibration and ground-borne noise railways above or below ground can cause perceptible vibration and generate audible rumbling in nearby buildings. guidance on vibration levels for human comfort, and criteria for sensitive equipment, provided in ch. 48, table 45 of ashrae hvac applications handbook ref. h.17

guidance on acceptable levels of ground borne noise given in federal transit administrations transit noise and vibration impact assessment manual ref. h.49 and association of noise consultants measurement and assessment of ground borne noise and vibration ref. h.50
h 88 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.11 digital services enablement and ict h.11.1 scope dubai has aspiration to enable digital services as described in h.11.7

applications automation dashboards reporting following sections of dbc define requirements for digital services entablement. these sections only apply when there client brief for digitally connected building

h.11.2 minimum requirements for digital services enablement h.11.2.1 digital building technology model digital services and operational technology (ot) in buildings relies on layers of key capabilities. these key capabilities cover smart devices, inter-connectivity across networks, applications and processes residing in centralized platforms (including data sets and user facing applications), data analytics and reporting systems. building users benefit from access to richer range of data sets that can be analysed and presented in management dashboards and performance reports. layered approach shall be adopted when defining overall smart buildings system architecture (see figure h.30). building management platforms application apis data lake connectivity devices figure h.30 example of layered approach to digital buildings system architecture h 89 dubai building code part h indoor environment apis future digital services digital building infrastructure building systems future digital services implementation requirements h.11.2.2 all building ot shall be digital-enabled by being configured to consume information, and communicate information that it produces, via open iot protocols

h.11.2 minimum requirements for digital services enablement h.11.2.1 digital building technology model digital services and operational technology (ot) in buildings relies on layers of key capabilities. these key capabilities cover smart devices, inter-connectivity across networks, applications and processes residing in centralized platforms (including data sets and user facing applications), data analytics and reporting systems. building users benefit from access to richer range of data sets that can be analysed and presented in management dashboards and performance reports. layered approach shall be adopted when defining overall smart buildings system architecture (see figure h.30). building management platforms application apis data lake connectivity devices figure h.30 example of layered approach to digital buildings system architecture h 89 dubai building code part h indoor environment apis future digital services digital building infrastructure building systems future digital services implementation requirements h.11.2.2 all building ot shall be digital-enabled by being configured to consume information, and communicate information that it produces, via open iot protocols

h.11.2 minimum requirements for digital services enablement h.11.2.1 digital building technology model digital services and operational technology (ot) in buildings relies on layers of key capabilities. these key capabilities cover smart devices, inter-connectivity across networks, applications and processes residing in centralized platforms (including data sets and user facing applications), data analytics and reporting systems. building users benefit from access to richer range of data sets that can be analysed and presented in management dashboards and performance reports. layered approach shall be adopted when defining overall smart buildings system architecture (see figure h.30). building management platforms application apis data lake connectivity devices figure h.30 example of layered approach to digital buildings system architecture h 89 dubai building code part h indoor environment apis future digital services digital building infrastructure building systems future digital services implementation requirements h.11.2.2 all building ot shall be digital-enabled by being configured to consume information, and communicate information that it produces, via open iot protocols

building ot, includes, but not limited to a) hvac equipment and ancillaries b) vertical transportation systems c) lighting systems d) bms e) energy metering f) renewable energy systems and g) occupancy monitoring systems

headings: iot protocols for digital services enablement
Description: figure h.31 shows one example of digital-enabled building, with building systems connected to digital building infrastructure, to which future digital systems might be connected. gateway/ translation engineering ui server engineering tools controller/io edge device lighting vertical transportation hvac/ bms fire alarm energy metering other cctv, access control district smart network smart city network other building analytics figure h.31 one example of digital-enabled building showing building operation systems connected h 90 dubai building code part h indoor environment iot protocols for digital services enablement h.11.2.3 current standard for communication with digital-enabled devices transmission of plain text javascript object notation (json) payload using message queueing telemetry transport (mqtt) as transmission protocol. mqtt/json should be used as iot protocol. iot protocol used shall be consistent across building

it not requirement for open iot protocol to replace extensive control and communication protocols which traditionally used within buildings. designer shall determine most suitable system topology for building. open iot protocol connections do not replace other external data connections which might be required (e.g. connections between building fire alarm system and dcd between building cooling systems and distinct cooling providers and between smart utility meters and utility providers) and which shall continue to meet relevant requirements
iso/iec 30141 provides standardized iot reference architecture using common vocabulary, reusable designs and industry best practices

headings: building control and operation communication protocols
Description: h.11.2.4 building control and operation communication protocols digital/iot integration gateways and interfaces should be provided at lowest level where secure ip network interface provided
note this to minimize middleware and additional commissioning steps that can lead to reduced robustness through failure of middleware layers as building and edge hardware adapted or updated over time

it might not be possible to incorporate iot protocols at device level in all instances, such as where sensors or actuators work on analogue signals. such devices traditionally connected to remote input/output gateway. gateways should be configured to communicate using open iot protocol over encrypted transmission control protocol/internet protocol (tcp/ip) connection, or they may be configured to connect to smart integration gateway. for devices which communicate via legacy protocols such as bacnet or lonworks, protocol conversion should be provided at controller to publish and optionally consume data using open iot protocol over encrypted tcp/ip connection. for systems such as konnex (knx), gateway should be provided with protocol conversion to publish and optionally consume data using open iot protocol over encrypted tcp/ip connection. knx systems can be connected to smart gateway via legacy protocol converter, but this option less preferred

for devices communicating over serial protocols such as modbus, protocol converter should be provided that publishes and optionally consumes data using open iot protocol over encrypted tcp/ip connection. technical information about individual modbus including address and payload should be recorded during procurement of all modbus equipment to facilitate this
m-bus installations should be provided with gateway that exposes protocol conversion interface to publish and optionally consume data using open iot protocol over encrypted tcp/ip connection

where open platform communication (opc) offered in building automation, protocol conversion to xml or json text payloads shall be provided. protocol converter or iot gateway should be provided, to publish and optionally consume data using open iot protocol over encrypted tcp/ip connection
where scada used in building automation, system should be configured to incorporate protocol converter to publish and optionally consume data using open iot protocol over encrypted tcp/ip connection

h 91 dubai building code part h indoor environment wireless sensor networks or iot networks installed in buildings, such as bluetooth, zigbee or lorawan, should expose smart interface at gateways, or be connected to smart gateway, to publish and optionally consume data using open iot protocol over encrypted tcp/ip connection

some devices may form part of managed service and connect directly to proprietary internet-based system via building network or cellular services. for these, service provider shall provide authenticated application programming interface (api) to allow access to data or support open iot protocols. any managed service specifications shall take into account requirements of tra iot regulatory policy ref. h.51 and tra iot regulatory procedure ref. h.52

any technology communicating using other control and operation communication protocols, and all other systems, should be configured to expose smart interface to publish and optionally consume data as required using open iot protocol over encrypted tcp/ip connection
figure h.32 depicts connectivity of common connectivity protocols which may be used within smart-enabled building

iot connectivity field level connectivity open iot protocols, e.g. mqtt/json tcp/ip over structured cabling open iot protocols, e.g. mqtt/json tcp/ip over structured cabling open iot protocols, e.g. mqtt/json tcp/ip over structured cabling open iot protocols, e.g. mqtt/json tcp/ip over structured cabling iot gateway e.g. bacnet, lonworks, modbus legacy communication protocol bms i/o knx to iot gateway knx controller e.g. 0-10v 4-20ma input device hardwired input/output knx output device knx device bms controller with protocol conversion e.g. bacnet, lonworks, modbus legacy communication protocol device iot gateway tcp/ip over structured cabling sensor gateway wireless e.g bluetooth, lorawan, zigbee, field device api or open iot protocols, e.g. mqtt/json tcp/ip over external internet provider proprietary cloud tcp/ip over external internet field device open iot protocols, e.g. mqtt/json tcp/ip over structured cabling ip eld device building systems network figure h.32 configuration of some typical building control/communication protocols to support open iot protocols h 92 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.11.2.5 device and data naming consistent device and data naming schema shall be adopted. device naming schema shall be used to assign names for all devices or equipment within building. data naming schema shall be used to assign consistent names to datasets and data points, including inputs and outputs. figure h.33 shows excerpt from example device naming standard

device type device type actuator actuator air dryer air dryer air handling unit air handling unit device abbreviation device abbreviation atr atr adr adr ahu ahu ae_db_bld1_ahu-43 building identifier device type unique identifier air control damper air control damper automatic transfer switch automatic transfer switch balancing valve acd acd ats ats bcv bms panel balancing valve bms pane bcv bms bms figure h.33 excerpt from example device naming standard h 93 schemas shall a) be applicable to all building control devices b) be applicable to any equipment that can change state and that monitored within building, including equipment provided by third parties such as building tenants or service providers c) incorporate all data inputs and outputs and d) be agreed during design stage with developer or building operator

data governance shall be adhered to throughout building lifecycle of building assets, allowing asset to be identified through design, construction and operation, including commissioning and decommissioning of assets. schema shall be documented and included within building documentation at handover

schema shall be consistent across media, including equipment data sheets, building information modelling (bim) model, control systems, record drawings, operations and maintenance, physical labels/qr codes, and computer aided facilities management (cafm) records
devices shall therefore have same name within record information and within digital representation

device and data naming schemas shall be non-proprietary. where developer or building operator has already applicable device and data naming schema from building within their portfolio, then this can be adopted
where developer or building operator does not have device and data naming schemas from building within their portfolio, bdns ref. h.53 open naming convention should be used
translation/mapping solution can be applied, if required, where linking datasets between different systems (e.g. bim and cafm). this to maximize consistency and interoperability between buildings

dubai building code part h indoor environment h.11.2.6 data governance and privacy sufficient controls shall be provided to facilitate data governance and restrict access to information. examples of controls include a) internal access, e.g. building operational data to enable facilities management and optimum building operation b) named access, e.g. personal data (such as people finding applications) or data from dwellings c) group-based, e.g. tenant information accessible by employees d) public/open, e.g. whole building metrics e) presence detection for energy saving, safety and/or security and f) sensing of home appliances

personal data shall be controlled in line with all applicable data protection requirements. h.11.2.7 home automation in residential buildings control systems installed within individual residences or within residential blocks shall utilize standardized open bus protocol or standardized radio frequency/mesh protocol for device-to-device digital communication. for integration between products of different suppliers, open interfaces should be used

personal data shall be controlled in line with all applicable data protection requirements. h.11.2.7 home automation in residential buildings control systems installed within individual residences or within residential blocks shall utilize standardized open bus protocol or standardized radio frequency/mesh protocol for device-to-device digital communication. for integration between products of different suppliers, open interfaces should be used

personal data shall be controlled in line with all applicable data protection requirements. h.11.2.7 home automation in residential buildings control systems installed within individual residences or within residential blocks shall utilize standardized open bus protocol or standardized radio frequency/mesh protocol for device-to-device digital communication. for integration between products of different suppliers, open interfaces should be used

smart systems installed within residential settings shall be able to communicate with common home automation systems. home automation systems include, but not limited to a) lighting systems b) smart assistant (speaker) c) sensor systems for comfort d) sensor systems for air quality and e) presence detection for energy saving, safety and/or security

h 94 h.11.2.8 device requirements and security building operational devices that connected to building ip network shall conform to part j. where part j applies, devices that part of buildings physical security and access control functions (e.g. surveillance cameras) shall be connected over independent dedicated security network
where critical systems required to operate without reference to dynamic host configuration protocol (dhcp) servers or name servers, then relevant devices on that system shall have static ip addresses

other ip-based smart-enabled building operation devices should support ietf standards, e.g. dhcp address assignment, encryption, authentication, remote administration and firmware/software updates. all data transmitted to and from any device shall be encrypted in transit using standard protocols (e.g. tls rfc-5246) suitable for transmission over internet
all devices shall have manufacturers default access credentials changed. certificate-based authentication should be used where available. each device should have its own unique certificate
suitable security on all devices connected to building network shall be provided to avoid devices being compromised maliciously or non-compliant devices being connected to network
security controls shall be implemented to restrict access of devices only to resources required

h.11.2.9 data validation upon completion, smart-enabled technologies shall be validated to demonstrate that they providing data using client protocols and in correct data format. dubai building code part h indoor environment h.11.3 ict h.11.3.1 overview physical infrastructure (including cabling, cable pathways and equipment rooms) required to enable smart building. infrastructure typically falls into following distinct categories a) incoming service provider enables one or more telecommunications service providers to deliver fixed and mobile cellular services into building. refer to g.11 and part k for buildings and single dwelling units respectively b) landlord landlord cabling and data network infrastructure to support smart applications c) tenant or occupier tenants or occupiers own cabling and network infrastructure to support smart applications within their own occupied spaces

h.11.2.9 data validation upon completion, smart-enabled technologies shall be validated to demonstrate that they providing data using client protocols and in correct data format. dubai building code part h indoor environment h.11.3 ict h.11.3.1 overview physical infrastructure (including cabling, cable pathways and equipment rooms) required to enable smart building. infrastructure typically falls into following distinct categories a) incoming service provider enables one or more telecommunications service providers to deliver fixed and mobile cellular services into building. refer to g.11 and part k for buildings and single dwelling units respectively b) landlord landlord cabling and data network infrastructure to support smart applications c) tenant or occupier tenants or occupiers own cabling and network infrastructure to support smart applications within their own occupied spaces

these three infrastructures shall be segregated to enable different parties to separately manage and operate their networks. this section specifies minimum requirements for landlord and/or occupier cabling, equipment rooms and cable pathways

equipment rooms and cabling pathways h.11.3.2 designer shall plan and design landlord and/or occupier infrastructure in accordance with iso/iec 11801, iso/iec 14763 and iso/iec 30129. following aspects of ict infrastructure shall be established as minimum a) landlord and/or occupier information and communications technology (ict) equipment room(s), main equipment room(s) (mers) or building distributor b) landlord and/or occupier ict riser, with optional secondary equipment rooms (sers) or floor distributors to remain within cable length constraints where building size necessitates c) landlord and/or occupier structured cabling system (scs), comprising backbone and horizontal cabling systems d) space for satellite reception dishes on roof or other location having clear line of sight of southern sky. satellite dishes shall not be placed towards edge of roof or close to roof parapet wall. satellite dishes shall be securely fixed against anticipated wind loading. for multi-tenant buildings, appropriate space and infrastructure shall be provided for integrated reception system served by common head end and common satellite dish(es), to avoid individual tenants placing their own dish and infrastructure on building or at their own windows/balconies

where business continuity important, planning for ict infrastructure shall mitigate impact of single points of failure. to facilitate high availability backbone infrastructure, design shall provide 1) at least two mers, located geographically apart with separation distance of not less than 30 and in separate fire evacuation zones 2) at least two risers, located geographically apart with separation distance of not less than 10 and in separate fire compartments and 3) backbone cabling system from one or more mers, with multiple cables utilizing physically separate cable pathways

h 95 dubai building code part h indoor environment landlord and tenant cabling infrastructure h.11.3.3 landlord and tenant ict cabling infrastructure shall be based on iso/iec 11801 and iso/iec 14763. all fixed and permanently installed telecom cables within building shall be halogen-free, achieve minimum rating of euroclass cca-s1b, d2, a2 when tested in accordance with bs en 13501-6 and be ce marked
note 1 ce marking represents manufacturers declaration that products conform to applicable manufacturing and testing standard
all other cables, microduct and conduit including patch cords shall meet minimum requirements of iec 60332-1-2

designer shall specify fire performance of cables according to iec 60332-1-2 for single wire installations and iec 60332-3 for vertically mounted bunched cables. landlord cabling infrastructure topology shall align with need to enable landlord ict systems within building. landlord ict systems deemed essential, irrespective of need to enable smart building

landlord cabling system shall include a) backbone cabling system, typically comprising optical fibre cables, and optionally copper cables by exception (see note 2) and b) horizontal cabling system, typically comprising copper category 6 (or higher performance), and optionally optical fibre cables by exception (see note 2). note 2 where designer considers that category 6 copper data cabling suitable for all foreseen applications during 10 year life of cabling infrastructure, and that use of power over ethernet (poe++, ieee 802.3bt  part of ieee 802.3 standards suite) not foreseen, then it may be used in design. tenant or occupier cabling system shall also follow standards iso/iec 11801 and iso/iec 14763. extent of tenant or occupier cabling system shall be determined according to extent of their occupancy in building (i.e. whether part floor, whole floor, multiple floors or whole building). depending on level of ownership and occupancy, tenant cabling system shall include 1) backbone cabling system, comprising optical fibre cables, and optionally copper cables by exception (see note 2) and 2) horizontal cabling system, comprising copper category 6 a, and optionally optical fibre cables by exception (see note 2). as minimum, landlord scs (see figure h.34) shall enable spatial safeguarding and connectivity for i) wireless networks operating in unlicensed spectrum to cover all landlord areas, and by exception to cover tenant areas where need arises ii) wired sensors and instrumentation iii) devices within landlord command and control rooms iv) v) ict devices for front of house services to tenants, staff and visitors to building, e.g. reception and visitor management services ict devices for back of house operations, security and facilities management services and vi) devices associated with enabling smart building applications, e.g. interactive displays, information kiosks, digital signage and advertising displays in public areas. h 96 dubai building code part h indoor environment 02 h.11.3.4 distribution techniques this subsection describes concept of zone distribution (see figure h.35), which applies equally to warehouses, factories, schools, hotels, residential apartments and multi-dwelling units. 01 05 04 03 figure h.34 typical approach to scs distribution (example of tenant occupying multiple floors) figure h.35 concept of zone density of iot connected devices expected to grow substantially in smart building, landlord cabling system (see figure h.36) shall be organized using one or combination of following options a) zone distribution topology with consolidation points or active zone enclosures that can be deployed in distributed manner closer to device and associated final telecommunications outlet (to) locations 6) where distributed zone enclosures with active equipment deployed, designer shall rationalize space, power and equipment density needs for ser or floor distributor rooms, or, in case of villas and townhouses, consolidation cabinet (see part k)

level riser riser b level mer b) zone distribution topology for field iot networking (see figure h.36). this 10 lettable space lettable space 10 comprises grid of consolidation points spaced in regular grid pattern, typically in ceiling, or series of distributed zone enclosures with active equipment (e.g. ruggedized switches) in compact form factor. following requirements shall be met as appropriate

1) floor-based distribution outlets shall be spaced in regular grid. outlets shall function as traditional to or consolidation point but respecting rules around permanent link limits prescribed by iso/iec 11801. 2) wall or column tos shall be spaced at regular intervals. tos shall function as traditional to or consolidation point but respecting rules around permanent link limits prescribed by iso/iec 11801. 3) multimedia type wall outlets points shall be provided to present range of ict and audio visual (av) interfaces at meeting desk where av services required. 09 08 07 06 05 04 03 02 01 lettable space landlord space lettable space lettable space landlord space lettable space lettable space landlord space lettable space lettable space landlord space lettable space lettable space landlord space lettable space lettable space landlord space lettable space lettable space landlord space lettable space lettable space landlord space lettable space lettable space landlord space lettable space 09 08 07 06 05 04 03 02 01 telecommunication intake room lettable space gf 4) private wireless technology shall be taken into account in planning of density gf lettable space of outlets. for instance, extending wireless coverage into multiple rooms within residential unit would require outlets in ceiling to be provided for wireless access points to enable ubiquitous wireless connectivity within residential environment

5) poe, poe+ and poe++ shall be taken into account in design and planning of scs copper cabling. power density and infrastructure resilience in network equipment rooms (mers, sers) shall also be taken into account

headings: connection topologies for digital services in buildings
Description: h.11.3.5 connection topologies for digital services in buildings there different types of connection topologies. most commonly adopted connection topologies shall be used. various topologies defined in h.11.8

h.11.3.5 connection topologies for digital services in buildings there different types of connection topologies. most commonly adopted connection topologies shall be used. various topologies defined in h.11.8

landlord data network infrastructure h.11.3.6 building shall be equipped with data network infrastructure. this infrastructure shall provide means of data communications for variety of landlord ict end point devices, including standards-based connectivity for wired or wireless sensors and instrumentation devices that intended for enabling smart building applications. landlord network infrastructure shall as minimum conform to ieee 802 series of data network standards. data network standards continually updated, and new standards introduced in response to continual technology advancements. most current and published standards shall be used at time of design of building technologies. where there time lapse between design and subsequent construction, technical design authority and contractor shall agree upon suitable procurement pathway to achieve state-of-the art for intended requirements for smart building enablement

landlord data network infrastructure h.11.3.6 building shall be equipped with data network infrastructure. this infrastructure shall provide means of data communications for variety of landlord ict end point devices, including standards-based connectivity for wired or wireless sensors and instrumentation devices that intended for enabling smart building applications. landlord network infrastructure shall as minimum conform to ieee 802 series of data network standards. data network standards continually updated, and new standards introduced in response to continual technology advancements. most current and published standards shall be used at time of design of building technologies. where there time lapse between design and subsequent construction, technical design authority and contractor shall agree upon suitable procurement pathway to achieve state-of-the art for intended requirements for smart building enablement

h 99 dubai building code part h indoor environment figure h.37 shows possible data network infrastructure in smart-enabled commercial building. there multiple network topology options for enablement of landlord data network infrastructure supporting sensor and instrumentation devices. network integration (enterprise it network) network switch access layer 2 nac authenticator network switch core layer 2 firewall(s) layer 3 iot non-native device non-ethernet wired legacy non-ip modbus rtu /bacnet serial ip gateway nac client (heating /cooling) sms vlan (heating /cooling) sms vlan (heating /cooling) bms rewall instance isp router iot non-native device non-ethernet wired legacy non-ip modbus rtu /bacnet serial ip gateway nac client air ow sms vlan air ow sms vlan air flow sms rewall instance iot cloud service internet smart services iot non-native device non-ethernet wired legacy non-ip dali eld interface ip gateway nac client lighting vlan lighting vlan lighting rewall instance iot non-native device non-ethernet wired legacy non-ip modbus rtu /bacnet serial ip gateway nac client power vlan power vlan power rewall instance isp router smart building systems network switch layer 2 nac authenticator network switch core layer 2 firewall(s) layer 3 remote support / management cloud compute proxy, a/d, dns, ntp, ca, aaa dmz compute proxy, a/d, dns, ntp, ca, aaa figure h.37 converged data network in typical building h 100 dubai building code part h indoor environment as minimum following topologies shall be included a) standalone ot network that operates independently of landlord common network system (cns) for it applications which facilitate landlord ict services within building and b) converged network topology that enables landlord cns to support data communications needs of smart building sensor and instrumentation devices

ot network shall be provided with wide area network communications capability in accordance with information assurance, network and cyber security requirements and implementation guidelines adopted by landlord or owner- occupier. as minimum following topologies should be included during design of network infrastructure 1) dedicated wide area communications network, which shall operate independently of other wide area communications network supporting landlord ict applications 2) common use wide area communications network, utilizing virtual private network (vpn) technologies to secure and segregate data within ot and it applications, which shall be designed and configured to be compatible with required smart building applications 3) hybrid option where i) specific smart building applications have dedicated wide area network communications, e.g. for direct access to external cloud computing resources via wireless networks, such as cellular 4g/lte, lte-m and future 5g services, and low power wide area network (lpwan) communications and, ii) some of smart building applications utilize wide area bandwidth provided for landlord ict applications with or without vpn segregation, e.g. access to common incoming service provider internet access service

fixed network telecommunications equipment shall be tra type approved. special safety monitoring requirements h.11.3.7 fire alarm control panels serving buildings or separate tenants shall be connected to dcd through smart and direct alarm systems in accordance with ch. 16 of uae flsc ref. h.1

interface units use cellular transmission to transmit critical building safety alarms to remote dcd monitoring system. smart alarm interface unit and its antenna (local to unit) require excellent cellular signal strength for effective transmission. cellular signal strength shall be achieved of at least 70 dbm for 2g/3g signals and 90 dbm for 4g signals at position of interface units deployed at various locations in building. requirements for providing in-building public cellular service specified in g.11. h.11.3.8 wireless technology h.11.3.8.1 wireless technology bands wireless technology falls under licensed bands and unlicensed bands. licensed bands cover technology such as public cellular (all forms including 4g, lte, 5g) services and certain emerging cellular iot solutions. unlicensed bands cover technology such as wireless lan, bluetooth, lpwan with its different variants in market (e.g. lorawan, sigfox). wireless technology equipment shall be tra type approved. h.11.3.8.2 public cellular (licensed) designer shall consult public licensed service providers (etisalat and/or du) to provide cellular-based solutions within their building. backbone infrastructure to provide cellular services in building shall meet requirements in g.11

interface units use cellular transmission to transmit critical building safety alarms to remote dcd monitoring system. smart alarm interface unit and its antenna (local to unit) require excellent cellular signal strength for effective transmission. cellular signal strength shall be achieved of at least 70 dbm for 2g/3g signals and 90 dbm for 4g signals at position of interface units deployed at various locations in building. requirements for providing in-building public cellular service specified in g.11. h.11.3.8 wireless technology h.11.3.8.1 wireless technology bands wireless technology falls under licensed bands and unlicensed bands. licensed bands cover technology such as public cellular (all forms including 4g, lte, 5g) services and certain emerging cellular iot solutions. unlicensed bands cover technology such as wireless lan, bluetooth, lpwan with its different variants in market (e.g. lorawan, sigfox). wireless technology equipment shall be tra type approved. h.11.3.8.2 public cellular (licensed) designer shall consult public licensed service providers (etisalat and/or du) to provide cellular-based solutions within their building. backbone infrastructure to provide cellular services in building shall meet requirements in g.11

h 101 dubai building code part h indoor environment h.11.3.8.3 private wireless (unlicensed) designer shall comply with tra regulations ref. h.54, ref. h.55, ref. h.56 in respect of design, specification of unlicensed technology. solutions deployed shall be approved for use in uae and supported locally. h.11.3.8.4 health and safety designer shall comply with tra regulations ref. h.56 in respect of health and safety requirements for radio and telecommunications equipment. designer shall follow international commission on non-ionising radiation protection (icnirp) guidelines ref. h.57 for specification and deployment of wireless transmission equipment, with respect to its impact on human health and exposure of humans to such equipment. planning of facilities and installation of equipment shall meet limits for exposure to electromagnetic fields, including exclusion zones

h.11.4 information management and asset data management when producing information, project team shall follow industry recognized standards such as iso 19650 series and iso 29481-1 to facilitate interoperability between software applications used during all stages of assets lifecycle. project team shall define at start of project what geometric and non- geometric properties to be captured and recorded. defined properties shall facilitate contractors and clients intended use of this information. this definition shall include capture of ict infrastructure to information against their respective devices, to keep track of correct provision and association of ict infrastructure points provided to ip and non-ip devices

project team shall establish information model with defined properties, regardless as to whether information to populate these properties available. to enable interoperability of information across lifecycle of asset, project team shall deliver project information within industry foundation classes (ifc) datasets conforming to iso 16739-1

h.11.5 recommended data collection for assets this subsection provides non-exhaustive list of some datasets which should be collected by asset operators, and which should be made available to dubai through api. this information may be by room, level, unit, or tenant within asset. captured information should be stored in persistent and secure data store. requirements for data governance given in h.11.2.6. datasets that should be collected include, but not limited to a) weather (e.g. temperature, humidity, precipitation, wind) b) total building occupancy/footfall c) granular occupancy/footfall d) vertical transportation (e.g. elevator status) e) water consumption f) total water consumption e.g. (metering data) g) storm drainage systems (e.g. flowrate at outfall) h) irrigation systems i) granular cooling demand j) total cooling demand k) electrical systems l) total electrical consumption (e.g. metering data) h 102 dubai building code part h indoor environment m) renewable energy generation n) fire alarm o) lighting (e.g. status, light levels) p) sprinkler system q) car parking (e.g. available places) r) electric vehicle charging (e.g. status, energy consumption). s) waste (e.g. chutes, bin fill) and t) faade systems (e.g. motorized blinds position)

h.11.5 recommended data collection for assets this subsection provides non-exhaustive list of some datasets which should be collected by asset operators, and which should be made available to dubai through api. this information may be by room, level, unit, or tenant within asset. captured information should be stored in persistent and secure data store. requirements for data governance given in h.11.2.6. datasets that should be collected include, but not limited to a) weather (e.g. temperature, humidity, precipitation, wind) b) total building occupancy/footfall c) granular occupancy/footfall d) vertical transportation (e.g. elevator status) e) water consumption f) total water consumption e.g. (metering data) g) storm drainage systems (e.g. flowrate at outfall) h) irrigation systems i) granular cooling demand j) total cooling demand k) electrical systems l) total electrical consumption (e.g. metering data) h 102 dubai building code part h indoor environment m) renewable energy generation n) fire alarm o) lighting (e.g. status, light levels) p) sprinkler system q) car parking (e.g. available places) r) electric vehicle charging (e.g. status, energy consumption). s) waste (e.g. chutes, bin fill) and t) faade systems (e.g. motorized blinds position)
note 1 it not recommended that residential assets capture information related to granular occupancy/ footfall or faade systems
note 2 it not recommended that information related to granular occupancy/footfall, water consumption, electrical systems, lighting or faade systems made available to city

h.11.6 technology in operation digital services and smart designer should analyse use cases to inform design, and determine whether smart applications might be appropriate, taking into account requirements of individual developer. table h.18 gives examples of common technologies. h 103 smart application/use case icon description digital twin dashboard applications asset information digital signage locating people creating digital representation of building, with potential to increase operational efficiency (thereby optimizing resource), improve asset management, deliver cost savings and improve productivity

visualizing whole building data through single system, generate insights and identify trends or anomalies. can be used to visualize energy and water consumption, and also used to set up rules and alerts to optimize running systems within buildings
asset management applications which can utilize live data and trends for more informed decisions and proactive maintenance
digital signage to display building information, such as news, wayfinding or dashboards such as energy consumption
indoor location services to support building occupants finding colleagues within commercial buildings
room calendar integration rooms such as meeting rooms integrated into calendar systems and capable of preconditioning resulting in potential energy savings
mobile apps building occupants can use their mobile phones for control, e.g. local environmental control, lighting, calling elevators
wayfinding wayfinding applications help building occupants navigate in building

robotic and integrated car parking robotic car parking solutions and car park information readily integrated with building information allowing use cases such as interaction by users via mobiles and correlation with occupancy

table h.18 common smart building applications and use cases dubai building code part h indoor environment h.11.7 annex  digital services and smart buildings background h.11.7.1 following some key drivers for digital building technology in dubai

context a) dubais integrated energy strategy (dies) 2030 has ambitious target of reducing energy and water demand by 30% by 2030. reducing cooling requirements within buildings key focus area for dewa and authority (www.taqati.ae/dies-2030/). b) dubai focused on achieving sustainable growth through effective waste management, green mobility and investment in clean energy and smart technologies. these pillars support environment that fosters innovation and discovery, promotes research and development of new technologies and builds supportive policy and regulatory frameworks. c) optimization of energy and water demand for buildings to enable demand side management (a strategic part of dies 2030 programme). d) dubai clean energy strategy 2050 targets increase in renewable electricity produced to 75% by 2050. h.11.7.2 conventional approach to digital services and smart functionality in buildings digital services and smart functionality have conventionally implemented through bms or using proprietary vendor hardware. however, this approach has posed several challenges e) might not be up to date with latest technological advancements  digital service applications typically rely on latest software and hardware, unlike bms solutions which might not be regularly updated f) diverged networks and inadequate network provisions, which could prevent data to be economically communicated between proprietary systems g) limitations to data sharing between building tenants and landlords

headings: conventional approach to digital services and smart functionality in
Description: context a) dubais integrated energy strategy (dies) 2030 has ambitious target of reducing energy and water demand by 30% by 2030. reducing cooling requirements within buildings key focus area for dewa and authority (www.taqati.ae/dies-2030/). b) dubai focused on achieving sustainable growth through effective waste management, green mobility and investment in clean energy and smart technologies. these pillars support environment that fosters innovation and discovery, promotes research and development of new technologies and builds supportive policy and regulatory frameworks. c) optimization of energy and water demand for buildings to enable demand side management (a strategic part of dies 2030 programme). d) dubai clean energy strategy 2050 targets increase in renewable electricity produced to 75% by 2050. h.11.7.2 conventional approach to digital services and smart functionality in buildings digital services and smart functionality have conventionally implemented through bms or using proprietary vendor hardware. however, this approach has posed several challenges e) might not be up to date with latest technological advancements  digital service applications typically rely on latest software and hardware, unlike bms solutions which might not be regularly updated f) diverged networks and inadequate network provisions, which could prevent data to be economically communicated between proprietary systems g) limitations to data sharing between building tenants and landlords

h.11.7.3 digital services enabled approach digital services enablement resolves some of challenges and mitigates some of disadvantages of conventional approach. providing fundamental connectivity requirements in terms of infrastructure, systems and technology allows for future implementation of smart functionalities, use cases and downstream initiatives. these might include, but not limited to a) analytics b) alerts c) calculations d) dashboards and e) prediction models

digital services enabled approach provides 1) building ot installed that can communicate via open iot protocols 2) consistent and standardized device naming and data structuring a) limited interoperability between systems, typically due to absence of 3) building ip network which can support suitable ip connectivity to devices and communication channels b) complexity and limited flexibility c) vendor lock-in, typically limited to single provider with difficulty to change d) convoluted naming of equipment and data, possibly requiring significant processing before any ingestion or analysis 4) open systems architecture

h 104 dubai building code part h indoor environment digital services and smart buildings can bring many benefits, including increased energy efficiency, enhanced marketability, predictive maintenance and enhanced user experience. efficiently collecting, analysing and leveraging data insights acts as catalyst for optimizing building performance, improving use of resources and moving towards buildings that can respond to climate emergency. this illustrated at building level in figure h.38. collecting data across dubai provides insightful statistics about how buildings performing at macro level. this can support decision-making and provides opportunity to contribute to wider smart city initiative

h 105 01 03 02 04 figure h.38 graphical illustration of smart buildings and functionality 05 06 key 01 occupancy 02 computer-aided facilities management (cafm) 03 bms analytics 04 dashboards 05 energy/water meter 06 environment conditions dubai building code part h indoor environment for building occupiers, fine level of control and data availability within smart buildings can help to improve internal environmental quality. research has shown that within office buildings, this can improve productivity and creativity. smart technology systems such as desk booking systems and heatmaps can allow employees to find suitable areas to work considering their personal preferences such as temperature or noise levels. collectively, such technologies improve occupiers experience of their space. functionality such as visualizations of energy consumption and water usage can help building occupants to understand their usage and encourage them to reduce these

there also benefits to building operators. visualizations and dashboards, such as that shown in figure h.39, can be assembled to show entire systems within building collectively, allowing level of insight into operation and usage of building. machine learning algorithms can be employed to optimize building running, reducing energy consumption and increasing efficiency. it allows for proactive maintenance where issues rectified earlier

h 106 figure h.39 web dashboard visualizing whole building information dubai building code part h indoor environment use of consistent data naming and device naming schemas through design, construction and operation, including commissioning and decommissioning, provides link between devices and data. it supported by i) using open standards for 3d model representations of devices and data interchange such as industry foundation classes (ifc) datasets conforming to iso 16739-1 ii) transferring parameters from design model to physical labels and metadata iii) keeping device identity and naming consistent across project phases

h 106 figure h.39 web dashboard visualizing whole building information dubai building code part h indoor environment use of consistent data naming and device naming schemas through design, construction and operation, including commissioning and decommissioning, provides link between devices and data. it supported by i) using open standards for 3d model representations of devices and data interchange such as industry foundation classes (ifc) datasets conforming to iso 16739-1 ii) transferring parameters from design model to physical labels and metadata iii) keeping device identity and naming consistent across project phases

there growing number of technologies which support iot. examples include software-defined networking (sdn) and iot specific firewall systems. there wide adoption of ip connectivity in devices and sensors, and increasing number of these supporting open iot protocols. leading software development companies offering solutions for iot and smart buildings as service, which includes dedicated infrastructure in addition to applications
there growing market expectation for smart building functionality, especially within residences owing to rise of home assistants and home automation devices

h 107 h.11.8 annex  connection topologies for digital services in buildings h.11.8.1 general there different types of connection topologies. most commonly adopted connection topologies shall be used. various topologies defined in h.11.8.2 to h.11.8.5. star topology h.11.8.2 star topology (figure h.40) can be deployed for most building ict distribution networks in combination of wired and wireless networks. 01 04 04 07 08 09 02 08 07 02 05 03 02 06 05 03 06 figure h.40 star network topology in sensor networks key 01 wired 02 sensor node 03 data collection unit 04 wireless 05 basic service set 06 access point 07 personal area network 08 zigibee coordinator 09 zigibee end device dubai building code part h indoor environment ring topology h.11.8.3 ring topology (figure h.41) can deliver efficiencies in network distribution in large buildings and can offer additional resilience especially at controller and gateway level in digital buildings. h.11.8.4 bus topology bus topology (figure h.42) simple and commonly used at device and field control level (e.g. fieldbus see iso/iec 61158)

performance statement will be met by following requirements of j.4 to j.7 j 2 dubai building code part j security intrusion detection system (ids) security system that detects unauthorized entry (intruders) into building or other area. j.2.2 acronyms and abbreviations anpr automatic number plate recognition pan tilt zoom (ptz) camera equipped with motors that allows it to pan, tilt and zoom using telemetry remote control

recognition (r) images used to recognize and follow previously identified persons (targets). whole body and surrounding area most important part of image. size of target image not less than 50% of display size
videoguard system that allows sira to monitor video surveillance systems (vss) in dubai to verify that they configured and working correctly
video surveillance systems (vss) surveillance cameras used for purpose of observing area
note vss sometimes referred to as cctv, which outdated term

eacs hvm ids ir ptz r sira chapter detection electronic access control systems hostile vehicle mitigation identification intrusion detection system infrared pan tilt zoom recognition security industry regulatory agency uae flsc united arab emirates fire and life safety code of practice vss video surveillance systems j.2 definitions j.2.1 terms automatic number plate recognition (anpr) technology that uses optical character recognition on images to read vehicle registration plates to create vehicle location data. anpr monitored by city ring
city ring system that allows sira to monitor anpr systems in dubai to verify that they configured and working correctly

detection (d) images used to detect key events such as nature of movement, direction and overall appearance of people. persons whole body and surrounding area at average distance most important part of image. size of target image not less than 10% of display size

electronic access control systems (eacs) type of security that manages and controls or what allowed entrance to system, environment or facility. it identifies entities that have access to controlled system, environment or facility based on validity of their credentials
hostile vehicle mitigation (hvm) measures provided to prevent vehicles passing control point

identification (i) images used to identify persons (targets) that not previously identified as they enter establishment. targets face most important part of image. size of target image not less than 120% of display size

j 3 dubai building code part j security j.3 references ref. j.1 security industry regulatory agency (january 2020). preventative systems manual, law 12 of year 2016 and by-law regulation 1-2018. version 3.1. dubai sira. available from www.sira.gov.ae/en/laws-and-regulations.aspxpage=1

ref. j.2 uae ministry of interior general command of civil defence, 2018. uae fire and life safety code of practice (uae flsc). united arab emirates ministry of interior general command of civil defence

j 4 dubai building code part j security j.4 legal context and mandatory requirements preventative systems manual, law 12 of year 2016 and by-law regulation 1-2018 ref. j.1 legal framework for security systems within dubai. it issued and maintained by sira, which oversees and monitors implementation of physical and electronic security systems

part j based on version 3.1 of preventative systems manual ref. j.1 and provides summary of security and vss requirements by building type. part j shall be used in conjunction with latest online version of manual

it mandatory under preventative systems manual ref. j.1 that security system consultants, installers and maintenance staff working on projects in dubai sira-registered security engineers. anybody appointing sira-registered security engineer shall verify that security engineers accreditation valid at time of design, installation and maintenance of system, and not under pending suspension, expectation of suspension, or withdrawal by sira
