j 14 dubai building code part j security k.1 k.2 k.3 k.4 k.5 k.6 k.7 k.8 k.9 performance statements definitions references scope architecture accessibility building envelope structure incoming utilities k.10 indoor environment k.11 security k 1 dubai building code part k villas k.1 performance statements section performance statement architecture building shall be appropriately integrated with surrounding natural and built environment

j 14 dubai building code part j security k.1 k.2 k.3 k.4 k.5 k.6 k.7 k.8 k.9 performance statements definitions references scope architecture accessibility building envelope structure incoming utilities k.10 indoor environment k.11 security k 1 dubai building code part k villas k.1 performance statements section performance statement architecture building shall be appropriately integrated with surrounding natural and built environment
building shall facilitate safety, convenience and welfare of building occupants as they move in and around building, including access and egress
building shall provide minimum communal provisions and facilities for health and welfare of building occupants
performance statement will be met by following requirements of k.5.1 and k.5.2 k.5.3 and k.5.5 k.5.4, k.5.7 and k.5.8 site shall provide appropriate access and safe circulation for vehicles
k.5.6 section performance statement performance statement will be met by following requirements of building envelope building envelope shall safely resist loads imposed upon it
building envelope shall reduce energy required to cool building
building envelope shall protect occupants from falling from balconies, roofs or through lightwells

k.7.1 k.7.2 k.7.4 k.7.6 k.7.6 k 2 dubai building code part k villas performance statement will be met by following requirements of k.8.1 to k.8.6 section performance statement performance statement will be met by following requirements of indoor environment building shall provide fixed building services that k.10.1 k.8.5 to k.8.6 k.8.1.4 k.9.1 to k.9.3 k.9.5 k.9.7 a) energy-efficient b) have effective controls c) ensure optimal operational efficiency and d) facilitate health and comfort of occupants
building shall provide drainage systems to collect and convey drainage flows in safe and efficient manner
building shall safeguard people from undue noise being transmitted from adjacent spaces, occupancies and exterior

k.10.2 k.10.4 k.10.5 section performance statement building structure shall safely sustain and transmit to ground combined dead, imposed, thermal, wind and seismic load conditions for its intended life

k.10.2 k.10.4 k.10.5 section performance statement building structure shall safely sustain and transmit to ground combined dead, imposed, thermal, wind and seismic load conditions for its intended life
building shall provide electrical installations that safeguard occupants against outbreak of fire and personal injury due to electric shock
building shall enable telecommunications services that suitably future-proof
structure incoming utilities k 3 dubai building code part k villas k.2 definitions k.2.1 general definitions in part apply

k.2.2 architecture affection plan plan of plot or site issued by authority, showing information that includes (but not limited to) plot boundaries, plot dimensions, plot areas, plot setbacks and surroundings as well as land uses. also called site plan

amenity area or space public or private area within boundaries of plot or development site for building occupants recreation or convenience (such as landscaped areas, patios, swimming pools, play areas, prayer rooms, exercise areas and similar uses)
balcony covered or uncovered occupied projection or partial projection outside external walls, attached to building and accessed from building interior spaces (see figure k.1)

basement floor storey of building wholly or partly below gate level that not first storey above gate level. basement slab soffit level not higher than 1,500 mm above building gate level. k 4 building projection projection or protrusion that extends outside vertical external wall of floor below, such as balconies
community single family dwelling units built in group by developer and sold, leased or rented to individual families
corridor enclosed component that defines and provides path of travel
courtyard open, uncovered space, unobstructed to sky, bounded on three or more sides by exterior building walls or other enclosing devices as shown in figure k.2

(a) all sides bounded courtyard (b) 3 sides bounded courtyard figure k.2 courtyard figure k.1 balcony boundary wall or fence free-standing structure constructed from approved materials surrounding plot, resting on ground and rising above ground level and used for confinement and/or screening for safety or security or division purposes
building height, total vertical distance measured from approved road edge level at plot main access to highest roof surface or element

building height vertical distance measured from approved road edge level at plot main access to mean finished level of building roof. dubai building code part k villas flight continuous run of stair treads from one landing to another
garage building or structure, or any part thereof, used or intended for parking or storage of vehicles, which may or may not include roof
gate level defined height on plots boundary at vehicular or pedestrian access point to plot. it elevation difference between road level (existing or future) and level of plots access point
gate level of plot minimum height of +300 mm from edge of road level or slope of between 2-5% from edge of road to plots access point

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features

gross area (ga) floor area within inside perimeter of exterior walls of building. measurement excludes shafts and courtyards, but includes corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, base of atria (or similar voids) and thickness of interior walls, columns or other features

ground floor first floor in building above gate level. guardrail vertical protective barrier erected along elevated walking surfaces, exposed edges of stairways, balconies and similar areas that minimizes possibility of fall from elevated surfaces to lower level

ground floor first floor in building above gate level. guardrail vertical protective barrier erected along elevated walking surfaces, exposed edges of stairways, balconies and similar areas that minimizes possibility of fall from elevated surfaces to lower level
guard room room, unit, or residential space on same plot of land as main building, or located within main building, designated for occupancy of guard

habitable space space in building for living, sleeping or eating involving occupancy for continuous period of time. bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces and similar areas not habitable spaces. handrail horizontal or sloping rail intended for handhold and grasping by hand for guidance or support (see figure k.3)
hardscape area of project site, excluding buildings, made with hard materials, including roads, car parks, patios, courtyards and walkways

k 5 01 03 02 figure k.3 stair components key 01 handrail 02 riser 03 tread housekeepers room attached or separate room or unit on same plot of land as main building, designated for residence of housekeepers or other maintenance staff such as gardeners, guards and drivers. landing floor area at top of flight of stairs or between two flights of stairs, or platform or part of floor structure at end of ramp or at entrance to elevator car
dubai building code part k villas low-rise building building height less than or up to 15 m, measured in accordance with uae flsc ref. k.1. more detailed definition given in uae flsc
massing overall mass or size of building or project, its physical volume or magnitude

net area (na) actual occupied area, not including unoccupied accessory areas such as corridors, stairways, ramps, toilet rooms, mechanical rooms and closets. net floor height net distance between finished floor level (ffl) of floor and exposed surface of floor celling. k 6 parapet wall part of any wall entirely above roof line

net area (na) actual occupied area, not including unoccupied accessory areas such as corridors, stairways, ramps, toilet rooms, mechanical rooms and closets. net floor height net distance between finished floor level (ffl) of floor and exposed surface of floor celling. k 6 parapet wall part of any wall entirely above roof line

plot area of land that a) clearly defined (by landmarks, coordinates, distinct number, and lengths of its sides and location) b) intended for construction under any approved plan or division project, or by any other method and c) legally authorized to be used for construction or building as one unit
riser near-vertical element in set of stairs, forming space between one step and next (see figure k.3)
dubai building code part k villas space identifiable area including room, toilet, hall, assembly area, entrance, storage room, alcove, courtyard or lobby
swimming pool constructed pool for swimming, bathing or wading whether above or below ground surface regardless of depth or water surface area
terraces covered or uncovered platform or roof, protected by guardrail or parapet wall and supported by structure of floor below

townhouses multiple villas connected by one or more walls to series of similar villas. tread stepping space in stair flight to set foot (see figure k.3). vehicle access roadway, usually paved, intended to provide ingress and egress of vehicular traffic from public right-of-way to building entrance or parking area
vehicular gate barrier intended for use at vehicular entrance or exit to facility, building or portion thereof
villa separate building located on separate plot allocated with all its floors for dwelling of one single family with independent car parking space in addition to independent external open space

k.2.3 accessibility accessibility ease of independent approach, entry, evacuation and/or use of building and its services and facilities by all of buildings potential users, regardless of disability, age or gender, and with assurance of individual health, safety and welfare
k.2.4 building envelope building elevation view showing image of one side of building. flat representation of one faade
containment glass barrier resisting penetration and preventing people from falling even after failure or breakage
damp-proof course layer of waterproof material or construction in wall of building near ground, to prevent rising damp

k 7 dubai building code part k villas thermal insulation materials/products or methods and processes used to reduce heat transfer. heat energy can be transferred by conduction, convection or radiation. flow of heat can be delayed by addressing one or more of these mechanisms and dependent on physical properties of material employed to do this

thermal transmittance rate of transfer of heat through material(s) or assembly, expressed as u-value. vapour resistance layer material layer within wall or roof build-up with high resistance to moisture vapour
glazing glass that installed as one of components of wall, floor, ceiling or roofing system. groundwater pressure pressure of groundwater held within soil or rock, in gaps between particles

solid metal panels factory manufactured panel consisting of solid metal skin or skins without core. solid metal panels could be aluminium, steel, copper, zinc, stainless steel, titanium, etc. mould type of fungus that grows on damp or decaying material surfaces

solid metal panels factory manufactured panel consisting of solid metal skin or skins without core. solid metal panels could be aluminium, steel, copper, zinc, stainless steel, titanium, etc. mould type of fungus that grows on damp or decaying material surfaces

operational forces forces sustained by building envelope during operation of building, e.g. impact from equipment or occupants. shading coefficient (sc) ratio of solar heat gain at normal incidence through glazing to that occurring through approximately 3 mm thick clear float glass

thermal bridge component or assembly of components penetrating through otherwise continuous thermal line through which heat transferred at substantially higher rate than through surrounding envelope areas. examples could be metal fastener, concrete beam, balcony slab or column. k 8 dubai building code part k villas k.2.5 structure k.2.6 incoming utilities geotechnical laboratory physical or legal entity in charge of carrying out geotechnical soil investigations and licensed to practice investigation activities in dubai in accordance with applicable legislation. electrical k.2.6.1 accessory device, other than current-using equipment, associated with such equipment or with wiring of installation

geotechnical specialist contractor physical or legal person in charge of carrying out specialist geotechnical works and design. it licensed to practice geotechnical construction and design activities in dubai in accordance with applicable legislation. serviceability condition beyond which structure or member becomes unfit for service and judged to be no longer useful for its intended use. active power real component of apparent power, expressed in watts (w)/kilowatts (kw)/megawatts (mw)

apparent power product of voltage (in volt) and current (in amps). it usually expressed in kilovolt- ampere (kva) or megavolt-ampere (mva) and consist of real component (active power) and imaginary component (reactive power)
arc fault detection device (afdd) devices that protect specifically against arc faults. they automatically trip circuit when they detect dangerous electric arcs
bonding conductor protective conductor providing equipotential bonding
bunched cables two or more cables that contained within single conduit, duct, or trunking, or if not enclosed, not separated from each other by specified distance
k 9 dubai building code part k villas conduit part of closed wiring system for cables in electrical installations, allowing them to be drawn in and/or replaced, but not inserted laterally
connector part of cable coupler or of appliance coupler which provided with female contacts and intended to be attached to end of flexible cable remote from supply
current-using equipment equipment which converts electrical energy into another form of energy, such as light, heat or motive power

duct enclosure of metal or insulating material, other than conduit or cable trunking, intended for protection of cables which drawn in after erection of ducting. earth conductive mass of earth, whose electric potential at any point conventionally taken as zero

earth continuity conductor (ecc) conductor used for some measures of protection against electric shock and intended for connecting together any of following parts a) exposed conductive parts b) extraneous-conductive-parts c) main earthing terminal d) earth electrode(s) or e) earthed point of source, or artificial neutral

earth continuity conductor (ecc) conductor used for some measures of protection against electric shock and intended for connecting together any of following parts a) exposed conductive parts b) extraneous-conductive-parts c) main earthing terminal d) earth electrode(s) or e) earthed point of source, or artificial neutral

k 10 dubai building code part k villas equipment any item for purposes such as generation, conversion, transmission, distribution or utilization of electrical energy, such as machines, transformers, apparatus, measuring instruments, protective devices, wiring systems, accessories, appliances and luminaires
equipotential bonding electrical connection maintaining various exposed conductive parts and extraneous conductive-parts at substantially same potential

exposed conductive part conductive part of equipment which can be touched, and which not live part, but which may become live under fault. external influence any influence external to electrical installation which affects design and safe operation of that installation

extra-low voltage normally not exceeding 50 v ac or 120 v ripple free dc, whether between conductors or to earth. fault circuit condition in which current flows through abnormal or unintended path, which can result from insulation failure or bridging of insulation. fault current current resulting from fault
low smoke and fume (lsf) cable cable rated class cca-s1b, d2, a2 in accordance with bs en 13501-6
flexible cable cable in which structure and materials make it suitable to be flexed while in service

isolator mechanical switching device which, in open position, meets requirements specified for isolating function. live part conductor or conductive part intended to be energised in normal use, including neutral conductor

low voltage normally exceeding extra-low voltage but not exceeding 1,000 v ac or 1,500 v dc between conductors, or 600 v ac or 900 v dc between conductors and earth. actual voltage of installation may differ from nominal value by quantity within normal tolerances

luminaire equipment which distributes, filters or transforms light from one or more lamps, and which includes any parts necessary for supporting, fixing and protecting lamps, but not lamps themselves, and, where necessary, circuit auxiliaries together with means for connecting them to supply

main earthing terminal terminal or bar provided for connection of protective conductors, including equipotential bonding conductors, and conductors for functional earthing, if any, to means of earthing

main earthing terminal terminal or bar provided for connection of protective conductors, including equipotential bonding conductors, and conductors for functional earthing, if any, to means of earthing
maximum demand summation of all electrical power demand that has occurred during specified period, measured in kw or kva

k 11 dubai building code part k villas nominal voltage voltage by which installation (or part of installation) designated. overcurrent current exceeding rated value. for conductors rated value current- carrying capacity
k 12 pv generator assembly of pv array
pv string circuit in which pv modules connected in series, for pv array to generate required output voltage
residual current vector sum of instantaneous values of current flowing through all live conductors of circuit at point in electrical installation

residual current operated circuit breaker with integral overcurrent protection (rcbo) residual current operating device designed to perform functions of protection against overall load and/or short circuit

residual current operated circuit breaker without integral overcurrent protection (rccb) residual current operated switching device not designed to perform functions of protection against overload and/or short circuit. resistance area surface area of ground (around earth electrode only) on which significant voltage gradient may exist
dubai building code part k villas wiring system assembly made up of cables or busbars and parts which secure and, if necessary, enclosed cable or busbar
xlpe cable cross linked polyethylene as insulation of cable

telecommunications k.2.6.2 building entry point (bep) point where external ducts physically enter building. this can be standalone location or incorporated into another telecoms space. cable pathway any system used to route cables, such as cable ducting, cable ladder, cable tray, conduit, duct and maintenance chamber

fibre to x (fttx) delivery of optical fibre signals directly to location. for sp telecom services x may be defined as b (building), c (cabinet), h (home), p (premise). optical network terminal (ont) active component of fttx optical network located at tenant premises

optical splitter passive component of fttx optical network taking signal from either one or two input optical cores and equally dividing signal to splitter outputs. k 13 passive optical network (pon) point to multipoint fttx network architecture utilizing unpowered optical splitters. variants of pon using same topology and passive components include gpon, xg-pon, xgs-pon and ng-pon2
k.2.7 indoor environment k.2.7.1 hvac systems and occupant comfort air contaminants unwanted airborne constituents that might reduce acceptability or adequacy of air quality
dubai building code part k villas diversity factor relates to thermal characteristics of building envelope, temperature swings and occupancy load

ductwork leakage escape of air through cracks and gaps when air-conditioning ductwork not airtight. ductwork leakage will result in increase in energy consumption of supply and return air fans. exhaust air air removed from building space and discharged to outside of building through mechanical or natural ventilation system

global warming potential (gwp) contribution of greenhouse gases released to atmosphere in global warming phenomenon. heat load calculation process of calculating total heat generated inside building by various sources. heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system (hvac) equipment, distribution systems, and terminals that provide either individually or collectively, processes of heating, ventilating, or air- conditioning to building or portion of building

make-up air (dedicated replacement air) air deliberately brought into building from outdoors and supplied to vicinity of exhaust hood to replace air and cooking effluent being exhausted. make-up air generally filtered and fan- forced, and it may be heated or cooled depending on requirements of application
space pressurization static pressure difference between adjacent spaces of building, with air tending to move from higher pressure spaces to lower- pressure spaces

supply air air entering space from air- conditioning, heating, or ventilating system for purpose of comfort conditioning. supply air generally filtered, fan-forced, and heated, cooled, humidified, or dehumidified as necessary to maintain specified temperature and humidity conditions. only quantity of outdoor air within supply airflow used as replacement air. thermal comfort condition of mind which expresses satisfaction with thermal environment. thermal comfort measurement subjective in nature as it depends on environmental and personal factors

k 14 dubai building code part k villas thermal insulation materials/products or methods and processes used to reduce heat transfer. heat energy can be transferred by conduction, convection or radiation. flow of heat can be delayed by addressing one or more of these mechanisms and dependent on physical properties of material employed to do this
k.2.7.2 water backflow flow upstream, that in direction contrary to intended normal direction of flow, within or from water fitting
microbiological bacteria microorganism capable of causing disease that may be transmitted via water supply
pumped hot water return domestic hot water return system that uses to pump generate circulation in pipework system. thermal balancing valve automatic valve that balances hot water return subcircuits
water outlet opening for discharge of water via plumbing fixture such as tap or showerhead
drainage k.2.7.3 cesspit holding tank installed below ground that used for temporary collection of faecal matter

drainage system system composed of drainage equipment, and other components collecting waste water and discharging by means of gravity, or effluent pumping plant which can be part of gravity drainage system. floor gully discharge fitting intended to receive water from floors through apertures in grating or from waste pipes that connect to floor gully body or trap. greywater waste water not containing faecal matter or urine

manhole chamber construction that provides access into drainage. chamber dimensions permit man entry at sewer drain level (if required). rainwater water resulting from natural precipitation that has not deliberately contaminated
sanitary fittings fittings supplied with water that used for cleaning and washing (i.e. baths, showers, wash basins, bidets and water closets)
sanitary fittings fittings supplied with water that used for cleaning and washing (i.e. baths, showers, wash basins, bidets and water closets)
k 15 dubai building code part k villas sanitation pipework arrangement of discharge pipework, with or without ventilated pipes, connected to drainage system
soakaway buried drainage feature that used to manage surface water on site and infiltrate into surrounding ground upper floor any floor above lowest level, which could be basement level

ventilation pipework main vertical ventilating pipe, connected to discharge stack, to limit pressure fluctuations within discharge stack. wastewater water which contaminated by use and all water discharging into drainage system

cross-references to other parts relate to design of systems or spaces such as elevators, prayer rooms, assembly areas, electrical or it rooms and underground parking which may be added to villa/townhouse but it not common practice
villas and townhouses converted to retail, restaurant, clinics or other non-residential use shall conform to parts to j

k.5.1 general architectural requirements villas and townhouses shall be designed according to planning limitations and provisions required by authorities, as stipulated in development control regulations (dcr) and/or affection plans. limitations on development include, but not limited to a) setbacks b) access locations c) datum level d) service lines e) any other planning restriction

villas and townhouses located in heritage areas should respect identity of these areas and shall adhere to any conservation requirements imposed by authorities. villa/townhouse or development should take following into account 1) arabic and islamic cultural identity 2) 3) local architectural character relationship with surrounding environment 4) compatibility with planning limitations and urban planning themes of surrounding developments. massing of proposed structure should take into account visual privacy of adjacent residential buildings in surrounding properties and neighbourhoods
space for utility provision and other services as required by concerned service providing authorities shall be provided within plot limits

k 26 dubai building code part k villas k.5.2 development limitations gate level k.5.2.1 gate level defined height on plots boundary at vehicular or pedestrian access point to plot. it elevation difference between road level (existing or future) and level of plots access point
gate level of plot shall be minimum height of +300 mm from edge of road level or slope of between 2-5% from edge of road to plots access point
building height k.5.2.2 villa and townhouse heights shall follow provisions noted within plot dcrs and affection plans as provided by permitting authorities

villa and townhouse height shall be calculated from approved road edge level at plot main access to average roof finish floor level as shown in figure k.4. ground level should be elevated from adjacent roads for protection from flooding. maximum total building height shall be limited to 16 m. k 27 2%-5% figure k.4 villa/townhouse height key 01 roof structure 02 roof level 03 ground floor 04 total building height 05 building height 06 gate level 07 road edge level plot limit 01 03 dubai building code part k villas annexes k.5.2.3 it permitted to build annexes to residential villas/townhouses without any setback from plot boundary

villa type villa annexes can be used as private garages, housekeepers rooms, external kitchens, amenities such as gym or enclosed swimming pool, or as majlis. townhouse/attached villa setback from road (z) (m) setback from neighbour (x) (m) setback from sikka (y) (m) 3 3 3 0 3 3 annexes shall conform to following requirements. table k.1 setback requirement key 01 villa 02 annex x setback from neighbours setback from sikka z setback from road a) setback shall be not less than 1.5 between annex and main villa building. in townhouses annex can be attached to main townhouse building. see figure k.5 and figure k.6
b) annexes shall either be attached to plot boundary or follow building setback requirements in accordance with k.5.2.4
c) area of annex shall not exceed 60% of main building gross area (ga)
d) maximum height of annex shall be limited to 5.5

01 building setbacks k.5.2.4 building setbacks shall follow permitting authorities requirements as noted in dcr or affection plan. dcr and affection plan limitations shall take precedence over requirements of this section
villas shall be separated or exterior walls shall be fire resistance rated to prevent external fire spread as required by ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. k.1

02 when setback limitations not defined, setbacks shall be in accordance with table k.1 and figure k.5 to figure k.9. for standalone villas, distance between multiple buildings within same plot shall be not less than 1.5 measured from least horizontal distance between buildings. setbacks for annexes shall conform to k.5.2.3

balconies, building projections and terraces limitations k.5.2.5 k.5.2.5.1 balconies and building projections shall conform to dcr or affection plan. dcr and affection plan limitations shall take precedence over requirements of this section
balconies and building projections shall meet following requirements. b) balconies and projections shall follow setback requirements and shall not project beyond plot limit
c) decorative projections up to 300 mm in depth allowed within villa setback not less than 2.7 above ffl. at roof, decorative projections allowed up to 900 mm in depth

d) minimum horizontal distance of projections from adjacent villas/townhouses or neighbouring plot limits shall be not less than 3 m. e) balconies shall be provided with life safety features, such as fall protection and guardrails in accordance with k.5.2.5.2
f) privacy of neighbouring plots should be taken into account when setting location and orientations of balconies

w 02 01 w  10% ofa key 01 habitable space room area w window net glazing area figure k.21 window glazing area to room area ratio key 01 door clear width 02 door figure k.20 door minimum clear width k 38 dubai building code part k villas following requirements and recommendations apply to windows

01 key 01 additional opening a) when windows equipped with mechanical opening means, they shall be positioned at height between 900 mm to 1,500 mm from room ffl. b) operable portion of window shall be positioned at safe height. window sill shall be positioned at height of not less than 900 mm from interior ffl

c) required amount of daylighting can be provided through skylights or windows or combination of both for all building spaces. skylight glazing should be positioned at slope of 15 or more from vertical and directly connected to space it serves

headings: habitable room conditions for natural lighting
Description: k.5.4.2.2 habitable room conditions for natural lighting for rooms to be adequately naturally lit through windows, room depth should not exceed three times its width (see figure k.22)

when room depth exceeds three times width in which window of room located, additional natural lighting should be provided through additional window adhering to criteria set in figure k.22. additional window can be along any of rooms other sides with direct access to daylighting. k 39 d<3x w=x figure k.22 windows in rooms k.5.4.2.3 access to views direct line of sight (views) shall be provided to outdoor environment from habitable spaces

dubai building code part k villas k.5.5 circulation and egress hallways and corridors k.5.5.1 hallways and corridors shall have minimum clear width of 1.0 and clear headroom of 2.3 without obstructions (see figure k.23)

key 01 bedroom 02 ensuite toilet 03 internal corridor figure k.23 corridor example stairs k.5.5.2 k.5.5.2.1 general spiral stairs, winders and open stairs permitted for all uses other than access and exit from basements. basements shall have standard enclosed exit stair of 1,000 mm clear width leading to discharge level. k.5.5.2.2 all stairways shall have at least 1,000 mm clear width

stairway width k 40 required width of stairway shall be measured from wall to clear available width of step (see figure k.24). maximum projections of handrails allowed in required width 100 mm on each side, at height of 865 mm to 965 mm (see figure k.24)

riser heights shall be as uniform as possible throughout each stair flight between landings
where riser heights adjusted to meet acceptable stair treads, flights and arrangements, there shall be no more than 10 mm difference in riser height within single flight
minimum stair tread depth shall be not less than 280 mm (see figure k.26)

tread depth shall be as uniform as possible throughout stair. there shall be no more than 10 mm difference in tread depth within single flight. 280 01 100-180 figure k.26 step dimensions 02 b key 01 riser height = - b 02 riser height = + b b figure k.25 stair risers k 41 dubai building code part k villas landings k.5.5.2.4 intermediate landing not required on stairways in villas regardless of floor to floor height. intermediate landings recommended if floor to floor height exceeds typical practice (e.g. > 4m). for enclosed staircases, stair shall have landing at door opening and landing width shall be not less than required stairway width
maximum landing area that door can encroach in its swing one half of required landing width
landing width shall not decrease in width along direction of egress travel, as shown in figure k.27
landing width shall be not less than 1,000 mm. landing width not required to exceed 1,000 mm in direction of travel, provided that stairway has straight run
landing slope shall not exceed 21 mm/m (2% slope)

handrails shall continue for full length of each flight of stair

headings: spiral or curved stairs and winders
Description: spiral or curved stairs and winders a) clear width of stairs shall be not less than 1,000 mm
b) curved stair headroom shall be not less than 2,300 mm and spiral stair headroom shall be not less than 2,030 mm
c) spiral stairs shall have tread depth not less than 190 mm at point 305 mm from narrower edge (see figure k.32)
d) curved stairs shall have tread depth of not less than 255 mm at point 305 mm from narrowest edge (see figure k.33)
e) height of risers shall not exceed 240 mm
f) all treads shall be identical
g) handrails shall be provided in accordance with k.5.5.2.5
h) turn of stairway shall be such that outer handrail at right side 305 of descending users
i) winders (see figure k.31) shall have tread depth of not less than 150 mm at their narrowest, and tread depth of not less than 280 mm when measured at point 305 mm from narrowest edge
spiral stairs have limited capacity for circulation and movement and not recommended to be utilized as main stairway of villa

k 46 dubai building code part k villas vehicle access and movement k.5.6.3 k.5.6.3.1 general requirements vehicle access shall be located away from any traffic intersections depending on road type, vehicle type and other factors as approved by authority. vehicle access shall conform to rta row requirements and shall be designed in accordance with rta dubai access management manual ref. k.3 and rta geometric design manual for dubai roads ref. k.4
vehicular entries and exits shall be separated from any local road intersection by at least 6 from chamfered edge of plot (see figure k.35)
access shall be as defined in affection plan or dcr and subject to agreement and approval from rta
vehicle access shall not be located opposite junction, as shown in figure k.36
k.5.5.3 if ramps provided for access, they shall conform to c.5.9.1
ramps k.5.5.4 if elevators provided, their design shall conform to d.5 and d.6
elevators k.5.5.5 means of egress shall conform to ch. 3 of uae flsc ref. k.1

means of egress k.5.6 access and vehicular requirements building access k.5.6.1 following provisions shall be included when setting villa/townhouse access strategy during design process. a) design shall allow for pedestrian access. b) access routes for firefighting shall be provided in accordance with ch.2 of uae flsc ref. k.1. c) all parts of site to which vehicles may have access shall be hard-surfaced and drained

means of egress k.5.6 access and vehicular requirements building access k.5.6.1 following provisions shall be included when setting villa/townhouse access strategy during design process. a) design shall allow for pedestrian access. b) access routes for firefighting shall be provided in accordance with ch.2 of uae flsc ref. k.1. c) all parts of site to which vehicles may have access shall be hard-surfaced and drained

firefighting vehicle access k.5.6.2 for cluster housing developments (with shared communal facilities), fire truck accessway with width not less than 6 shall be provided to within travel distance of 60 from every point on projected plan area of any building in housing developments, as shown in figure 2.10, ch. 2 of uae flsc ref. k.1

k 51 k.5.7 sanitary requirements general requirements k.5.7.1 every villa/townhouse shall include sanitary facilities, including water closet, sink and bathtub or shower
water closet, wash basins, showers and baths shall have smooth and readily cleanable non-absorbent surface

all sanitary fixture finishing materials and fixed fittings shall be moisture-proof and floors of these fixtures shall be made of non-slip materials. lighting shall be provided in all sanitary facilities

appropriate ventilation should be provided in all sanitary facilities in accordance with k.10.1.6. in toilets, bathrooms and shower rooms, floor finish material shall have smooth, hard, non-absorbent surface. intersections of such floors with walls shall have smooth, hard, non-absorbent vertical base that extends upward to walls to height of not less than 100 mm
walls and partitions within 600 mm of sanitary fixtures shall have smooth, hard, non-absorbent surface, up to height of not less than 1,200 mm above ffl. finished material should be moisture-proof
shower compartments and walls above bathtubs shall be finished with smooth, non-absorbent surface to height of not less than 1,800 mm above drain outlet

dubai building code part k villas fixture clearances k.5.7.2 fixed fittings in sanitary facilities shall conform to fixture clearances in figure k.40 and as follows a) centres of water closet, wash basins and faucets shall be not less than 1) 400 mm from any side wall, partition, vanity or other obstruction and 2) 750 mm from centre of adjacent fixture. b) there shall be 750 mm clearance in front of water closet or wash basin to any wall or door leaf, and 600 mm clearance to any opposite fixture

swimming pools shall be provided with adequate lighting, both above and under water surface in order to provide adequate illumination for overall area of pool
operable windows adjacent to pool shall have minimum sill height of 1,200 mm above indoor ffl
swimming pools shall conform to safety requirements of dm-ph & sd-gu80- prsps2 ref. k.5

c) any openings in fence shall not allow passage of 100 mm diameter sphere

dubai building code part k villas k.5.9 waste storage general k.5.9.1 all villas and townhouses shall be provided with suitable area for storage of general waste and recycling. this shall be either d) distance that waste contractors have to travel in order to access waste storage areas, from location where waste collection vehicle can safely stop, should be no more than 30 for bins of up to 240 l, or 15 for containers greater than 240 l. manual manoeuvring of waste containers greater than 1,500 l in capacity should be avoided as far as possible

a) dedicated waste storage area within boundary of property with e) to limit effect of odour, waste storage areas shall not be placed in close minimum of one 240 l bin for general waste, and one 240 l bin for recycling, with maximum allowable container size of 360 l or proximity to property and any ventilation openings shall be located away from windows

b) communal waste storage area for consolidated storage of waste and f) waste storage area shall meet requirements for fire safety as detailed in recycling from multiple properties. this shall be adequately roofed and enclosed and located in convenient and accessible location. communal waste storage areas shall be provided with larger bulk containers for waste and recycling of up to 2,500 l as appropriate. k.5.9.2 specification of waste storage areas all waste storage areas shall meet following requirements

b) communal waste storage area for consolidated storage of waste and f) waste storage area shall meet requirements for fire safety as detailed in recycling from multiple properties. this shall be adequately roofed and enclosed and located in convenient and accessible location. communal waste storage areas shall be provided with larger bulk containers for waste and recycling of up to 2,500 l as appropriate. k.5.9.2 specification of waste storage areas all waste storage areas shall meet following requirements
where waste storage room or enclosed waste storage area provided, including those provided for communal waste storage, following additional requirements shall be met
1) waste storage areas shall have concrete pad designed to handle load of bins and any other equipment

a) waste storage areas shall be convenient and easily accessible for residents and waste contractors alike. where access by waste management contractor required, suitable and unimpeded access shall be provided for waste collection vehicles to allow easy removal of waste and recycling from property. 2) floor and wall surfacing shall be finished with non-slip concrete, ceramic tiles, or similar impervious and waterproof material to facilitate cleaning. textured finishes should be avoided, as they attract dirt and detritus. walls, floors and ceilings shall be finished with light colour

b) access to waste storage areas shall be sufficient to facilitate easy entry, exit and manoeuvring of waste and recycling containers. where change in floor level exists, any longitudinal gradient falling away from storage location shall not exceed 8.33% (112). access paths should be free of kerbs and steps, and avoid difficult turns and bends. drop kerbs shall be provided where access paths meet roadways. 3) water supply and adequate drainage shall be provided to facilitate cleaning of waste storage area and waste containers. this may be provided direct from water supply network or from high-level tank. all drains and gullies should be connected to drainage pipes of development and have cleanable filters and/or grates to prevent blockages to drainage system caused by waste residue
c) distance that residents have to travel in order to access waste storage areas, whether separated or as part of building, should be no more than 50 m, excluding any vertical distance
4) lighting shall be provided with sealed (ingress protection rated) bulkhead fittings to protect against water from cleaning and washdown

k 54 dubai building code part k villas 5) all windows shall be airtight and protected by metal mesh wire screen in order d) dimensions of waste storage area shall allow for manoeuvring of to prevent insects and rodents from accessing waste storage area

6) all doors shall be provided with ventilation louvers or mechanical ventilation. doors shall open to outside and be fitted with automatic door closers. they shall be of sufficient width to allow waste containers to pass into and out of waste storage area. dimensions of waste storage areas k.5.9.3 suitable storage space for waste and recycling shall be calculated and determined based on type and number of containers required and collection frequency. storage space provision shall be sized for two days of waste and recycling generation as minimum. in order to determine area required for waste storage, following requirements shall be met a) required number of containers shall be calculated based on estimates of potential waste and recycling quantity to be generated by development, using suitable metrics for estimating waste and recycling produced, such as expected occupancy of development, and number of bedrooms. suggested waste generation rate of 2.5 kg/bedroom provided by authority

6) all doors shall be provided with ventilation louvers or mechanical ventilation. doors shall open to outside and be fitted with automatic door closers. they shall be of sufficient width to allow waste containers to pass into and out of waste storage area. dimensions of waste storage areas k.5.9.3 suitable storage space for waste and recycling shall be calculated and determined based on type and number of containers required and collection frequency. storage space provision shall be sized for two days of waste and recycling generation as minimum. in order to determine area required for waste storage, following requirements shall be met a) required number of containers shall be calculated based on estimates of potential waste and recycling quantity to be generated by development, using suitable metrics for estimating waste and recycling produced, such as expected occupancy of development, and number of bedrooms. suggested waste generation rate of 2.5 kg/bedroom provided by authority

6) all doors shall be provided with ventilation louvers or mechanical ventilation. doors shall open to outside and be fitted with automatic door closers. they shall be of sufficient width to allow waste containers to pass into and out of waste storage area. dimensions of waste storage areas k.5.9.3 suitable storage space for waste and recycling shall be calculated and determined based on type and number of containers required and collection frequency. storage space provision shall be sized for two days of waste and recycling generation as minimum. in order to determine area required for waste storage, following requirements shall be met a) required number of containers shall be calculated based on estimates of potential waste and recycling quantity to be generated by development, using suitable metrics for estimating waste and recycling produced, such as expected occupancy of development, and number of bedrooms. suggested waste generation rate of 2.5 kg/bedroom provided by authority

b) waste storage areas shall accommodate all required containers according to their standard size. type of container required shall be determined based on quantity of waste and recycling generated by development, and practicalities of access to development and removal of waste and recycling by waste management contractor. c) guideline dimensions and examples of typical container sizes shown in table k.8 and table k.9. container sizes vary by manufacturer. typical standards for waste containers provided in bs en 840-1 to bs en 840-4 and these shall be taken into account when determining waste storage requirements

required containers so as to provide suitable access to containers as well as easy removal and return to waste storage area. this shall include minimum clearance of 150 mm between individual containers and between containers and any surrounding walls. any doors or openings through which waste containers must pass through shall be wide enough to accommodate relevant waste container sizes

k 57 dubai building code part k villas k.7 building envelope k.7.1 structural strength and stability k.7.1.1 k.7.1.1.1 general any part of building envelope presents hazard if it becomes detached from building. building envelope and associated openings shall be designed and constructed to safely resist loads required by k.8 and those mentioned in this section

k 57 dubai building code part k villas k.7 building envelope k.7.1 structural strength and stability k.7.1.1 k.7.1.1.1 general any part of building envelope presents hazard if it becomes detached from building. building envelope and associated openings shall be designed and constructed to safely resist loads required by k.8 and those mentioned in this section

building envelope shall a) be capable of safely sustaining, and transmitting to supporting structure of building, all static and dynamic design loads (i.e. dead, imposed, thermal, seismic, wind, etc.) without fracture or permanent deterioration of its performance b) be securely fixed to and supported by structure of building. this shall comprise both vertical support and horizontal restraints c) be made, where necessary, to accommodate differential movement of cladding and supporting structure of building, such as differential settlement, inter-storey drifts, etc. d) be of durable materials/products. service life of fixings shall be not less than building envelope. fixings shall be corrosion-resistant and of material type appropriate for local environment and exposure conditions e) not fully or partially detach from building (although it may break under life safety structural performance level as described in k.8) and f) not be source of noise or be at risk of resonant excitation caused by wind

k.7.1.1.2 wind loads wind loads shall be calculated in accordance with k.8.4.11. note pressure coefficients might vary across building envelope. higher pressure expected at corners

load resistance and transmission k.7.1.1.3 building envelope shall be capable of resisting and transmitting to its points of support all static and dynamic design loads without fracture or permanent deterioration of its performance. there shall be no significant irreversible deformation of surfaces resulting from such design loads

k.7.1.1.4 permanent fixture loading building envelopes which intended to support permanent fixtures and/or maintenance equipment attached to either internal or external faces shall be capable of withstanding, without excessive deflection or permanent deterioration of its performance, forces arising from these fixtures, including during use. k.7.1.1.5 operational forces without any reduction in its performance, building envelope shall be capable of sustaining and transferring single concentrated load of 0.89 kn (200 lb) in accordance with section 4.5.1 of asce/sei 7-16, or be provided with guardrail

balustrades and guardrails at balconies, terraces, roofs and changes in level greater than 760 mm shall conform to k.5.2.5.2. k.7.1.1.6 thermal movements building envelope shall be capable of accommodating changes in dimension and shape of its components resulting from changes in service temperatures, and from differential service temperatures between inside and outside of building, without any reduction in its performance

k.7.4.2 building envelope shall ground moisture a) resist passage of moisture from ground to inside of building b) not be damaged by moisture from ground and c) not carry moisture from ground to any part which could be damaged

for building envelope walls that not subject to groundwater pressure, damp-proof course shall be provided at least 150 mm above level of adjoining ground, as shown in figure k.49, unless there part of building design that protects wall. damp-proof course shall be continuous with any damp-proof membrane in floor

k.7.4.3.2 horizontal and inclined surfaces horizontal surfaces or inclined surfaces in building envelope (see figure k.50) shall a) be jointless and impermeable to moisture b) have sealed joints and be impermeable to moisture or, figure k.49 minimum height for damp-proof course at ground level ( crown copyright, 2013. figure based on diagram 8 of building regulations (2010), approved document part c, 2004 edition with 2010 and 2013 amendments. contains public sector information licensed under open government licence v3.0) c) have overlapping joints and be impermeable or be backed by material which directs precipitation towards outer face

a) solid external walls wall shall hold moisture arising from rainwater until moisture can be released in dry period, without penetrating to inside of building or causing damage to building. if wall insulated, insulation shall provide resistance to ingress of moisture to keep wall dry. b) solid external walls with air cavities or with rainscreens outer leaf of external cavity wall shall either be separated from inner leaf by drained air space or prevent precipitation from being carried to inner leaf. c) curtain walling, doors and windows joints between curtain walling, doors, windows and interfaces with other walls shall resist penetration of precipitation to inside of building and not permit moisture to reach any part of building which could be damaged

10 11 10 11 08 (a) solid external walls (b) windows, doors or curtain walls 10 11 10 11 09 09 (c) solid external walls with rainscreens (d) solid external walls with cavities figure k.51 examples of external wall build-up types k 67 dubai building code part k villas flashing k.7.4.3.4 flashing shall be installed to prevent moisture from entering building envelope or redirect moisture to exterior. flashing shall be installed at a) perimeters of exterior door and window assemblies b) penetrations and terminations of exterior wall assemblies c) exterior wall intersections with roofs, balconies and similar projections and d) built-in gutters from which moisture could enter wall

k.7.4.4 building envelope shall risk of interstitial or surface condensation a) be designed and constructed such that its structural and thermal performance not adversely affected by interstitial condensation and b) not promote surface condensation or mould growth. following technical solutions may be used to minimize condensation risk, depending on wall type

headings: risk of interstitial or surface condensation
Description: k.7.4.4 building envelope shall risk of interstitial or surface condensation a) be designed and constructed such that its structural and thermal performance not adversely affected by interstitial condensation and b) not promote surface condensation or mould growth. following technical solutions may be used to minimize condensation risk, depending on wall type
1) curtain walling, skylight, doors and windows can incorporate thermal breaks in glazed framed systems. 2) roofs and solid external walls can include vapour resistance layer

3) interfaces and junctions between different elements of building envelope (such as windows) can ensure continuity of vapour barrier by extending and overlapping vapour resistance layer between elements

note bs 5250 gives further guidance on control of condensation in buildings. while guidance provides principles to control condensation, some commentary and forms of construction given in annexes might not be applicable to delete dubai climate. k 68 k.7.5 acoustics building envelope shall meet acoustic requirements of k.10.4

hard or sharp components of maintenance equipment shall be covered with soft protection prevent building envelope from being impacted. energy impact that maintenance equipment or operator might exert on building envelope shall be calculated. building envelope shall be capable of withstanding applied or transferred impacts that might occur during maintenance without sustaining damage that not repairable and without deterioration of its performance. k 71 dubai building code part k villas k.8 structure k.8.1 structural system requirements general conditions k.8.1.1 structural design of buildings shall be undertaken by engineer. engineer shall only use appropriate structural analysis and design software, approved by authority

structural system and robustness k.8.1.4 measures shall be taken to ensure that building stable under design basis load conditions. where necessary, these measures shall also allow for maximum credible loads for which collapse limit state might be chosen as being applicable

any features of structure that have critical influence on its overall stability shall be identified and included in design, including all members that provide restraint to critical members in compression. structure shall be designed to behave as one three- dimensional entity. layout of its constituent parts, such as foundations, primary frame, steelwork, joints and other structural components should constitute robust and stable system under normal loading to ensure that, in event of misuse or accident, damage will not be disproportionate to cause. measures shall be taken to ensure that building robust and resistant to disproportionate collapse under specified load conditions. engineer shall include implicit considerations of resistance to progressive collapse during design process through provisions stipulated under appendix c of asce/ sei 7-16 (indirect design approach). durability k.8.1.5 all elements shall be designed with appropriate detailing and material specifications to achieve specified design life, considering environment of project and whole lifecycle of building. following specific requirements shall be met

any features of structure that have critical influence on its overall stability shall be identified and included in design, including all members that provide restraint to critical members in compression. structure shall be designed to behave as one three- dimensional entity. layout of its constituent parts, such as foundations, primary frame, steelwork, joints and other structural components should constitute robust and stable system under normal loading to ensure that, in event of misuse or accident, damage will not be disproportionate to cause. measures shall be taken to ensure that building robust and resistant to disproportionate collapse under specified load conditions. engineer shall include implicit considerations of resistance to progressive collapse during design process through provisions stipulated under appendix c of asce/ sei 7-16 (indirect design approach). durability k.8.1.5 all elements shall be designed with appropriate detailing and material specifications to achieve specified design life, considering environment of project and whole lifecycle of building. following specific requirements shall be met
a) for concrete structures, engineer shall implement recommendations of bs en 206 and bs 8500-1 in design and specifications of concrete structures. criteria listed under f.11 shall also be followed

b) for steelwork structures, engineer shall provide steelwork material specifications, stating steel grades and protective paint systems which durable and compatible with climate of dubai. paint protective coatings for steelwork shall be specified in accordance with bs en 12944 as minimum, with additional requirements to address susceptibility of protective coatings to ultra violet degradation. k.8.2 fire resistance villas shall be classified group or group b in accordance with table 1.1, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. k.1

b) for steelwork structures, engineer shall provide steelwork material specifications, stating steel grades and protective paint systems which durable and compatible with climate of dubai. paint protective coatings for steelwork shall be specified in accordance with bs en 12944 as minimum, with additional requirements to address susceptibility of protective coatings to ultra violet degradation. k.8.2 fire resistance villas shall be classified group or group b in accordance with table 1.1, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. k.1

b) for steelwork structures, engineer shall provide steelwork material specifications, stating steel grades and protective paint systems which durable and compatible with climate of dubai. paint protective coatings for steelwork shall be specified in accordance with bs en 12944 as minimum, with additional requirements to address susceptibility of protective coatings to ultra violet degradation. k.8.2 fire resistance villas shall be classified group or group b in accordance with table 1.1, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. k.1

construction type and fire resistance of structure shall be defined based on classification of villa, height and general arrangement of largest storey of villa and whether it sprinkler protected or not in accordance with table 1.7, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. k.1. villas/townhouses do not require fire-rated or listed roof assemblies (see section 6.3.7, ch. 1 of uae flsc ref. k.1). structure supporting 2 h fire-rated walls between townhouses (see k.5.11) shall also achieve 2 h fire resistance. k 73 dubai building code part k villas k.8.3 materials k.8.4 loads structural design shall meet material requirements specified in codes and standards listed in table k.19. k.8.4.1 loads shall be defined in accordance with asce/sei 7-16 and this section. general remarks  k.8.4.2 loads shall be factored and combined in accordance with ch. 2 of asce/sei 7-16

dubai building code part k villas superimposed dead loads k.8.4.4 engineer responsible for determining superimposed dead loads for components not included as either live or dead loads (including anticipated internal partitions, floor and ceiling finishes, facades and external cladding). loads shall be defined as concentrated point loads, uniform loads on plan, and/or uniform loads on elevation, as appropriate. following minimum load allowances (defined as average uniform loads on plan) shall be adopted for purpose of evaluating maximum load effect a) internal drywall partitions b) suspended services with ceiling finishes c) suspended services without ceiling finishes 0.75 kn/m2 0.50 kn/m2 0.30 kn/m2

dubai building code part k villas superimposed dead loads k.8.4.4 engineer responsible for determining superimposed dead loads for components not included as either live or dead loads (including anticipated internal partitions, floor and ceiling finishes, facades and external cladding). loads shall be defined as concentrated point loads, uniform loads on plan, and/or uniform loads on elevation, as appropriate. following minimum load allowances (defined as average uniform loads on plan) shall be adopted for purpose of evaluating maximum load effect a) internal drywall partitions b) suspended services with ceiling finishes c) suspended services without ceiling finishes 0.75 kn/m2 0.50 kn/m2 0.30 kn/m2

engineer shall provide detailed calculations supporting superimposed dead load assumptions. if supporting calculations not provided, vertical load listed in table k.21 shall be included for partition assumptions. type of wall superimposed dead load applied vertically, including finishes (kn/m2) live loads k.8.4.5 minimum uniform live loads shall be not less than those listed in ch. 4 of asce/sei 7-16. following requirements shall also be followed

a) concentrated live loads shall be evaluated for objects creating significant point loads, including machinery, vehicles and storage racks. b) minimum live load for garage and car parking 3.5 kn/m2 which should be validated based on type of vehicles accessing facility. c) live load for drained areas of floor surrounding swimming pool 2 kn/m2. pool tanks and other areas susceptible to flooding shall be designed for load not less than maximum retained head of water
d) engineer shall design supporting structure to withstand loading imposed by mechanical, electrical and public health (mep) equipment in designated areas and along proposed equipment access route

soil loads and hydrostatic pressure k.8.4.6 minimum soil and hydrostatic pressures shall be not less than those listed in table k.22. lower values shall not be used without project specific justification. lightweight block wall normal weight block wall drywall 4.5 5.5 4.0 table k.21 minimum superimposed dead load loading plan drawings showing load provision should be submitted for approval. design assumptions shall be validated against systems installed. any late amendments and/or retrospective changes shall not be made without new approval

description soil for planters (saturated) compacted soil for trafficable areas water brackish water table k.22 material densities minimum load (kn/m3) 19 22 10 10.3 k 75 dubai building code part k villas in addition to geotechnical requirements specified under k.8.6, engineer shall include following aspects in design of permanent structures h) uplift due to heave shall also be included for both permanent and temporary conditions whenever applicable. a) all foundation elements and retaining walls shall be designed by recommendations given in geotechnical interpretive report (gir). b) design water table shall be established in gir considering fluctuation of water table level during design life of structure. in particular, effect of dewatering in neighbouring areas, seasonal variation of water table, future developments (such as canal, water bodies, landscaping and similar) and potential impact of climate change shall be included in definition of design groundwater level. design groundwater level and its fluctuations shall be stated by engineer in design drawings and agreed with authorities. c) in any case, minimum water table level shall be assumed as follows 1) in proximity to bodies of water 0.00 dubai municipality datum (dmd) plus 1.0 for seasonal and tidal variations and 2) away from bodies of water actual water table level with dewatering taken into account, as defined in gir, plus 1.0 for seasonal and tidal variations

d) for structures below water table, hydrostatic uplift and lateral pressures shall be checked in accordance with section 10 of bs en 1997-12004+a12013 and associated uk na. any dewatering system, whether used for construction or throughout design life, temporary unless system can be demonstrated to be reliable throughout design life. e) where construction of project staged, or in case of construction on adjacent plot, any possibility of unbalanced lateral soil load shall be included. f) any retaining wall assumed to be subjected to lateral pressure during construction shall be designed according to possible surcharge and hydrostatic loading. lateral soil pressure arising from compacted soil placement shall be included where this exceeds at rest or passive pressure (as relevant)

g) bracing conditions of retaining structure and construction sequence shall be carefully captured in analysis and design. construction load k.8.4.7 minimum design load requirements during construction of buildings shall be defined in accordance with asce 37
construction-stage loads, including locked-in stresses arising from construction sequence and affecting overall behaviour of structure, shall be included by engineer

engineer shall clearly state construction load assumptions on detailed design drawings and verify that structural system can withstand these loads during all stages of construction. any departure from engineers assumptions that invoked by contractors construction sequence shall be assessed

accidental impact load k.8.4.8 structural elements shall be designed to resist accidental impact loading conditions specified under section 4.6 of asce/sei 7-16. secondary protection system should be provided to all primary structural members to avoid accidental impact load

self-straining forces k.8.4.9 structures shall be designed to resist any self-straining forces arising from contraction or expansion of structural elements. such volume changes can result from shrinkage, creep and/or moisture change in component materials, including soil. it might occur at any stage in structures lifecycle. use of details to alleviate self-straining forces may be used when practical and not in violation of any assumed load paths. such details, where permanent, shall be durable and/or have provision for maintenance. k 76 dubai building code part k villas thermally induced forces k.8.4.10 thermally induced forces shall be derived considering structural restraints, and changes in temperature of structural members arising across construction/ operational phases, seasonal and daily variations

self-straining forces k.8.4.9 structures shall be designed to resist any self-straining forces arising from contraction or expansion of structural elements. such volume changes can result from shrinkage, creep and/or moisture change in component materials, including soil. it might occur at any stage in structures lifecycle. use of details to alleviate self-straining forces may be used when practical and not in violation of any assumed load paths. such details, where permanent, shall be durable and/or have provision for maintenance. k 76 dubai building code part k villas thermally induced forces k.8.4.10 thermally induced forces shall be derived considering structural restraints, and changes in temperature of structural members arising across construction/ operational phases, seasonal and daily variations

for effects on covered concrete structural members, mean monthly temperatures should be used to establish appropriate range. default thermal range of 20 c may be used for exposed concrete elements and 15 c for non-exposed concrete elements. for steel structural members and structural members exposed to solar radiation, range equivalent to maximum temperature swing appropriate. default thermal range of 25 c may be used for protected steel elements. for exposed steelwork, this can arise from hourly maxima and minima. engineer shall assess thermal range and assess thermally induced forces on case by case basis considering construction stages, exposure and when steel structure locked in final configuration. note relative humidity values and mean monthly temperature for specific sites available from national centre for meteorology and seismology website ref. k.17

for effects on covered concrete structural members, mean monthly temperatures should be used to establish appropriate range. default thermal range of 20 c may be used for exposed concrete elements and 15 c for non-exposed concrete elements. for steel structural members and structural members exposed to solar radiation, range equivalent to maximum temperature swing appropriate. default thermal range of 25 c may be used for protected steel elements. for exposed steelwork, this can arise from hourly maxima and minima. engineer shall assess thermal range and assess thermally induced forces on case by case basis considering construction stages, exposure and when steel structure locked in final configuration. note relative humidity values and mean monthly temperature for specific sites available from national centre for meteorology and seismology website ref. k.17

k.8.4.11 design for wind loading effects k.8.4.11.1 general engineer shall calculate effects of wind loading, taking into account strength for life safety, and serviceability for building movements affecting cladding or building occupant comfort. calculations for wind design shall be based on asce/sei 7-16 and additional rules for application in dubai from this section

k.8.4.11 design for wind loading effects k.8.4.11.1 general engineer shall calculate effects of wind loading, taking into account strength for life safety, and serviceability for building movements affecting cladding or building occupant comfort. calculations for wind design shall be based on asce/sei 7-16 and additional rules for application in dubai from this section

k.8.4.11.2 wind pressures this subclause provides basis for calculation of wind pressures to be used with asce/sei 7-16. wind speeds of table k.23 replace use of wind maps of section 26.5 or asce/sei 7-16. wind reference speed for 50 mri shall be used only for strength design in accordance with clause 5.3.5 of aci 318 19

vertical and horizontal deflections shall be within limits specified in referenced design standards, as applicable, and project specific requirements

when checking for deflections most adverse realistic combination and arrangement of serviceability loads shall be included. engineer shall verify that adopted deflection limits will enable functional performance of building to be maintained. in particular, following apply

a) deflection limits for steel structures shall conform to requirements stipulated in aisc 360 and aisc design guide 3 ref. k.24. b) deflection limits for concrete slabs and beams shall be in accordance with 24.2.2 of aci 318-19. value of incremental deflection shall not exceed 20 mm after installation of partition and finishes and shall be calculated in accordance with aci 435r-95 and aci 318-19. when evaluating deflection of concrete structures, detrimental effects of cracking shall be included by modifying stiffness (ei) for areas which have exceeded allowable tensile stresses. modified ei shall be chosen based on extent of cracking under design load. default stiffness modifiers given in aci 318-19 may be followed for regular structures subject to approximately uniform loads

c) design for strength and serviceability requirements of post-tensioned concrete members shall conform to aci 318-19. structural calculations shall verify that both short and long-term deflections, camber, vibration frequency and amplitude within permissible limits

c) design for strength and serviceability requirements of post-tensioned concrete members shall conform to aci 318-19. structural calculations shall verify that both short and long-term deflections, camber, vibration frequency and amplitude within permissible limits
crack control in concrete structure k.8.5.4 engineer shall perform crack width calculation checks for reinforced concrete structures in accordance with aci 224r
crack control in concrete structure k.8.5.4 engineer shall perform crack width calculation checks for reinforced concrete structures in accordance with aci 224r

in absence of more specific requirements, following maximum crack width limits shall be adopted a) for section of structure in contact with groundwater, crack width limits (wk) defined as function of ratio of hydrostatic pressure, hd to wall thickness of containing structure, hw
1) for hd/hw <5, wk = 0.2 mm

2) for hd/hw >35, wk = 0.05 mm. k 78 dubai building code part k villas purpose of this calculation to control displacements of building which can cause overstress or fatigue damage or loss of effectiveness to cladding, internal partitions or other non-structural components of buildings

movement joints common source of water infiltration. structures below ground level should be designed without movement joints to mitigate risk of water ingress. design for construction without permanent joints below ground level can be achieved by following recommendations provided in ciria c766 ref. k.22. vibration k.8.5.7 vibration and oscillation of building structures should be limited to avoid discomfort to users, damage to contents or damage to structure, as detailed below. a) steelwork. natural frequency of steelwork floor systems for normal occupancy shall be evaluated in accordance with aisc design guide 11 ref. k.25 or sci p354 ref. k.26

movement joints common source of water infiltration. structures below ground level should be designed without movement joints to mitigate risk of water ingress. design for construction without permanent joints below ground level can be achieved by following recommendations provided in ciria c766 ref. k.22. vibration k.8.5.7 vibration and oscillation of building structures should be limited to avoid discomfort to users, damage to contents or damage to structure, as detailed below. a) steelwork. natural frequency of steelwork floor systems for normal occupancy shall be evaluated in accordance with aisc design guide 11 ref. k.25 or sci p354 ref. k.26

c) section of structure not in contact with water wk = 0.3 mm
d) structural elements (such as piles) under permanent tension loads wk = 0.1 mm

k 79 dubai building code part k villas b) reinforced concrete. cast-in-place floor systems designed in accordance with minimum thickness and deflection requirements of aci 318-19 have generally found to provide vibration performance suitable for human comfort under typical service conditions. however, there might be situations where serviceability conditions not satisfied, for example 1) long spans and open floor plans 2) facilities subject to rhythmic loadings or vibrating mechanical equipment

transfer elements k.8.5.9 any beam, slab or truss structure used to redirect vertical gravity or lateral load path of upper storeys to vertical structure of lower storeys shall be treated as transfer element
following requirements shall be met in design of transfer elements
a) transfer beams shall be supported on at least two direct supports

b) eccentricity between column axis and longitudinal axis of beam not permitted. load transferred to planted column, transfer beam or slab shall be not less than loads calculated by manual method (tributary area)

c) any structural elements supporting planted/floating columns that might cause progressive collapse shall to be included as key element. reinforcement shall be detailed to facilitate robustness by means of provision of adequate peripheral, vertical and horizontal ties. d) entire length of supporting columns shall be included as critical length and stirrups shall be spaced to provide effective confinement for columns

e) structural system elements of planted portions of structure shall have redundancy to facilitate alternative load paths in case of failure of any structural member, as specified under k.8.1.4. f) any structural members or elements that do not fall under purview of adopted design codes should be analysed and designed for various possible critical combinations. g) transfer structure should be capable of withstanding reactions from any attached building components. reactions should be maximum values that might reasonably be transmitted considering strength of connecting component and its connection
h) engineer shall check that deflections of structural members supported by transfer elements within deflection limits specified in k.8.5.3

k 80 dubai building code part k villas k.8.6 geotechnics general k.8.6.1 this subsection provides minimum geotechnical requirements that appropriate for geology, stratigraphy, geotechnical and groundwater conditions of dubai. major characteristic of ground in dubai its calcareous origin for both soils (e.g. calcareous sand) and soft calcareous rocks, with clay minerals of various expansion potential. groundwater saline with chlorites and sulphates that make very aggressive environment for concrete and reinforcement in ground

geotechnical requirements and design aspects discussed in k.8.6.3 to k.8.6.5. geotechnical design of buildings in dubai shall be based on requirements stated herein and referenced standards (see figure k.56 for piling works). this subsection should also be read in conjunction with all other relevant subsections of k.8. additional studies should be conducted for unusual constructions and might result in variation from these requirements which would require approval from authority

geotechnical site investigations and testing shall be undertaken by geotechnical laboratory. all geotechnical reports submitted by geotechnical laboratory shall be reviewed and approved by engineer witnessed execution of soil testing
