walk-over survey standards k.8.6.2 geotechnical site investigations and geotechnical works shall be designed to meet or exceed minimum requirements of codes and standards listed in k.3.5.5
walk-over survey standards k.8.6.2 geotechnical site investigations and geotechnical works shall be designed to meet or exceed minimum requirements of codes and standards listed in k.3.5.5

geotechnical site investigation k.8.6.3 k.8.6.3.1 general geotechnical site investigations shall be planned and carried out in accordance with bs 5930, bs en 1997-2 and associated uk na, bs 1377 and bs 10175

ground investigation   preliminary investigation main investigation as indicated in bs 5930, primary objectives of geotechnical investigation as follows field works and tests samples laboratory testing a) to assess general suitability of site for proposed works b) to enable adequate and economic design to be prepared c) to foresee and provide against difficulties that may arise during construction due to ground and local conditions and geotechnical investigation factual report (gifr) d) to predict any adverse effect of proposed construction on neighbouring structures. schematic representation of geotechnical site investigation illustrated in figure k.57

geotechnical interpretative report (gir) k 82 design figure k.57 schematic organization of site investigation dubai building code part k villas k.8.6.3.2 geotechnical desk study geotechnical desk study shall provide conceptual model of site based on all available morphological, geological, hydrological, geotechnical information, and land use history from public sources and technical literature. extent of study shall be determined according to nature of project and anticipated ground conditions

k.8.6.3.3 planning geotechnical investigation extent of geotechnical investigation dependent on complexity, size and criticality of development. guidance on spacing and depth of investigation points given in annex b of bs en 1997-22007 and associated uk na. soil investigation for any building shall be defined by a) location of building b) magnitude of imposed loads c) number of floors d) shape of building e) previous uses of land f) terrain surface features g) geological features and h) surface water drainage

k.8.6.3.4 geotechnical on-site investigations requirements for geotechnical soil investigations provided in bs en 1997- 2 and associated uk na and bs 5930. as minimum, investigations shall include following a) non-intrusive investigations (mapping, geophysics) b) intrusive investigations (boreholes, trial pits, observation wells) c) sampling of soils, rocks and groundwater d) in-situ testing including 1) standard penetration test (spt) 2) cone penetration test (cpt) 3) pressure meter 4) permeability 5) in-situ strength and 6) deformability

depth of investigation shall extend at least three times shortest plan dimension of proposed foundation as specified in annex b of bs en 1997- 22007. minimum number of boreholes shall be in accordance with bs en 1997-2 and following a) for community of villas/townhouses one borehole for each plot and b) for single villas minimum two boreholes per villa
example of organization and phasing of on-site investigation given in figure k.58

k 83 dubai building code part k villas 03 key 01 soil test boring with spt soil tests shall be conducted in laboratories licensed and approved by eiac. all soil tests shall conform to eiac approved standards

02 cpt 03 dilatometer test rb-1 01 cp-1 cp-3 dmp-1 dmp-2 rb-2 cp-2 rb-4 rb-3 02 figure k.58 typical organization and phasing of on-site investigation k.8.6.3.5 geotechnical laboratory testing requirements for geotechnical soil investigations shall conform to bs 1377, bs en 1997-2 and associated uk na, and bs 5930. following list indicates minimum level of laboratory testing a) soil classification/index tests b) soil engineering properties tests (strength, stiffness, deformability) c) rock classification/index tests d) rock engineering properties tests and e) soil, rock and groundwater chemical tests

k 84 k.8.6.3.6 geotechnical reporting throughout, and particularly at end of, investigation, geotechnical laboratory shall issue geotechnical investigation factual report (gifr) and geotechnical interpretative report (gir) which reviewed and approved by engineer

for major developments and special projects, gir should be issued by engineer based on gifrs issued by geotechnical laboratory. following items shall be as minimum included in gifr a) clear definition of site, general topography b) site plan/drawing with all as-completed investigation location coordinates c) time and duration of on-site investigations d) meteorological/weather conditions at time of investigations e) use and state of site at commencement of on-site investigation f) accurate account of equipment with key specifications mobilized and used for on-site investigation and in-situ testing and methodologies and standards adopted g) all levels of topography including any lidar scans or other means of obtaining point cloud data, all site investigation points (e.g. trial pits, boreholes, cpts, spts), all stratigraphic levels, groundwater levels recorded and similar, to be specified in dmd h) groundwater monitoring level, period and frequency i) groundwater temperature j) borehole and trial pit logs with coordinates and description of encountered strata and levels, levels and types of all specimens taken (soil, rock and groundwater) dubai building code part k villas k) qualitative and quantitative description of boring (e.g. rock quality designation, 1) details of recommended foundation system, with allowable bearing capacity, total core recovery, etc.) l) levels and results of all in-situ tests (e.g. spt) m) borehole logs shall be supplemented with all relevant laboratory tests that facilitate classification of strata (e.g. uniaxial compressive strength) n) colour photos of borehole cores, including depth labels and colour chart o) full documentation of all performed laboratory tests, with suitable illustrative plots/diagrams p) ground profile plot with key information of stratigraphy and groundwater level (see figure k.59)

k 86 geotechnical design earthworks (excavation and fill) k.8.6.4 k.8.6.4.1 excavation works shall be designed in accordance with bs en 1997-1 and associated uk na, and bs 6031. design recommendations of ch. 23 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. i) ref. k.27 should also be followed for slope stability analysis
geotechnical specialist contractor shall provide slope stability analysis for any open cut excavation (see figure k.60)

figure k.60 open cut excavation dubai building code part k villas geotechnical specialist contractor shall design remedial actions when slopes display signs of instability or geotechnical analysis confirms risk of failing. list below presents some of common slope stabilization techniques which may be used in dubai
c) retaining wall. retaining walls shall be designed in accordance with k.8.6.4.3.1

d) soil nailing. in-situ reinforcement technique consisting of drilling or driving steel bars into soil mass (see figure k.61 and figure k.62). soil nails secured to steel plates at surface and optional erosion and vegetation control geosynthetic mesh can be placed over slope face. if soil loose on surface, concrete can be sprayed to cover slope face (see figure k.61). further guidance can be sought in ch. 74 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. k.27

e) filling material. material used for backfilling purposes shall be of selected fill composed of sand/granular mixture. plasticity index of backfill material should not exceed 10%. maximum particle size of backfill material shall not exceed 75 mm. percentage passing through 75 mm sieve shall not exceed 20%. organic materials content shall not exceed 2% and water-soluble salt content shall not exceed 5% f) compaction. backfill materials shall be placed in layers of thickness 150 mm to 250 mm and compacted to not less than 95% of maximum dry density. engineer shall state whether material available on site could be used for general backfilling or not after performing necessary analysis. 03 01 02 11 10 09 08 key 01 permanent facing (e.g. cast-in-place reinforced concrete) 02 temporary facing (shotcrete) 03 geocomposite strip drain 04 grout 05 steel bar 04 06 welded wire mesh 05 07 reinforcement 08 bearing plate 09 washers 10 nail head 11 studded head 07 06 figure k.61 soil nailing detail (modified figure based on figure 2.1 from cir 7 fhwao-if-03-017 geotechnical engineering circular no.7 soil nail walls, 2003, united states department of transportation federal highways administration) k 87 dubai building code part k villas key 01 strip footing 02 isolated footing 03 stepped footing 04 combined footing 05 mat foundation 06 deep foundation system with piles and pile cap 07 retaining and buttressed wall foundation 08 column 09 piles 10 pile cap 11 stem 12 toe 13 key (optional) 14 heel 15 counterfort 08 09 15 01 03 05 11 13 12 02 04 10 06 14 07 figure k.63 types of foundation ( aci. modified figure based on figure r13.1.1, aci 318-19, pg.192) figure k.62 installation of soil nailing system foundations design k.8.6.4.2 k.8.6.4.2.1 general geotechnical design of foundations shall be undertaken in accordance with bs en 1997-1 and associated uk na. typical foundation systems in dubai illustrated in figure k.63

k 88 dubai building code part k villas k.8.6.4.2.2 shallow and raft foundations geotechnical design of shallow foundations (i.e. isolated, strip, stepped, combined footing and raft) shall be in accordance with section 6 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. k.8.6.4.2.3 deep and piled foundations geotechnical design of deep and piled foundations shall be in accordance with section 7 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. following limit states shall be included in design of deep foundations most common limit states for spread foundations a) loss of overall stability b) bearing resistance failure (the equations for bearing capacity given in annex d, bs en 1997-1 and associated uk na) c) failure by sliding d) combined failure in ground and in structure e) structural failure due to foundation movement f) excessive settlements (refer to annex h of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na) g) excessive heave due to swelling, frost and other causes and h) unacceptable vibrations

k 88 dubai building code part k villas k.8.6.4.2.2 shallow and raft foundations geotechnical design of shallow foundations (i.e. isolated, strip, stepped, combined footing and raft) shall be in accordance with section 6 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. k.8.6.4.2.3 deep and piled foundations geotechnical design of deep and piled foundations shall be in accordance with section 7 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. following limit states shall be included in design of deep foundations most common limit states for spread foundations a) loss of overall stability b) bearing resistance failure (the equations for bearing capacity given in annex d, bs en 1997-1 and associated uk na) c) failure by sliding d) combined failure in ground and in structure e) structural failure due to foundation movement f) excessive settlements (refer to annex h of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na) g) excessive heave due to swelling, frost and other causes and h) unacceptable vibrations

k 88 dubai building code part k villas k.8.6.4.2.2 shallow and raft foundations geotechnical design of shallow foundations (i.e. isolated, strip, stepped, combined footing and raft) shall be in accordance with section 6 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. k.8.6.4.2.3 deep and piled foundations geotechnical design of deep and piled foundations shall be in accordance with section 7 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. following limit states shall be included in design of deep foundations most common limit states for spread foundations a) loss of overall stability b) bearing resistance failure (the equations for bearing capacity given in annex d, bs en 1997-1 and associated uk na) c) failure by sliding d) combined failure in ground and in structure e) structural failure due to foundation movement f) excessive settlements (refer to annex h of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na) g) excessive heave due to swelling, frost and other causes and h) unacceptable vibrations

load-bearing mechanism (i.e. end bearing, friction, friction with end bearing piles) shall be recommended in gifr. in particular, end bearing capacity shall be agreed with authority before design commenced. design of permanent concrete structural elements shall be in accordance with f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19. design criteria listed in table k.24 applicable to reinforced concrete foundations on piles
k 89 dubai building code part k villas design criterion minimum requirement design criterion minimum requirement pile design general ensure pile design allows for both gravity and lateral loads
pile caps shall be designed in accordance with requirements specified under aci 318-19
0.2 mm considering tension load

vertical stiffness of piles table k.24 piles foundation minimum design criteria k 90 dubai building code part k villas shoring and retaining systems k.8.6.4.3 k.8.6.4.3.1 general geotechnical design of earth retaining systems shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004+a12013 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall be in accordance with f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19. shoring systems and retaining structures deemed to be temporary if design life of system less than two years. they shall not be treated as part of permanent structures. physical segregation shall be provided between temporary and permanent structural systems. alternative techniques specified in accordance with international codes and standards may also be accepted

vertical stiffness of piles table k.24 piles foundation minimum design criteria k 90 dubai building code part k villas shoring and retaining systems k.8.6.4.3 k.8.6.4.3.1 general geotechnical design of earth retaining systems shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004+a12013 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall be in accordance with f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19. shoring systems and retaining structures deemed to be temporary if design life of system less than two years. they shall not be treated as part of permanent structures. physical segregation shall be provided between temporary and permanent structural systems. alternative techniques specified in accordance with international codes and standards may also be accepted

vertical stiffness of piles table k.24 piles foundation minimum design criteria k 90 dubai building code part k villas shoring and retaining systems k.8.6.4.3 k.8.6.4.3.1 general geotechnical design of earth retaining systems shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004+a12013 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall be in accordance with f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19. shoring systems and retaining structures deemed to be temporary if design life of system less than two years. they shall not be treated as part of permanent structures. physical segregation shall be provided between temporary and permanent structural systems. alternative techniques specified in accordance with international codes and standards may also be accepted
shoring and bracing systems further described in ch. 62, 63 and 64 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. k.27
k.8.6.4.3.2 required shoring systems table k.25 should be followed for different depths of excavation and site conditions
type of shoring system permitted under following criteria all types up to 5 deep excavation one basement
shoring and retaining systems shall be designed to retain soil and actual groundwater pressure (including tidal effect)
all types, except soldier pile with lagging up to 9 depth and no buildings in adjacent plots
shoring system preventing water leakage presence of buildings in adjacent plots table k.25 type of shoring system high groundwater level proximity to water bodies

it possible to adopt shoring systems other than those in table k.25, based on soil examination report, groundwater level, presence of water sources, adjacent buildings and surrounding constructions. minimum requirements listed in table k.26 shall be included in design of temporary shoring systems. note shoring and earth retaining systems typically used and accepted in dubai as follows a) non-watertight shoring systems 1) soldier piles with lagging system/king post walls 2) contiguous pile walls 3) slurry walls b) watertight shoring systems 1) secant pile walls 2) diaphragm walls 3) sheet piles c) bracing for temporary earth retaining systems 1) anchors 2) rakers and 3) struts

k 91 dubai building code part k villas design criteria minimum additional loads minimum requirement additional uniform distributed load of 20 kn/m2 shall be taken into consideration in proximity to roads and land plots. additional surcharge load needs to be assessed based on actual conditions on-site and adjacent structures. minimum distance between anchors maximum length of anchors minimum length of anchors 1.2 10 3 maximum lateral displacement 40 mm unplanned excavations heave retaining walls shall be designed assuming presence of unplanned excavations in front of wall, with depth of not less than 10% of total height of vertical walls, or 10% of vertical distance between lowest anchor and bottom of excavation, but not less than 0.5

geotechnical design shall assess heave if swelling and collapsible soils have identified in gifr. further guidance can be sought in ch. 32 and 33 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. i) ref. k.27

table k.26 minimum requirements for earth retaining system k.8.6.4.3.3 permanent earth retaining system any retaining structure deemed to be permanent if design life of system more than two years. permanent retaining system shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without allowing for temporary retaining system

table k.26 minimum requirements for earth retaining system k.8.6.4.3.3 permanent earth retaining system any retaining structure deemed to be permanent if design life of system more than two years. permanent retaining system shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without allowing for temporary retaining system

temporary retaining structures listed under note to k.8.6.4.3.1 may be designed as permanent structures, provided they included in analysis of overall structure. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to both main structural system and permanent retaining system. in addition to requirements for temporary retaining systems stipulated under k.8.6.4.3.2, engineer shall design retaining systems considering intended design life. in particular, engineer shall consider applicable performance, serviceability and durability requirements of f.6 and f.8

temporary retaining structures listed under note to k.8.6.4.3.1 may be designed as permanent structures, provided they included in analysis of overall structure. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to both main structural system and permanent retaining system. in addition to requirements for temporary retaining systems stipulated under k.8.6.4.3.2, engineer shall design retaining systems considering intended design life. in particular, engineer shall consider applicable performance, serviceability and durability requirements of f.6 and f.8

k.8.6.4.3.4 basement walls permanent basement concrete wall should be provided in front of temporary retaining systems detailed in k.8.6.4.3.1. permanent basement wall shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without considering temporary retaining system. permanent basement wall shall be fully integrated with main structural system of building. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to main structural system and basement walls. geotechnical design of permanent basement walls shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall follow f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19

k.8.6.4.3.4 basement walls permanent basement concrete wall should be provided in front of temporary retaining systems detailed in k.8.6.4.3.1. permanent basement wall shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without considering temporary retaining system. permanent basement wall shall be fully integrated with main structural system of building. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to main structural system and basement walls. geotechnical design of permanent basement walls shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall follow f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19

k.8.6.4.3.4 basement walls permanent basement concrete wall should be provided in front of temporary retaining systems detailed in k.8.6.4.3.1. permanent basement wall shall be designed to retain soil and future groundwater pressure (including tidal effect) without considering temporary retaining system. permanent basement wall shall be fully integrated with main structural system of building. same design life, performance and durability requirements shall be applied to main structural system and basement walls. geotechnical design of permanent basement walls shall be performed in accordance with section 9 of bs en 1997-12004 and associated uk na. design of concrete structural elements shall follow f.6, f.8 and aci 318-19

k.8.6.4.4 groundwater control and dewatering dewatering systems shall be designed in accordance with bs en 1997-1 and associated uk na and ciria c750 ref. k.28, taking into account following a) all existing facilities shall always be protected
b) dewatering system shall reduce loss of soft materials in soil and any effect on surrounding structures. hydrogeological model shall identify and assess any piping effect. (see figure k.64)

k 92 dubai building code part k villas c) depth of shoring systems and internal excavations shall prevent soil heave. this to avoid possibility of seepage, and to ensure compatibility between designs of shoring systems and dewatering system (see figure k.65). d) seepage analysis and groundwater/hydrogeological model shall be prepared for at least 20 below bottom of excavation. model shall determine following 01 1) type of soil and rocks 2) horizontal permeability of each layer 3) incoherent or gypsum soils and 4) other areas exposed to water leakage under surface. figure k.66 shows permeability of different soil types and recommended dewatering systems

liquefaction shall be assessed using pga determined based on either (1) site- specific study considering soil amplification effects as specified in f.7.13.9 or (2) pgam, from eq. k.1
pgam = fpga . pga eq. k.1 where pga mceg peak ground acceleration taken from table k.27 and fpga site coefficient from table k.28

site class short period fpga b c e f 0.80 0.90 1.27 1.54 2.25 * *a site response analysis shall be performed in accordance with 21.1 of asce/sei 7-16 for structures on site class f sites. site response study or ground motion hazard analysis not required in any other circumstances unless specifically requested by authority

table k.28 pga site coefficient fpga for liquefaction assessment in dubai factor of safety (fs) against occurrence of earthquake-induced liquefaction shall be defined as available soil resistance to liquefaction, cyclic resistance ratio (crr) divided by cyclic stress generated by design event, cyclic stress ratio (csr) as shown in eq. k.2. fs shall be not less than 1.5

fs  1.5 (crr/csr) eq. k.2 groundwater level shall be selected based on peak over design period, which allows natural changes (such as "spring" tide peak), land use changes and considerations for global warming

when assessing potential for liquefaction any published and internationally accepted methodology ref. k.19 can be used provided it internally consistent. impact of carbonate sands on liquefaction potential should also be included

k 94 dubai building code part k villas requirements for foundations design in liquefiable sites shall follow requirements in section 12.13.9 of asce/sei 7-16 and associated subclauses. this shall include consideration of following issues regarding liquefaction, namely a) lateral spreading b) global and differential settlements c) provision of ties between individual foundations and d) negative skin friction (i.e. downdrag) on vertical capacity of piles. where impact of liquefaction exceeds requirements of asce/sei 7-16 (table 12.13-2 for lateral spreading and table 12.13-3 for differential settlement thresholds), suitable ground improvement shall be required
k.8.6.4.6 ground improvement ground improvement shall be designed according to bs en 1997-1 and ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. i) ch.25 ref. k.27
note following ground improvement techniques accepted in dubai (see figure k.67) a) dynamic compaction b) vibro-compaction c) soil replacement d) soil mixing e) grouting and f) vertical drains

execution of geotechnical works k.8.6.5 k.8.6.5.1 general geotechnical works shall be carried out in accordance with bs en standards listed in k.3.5.5. engineer and geotechnical specialist contractor shall also conform to following subclauses. earthworks (excavation and filling) k.8.6.5.2 in addition to requirements specified bs en 6031, following requirements shall be included in execution of excavation and backfill activities

a) materials used for backfilling purposes shall consist of selected materials such as sand/granular mixture free from organic materials or other biodegradable materials. engineer shall determine whether excavated materials can be used in general backfilling works after conducting necessary testing

d) all excavation activities shall be carried out inside plot limits only. no encroachment, no parking, and no stopping zone with minimum width of 1 shall be provided in proximity to excavated area. e) for any works required outside of plot limits, noc approval from relevant authorities, departments or plot owners shall be submitted

f) execution of excavation and filling activities should meet requirements stipulated in ch. 75 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. k.27. g) installation of soil nails shall conform to requirements of bs en 14490. further guidance can be sought in ch. 88 of ice manual of geotechnical engineering (vol. ii) ref. k.27

k 96 dubai building code part k villas shoring retaining systems k.8.6.5.3 in addition to requirements of bs 8081, bs en 1536, bs en 1537, bs en 1538 and bs en 12063, following requirements shall be included in construction of earth retaining structures a) all existing structures and utilities shall always be protected
e) anchors can be removed on site only after obtaining written consent of engineer
foundations k.8.6.5.4 it envisaged that following foundation systems will be typically provided for buildings in dubai a) shallow foundations b) deep foundations and c) raft foundations

in addition to requirements of bs en 1536, bs en 12699 and bs en 14199, minimum testing criteria listed in table k.29 shall be followed during and after execution of reinforced concrete foundations on piles

test minimum requirement static test on working piles minimum 1% of all piles and each different diameter dynamic test on working piles 5% of all piles cross-hole sonic logging (for more than 1 diameter and 20 length) 10% of all piles 900 mm or greater with minimum four tubes/holes and minimum three tubes for 750 mm. minimum length of testing 20 or full length if shorter. end bearing piles full length testing integrity test working piles 100% cubes test (concrete) reinforcement test as per technical specification as per technical specification table k.29 minimum testing requirements for pile foundation it responsibility of both engineer and geotechnical specialist contractor to select test location which does not interfere with location of permanent structural piles of main structure. geotechnical specialist contractor may propose test locations to be reviewed by engineer may accept them or propose alternative locations. non-working preliminary test pile (ptp) location and arrangement shall be submitted officially to authority during design stage and shall at least include following. 1) detailed drawings that clearly show location of test pile and instrumentation
4) minimum 1no. ptp for each project. maximum diameter and length of pile should be considered, assuming that they most representative for site

ptp results shall be used to optimize pile design in accordance with bs en 1997-1 and associated uk na. k 97 dubai building code part k villas k.8.6.5.5 groundwater control and dewatering in addition to requirements given in ciria c750 ref. k.28, following requirements shall also be included during execution of dewatering on site

b) network shall be developed to monitor groundwater pressure/piezometric pressure separated from dewatering system, vertical groundwater gradients as well as horizontal gradients, and water rises inside and outside excavations/shoring systems

c) dewatering works shall not be stopped without written approval of engineer, after achieving balance between water pressure and weight of construction. factor of safety shall be at least 1.1, irrespective of friction between walls and soil. d) care shall be taken during dewatering process to ensure that fine particles soil not removed during pumping as this might lead to unexpected subsidence in surrounding lands and associated structures
k.8.6.5.6 ground improvement ground improvement shall be executed in accordance with bs en 12715, bs en 12716, bs en 14199, bs en 14475, bs en 14679, bs en 14731, bs en 15237
in addition to requirements specified in referenced codes and standards, following requirements shall also be included during execution of ground improvement on site

1) bearing capacity i) one plate load test per each 750 m2 area (minimum one test for each building) shall be carried out in accordance with astm d1195m. recommended acceptance criterion to achieve targeted bearing pressure with total settlements less than 25 mm. ii) one zone load test in accordance with astm d1195m shall be performed for major development comprising more than one building and special structures

2) improvement to mitigate liquefaction risk efficiency of improvement shall be verified with cpt readings (in accordance with astm d5778 or bs en iso 22476). pre-improvement cpt tests should be carried out every 900 m2 maximum (or as stipulated in project specifications) to compare results with post-improvement cpt tests. locations of post- improvement cpt tests should be selected at central points between improved points. weighted average of cpt tip resistance for near and far tested points, should be not less than 6.0 mpa for shallow foundations
3) deep piled foundation it recommended that, after completion of ground improvement, weighted average of cpt tip resistance profile at least 8.0 mpa
d) all existing facilities and utilities shall always be monitored and protected a) technical design should be prepared by geotechnical specialist contractor by geotechnical specialist contractor
and approved by engineer prior to submission to authority

e) all activities shall be carried out inside plot limits only. for any activity outside of plot limits, noc from all of relevant authority departments (e.g. dewa, rta. etc.) or plot owners shall be submitted to authority

k 98 dubai building code part k villas k.9 incoming utilities k.9.1 design, erection and installation of electrical systems general k.9.1.1 this section outlines requirements for design of electrical installations. it based on latest edition of bs 7671 and institution of engineering and technology (iet) documents ref. k.29 and ref. k.30. subsections k.9.1 to k.9.3 not intended to a) take place of detailed specification b) instruct untrained persons or c) provide for every circumstance
where situation arises which not covered or allowed for within these subsections, dewa shall be consulted to obtain further clarity and guidance

electrical supply k.9.1.2 nominal electric supply voltage from dewa (iec 60038) 230/400 v  10%, 50 hz, three-phase, 4-wire with separate neutral and protective conductor (generally metallic armour of dewa service cable). neutral solidly earthed at dewas substations and shall not be earthed elsewhere in consumers electrical installations. design fault level within substation 40 ka (fault duration 1 s), except for fuse protected equipment/circuits

all equipment, apparatus, materials and accessories used in electrical installations shall be designed and rated for operation on this electric supply. overload, short circuit and earth leakage protective devices shall be provided. depending on design of consumer installations, protective devices shall also be provided to protect against following as required a) over voltages b) fluctuations c) transients and harmonics d) loss of one or more phases and e) unforeseen interruptions

incoming and metering k.9.1.3 before commencing building design, consumer shall obtain confirmation of availability of power supply from dewa. power supply from dewas network subject to all applicable terms and conditions as issued by dewa
consumer shall protect all elements of dewa installations provided for and within premises. any violation, defect or damage to dewa lines, equipment or metering shall be reported immediately

where total connected load (tcl) exceeds 400 kw, provision shall be made within building or plot for dewa substation. in some circumstances dewa substation might be required for connected loads less than 400 kw
meters shall be installed to measure and record electricity demand and consumption of facility. all tariff meters shall conform to dewa specifications. tariff meters supplied and installed by dewa

tariff metering shall be in accordance with k.9.1.5. k 99 dubai building code part k villas point of supply k.9.1.4 k.9.1.4.1 general point of supply shall be made available at one location within plot/project, unless otherwise approved by dewa. point of supply defines boundary of dewa equipment, and shall be decided by dewa

tariff metering shall be in accordance with k.9.1.5. k 99 dubai building code part k villas point of supply k.9.1.4 k.9.1.4.1 general point of supply shall be made available at one location within plot/project, unless otherwise approved by dewa. point of supply defines boundary of dewa equipment, and shall be decided by dewa

all incoming cable terminations/live connections in metering cabinets, mdbs and smdbs shall be adequately shrouded and insulated
all exposed live terminal connections and busbars in any low voltage (lv) distribution board (db) shall be shrouded and/or insulated

refer to g.4.4 in event of main electrical switchroom and lv distribution panel being required. switchgear locations k.9.1.4.2 where main or submain electrical switchroom required, refer to g.4.4 for further details and requirements. k 100 dubai building code part k villas key 01 compound wall

all tariff metering shall be smart meters, normally provided by dewa and restricted to one for each consumer installation, unless otherwise approved/specified by dewa

k.9.1.5.2 ct metering requirements metering by means of current transformers (cts) shall be installed where circuit breaker rating at point of supply 160 and above. note 1 dewa provides smart kwh meter(s) and associated cts for all tariff metering. in some circumstances consumer might be permitted to provide kwh meter and cts as private check meters for energy monitoring purposes

k.9.1.8 wiring installation exposed to high temperatures any part of wiring installation (such as individual circuit cables, final connections to equipment, appliances and light fittings) shall be rated to maintain its performance at temperatures likely to be encountered. heat-resistant sleeves shall be provided for individual cores and/or heat-resistant cables

k.9.1.9 wiring installations in hazardous areas all light fittings, wiring accessories and other electrical equipment in potentially hazardous atmospheres shall be selected in accordance with bs en 60079

k.9.1.9 wiring installations in hazardous areas all light fittings, wiring accessories and other electrical equipment in potentially hazardous atmospheres shall be selected in accordance with bs en 60079

load balancing k.9.1.10 in all cases where three-phase supply provided to premises, various categories of connected load such as lighting, socket outlets, water heaters, single- phase air-conditioning units, equipment, apparatus, etc. shall be distributed and connected on red, yellow and blue phases as evenly as possible, to ensure load balance between phases at all distribution levels

k.9.1.11 wiring accessories k.9.1.11.1 conduits and fittings high impact rigid pvc conduits and fittings shall conform to all relevant parts of bs 4607, bs en 60423 and bs en 61386. they shall meet following requirements a) be suitable for use at maximum ambient temperature of 48 c b) not soften or suffer structural degradation at temperature of 70 c c) be non-hygroscopic and d) be heat-resistant pvc conduits shall be provided with copper/brass terminals

k.9.1.11 wiring accessories k.9.1.11.1 conduits and fittings high impact rigid pvc conduits and fittings shall conform to all relevant parts of bs 4607, bs en 60423 and bs en 61386. they shall meet following requirements a) be suitable for use at maximum ambient temperature of 48 c b) not soften or suffer structural degradation at temperature of 70 c c) be non-hygroscopic and d) be heat-resistant pvc conduits shall be provided with copper/brass terminals

k 105 dubai building code part k villas k.9.1.11.3 cable trays and supports cable trays, accessories and supports shall be either hot-dip galvanized or pvc-coated steel. cable trays shall be either perforated type or ladder type. they shall have sufficient strength and rigidity to support cables installed, and be provided with upstands of adequate dimensions on both sides

k villas k.9.1.13 apparatus and accessories k.9.1.13.1 switches switches provided for local isolation of electric supply to individual apparatus and/or circuits shall conform to bs en 60669. rating of switches shall be selected based on individual applications, such as for resistive or inductive loads. current rating shall be not less than 5
for outdoor locations, switches with weather protection in accordance with ip55 shall be used
k 109 k.9.1.13.2 plugs and socket outlets single-phase plugs and socket outlets used in domestic installations shall conform to bs 1363. socket outlets shall be of type illustrated in figure k.70
figure k.70 typical 3-pin flat, double-pole, shuttered, switched twin socket 15 plugs and socket outlets used in domestic installations shall conform to bs 546
shaver socket outlets shall conform to a) bs en 61558 in bathrooms and b) bs 4573 in rooms other than bathrooms

dubai building code part k villas industrial plugs and socket outlets shall conform to bs en 60309. they shall feature switch that integrally built in or attached to it. rating and type of socket outlets with plugs shall be selected to suit individual applications and shall not be interchanged for different current ratings
weather protected type (ip55) socket outlets shall be used for outdoor applications

k.9.1.13.3 arc fault detection devices (afdds) additional protection to mitigate risk of fire due to arcing recommended in certain applications. afdds protect against series and parallel arcing by detecting low-level hazardous arcing that circuit breakers, fuses and rcds not designed to detect. afdds shall be selected in accordance with bs en 62606. afdd shall be placed at origin of circuit to be protected

afdds available in following types a) one single device, comprising afd unit and opening means, intended to be connected in series with suitable short circuit protective device declared by manufacturer as conforming to one or more of following standards examples of where such devices can be used include 1) premises with sleeping accommodation 2) 3) locations with risk of fire due to nature of processed or stored materials locations with combustible construction materials 4) structures having fire propagating features and 5) locations with endangered or irreplaceable objects (such as museums, libraries, art galleries)

afdds available in following types a) one single device, comprising afd unit and opening means, intended to be connected in series with suitable short circuit protective device declared by manufacturer as conforming to one or more of following standards examples of where such devices can be used include 1) premises with sleeping accommodation 2) 3) locations with risk of fire due to nature of processed or stored materials locations with combustible construction materials 4) structures having fire propagating features and 5) locations with endangered or irreplaceable objects (such as museums, libraries, art galleries)

k.9.1.13.4 cooker control units all stationary cooking appliances in domestic premises shall have cooker control switch. switch shall conform to bs 4177 and be located separate from appliance (see figure k.71). cooking appliance shall incorporate integral earthing terminal

k.9.1.13.4 cooker control units all stationary cooking appliances in domestic premises shall have cooker control switch. switch shall conform to bs 4177 and be located separate from appliance (see figure k.71). cooking appliance shall incorporate integral earthing terminal

k.9.1.13.4 cooker control units all stationary cooking appliances in domestic premises shall have cooker control switch. switch shall conform to bs 4177 and be located separate from appliance (see figure k.71). cooking appliance shall incorporate integral earthing terminal
cooker control switch shall be two-pole (for single-phase appliance) or four-pole (for three-phase appliance). it shall be connected to separate final sub-circuit from db, through 100 elcb

1) bs en 60898-1 2) bs en 61009-1 or 3) bs en 60269 series b) one single device, comprising afd unit integrated in protective device conforming to one or more of following standards 1) bs en 60898-1 2) bs en 61008-1 3) bs en 61009-1 or 4) bs en 62423 c) afd unit (add-on module) and declared protective device, intended to be assembled on-site

k 110 dubai building code part k villas k.9.1.13.5 kitchen appliances electrical appliances used in consumer installations (such as water heaters, cookers, hot plates, etc.) shall generally conform to bs en 60335. figure k.72 illustrates typical setting-out details of kitchen

figure k.71 cooker control unit installed within 2 of appliance ( institution of engineering and technology. figure based on figure 4.4 in institution of engineering and technology, 2018. electricians guide to building regulations ref. k.29) key 01 control switch to be located within 2 from controlled appliance 02 electric hob 03 electric oven 04 consumer unit cooker control units incorporating general purpose socket outlet shall be avoided, to allow grouping of socket outlet circuits in separate 30 rcd/elcb section

figure k.72 cooker and kitchen typical installation setting out details ( institution of engineering and technology. figure based on figure 5.2.2 in institution of engineering and technology, 2018. electricians guide to building regulations ref. k.29) key 01 no sockets within 300 mm of edge of sink 02 no sockets or accessories above gas or electric hobs 03 cooker switch 04 dishwasher 05 fridge 06 cooker connection k 111 dubai building code part k villas k.9.1.13.6 control of water heaters, saunas, jacuzzis and washing machines double-pole switches with neon indicator shall be provided, appropriately rated for control of equipment. final connection to equipment shall be made from flex outlet plate. plate shall be mounted adjacent to equipment. for water heaters installed in bathroom or water closet, control switch shall be installed immediately outside room. for saunas and jacuzzis, control gear shall be placed outside sauna room/cabin

figure k.72 cooker and kitchen typical installation setting out details ( institution of engineering and technology. figure based on figure 5.2.2 in institution of engineering and technology, 2018. electricians guide to building regulations ref. k.29) key 01 no sockets within 300 mm of edge of sink 02 no sockets or accessories above gas or electric hobs 03 cooker switch 04 dishwasher 05 fridge 06 cooker connection k 111 dubai building code part k villas k.9.1.13.6 control of water heaters, saunas, jacuzzis and washing machines double-pole switches with neon indicator shall be provided, appropriately rated for control of equipment. final connection to equipment shall be made from flex outlet plate. plate shall be mounted adjacent to equipment. for water heaters installed in bathroom or water closet, control switch shall be installed immediately outside room. for saunas and jacuzzis, control gear shall be placed outside sauna room/cabin

water heaters, saunas, jacuzzis and washing machines shall be connected to separate final sub circuit from db. water heaters shall incorporate integral earthing terminal adjacent to phase and neutral terminals. all terminals shall be housed in suitable recess with splash proof removable cover. every heater circuit shall be protected by 30 rccb/elcb

k.9.1.13.7 control of air-conditioning unit/equipment for other room air-conditioning units other than window type, double-pole switch of appropriate rating, with flex outlet, shall be provided and mounted adjacent to unit. each room air-conditioning unit shall be connected to separate final sub-circuit from db

maximum of two window type air-conditioning units permitted to connect on single-phase supply. where three or more window type units installed, they shall be balanced as evenly as possible over three-phase supply
breaker rating and wire size shall be selected based on connected load of air-conditioning unit, subject to minimum 20 with 4 mm2 circuit wires

k.9.1.13.8 extra lv safety apparatus extra-lv safety apparatus includes a) electric buzzers and bells b) mirror lights and shaver socket outlets in bathrooms c) light fittings for underwater installations

extra lv safety apparatus shall incorporate appropriately rated double wound safety isolation transformer. transformer shall either be integral or mounted separately. cartridge fuse or mcb shall be incorporated in secondary circuit. safety isolation transformer shall conform to bs en 61558. segregation of lv and extra-lv circuits shall be in accordance with k.9.1.17.3
k.9.1.13.9 electric motors and starters control of electric motors shall conform to bs en 60204 where equipment within scope of standard

all motors shall be protected against overload, short circuit and earth leakage. they shall also be protected against voltage fluctuations and loss of one or more phases, as necessary for individual application

every motor having rating exceeding 0.37 kw shall be provided with control equipment incorporating means of protection against overload of motor. only installation of single-phase motors rated up to 3.7 kw, and three-phase motors up to 110 kw, permitted, unless otherwise approved by dewa. where multiple motors above 110 kw proposed, advice of dewa shall be sought on obtaining bulk supply

k 112 dubai building code part k villas standby generators k.9.1.14 if permanent installation of standby generator required, it shall meet requirements in g.4.14. k.9.1.15 assessment of connected load and maximum demand k.9.1.15.1 lighting and small power circuits all lighting and fan circuits shall be installed as follows a) maximum load per circuit of 2,000 w b) minimum circuit wire/eec size of 2.5 mm2 lsf copper, with maximum circuit breaker protection of 16

k 112 dubai building code part k villas standby generators k.9.1.14 if permanent installation of standby generator required, it shall meet requirements in g.4.14. k.9.1.15 assessment of connected load and maximum demand k.9.1.15.1 lighting and small power circuits all lighting and fan circuits shall be installed as follows a) maximum load per circuit of 2,000 w b) minimum circuit wire/eec size of 2.5 mm2 lsf copper, with maximum circuit breaker protection of 16

k 112 dubai building code part k villas standby generators k.9.1.14 if permanent installation of standby generator required, it shall meet requirements in g.4.14. k.9.1.15 assessment of connected load and maximum demand k.9.1.15.1 lighting and small power circuits all lighting and fan circuits shall be installed as follows a) maximum load per circuit of 2,000 w b) minimum circuit wire/eec size of 2.5 mm2 lsf copper, with maximum circuit breaker protection of 16

k 112 dubai building code part k villas standby generators k.9.1.14 if permanent installation of standby generator required, it shall meet requirements in g.4.14. k.9.1.15 assessment of connected load and maximum demand k.9.1.15.1 lighting and small power circuits all lighting and fan circuits shall be installed as follows a) maximum load per circuit of 2,000 w b) minimum circuit wire/eec size of 2.5 mm2 lsf copper, with maximum circuit breaker protection of 16
figure k.73 push buttons motors and their control gear shall be located in well- ventilated areas with adequate space for operation, inspection and maintenance

all starters, isolators and pushbuttons (see figure k.73) shall be clearly marked in arabic and english stating which machine they control and their function. to avoid confusion, words start and stop shall be used (and not open and closed)
k 113 dubai building code part k villas k.9.1.15.2 maximum demand all dbs shall be rated for tcl before demand factor applied

details of load distribution schedules shall be submitted for dewas approval in format identified in table k.37 to table k.40. tcl of individual distribution levels/circuits shall be determined as recommended in k.9.1.15. appropriate demand factor worked out by qualified electrical engineer permitted, to determine maximum demand at main or submain distribution level

current demand of 13 shall be assumed for each 13 switched socket outlet circuit. minimum of 200 w per point shall be considered for each 13 switched socket outlet, installed for general utility purpose, other than kitchen. all twin socket outlets shall be taken to be as two separate socket outlet points. kitchen areas might need separate circuits
for stationary appliances and equipment, including air-conditioners, actual load of each appliance and equipment shall be taken to be connected load
assumed connected load of additional spaces/circuits shall also be indicated in load distribution schedules submitted for dewas approval (see k.9.1.15.2)

only flush-type switches, socket outlets and accessories shall be used for concealed wiring

standard conduit boxes, draw-in boxes, floor-outlet boxes, etc. shall be installed with cover/lid flush with outer finish of building structure (see bs 4662, bs 5733, bs en 61535)
where conduit and/or conduit fittings attached to equipment, smooth bore male brass brushes and flanged coupling shall be used

except where provision made for fastening, conduits shall be saddled to structure of building in accordance with following 1) within 150 mm of each terminal angle box, bend or other conduit fittings 2) at maximum intervals of 1.5 couplings and through fittings 3) at maximum intervals of 15 couplings
through-type draw boxes shall be counted as part of straight run conduit
all conduit accessories shall be of substantial sections and of same quality as conduit
k.9.1.16.2 flexible conduits flexible conduits shall not be used for complete fixed wiring installations. they shall only be used as and where permitted

k 121 dubai building code part k villas flexible conduits shall only be run exposed and shall be so positioned that they not susceptible to mechanical damage. wherever necessary, flexible conduits shall be supported in accordance with manufacturers recommendations
k.9.1.16.3 cable trays trays for supporting cables shall be used in warehouses, industrial plant and equipment rooms, cable trenches, shafts in buildings, etc

k.9.1.16.3 cable trays trays for supporting cables shall be used in warehouses, industrial plant and equipment rooms, cable trenches, shafts in buildings, etc
type and material of cable trays shall be selected to suit individual site locations and shall meet relevant requirements specified in k.9.1.11.3
cable trays shall be supported at regular intervals with purpose-made supports (see table k.43)

cables shall be fastened securely by purpose-made clips, cleats or saddles and spaced as shown in table k.44. cable ties shall not be used to support multicore cables installed on cable trays that fitted vertically

sufficient space shall be provided and maintained around cable trays to permit access for installing and maintaining cables without causing unnecessary damage. vertical clearance above tray shall be not less than 1.5 times height of tray, or as given in cable and cable tray manufacturers recommendations. cable trays shall be installed as complete systems with bends and other accessories. each run of cable trays shall be completed before installation of cables. all sharp edges, burrs and projection shall be removed, and tray shall be finished smooth to prevent injury to cables
metallic cable trays shall not be used as ecc, although sections shall be bonded using copper links

k.9.1.17 design criteria for installation of cables, equipment, accessories and wiring systems k.9.1.17.1 armoured cables armoured cables shall be installed in one of following ways a) directly buried in ground b) drawn through ducts c) laid in concrete trenches d) cleated to wall e) mounted on cable trays

k.9.1.17 design criteria for installation of cables, equipment, accessories and wiring systems k.9.1.17.1 armoured cables armoured cables shall be installed in one of following ways a) directly buried in ground b) drawn through ducts c) laid in concrete trenches d) cleated to wall e) mounted on cable trays

cables shall be installed and used in association with other equipment in accordance with bs 7671. for environments or installations not explicitly described within this part, appropriate regulations and standards shall be observed
k 122 dubai building code part k villas cables shall be selected ensuring voltage drops within limit described in k.9.1.7.3 and g.4.7.3

only armoured cables shall be used for underground installations. precautions shall be taken to avoid mechanical damage to cables before and during installation. cables shall be laid as shown in figure k.76. where protective covers required, they shall be centred over cables, throughout their length

where cables pass underneath driveways or roads, pvc-u ducts shall be provided with heavy-duty (hd) manhole covers. cable routes shall be marked by cable route markers/marking tape, placed at maximum intervals of 10 along straight runs and 2 at deviations (see figure k.77). route markers shall indicate voltage level in arabic and english
heavy-duty conduit shall be provided for motor connections, external applications and locations subject to vibration, risk of mechanical damage or exposure to moisture

cables shall be installed on cable trays at specific locations and as stipulated in k.9.1.11

no joints shall be included in any cable runs in consumers fixed wiring installation

where cables or wiring systems pass through floors, walls, partitions or ceilings, openings remaining after passage of wiring systems shall be sealed by listed fire stopping system to degree of fire resistance required by uae flsc ref. k.1. cable glands used for armoured cables shall be of brass compression type, conforming to bs 6121, with earth tags and pvc shroud

all terminations of cable conductors shall be mechanically and electrically sound. terminations shall be made using terminal or compression type socket/lug, approved by dewa. terminations shall not impose any mechanical strain on terminal or socket/lug
separate eccs shall be installed and terminated for each feeder/circuit, as specified in k.9.1.18

dbs shall be selected and designed in accordance with k.9.1.12
every circuit breaker or fuse within db shall be identified and labelled to indicate apparatus or circuit it controls. table k.38 and table k.39 show single-phase and three-phase db schedules

dubai building code part k villas where residential premises supplied with three-phase supply, light fittings, socket outlets, water heaters, cookers and other single-phase apparatus in any room shall not be connected to more than one phase, unless this unavoidable. if connection to more than one phase cannot be avoided, minimum distance of 2 shall be maintained between outlets, accessories or appliances connected to different phases. where switch box contains more than one phase, for group switching, approved switch boxes with phase barriers shall be used and labelled to indicate that 400 v present within box. all circuit wires shall be identified by colour as shown in table k.34 and table k.35. where wiring system in close proximity to non-electrical services, wiring system shall be segregated and protected against hazards that likely to arise from presence of other service(s) in normal use. provision shall be made for safe and adequate access to all parts of wiring system which might require inspection, maintenance or replacement
track system for luminaires shall conform to bs en 60570
k 126 k.9.1.17.4 mounting heights of accessories accessories (as described in k.9.1.13) shall be mounted as follows (and as shown in figure k.80)

a) all lighting switches, dp switches of air-conditioning units and water heaters, ceiling fan regulators, shaver socket outlets, etc., provided as part of electrical installation shall be mounted 1.25 above ffl

b) 13 switched socket outlets used for general purpose shall be installed at 450 mm above ffl. 13 switched socket outlets provided in kitchens shall be installed 150 mm above worktop. all switches shall be mounted in readily accessible positions

1 , 2 5 0 150 450 figure k.80 typical mounting heights of electrical accessories dubai building code part k villas identification labels and notices k.9.1.17.5 all sections of consumer installation at dbs shall be provided with identification labels to indicate location and purpose of each protection device, piece of connected equipment and circuit. instructions or caution notices for correct operation shall also be provided where necessary. all labels shall be in both english and arabic as shown in figure k.81. font sizes shall be chosen to suit individual application

figure k.81 typical electrical warning label k 127 earthing and earth leakage protection k.9.1.18 k.9.1.18.1 general earthing systems shall be designed and installed in such way that they remain safe and do not endanger health and safety of persons or their surroundings. every consumer installation shall be provided with separate earthing system within plot limits, installed and maintained by consumer

figure k.81 typical electrical warning label k 127 earthing and earth leakage protection k.9.1.18 k.9.1.18.1 general earthing systems shall be designed and installed in such way that they remain safe and do not endanger health and safety of persons or their surroundings. every consumer installation shall be provided with separate earthing system within plot limits, installed and maintained by consumer

earth system shall remain perform effective throughout life of plant. it difficult in many cases to continuity check after installation system shall therefore be robust and protected from mechanical damage and corrosion where necessary

eccs shall be provided for every outgoing circuit from dbs, equipotential bonding of all metalwork and exposed conductive parts and enclosures, etc. bs 7430, bs en 50522 and iec 60364 shall be referred to for guidance
consumers earthing system shall be connected to dewa earthing system either incoming supply cable armour or earth continuity conductor (ecc), as approved by dewa
consumers earthing system shall be connected to dewa earthing system either incoming supply cable armour or earth continuity conductor (ecc), as approved by dewa
following shall have separate earthing networks and shall not be connected to main electrical earthing system a) lv networks b) extra lv networks c) private generators d) lightning protection systems
dubai building code part k villas earthing system shall be of low electrical resistance, good corrosion resistance, and able to dissipate high fault current repeatedly

consumer main earthing connection shall be tn-s system (see figure k.82). exposed conductive parts of all electrical equipment of installation shall be connected by circuit eccs to main earthing terminal. earth fault loop impedance shall be sufficiently low for protective device (fuse, circuit breaker, rcd) to operate in required time in event of fault to earth

figure k.82 typical tn-s earthing arrangement ( british standards institute. figure extracted from bs 76712018. permission to reproduce extracts from british standards granted by bsi standards limited (bsi). no other use of this material permitted.) key 01 source of energy 02 protective conductor (pe) 03 consumers installations 04 source earth 05 equipment in installation 06 exposed-conductive-parts k 128 neutral and earth conductors shall be kept separate. they shall not be connected together at main earth terminal or at any other point in consumers installation

figure k.82 typical tn-s earthing arrangement ( british standards institute. figure extracted from bs 76712018. permission to reproduce extracts from british standards granted by bsi standards limited (bsi). no other use of this material permitted.) key 01 source of energy 02 protective conductor (pe) 03 consumers installations 04 source earth 05 equipment in installation 06 exposed-conductive-parts k 128 neutral and earth conductors shall be kept separate. they shall not be connected together at main earth terminal or at any other point in consumers installation

foundation metalwork in concrete may be used as ready made and effective earth electrode. total electrode area formed by underground metalwork of large structure can be used to provide earth resistance lower than that obtainable by other methods. it important that consideration given to possibility of corrosion of metalwork reinforcement. products of corrosion occupy greater volume than original metal, and cracking might occur. continuous earth currents shall be resolved by designer of electrical system. note possible source of such current might be incompatible with other buried metalwork, including other types of earth electrode to which foundation metalwork could be bonded, such that it might be necessary to consider need for cathodic protection. damage to concrete in form of cracking, due to arcing or rapid evaporation of moisture, can occur where long-term duration earth fault currents exceed carrying capability of electrode. this situation unlikely to arise if electrode has resistance sufficiently low to avoid dangerous voltages to earth. where, in structures made of bolted sections, electrical continuity of structural joints cannot be relied upon to form permanent and reliable earth bonds, it necessary to install loops bonding across these joints

foundation metalwork in concrete may be used as ready made and effective earth electrode. total electrode area formed by underground metalwork of large structure can be used to provide earth resistance lower than that obtainable by other methods. it important that consideration given to possibility of corrosion of metalwork reinforcement. products of corrosion occupy greater volume than original metal, and cracking might occur. continuous earth currents shall be resolved by designer of electrical system. note possible source of such current might be incompatible with other buried metalwork, including other types of earth electrode to which foundation metalwork could be bonded, such that it might be necessary to consider need for cathodic protection. damage to concrete in form of cracking, due to arcing or rapid evaporation of moisture, can occur where long-term duration earth fault currents exceed carrying capability of electrode. this situation unlikely to arise if electrode has resistance sufficiently low to avoid dangerous voltages to earth. where, in structures made of bolted sections, electrical continuity of structural joints cannot be relied upon to form permanent and reliable earth bonds, it necessary to install loops bonding across these joints

earth electrodes shall not be installed close to metal fence, unless they used for earthing that fence. this to avoid possibility of fence becoming live and thus dangerous at points remote from substation, or alternatively giving rise to danger within resistance area of electrode by introducing good connection with general mass of earth

dubai building code part k villas k.9.1.18.2 consumers main earth electrode minimum of one main earth electrode shall be provided for each incoming point of supply/consumers db, within consumers premises. for installations with main incomer of 200 and above, minimum of two earth pits shall be provided

earthing systems shall consist of copper conductors or steel rods (austenitic steel or copper clad) of appropriate dimensions, set with driving pin and head driven to minimum depth of 3 m. earth electrode shall be installed inside 300 mm  300 mm  300 mm earth pit with inspection cover. connection of earthing conductor to earth electrode or other means of earthing shall be made using compound filled, encapsulated or substantial clamps of non-ferrous material. note uncoated buried copper electro-positive to uncoated buried steel. when interconnected by current-carrying conductor, these metals form electrochemical cell that can cause accelerated corrosion of steel. consumers main earth electrode shall be installed within 1.5 of db. where more than one earth electrode installed within premises, they shall be spaced not less than 6 apart. apart from risk of corrosion to earthing system, chemical treatment of soil has environmental implications and not long-term solution to meet specified level of resistance. coke breeze shall not be used due to its highly corrosive nature
lightning protection earthing, if required, shall be separate from earthing of incoming dewa supply/mdbs. minimum distance of 7 shall be maintained between earthing inspection pits

k.9.1.18.3 earth continuity conductor (ecc) every circuit in mdbs, smdbs and final dbs shall be provided with separate green and yellow (g/y) lsf insulated copper ecc. minimum size of eccs shall be selected as specified in table k.45

joints shall be made such that their current-carrying capacity not less than that of conduit itself. joints shall also have same insulation, mechanical strength and protection properties as those of wiring system or conduit of which they part
eccs shall be covered with green and yellow lsf insulation and terminated with purpose-made lugs or fixings
k 129 dubai building code part k villas where associated with circuits, eccs shall be labelled at their termination points with circuit identification numbers

following shall not be used as ecc 1) gas pipes 2) oil pipes 3) metallic conduit, support wires or other flexible metallic parts or 4) construction elements other than metalwork as described in k.9.1.18

where two eccs used, ends of ecc shall be terminated independently of each other at all connection points throughout circuit, dbs, junction boxes and socket outlets. to achieve this, accessory shall be provided with two separate earth terminals

headings: design and installation of telecom infrastructure
Description: design and installation of telecom infrastructure k.9.7.1 k.9.7.1.1 general requirements this subsection provides requirements for design of all telecommunications (telecom) infrastructure installations to private residential villas and townhouses

for all buildings having cooling load of at least 1 mw or gross floor area of 5,000 m2 or greater, additional water metering shall be installed to record consumption data for major water use of building and major water uses in and around building

headings: design and installation of water meters
Description: requirements herein based on version 2 of telecommunication regulatory authority (tra), in-building telecommunication network  specification manual guidelines for fttx in new buildings ref. k.31. if tra updated to give more stringent requirements, these shall be used in preference to dbc. design and installation of water meters k.9.5.2 design and installation of dewa water meters, including smart metering communications requirements, shall follow specifications and sample drawings in dewa circulars and regulations ref. k.38 and as listed in table k.48

headings: design and installation of water meters
Description: this section specifies minimum requirements to provide baseline infrastructure. there no restriction to extending baseline, provided that design meets requirements in this section and does not prevent competition, e.g. by using proprietary standards. dewa specification sample drawing number sample drawing title all telecom infrastructure shall enable each user/tenant freedom of choice between telecommunication service providers (sps). domestic meter installation in villas and sheds  guidelines pew-std-ami-001 advanced metering infrastructure  water meters on wall (for villas and sheds) code includes all aspects of infrastructure for a) civil infrastructure and entry ducts table k.48 dewa specifications and sample drawings for design and installation of water meters k.9.6 district cooling where villa or townhouse communities to be provided with district cooling systems, system shall conform to g.10. b) building pathways c) isp cables

passive optical fibre infrastructure shall be provided to support deployment of ftth broadband networks. copper access networks shall not be used for sp services

k 134 dubai building code part k villas all villas/townhouses shall be equipped with physical infrastructure capable of supporting multiple high-speed sp networks which can be easily accessed by sp. developer shall assume minimum of two active sps in region but may future-proof infrastructure by incorporating provision to support possible third sp

new installations shall be based upon minimum of category 6 balanced twisted pair cabling as specified in iso 11801 1. designers may future-proof designs by providing category 6 cabling, which supports higher data rates and provides support for newer power-over-ethernet (poe) standards that typically used for video surveillance camera and wireless local area network access points. where category 6 specified, unshielded twisted pair (utp) or shielded twisted pair (stp) may be utilized
category 6 cabling (structured cabling system) shall as minimum conform to requirements specified in k.9.7.4.4

cabling within tenant space for onward distribution of services beyond tenant equipment not in scope of these requirements. installations where special telecom requirements might exist shall be referred to registered dubai sp at preliminary design stage to incorporate any specific requirements above that of this section

k.9.7.1.2 telecoms service to support deployment of sp optical broadband networks and services, developer shall design and install in-building elements of telecom infrastructure up to and within villas/townhouses
k.9.7.1.3 reference architecture reference architecture allows end user to change sps. it also allows services to be provided by multiple sps in parallel if required

design shall include all following elements of reference architecture a) pull box inside villa/townhouse boundary b) duct from pull box to villa/townhouse building entry point (bep) including handholes, turning chambers and pulling chambers as required c) beps to accommodate sp cabling d) in-building cabling
design standards applied shall be iso/iec 11801-1, iso/iec 11801-4 and iso/ iec 11801-6

design shall include 1) shared sp infrastructure 2) roles and responsibilities matrix (see k.9.7.2) 3) provision or cessation of service to enable each tenant to adopt either sp without on-site intervention 4) choice of sp 5) provisions for minimum of two sps note design may include option to enhance this provision to support future third sp
k 135 dubai building code part k villas 6) minimum of four optical fibre cores per premise, for two-sp design, enabling no

item description possibility for either sp to provide ethernet-based service masterplan developer villa/townhouse developer service provider (sp) 7) sp olts/fibre switches connected directly to dedicated fibre cores allocated to them 8) dedicated end-to-end fttx network with full-service delivery control for each sp 9) at least one dedicated fibre from each sp olt to each villa/townhouse and 10) within each villa/townhouse, consolidation cabinet configured to house minimum of two onts in parallel

entry boxes shall be provided for sps to install their cables through lead-in ducts. examples of acceptable arrangements provided in figure k.84 to figure k.87. alternative arrangements can be proposed

entry boxes shall be provided for sps to install their cables through lead-in ducts. examples of acceptable arrangements provided in figure k.84 to figure k.87. alternative arrangements can be proposed

maximum of two shallow bends up to 90 each shall be permitted on any duct section between chambers. maximum distance between entry box/maintenance holes/handholes shall be not more than 200 m. handholes shall not be used for turns, junctions or accommodating any fttx equipment

work required to connect projects infrastructure to any sp infrastructure shall be minimized. connection points at plot boundary shall be designed after consulting with utilities records to establish existing sp infrastructure in site area. all ducts designed and installed by developer shall a) be made from black pvc-u or hdpe b) be of smooth bore construction c) be buried to depth of 600 mm below finished ground level d) be sloping away from building e) be protected by concrete when running under permanent paved surfaces f) be sealed at each end to prevent ingress of water, sub soil, gas, or pests g) have entry/pull box installed for any right-angled or sharp bends in lead-in duct route and h) include draw rope in each duct made of twisted mildew resistant polypropylene minimum outside diameter of 6 mm minimum tensile strength of 1,000 kg

telecom spaces shall not be located directly beneath or next to wet areas such as showers, washrooms, swimming pools and waste areas. telecom spaces shall be designed to be free from any of following items unless otherwise indicated in this section 1) equipment not associated with space 2) utility pipes 3) cables 4) sprinkler systems 5) windows. rodents often gnaw cables resulting in damage and service disruption. best practice pest control methods shall be used to prevent pests from entering telecom spaces and cable pathways. additional measures to protect against pests may involve installation of covers to cable trays. if used, covers shall be removable to allow for installation of additional cables

telecom spaces shall not be located directly beneath or next to wet areas such as showers, washrooms, swimming pools and waste areas. telecom spaces shall be designed to be free from any of following items unless otherwise indicated in this section 1) equipment not associated with space 2) utility pipes 3) cables 4) sprinkler systems 5) windows. rodents often gnaw cables resulting in damage and service disruption. best practice pest control methods shall be used to prevent pests from entering telecom spaces and cable pathways. additional measures to protect against pests may involve installation of covers to cable trays. if used, covers shall be removable to allow for installation of additional cables

telecom spaces shall not be located directly beneath or next to wet areas such as showers, washrooms, swimming pools and waste areas. telecom spaces shall be designed to be free from any of following items unless otherwise indicated in this section 1) equipment not associated with space 2) utility pipes 3) cables 4) sprinkler systems 5) windows. rodents often gnaw cables resulting in damage and service disruption. best practice pest control methods shall be used to prevent pests from entering telecom spaces and cable pathways. additional measures to protect against pests may involve installation of covers to cable trays. if used, covers shall be removable to allow for installation of additional cables

k 139 k.9.7.4.2 consolidation cabinets each villa/townhouse shall be provided with consolidation cabinet (see figure k.88 or figure k.89). each cabinet shall be capable of accommodating two telecom operators requirements at same time (see figure k.90). optical fibre cabling to consolidation cabinet shall be installed and terminated by sps

copper cabling to final to positions shall be minimum specification of category 6. developers may future-proof installation through use of category 6 cabling, especially if future use of wifi overlay anticipated
consolidation cabinets shall be provided in accordance with table k.51
